title: Reeves wants to talk about the budget, but sheâ€™s taken a vow of white noise | John Crace | The Guardian
description: Exclusive: It must be tough overseeing SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s economy, fixing the foundations while also failing to fix them
Author: John Crace
Headline: Exclusive: It must be tough overseeing SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s economy, fixing the foundations while also failing to fix them
Content: The chancellor, Rachel Reeves, spoke for 20 minutes this morning without ever saying the thing she was clearly trying to say.Photograph: Andy Rain/EPAView image in fullscreenThe chancellor, Rachel Reeves, spoke for 20 minutes this morning without ever saying the thing she was clearly trying to say.Photograph: Andy Rain/EPAThe politics sketchBudget 2025Reeves wants to talk about the budget, but sheâ€™s taken a vow of white noiseJohn CraceExclusive: It must be tough overseeing SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s economy, fixing the foundations while also failing to fix themTue 4 Nov 2025 10.28 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 16.02 ESTShareItâ€™s this seasonâ€™s fashion accessory for every politician. Outside election campaigns, press conferences usually signal major set piece events or a national emergency. Now you canâ€™t move for them. Reform have had four inside a week with another one lined up for tomorrow. EvenKemi Badenochhas been at it with a bizarre outdoors show-and-tell last Thursday. Blink and you would have missed it.Tuesday wasRachel Reevesâ€™s turn. Her Lance Corporal Jones â€œDonâ€™t Panic! Donâ€™t Panic!â€ moment. Normally a chancellor takes a vow of silence in the weeks leading up to the budget. Locked away in the Treasury, head down over economic forecasts, anxious to give nothing away.But not this year. Now Rachel wanted to give as many clues away as possible. Call it the budget performed in interpretative dance. Nothing actually spelled out but the message was clear. Not least in the timing. A press conference that takes place at 8.10am in Downing Street and is broadcast on nearly every terrestrial channel screams: â€œHelp! Things have gone seriously tits up!â€ Anyone watching would have been well advised to run for cover. You could see the bad news coming a mile away.This was Reeves trying to catch a break. Hoping to get in the bad headlines early so that, come 26 November, she will get an easier ride. Let people imagine the worst and be pleasantly surprised when it turns out not to be so terrible as expected. We are rapidly approaching the point where words no longer have meaning.A speech that was delivered as code. Twenty minutes of white noise in which the thing she was trying to tell us was never actually mentioned. How to tell your audience you are going to raise income tax without actually telling them you are planning to raise income tax. Something she and Keir Starmer have been practising relentlessly for the last couple of months. There canâ€™t be many people left who arenâ€™t preparing to be worse off. So you could call it job done.â€œI want to be honest with the country,â€ Reeves said. Really? It didnâ€™t feel that way. For a start, there was the inability to say the one thing that was on her mind. Around which everything else was just padding and self-justification. Then there were the more philosophical questions. If she was being honest now, how come she hadnâ€™t been able to be honest with us previously? Was themanifesto pledge not to raise income tax, VAT and national insurancenever meant to be taken seriously? Just some bullshit to win an election. And why repeat the promise to the CBI when she must have known she was unlikely to be able to keep it?Next we were into SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s economy. At last yearâ€™s budget, Reeves had fixed the foundations of the economy and yet somehow failed to fix the foundations of the economy. Everything was both tickety-boo â€“ we were the fastest growing economy in the G7, borrowing costs were going down etc â€“ and yet she somehow now had another hole in the public finances to fill that she hadnâ€™t anticipated. Nor should we be too bothered by the forecasts of the Office forBudgetResponsibility because their forecasts were not forecasts. They were forecasts that looked backwards. Weâ€™ll have to take her word for that.Anyone would be facing these choices that could not be named, Rachel continued. And she was proud of what she had done. There would be no return to the austerity of the Tories. Reform had no solutions either. We all just had to bite the bullet and suck it up. She just hadnâ€™t anticipated quite how much damage Brexit and the Liz Truss budget had done to the economy. Basically, she was just being courteous and doing us all a favour. We should be happy to pay a bit more to protect our public services. Look at it this way, this was far more painful for her than it was for us. We are all so broke we wonâ€™t notice becoming even more broke.â€œA brighter future is within our grasp,â€ Reeves concluded. At which point you could feel everyoneâ€™s heart sink. Politicians have been saying that repeatedly over the past 15 years and every time things have only got worse. Itâ€™s the reverse Midas touch.Understandably most of the questions cut straight to the chase. Why couldnâ€™t she just admit she was planning on raising taxes and why did she find it so hard to keep her promises? Rachel stonewalled. She had said all she had come to say. Now she just wanted to get the hell out of the room. It had been an excruciating 40 minutes for her. Still, at least almost no one was talking about her embarrassing rental faux pas. Bank the small wins while you can.1:48Rachel Reeves avoids answering question on tax rises in pre-budget speech â€“Â videoReeves wasnâ€™t the only one having a press conference. Kemi Badenoch was also up and about in front of the cameras. Only whereas the chancellorâ€™s had some tangental purpose, Kemiâ€™s had none whatsoever. Though the Tory leader has clearly got the taste for them. Her very own echo chamber where she can stand up in front of a small gathering of her shadow ministers and say things that are totally irrelevant to the rest of us straight to camera. Gone and quickly forgotten.With four union jacks behind her, Kemi proceeded to deliver the directorâ€™s cut of the speech she had given last week. No one had listened then and no one was paying much attention now. Just an exercise in existential self-indulgence. This time she droned on for twice as long. Sending twice as many people to sleep.Tory patience wears thin as Badenochâ€™s critics count down to May electionsRead moreHer theme was the familiar one. Like Nigel Farage, she is a broken record. The country is broken and only she could save it. Primarily by cutting benefits and a return to austerity. She hasnâ€™t yet realised that as much as people have doubts about Reevesâ€™s ability to turn the country around, the last thing anyone wants is a lecture from the Tories. After all, it was theConservativeswho brought the country to its knees and there is no enthusiasm for their return. The kindest thing they could do is give us all a break and self-destruct in private.A year in Westminster: John Crace, Marina Hyde and Pippa Crerar.On Tuesday 2 December, join Crace, Hyde and Crerar as they look back with special guests at another extraordinary year, live at the Barbican in London and livestreamed globally.Book tickets hereExplore more on these topicsBudget 2025The politics sketchRachel ReevesKemi BadenochLabourReform UKConservativesNigel FaragecommentShareReuse this content

title: Rise of the â€˜porno-trollsâ€™: how one porn platform made millions suing its viewers | Pornography | The Guardian
description: A company called Strike 3, owner of Vixen and Tushy, has clogged US courts with lawsuits, mostly against porn watchers who feel shamed into settling privately
Author: Tarpley Hitt
Headline: A company called Strike 3, owner of Vixen and Tushy, has clogged US courts with lawsuits, mostly against porn watchers who feel shamed into settling privately
Content: Illustration: Guardian Design/Guardian Design; Source images via Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenIllustration: Guardian Design/Guardian Design; Source images via Getty ImagesPornographyRise of the â€˜porno-trollsâ€™: how one porn platform made millions suing its viewersA company called Strike 3, owner of Vixen and Tushy, has clogged US courts with lawsuits, mostly against porn watchers who feel shamed into settling privatelyTarpley HittTue 4 Nov 2025 07.18 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 09.14 ESTShareWhen 73-year-old Tom Brown*,a retired police officer from Seattle, received a letter from Comcast, he might have mistaken it for a broadband bill. Instead, it was a subpoena. He had been sued in federal court for illegally downloading 80 movies. Some of the titles sounded cryptic â€“ Do Not Worry, We Are Only Friends â€“ or banal, like International Relations Part 2. Others were less subtle: He Loved My Big Ass, He Loved My Big Butt, and My Big Booty Loves Anal.Brown, who had spent decades investigating sex crimes, claimed he had never watched any of them. His years â€œdealing with pimpingâ€, he wrote in a court filing, left him â€œwith no interest in pornographyâ€. He had been married for 40 years, he did not need to download Hot Wife, another title in the list. But the subpoena did not seem like something he could laugh off. It said he could face damages of up to $150,000 per movie â€“ as much as $12m for all 80 films. If he did not respond promptly, the letter said, Comcast would identify him to the plaintiff in the case: a company called Strike 3 Holdings.â€˜I didnâ€™t start out wanting to see kidsâ€™: are porn algorithms feeding a generation of paedophiles â€“ or creating one?Read moreStrike 3 is not a name that Brown, or most people outside the world of copyright law, would recognize. The Delaware-based corporation, formed in 2015, owns the intellectual property rights to a catalog of about 2,000 adult films, mostly made by Vixen Media Group, its porn production subsidiary. It had very little online footprint; no social presence to speak of. But its associates were better known. The company was co-founded by Greg Lansky, the French porn director whose recent pivot to the art world has yielded works such as Algorithmic Beauty,amarble reproductionof the Venus de Milo with breast implants taking a selfie.Lansky, a 42-year-old Parisian, was something of a celebrity in the adult industry, having formed Vixen, the production company behind some of the porn worldâ€™s most popular brands: Vixen, Slayed, Wifey, Milf-y, Tushy, Tushy Raw, Blacked, Blacked Raw. The studioâ€™s commitment to high-production value had attracted dozens of awards in adult media and write-ups from outlets outside it. How One Pornographer Is Trying to Elevate Porn to Art, read a Forbes profile of Lansky from 2017.View image in fullscreenGreg Lansky and adult film actors Vicki Chase, Teanna Trump, Riley Reid, Abigail Mac and Lena â€˜The Plugâ€™ Nersesian pose at Lanskyâ€™s Blacked, Tushy and Vixen studios booth at 2019 AVN Adult Entertainment Expo at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino on 23 January 2019 in Las Vegas, Nevada.Photograph: Ethan Miller/Getty ImagesLansky courted the press, branding himself as the â€œSteven Spielberg of pornâ€, and his company as a home for â€œfeminist, ethical pornâ€. His free videos regularly ranked among the most-viewed scenes on PornHub, pushing viewers towards a paid tier. And his websites, Lansky has said, follow the â€œsame business model as HBOâ€: premium subscription services, charging between $9.95 and $29.95 a month.What Lansky left out was that, since September 2017, Vixenâ€™s owners had been pursuing another revenue stream: filing thousands of boilerplate copyright lawsuits against individual â€œJohn Doesâ€ and collecting millions in settlement fees â€“ a mass litigation campaign one federal judge likened to â€œa hi-tech shakedownâ€.Brown, who was sued in November of 2017,numbered among Strike 3â€™s earliest targets. But in the eight years since, Strike 3 has become the most prolific copyright plaintiff in the country â€“ filing, bythe Guardianâ€™s analysis of Pacer data, more than 20,000 federal copyright cases since September 2017.[Strike 3] treats this Court not as a citadel of justice, but as an ATMJudge Royce C LamberthMore recently, Strike 3 has been in the news for a higher profile case: a $350m copyright lawsuit against Facebookâ€™s parent company Meta. Meta is a rare corporate defendant; the overwhelming majority of Strike 3â€™s suits are aimed at anonymous users across the country. Lansky, who sold his stake in Vixen Media in 2020, did not respond to multiple requests for comment, nor did a representative for Vixen Media Group. A spokesperson for Strike 3 declined to answer specific questions about its legal strategy, but provided a statement to the Guardian: â€œStrike 3 is a legitimate film studio, that has created award-winning content, distributed through paid subscription platforms,â€ she wrote, â€œand has resorted to litigation only when necessary to protect the livelihood [sic] and its paying subscribers from widespread piracy.â€Some judges are furious at just how many cases Strike 3 are filing. Armed with â€œhundreds of cut-and-pasted complaints and boilerplate discovery motions, Strike 3 floods this courthouse (and others around the country) with lawsuits smacking of extortionâ€, district judge Royce C Lamberth wrote. â€œIt treats this Court not as a citadel of justice, but as an ATM.â€The sheer number of lawsuits has spawned a cottage industry of defense attorneys looking to take on the John Doesâ€™ cases. â€œI see new ones popping up all the time,â€ said attorney Steve Vondran, who is something of an influencer in this community, having defended more than 500 Strike 3 cases. He answers questions on YouTube and LinkedIn like: â€œAm I going to lose my house?â€ or â€œWill I have to file for bankruptcy?â€Thousands of lawsuits follow a similar formula: Strike 3 claims to use a proprietary software called VXN Scan to track IP addresses that have downloaded porn they own. The software cannot identify the user beyond a rough geographic location, so Strike 3 files suit against an anonymous John Doe, and subpoenas their internet service provider (ISP) to unmask the user. The ISP in turn alerts the subscriber â€“ which is when most people find out they have been sued.These people are often keen to settle, being cheaper than litigation and the only way to ensure their anonymity.That was certainly the case for Ken Jones*, a 28-year-old mental health worker, who received his own subpoena earlier this year. (Jones was the only defendant out of the dozen the Guardian contacted who was willing to discuss his case on the record, and he agreed to do so only on the condition of anonymity and without specifics to his settlement agreement.) â€œI remember being terrified. I had no idea what to do,â€ he said. â€œMy mind kept going to the worst case scenario: life savings gone because of a few downloads. It felt unreal. I was unable to eat or sleep for some time.â€Though he maintained to the Guardian he had never seen any of their films, Jones decided to settle because â€œit was the quickest way to leave this in the pastâ€, he said.The â€œshame and tabooâ€ made â€œthe decision to fight the allegations a bit more challengingâ€.As Strike 3 tells it, these lawsuits are merely a defense against piracy. Its films, the company claims, â€œare among the most pirated content in the worldâ€ (though they did not provide data to support that claim).Critics see Strike 3 differently â€“the countryâ€™s leading â€œcopyright trollâ€, or a rightsholder who treats litigation as a business model, rather than a means of protecting their work. Strike 3 does not disclose how much it makes from lawsuits, but several defense attorneys who spoke to the Guardian estimated that the company makes millions each year. Though copyright law allows for statutory damages of up to $150,000 per film, in reality, most defendants pay about $750 per title, according to Vondran. But for several dozen titles, that can quickly become settlements that range between $20,000 and $30,000.â€œThey want usually, minimum, what I call â€˜five-figure settlementsâ€™: $10,000 or more,â€ Vondran said. â€œItâ€™s why I think they wait to get at least 24 movies before they sue you, because that takes them right into that zone.â€ Even if only half of their cases settle in a given year, Strike 3 could collect between $20m and $30m in fees.The rise of theâ€˜copyright trollsâ€™Copyright trolls, a category which many have argued includes Strike 3, have skirted much notice outside legal circles, in part because they are seen as a relic of a bygone era.The copyright troll emerged from the 2000s internet, when the proliferation of peer-to-peer sharing tools first gave the public unprecedented access to almost any copyrighted work â€“ be it My Little Pony Crystal Princess: The Runaway Rainbow(2006) orbootleg footage of the heavy metal Fuck Christ Tour â€˜93.Between 2003 and 2008, the Recording Industry Association of America responded by filing more than 35,000 lawsuits against music pirates. Their campaign focused more on deterrence rather than revenue, but they created a model others soon copied. By the new decade, the courts were inundated by a new kind of mass copyright litigation â€“ what law professor and part-time trolling historian Matthew Sag called, the â€œBitTorrent eraâ€, after the sharing protocol popularized by sites like the Pirate Bay.View image in fullscreenThe homepage of the Pirate Bay, the popular filesharing website.Photograph: FocusDigital/AlamyThese suits were perfectly legal; any copyright owner is entitled to sue for infringement. But between 2011 and 2014, several entities emerged as what Aaron Moss,author of the Copyright Lately newsletter, calls â€œfrequent flyersâ€â€“ plaintiffs who seemed more interested in a â€œsue and settleâ€ approach, rather than earnestly deterring pirates. Theserepeat litigants tended to come from struggling industries such as newspaper and independent movies (Voltage Pictures, the production company behind The Hurt Locker and later, Dallas Buyers Club,is notoriously aggressive for pursuing lawsuits against individual John Does).But the vast majority came from porn companies â€“ so many that the subset earned its own name: â€œporno-trollingâ€.[Most] reluctantly pay rather than have their names associated with illegally downloading porn ... For these individuals, resistance is futileJudge Otis WrightPorno-trolls had â€œdiscovered the nexus of antiquated copyright laws, paralyzing social stigma, and unaffordable defense costsâ€, Judge Otis Wright wrote in the opinion that coined the term. â€œThey exploit this anomaly by accusing individuals of illegally downloading a single pornographic video. Then they offer to settle â€“ for a sum calculated to be just below the cost of a bare-bones defense.â€ Most â€œreluctantly pay rather than have their names associated with illegally downloading pornâ€, he went on. â€œFor these individuals, resistance is futile.â€Porn was itself a struggling industry; the proliferation of free streaming sites cut into producersâ€™ profits. But the early porno-trolls seemed to stretch the bounds of what copyright law allowed. The bulk of these cases were represented by a firm called Prenda Law, many of whose clients, it turned out, did not exist.The firm, prosecutors later alleged, had ahabitof creating â€œshamâ€ porn companies with fake executives and suing on their behalf. (One of the â€œofficersâ€ of their supposed clients was in fact, per theLos Angeles Times, â€œthe unpaid caretaker of Steeleâ€™s cabin in rural Minnesotaâ€ who had been promoted to fake porn executive without his knowledge.) By 2016, partners at Prenda Law, John Steele and Paul Hansmeier, were arrested by federal authorities and charged on 18 counts of fraud, perjury, and money laundering. At times, the complaintalleged, Steele and Hansmeier went so far as to film low-budget porn themselves and upload it to torrent sites â€œin order to lure people to download the moviesâ€. Steele was eventually sentenced tofiveyears in federal prison; Hansmeier to14.Not every porno-troll went to such overtly illegal lengths. If Prenda Law invented the model, Malibu Media professionalized it. The most prolific of the porn plaintiffs, Malibu Media was the legal arm of softcore website X-Art, run by the pornographer couple Colette Pelissier and Brigham Field. The coupleâ€™s prolific caseload attracted national press and aprofilein the New Yorker.(The headline read: The Biggest Filer of Copyright Lawsuits? This Erotica Website.) In 2014, the couple had filed a third of all US copyright litigation that year: 1,300 infringement cases.By the end of the Obama administration, however, it seemed that copyright trolling had peaked. BitTorrenting was on the wane, as streaming platforms took over popular entertainment. Many of the biggest players seemed to burn out: the Prenda partners went to jail, and Malibu imploded into infighting. (In late 2016, Malibuâ€™s founders sued their own lawyer, Florida attorney Keith Lipscomb, for professional negligence and breach of fiduciary duty; the case was later dismissed). The era of copyright trolling appeared to be winding down. â€œFilesharing lawsuit numbers drop by more than half,â€ Ars Technicareportedthat year. Sag, the fieldâ€™s most-cited scholar, moved on to other research. â€œMy gut says that it has decreased in volume somewhat,â€ one IP attorney told me, â€œbut thatâ€™s just my gut feeling.â€But in reality, the field was merely changing shape. In 2017, a lawyer from the Lipscomb firm, which had led Malibu Mediaâ€™s copyright campaign, found a new job as general counsel at Vixen Media Group. Strike 3 filed its first copyright claim three months later. These days, bulk copyright cases still account for the majority of federal copyright filings; the field of participants has merely become more concentrated. According to Westlaw and Pacer data from the past three years, Strike 3 accounted for 50% of the federal copyright docketall on its own.I first heard about Strike 3 in September, when some legal clerk friends mentioned that nearly every judge on their circuit was handling a stack of Strike 3 cases â€“ which are now so consistent as to have become routine. One would be hard pressed to find a federal judge in America who has not encountered the porn company; in a 2022 article about intellectual property experience in the western district of Texas, for example, half of the justices explicitly cited Strike 3:Chief judge Orlando Garcia: â€œThe chief judgeâ€™s docket features a hefty amount of trademark and copyright work, particularly from a litigious porn studio, Strike 3 Holdings.â€Judge Fred Biery: â€œJudge Bieryâ€™s docket, like the chiefs, is full of copyright suits filed by Strike 3.:Judge Robert Pitman: â€œHis docket is likewise filled with cases from Strike 3.â€Judge Jason Pulliam: â€œJudge Pulliam â€¦ like several of his colleagues, has Strike 3 filing up a big portion of his intellectual property work.â€Judge Xavier Rodriguez: â€œAnd like some of his peers, he has faced a series of copyright suits from Strike 3.â€The vast majority of Strike 3â€™s cases are settled or voluntarily dismissed for undisclosed reasons. None of the lawyers I spoke to could name a single claim that had gone to trial, and according to Westlawâ€™s litigation analytics, no case ever has.Only 10 or so people have even tried â€“ one of them was Brown, the retired cop. Shortly after receiving his subpoena, he countersued the company for negligent emotional distress. He hired the intellectual property lawyer J Curtis Edmondson, a recurring figure on the Strike 3 circuit. Of the maybe 10 cases that â€œhave gone the distanceâ€, as he puts it, to litigate Strike 3â€™s allegations, Edmondson has represented all but one.Edmondsonâ€™s interest in litigating Strike 3 cases stems from the fact that, despite the companyâ€™s broad success in bringing copyright infringement claims, there remain several open questions about its methods. For one, IP addresses are notoriously fickle; it is easy to spoof an IP address through a virtual private network (VPN) or to use someone elseâ€™s address via malware that bypasses passwords. More to the point, as Mitch Stoltz, IP litigation director at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, puts it: â€œIn a lot of cases, many, many people are using the same IP address.â€ Any given address may be shared between roommates, colleagues or members of a family.The prevalence of shared IP addresses has yielded some high-profile misfires; in 2011, for example, a porn company called Hard Productions sued a grandma in her 70s for torrenting hours of hardcore. (The retired widow â€œdoesnâ€™t know what BitTorrent isâ€, SF Gatereported at the time, though she did live next to â€œa handful of young menâ€.) A few years later, the production company behind the 2014 Adam Sandler film The Cobbler sued an Oregon man for allegedly downloading the film multiple times. The defendant, it turned out, ran an adult foster care, and his internet was regularly accessed by his residents. The case, Cobbler Nevada v Gonzales, went up to the ninth circuit, which ruled that IP addresses alone were insufficient for identifying infringement. In order to state a claim, the justices wrote, the plaintiff had to allege â€œsomething moreâ€ â€“ some additional evidence to establish â€œa reasonable inference that a subscriber is also an infringerâ€.Brown found himself in a similar situation. As it turned out, the retired cop had an adult son who lived at home, who had not held a job in 10 years and lived with a social anxiety so absolute it prevented him from â€œtalking to strangersâ€ or driving, during which he would â€œconstantly worry about how other people on the road can run into meâ€. As a result, the son later wrote in a legal filing: â€œI rarely leave my house and spend most of the time in my own room.â€ As the case progressed, Strike 3 found their â€œsomething moreâ€ â€“ namely, the sonâ€™s profile on a uTorrent forum, where he wrote things such as â€œutorrent is a keeper.â€ But in this case, that was neither here nor there; they had sued Brown, not his son. Strike 3 quickly dropped the claims, and in 2020, a judge sided with Brown on his countersuit, affirming that he had not infringed any copyright and awarding him $47,777.26 in attorneyâ€™s fees. It remains the biggest victory any John Doe has notched against Strike 3, and yet for many critics, somewhat bittersweet.The black box suing softwareFor Edmondson, the real question at the heart of Strike 3â€™s cases, and others like it, concerns the detection software used to identify those downloading Vixenâ€™s porn videos. As part of a case, Strike 3 and its peers submit records that a given IP address is linked to specific downloads. But the software that produces those records is shrouded in mystery. â€œThe corporate entities, people, software, and processes relied upon to prove infringement,â€ Sag wrote, â€œare somewhat shadowy and opaque.â€And there are many reasons, Edmonson argues, to doubt their accuracy. When geolocation services cannot match an IP address with a specific location, as Vondran has noted, they may â€œrandomly assign addresses to a general locationâ€. In one prominent example from 2017, for example, Venice PI, the company that owns the copyrights to the Bruce Willis film Once Upon A Time in Venice, filed two suits against the same defendant: a 91-year-old man named Wilbur Miller who was not only deceased but had, as his widow attested, â€œsuffered from dementiaâ€ for at least five years, rendering him â€œboth mentally and physically incapable of operating a computerâ€.For a time, nearly every John Doe copyright case in the US claimed to use a suite of detection services based in Germany. These companies went by many names â€“ Guardaley, IPP International, Maverickeye UG, Excipio Gmbh or Crystal Bay Corp â€“ but they employed many of the same staff, filed many near-identical declarations in court cases, and seemed on the whole to be, per Sag, â€œessentially the same entityâ€. At the very least, they seemed to all be controlled by the same few people, though who those people were exactly was somewhat unclear. Crystal Bay Corp, for example, filed more than 500 declarations signed by an expert witness identified as â€œDarren M Griffinâ€ â€“ a man who, as Edmondson laterwrote, â€œis in fact a completely fictitious personâ€. (Griffin did, however, have two flesh-and-blood colleagues at Crystal Bay, who variously attested to work at Guardalay, IPP and Maverickeye.)We were all waiting to see ... What was their technology going to show?Steve Vondran, attorneyStrike 3 relied on these same services until 2018,when they debuted their own tracking software, VXN Scan. In legal filings, Strike 3 claims it functions much like a BitTorrent client â€“ downloading pieces of a given work from peers within the torrent network, and tracing those pieces back to the IP addresses seeding them. But Edmondson and others argue that the new detection tool, like its German predecessors, is a â€œblack boxâ€. As Edmondson put it: â€œNobody knows how it works.â€Because none of Strike 3â€™s cases have ever gone to trial, the company has never had to disclose the source code, or submit the software to closer scrutiny. In 2023, the Strike 3 legal community watched as one Florida defendant, a defense contractor and another Edmonson client, got closer than anyone ever had. After three years of litigation, a jury trial had been scheduled that spring. â€œWe were all waiting to see â€“ what was going to be the outcome?â€ Vondran recalled. â€œWhat was their technology going to show?â€ They never found out; on the eve of trial, the parties reached a confidential settlement.Strike 3â€™s critics may now get another chance. The companyâ€™s lawsuit against Meta, first filed in July, takes its copyright litigation to new heights, and a much larger target.The case emerged amid a flood of copyright lawsuits against the AI firms that now dominate the US economy. Meta and its peers have argued their use of copyrighted material is â€œtransformativeâ€, meaning it changes the original work enough to amount to fair use. But in a lawsuit filed by a group of authors, Meta emails revealed the company had torrented as much as 81.7 terabytes of pirated books and academic papers from such sites as Annaâ€™s Archive. (A district judge later ruled against the authors on procedural grounds, without determining if Metaâ€™s use of copyrighted work was lawful).The case prompted Strike 3 to examine its archive of recorded infringement, where it claims to have identified 47 different IP addresses owned by Meta. Strike 3 alleges that, over the course of years, Meta torrented at least 2,396 of its films for training artificial intelligence â€“ infringements which could, if proven, amount to $350m in damages.â€˜Would love to see her fakedâ€™: the dark world of sexual deepfakes â€“ and the women fighting backRead moreThe tech company is fighting the case â€“ filing a motion to dismiss last week that argued Strike 3 had failed to show that Meta â€œwas aware of the downloadsâ€ or â€œdirected this activityâ€. The motion instead pointed the finger at Strike 3â€™s more common target: â€œunidentified usersâ€ who downloaded porn for â€œprivate personal useâ€. In a statement to the Guardian, Strike 3â€™s spokesperson contested that characterization: â€œThis case is not about isolated personal activity,â€ she wrote. â€œThis complaint reflects coordinated, corporate-scale conduct and the unauthorized distribution of creative works across multiple networks and jurisdictions.â€)For Strike 3 defense lawyers, the larger case presents a new opportunity to scrutinize the porn firmâ€™s piracy detection practices because, according to the complaint, the company tracked Metaâ€™s downloads the same way they had the Doesâ€™: VXN Scan. If the case proceeds to trial, it may finally let the public look inside Strike 3â€™s black box.Strike 3â€™s spokesperson indicated they are keen to fight the case. â€œIf the Meta case represents anything, it is Strike 3â€™s belief in its company and confidence in its technology,â€ she wrote. â€œMeta will undoubtedly bring the most powerful legal team to bear, but that does not change the facts or the law.â€For Edmondson, the concern is the precedent it sets in a world where digital records are easy to falsify. â€œI kind of look 10 years into the future when it will be ridiculously easy to fabricate information,â€ he said. As he sees it, the courts should â€œtake a stand now, at the beginning of a case, as to whether the evidence is good evidence or notâ€, because in the future, â€œyou could just create that all using AI.â€*Using a pseudonym

title: Football Manager 26 review â€“a modern sim for the modern game | Games | The Guardian
description: After a two-year wait, Football Manager 26 upgrades every aspect of the football sim, but it may take some getting used to
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: After a two-year wait, Football Manager 26 upgrades every aspect of the football sim, but it may take some getting used to
Content: The atmosphere is palpable  â€¦ Football Manager 26.Photograph: SegaView image in fullscreenThe atmosphere is palpable  â€¦ Football Manager 26.Photograph: SegaGamesReviewFootball Manager 26 review â€“a modern sim for the modern gameSports Interactive; PC (version tested), PS5, Switch, XboxAfter a two-year wait, Football Manager 26 upgrades every aspect of the football sim, but it may take some getting used toBen SledgeTue 4 Nov 2025 08.00 ESTShareYou can imagine what the home fans are singing in the Stadium of Light: â€œTop of the league, youâ€™re having a laugh!â€ Your Liverpool team, who until this afternoon were five points clear at the top of the table, trail by two goals in the 82nd minute. You wonder where Mo Salah left his shooting boots, or why Virgil van Dijk seems to have forgotten the whole concept of tackling. But this isnâ€™t on the players, itâ€™s on you â€“ or so youâ€™ll tell the press â€“ as you stare at the tactics screen trying to figure out which of the dozens of potential tweaks will change the tide of this depressing spectacle.Football Manager was always the data-driven alternative to the visually opulent Fifa series (now EA Sports FC), but the latest instalment starts to bridge the graphical gap. The 3D-rendered match highlights have been given an upgrade via the new Unity engine, and the results are impressive. Premier League derbies, Champions League finals, and even away matches in the north-east have visual gravitas now, even if the replays and so-called important moments often overstay their welcome. There are no Fifa-style authentic chants ringing around the stadia, but the atmosphere is palpable and your imagination fills in the blanks.View image in fullscreenA tangible impact on tactics â€¦ Football Manager 26.Photograph: SegaThis new engine and the elevated matchday experience are the biggest signs of Football Managerâ€™s vision of the future. However, the visual upgrade is about more than spectacle â€“ there is a tangible impact on tactics. While watching a game, you can study your playersâ€™ movement on the pitch, making changes accordingly. But when you desperately need to turn things around in front of 45,000 raucous Mackems, data-driven metrics are still king. You might want to switch your build-up strategy to play through the press, or overload one flank with overlapping runs. There are myriad possibilities and you will experiment with them all.The biggest change is the separation of tactical strategies for when you have possession of the ball and when you donâ€™t. Itâ€™s the most significant overhaul in a decade, properly representing the intricacies of the modern game. Now you can completely change formation, swap player positions, and give granular instructions that shift depending on which team has the ball. Want your fullback inverting when you reach the final third? Itâ€™s not only possible, but theyâ€™ll dutifully head back to their rightful position when Alexander Isak is bundled to the floor on the edge of the box.But thereareissues. After a fallow year to manage the transition to the new engine, Football Manager 26 remains remarkably unpolished. It has already received numerous hotfixes to tackle the worst bugs, but many remain, from overlapping UI and subs running on to the pitch in their tracksuits, to menu errors that prevent progress completely.Between matches, the new UI will take some getting used to, especially as some important screens are multiple clicks away when they used to be more accessible. You have all the same information at your disposal (even more, with the addition of womenâ€™s leagues), itâ€™s just found in slightly different places. Relearning a lifetime of muscle memory is frustrating and more customisation would be preferable, but itâ€™s a minor gripe that time will soothe.And despite these issues, this is still Football Manager, with all of its delicious tactical minutiae to get lost in. Thanks to the modernised tactics and match engine, making the perfect tactical tweaks to kickstart a stoppage time comeback and silence those oh-so-confident home fans has never felt better. Football Manager 26 provides tangible feedback to your split-second decisions and lets you conceive fictional rivalries that can last for seasons. And when you beat Sunderland with three goals in the final five minutes, the thrill remains unsurpassed.Football Manager 26 is out now, Â£49.99Explore more on these topicsGamesSports gamesPCPlayStation 5Xbox series S/XNintendo Switch 2Simulation gamesreviewsShareReuse this content

title: LOL: is this the ultimate texting faux pas (and what should you use instead)? | Mobile phones | The Guardian

Author: Guardian staff reporter

Content: The cry-laugh emoji: preserve of the oldies only.Photograph: Posed by model; atomicstudio/Getty Images/iStockphotoView image in fullscreenThe cry-laugh emoji: preserve of the oldies only.Photograph: Posed by model; atomicstudio/Getty Images/iStockphotoPass notesMobile phonesLOL: is this the ultimate texting faux pas (and what should you use instead)?From abbreviations to happy poos, gen Z has strong opinions on appropriate texting behaviour. But can anyone keep up with the ever-changing rules?Tue 4 Nov 2025 11.25 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 13.26 ESTShareName:â€œLOLâ€.Age:The Oxford English Dictionary first includedLOLin 1997.Not to be confused with: Loll, which is what dogs sometimes do.So as in â€œlaugh out loudâ€?Or laughing out loud, though David Cameron thought it stood for â€œlots of loveâ€ and used to sign off to Rebekah Brooks, the former Sun and News of the World editor, with a LOL.Iâ€™m LOL-ing at his LOL mishap.Well, you shouldnâ€™t.Why?Because anyone who still LOLs is not cool.Laughing out loud is no longer acceptable?No, using LOL in a text or aWhatsAppis no longer acceptable.Says who?Itâ€™s according to gen Z. A survey by Sky Mobile has revealed that getting a LOL in a message gives 26% of 18- to 28-year-olds the ick. Their second biggest gripe, in fact.Whatâ€™s topof the icks?Sluggish replies. Related, and not far behind, is an impatient â€œ??â€ if you donâ€™t get an immediate reply to the first message. Though, interestingly, 79% admitted to ignoring messages.Almost like they hate themselves!Actually, 61% did admit to being embarrassed by their own texting habits.Iâ€™ll probably just stick to a simplethumbs upemoji, to be on the safe side ğŸ‘Again, thatâ€™s considered cringe, Iâ€™m afraid. Likewise, the see-no-evil monkey ğŸ™ˆ, an awkward grimace ğŸ˜¬, and the happy poo ğŸ’©.Ew! And the tears of joy emoji ğŸ˜‚, as aLOL substitute? Iâ€™m guessing thatâ€™s over too?Onlyused by oldies. Gen Zs (and below) are more likely to send a skull ğŸ’€, or a coffin âš°ï¸.Sodyingof, not crying with,laughter?Exactly.What about abbreviations, like â€œhruâ€ and â€œwydâ€?How am I? Iâ€™m fine. And I am probably not replying to that, thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m doing.Rly?Really. A study published in theJournal of Experimental Psychologyfound that while they might save the sender time, the receiver might see using abbreviations as a sign of insincerity. Annoying to young and old alike.God, itâ€™s complicated isnâ€™t it, trying to keep up?Tell me about it. Thereâ€™sa video on ABC newsof school kids telling their teacher that â€œcringeâ€ is out.â€œCringeâ€ is cringe!And â€œickâ€ probably gives them the ick.Does any of it matter? Iâ€™m hoping that people will be able to see beyond text speak and emojisto the actual person.Keep hoping. Going back to that Sky Mobile survey, 58% of these gen Zs confessed they have considered dumping their partner because of what they see as bad phone etiquette. Whoâ€™s LOL-ing now?Do say:â€œIt was an ironic LOL, obviously â€¦â€Donâ€™t say:â€œHappy Valentineâ€™s Day, Samantha, LOL!â€Explore more on these topicsMobile phonesPass notesLanguageWhatsAppfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: The best umbrellas in the UK for staying dry in the wind and rain â€“ tested on a 517m hilltop | Accessories | The Guardian
description: Our reviewer braved Peak District downpours to see which brollies â€“ from budget to mini to windproof â€“ stayed standing
Author: Pete Wise
Headline: Our reviewer braved Peak District downpours to see which brollies â€“ from budget to mini to windproof â€“ stayed standing
Content: Brolly good show: some umbrellas, such as the Davek Elite pictured, sailed through the Mam Tor test.Photograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianView image in fullscreenBrolly good show: some umbrellas, such as the Davek Elite pictured, sailed through the Mam Tor test.Photograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianThe FilterAccessoriesReviewThe best umbrellas in the UK for staying dry in the wind and rain â€“ tested on a 517m hilltopOur reviewer braved Peak District downpours to see which brollies â€“ from budget to mini to windproof â€“ stayed standing10 stylish and practical ways to look good in wet weatherPete WiseTue 4 Nov 2025 10.32 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 10.33 ESTShareThe Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.Inoticed something while testing umbrellas over pavement and muddy hilltop: people are more likely to smile at you. Or perhaps I was more likely to smile atthem, while feeling content and dry-headed under the canopy.The Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.We Britons have loved brollies â€“ previously an aristocratic luxury â€“ since about the turn of the 19th century. Today, theyâ€™re a broad tent covering tight budgets and expensive tastes alike. Youâ€™ll see them sprout like mushrooms whenever rain hits the high street.Most decent umbrellas will succeed in keeping you dry(-ish), but there are differences to be found when you peer under the canopy. Some have a stronger and smoother mechanism of ribs, stretchers, runner and frame; others are lighter and nicer to hold; and certain models reveal exceptional craft in details such as a smooth wooden handle or a shiny tip.Of course, many of us care about the appearance of our umbrellas, too. Excellent finishing is an aesthetic consideration, as well as a clue as to the brollyâ€™s longevity.At a glanceBest umbrella overall:London Undercover ClassicÂ£115 at London UndercoverBest budget umbrella:Doppler Zero 99Â£29.99 at AmazonBest folding umbrella:Blunt Metro UmbrellaÂ£74.70 at AmazonBest-looking umbrella:Oswin Hyde JosephÂ£49 at DebenhamsBest mini umbrella:Davek MiniÂ£60 at DavekBest golf umbrella:Fulton Titan 1Â£29.87 at AmazonWhy you should trust meAs a regular umbrella carrier, I use these contraptions to stay dry on my soggy travels around the north of England. The best ones keep the rain off and are convenient to carry, whether in hand or inside a bag. Iâ€™m also selective about colourways, materials, design and construction.If Iâ€™m under a brolly, thereâ€™s a good chance Iâ€™m either on my way to field-test a product or nipping to the library where I do much of my writing. Iâ€™ve extensive experience reviewing useful things, fromtravel pillowstoreusable cups, for titles including the Filter. For the past decade or so, Iâ€™ve devoted much of my time to working out what differentiates one product from the next, and what really matters to the user.How I testedPete Wise stands on a rural hill holding various umbrellas â€“ some have reversed in the windAs well as using them in the rain, we tested all the brolliesâ€™ wind resistance on top of the Peak Districtâ€™s Mam Tor. Video: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianThroughout October 2025, I carried each umbrella and used it in daily life, noting how effectively it sheltered me from rain and wind. I considered how convenient each model was to use and carry. Did it cover my head, shoulders and torso adequately? Was it comfortable to hold? And would a sudden gust of wind turn its canopy inside out?For a sterner test of resilience and wind resistance, I opened the umbrellas in strong winds (and clung on for dear life) near the summit of Mam Tor, a highly exposed, 517-metre hill in the Peak District, which overlooks part ofthe newly minted Steel Cotton Rail Trail. At an altitude greater than the height of any building in Europe, this seemed like an adequate testing ground to see how the brollies would handle a stiff breeze. (Thanks to photographer Christian Hopewell for capturing the fun, and to Alice Ostapjuk-Wise for helping it run smoothly.)Of course, not all umbrellas are designed for use in extreme conditions. Each of the reviews below reflects the umbrellaâ€™s performance against the manufacturerâ€™s claims, as well as how it fared during hilltop testing.I assessed 15 umbrellas in total, and have featured the best selection here. After testing, I took the wind-buffeted brollies to my localMindcharity shop.The best umbrellas in 2025View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianBest umbrella overall:London Undercover ClassicView image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£115 at London UndercoverThe London Undercover Classic emerged as the top performer in both day-to-day use and hilltop testing.Why we love itItâ€™s a beautifully finished item with exceptional components, right down to the frilly, orange rosette on the runner. Each design has a pleasant colour contrast on the underside to add some cheer to your under-brolly microclimate, which proved impressively dry in this umbrellaâ€™s case. I found the slim, elegant maple hook handle very comfortable to hold, with just the right hint of tangible grain to add grip to its smoothness.The canopy is made entirely from recycled polyethylene terephthalate fabric. It comprises two layers of material â€“ a dual-layer designâ€“ and this is key to the Classicâ€™s exceptional wind resistance. During my hilltop testing, it withstood very strong gusts without inverting, and even when I held it high into the air, it only inverted slightly at one side.As the canopy is fairly deep, thereâ€™s very good coverage of the head and shoulders. For taller users, a wider model might be better for the torso and legs.Itâ€™s a shame that â€¦at Â£115, this umbrella is a serious investment, although I would argue that youâ€™re getting outstanding quality in return. Still, most of the other brollies featured here cost far less.Weight:500gLength (folded):91.5cmCanopy diameter:105cmWarranty:one year (and exceptional cases considered over a longer period)Best budget umbrella:Doppler Zero 99View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£29.99 at DopplerÂ£29.99 at AmazonAre you the sort of person who sometimes ends up buying an ultra-cheap brolly from a cut-price shop on unexpectedly rainy days? I suspect many of us are.Why we love itThis fairly priced, pocket-sized brolly from Doppler is a better, eco-friendlier solution for those who want convenient access to a brolly, without ladening themselves down. The weight and size are negligible, so you can pop it inside your bag for permanent storage and pluck it out with satisfaction whenever rain starts to fall. When I used it on the sodden streets of Leeds, it proved a helpful companion during moderate showers, although the small-ish canopy diameter meant my legs received a dousing.Its features are cleverly designed to minimise the heft, especially the small, circular grip at the bottom of the pole, which is just as clutchable as a knob but a fraction of the size. For the price youâ€™re paying, the design is outstanding.Itâ€™s a shame thatâ€¦this lightweight umbrella is highly prone to inverting in the wind, and coverage is relatively limited. It could keep your head and shoulders dry in a shower, but as I discovered on the windy peak of Mam Tor, itâ€™s not suitable for challenging weather.Weight:99gLength (folded):21cmCanopy diameter:90cmWarranty:three yearsBest folding umbrella:Blunt Metro UmbrellaView image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£75 at Blunt UmbrellasÂ£74.70 at AmazonThe Blunt Metro is a statement piece that will bring sunshine to a rainy day â€“ especially if youâ€™ve chosen the citrus yellow colour I received for testing.Why we love itIt feels very sturdy and durable, and the sweetly shaped canopy proved broad enough to keep my head and shoulders dry. The automatic opening action is very smooth, although I did find that the button was easy to press accidentally, as itâ€™s incorporated so deftly into the handle.Victorian Londoners were crying out for this brolly: an initial brake on their uptake of umbrellas was the risk of collisions on crowded streets â€“ so argued William Sangster in his book of 1855, Umbrellas and Their History.The Metro has a unique and brilliant solution for this continuing problem: it can spin freely through 360 degrees when open, so it rolls breezily away when knocked.Like every other folding umbrella I tested, the Metro soon inverted once held open to strong wind on the hilltop, but it popped back into shape easily enough. It stood up well against sudden gusts in day-to-day use, with no inverting where other small brollies failed.Itâ€™s a shame that â€¦this umbrella has the odd trait of sending a shower of droplets back towards you when you try to shake it dry. Youâ€™re better off letting it drip.Weight:385gLength (folded):37.5cmCanopy diameter:100cmWarranty:two yearsBest-looking umbrella:Oswin Hyde JosephView image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£49 at DebenhamsÂ£49 at BurtonThis Oswin Hyde umbrella is remarkable for its currently reduced price of Â£49 (RRP: Â£75). It looks beautiful, with a many-ribbed, rounded shape thatâ€™s reminiscent of traditional Indian state umbrellas (calledchatra). Most of the components feel of good quality (although theyâ€™re not at the premium end of the market), and the brolly rolls up prettily for carrying or storage inside its protective sleeve.Why we love itI found this a very pleasant umbrella to shelter under, with broad coverage and pleasing acoustics that made my voice sound uncharacteristically interesting while recording notes, mid-review. Itâ€™s broad enough to prevent vertical or near-vertical rain from hitting most parts of the body, although Iâ€™d recommend something with a deeper canopy for sideways rain. Itâ€™s wide enough for two people to shelter under, and the attractive shape and detailing might make it a romantic choice for shared use.While this umbrella did invert in the wind, without needing as much blustery coercion as some of its competitors, I was impressed with how it bounced back from these episodes. Itâ€™s clear that the ribs are highly flexible, which should help them to resist damage.Itâ€™s a shame that â€¦this isnâ€™t quite as robust as some of the higher-end brollies weâ€™ve reviewed. I found that the tip can be dented easily.Weight:658gLength (folded):92cmCanopy diameter:112cmWarranty:six monthsBest mini umbrella:Davek MiniView image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£60 at DavekA charming little helper that lives happily in a handbag or rucksack, the Davek Mini is the finest miniature umbrella Iâ€™ve ever unfurled. I enjoyed admiring its elaborate frame (fibreglass reinforced for wind resistance) from beneath its brightly hued canopy. In ferocious winds at the summit of Mam Tor, it held up for longer than other folding models before turning inside out. However, I wouldnâ€™t recommend it for use in blustery weather.Why we love itThis brolly feels incredibly light, and if you study the fine details, youâ€™ll appreciate how it came to be so. For instance, the handle is tiny and hollow, but itâ€™s surprisingly comfortable and nicer to grasp than many of its more bulbous rivals. Iâ€™d suggest using the slightly elasticated wrist strap at the same time, since this allows a more casual grip without fear of dropping.The canopy is broader than you might expect, with a diameter that rivals some mid-size umbrellas. It kept my head dry during rain showers, although the same canâ€™t be said for my gangly legs.Itâ€™s a shame that â€¦it costs Â£60, which is steep for a mini umbrella. However, factoring in the lifetime guarantee, this could be a prudent choice in the long term.Weight:225gLength (folded):17cmCanopy diameter:86cmWarranty:unconditional lifetime guaranteeskip past newsletter promotionSign up toThe FilterFree weekly newsletterGet the best shopping advice from the Filter team straight to your inbox. If you do not have an account, we will create a guest account for you ontheguardian.comto send you this newsletter. You can complete full registration at any time. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionBest golf umbrella:Fulton Titan1View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£41.95 at HansfordsÂ£29.87 at AmazonIâ€™ll admit that golf umbrellas arenâ€™t my favourite breed of brolly, but this model from Fulton won me over. The windproof, vented canopy proved highly effective at resisting inversion in strong winds, even when gusts were so powerful that I started to lose my footing.Why we love itFulton describes this canopy as â€œsupersizeâ€, and at 136cm in diameter, itâ€™s certainly the largest Iâ€™ve tested. Thereâ€™s ample coverage for two people to shelter without catching the runoff from the umbrellaâ€™s sides. Its fabric, with the concave dips between the rib tips, nicely frames your view of the world.The Titan 1â€™s construction is impressive, too, especially considering the affordable pricing. Its lightweight, fibreglass frame has remarkable flexibility and gives the brolly a bouncy feel in hand.Rather than a sleeve, the Titan comes in a carry case with a shoulder strap, allowing for easier, hands-free transportation.Itâ€™s a shame that â€¦this umbrella can sometimes make your forearms ache. Holding it by the straight grip (which is undoubtedly comfy), I found it easy to rest back on my shoulder, but quite strenuous to hold forwards into the wind.Weight:950gLength (folded):98cmCanopy diameter:136cmWarranty:all manufacturing faults consideredThe best of the restView image in fullscreenâ€˜Resisted inversion impressivelyâ€™: the Davek Elite.Photograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianFulton Minilite2View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£26 at John LewisÂ£12.05 at AmazonBest for:a pocket umbrellaFulton makes this Minilite 2 style with various printed canopies, including retro stripes, art prints and the glitter bow version shown.Itâ€™s a cheerful, affordable option, and I enjoyed seeing the shimmering pattern through the material as I walked under streetlights on a rainy night.It was prone to inverting in the breeze, although the aluminium frame proved wind resistant, as promised, with no signs of damage after a sojourn in powerful winds. The folded size is suitable for handbags and backpacks.It didnâ€™t make the final cut because â€¦it feels quite rickety compared with the other options featured here.Weight:236g;length (folded):25cm;canopy diameter:96cm;warranty:all manufacturing faults consideredPaul Smith compact umbrellaView image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£120 at Paul SmithÂ£120 at John LewisBest for:a designer umbrellaWould you like an umbrella with ample coverage and a classic aesthetic, or one that fits inside a rucksack? Where most brands make you choose, this one from Paul Smith covers all the bases. Its canopy is wide and deep, and the telescopic pole allows it to fold down to a manageable size.My favourite touch here is the wooden crook handle â€“ a rarity in folding umbrellas. Thereâ€™s just the right degree of irregularity to the finishing around its edges.It didnâ€™t make the final cut because â€¦although itâ€™s mid-size, this umbrella fared little better than smaller folding models when used in strong winds. It inverted quickly during my stress test in the Peak District.Weight:433gLength (folded):47cmCanopy diameter:100cmWarranty:two yearsKnirps T200 DuomaticView image in fullscreenÂ£69.99 at KnirpsÂ£61.98 at AmazonBest for:automatic opening and closingI was impressed with this smart-looking, meticulously engineered folding umbrella from Knirps. While not quite as small as some mini or pocket folding umbrellas, it will fit comfortably inside a good-size backpack or handbag. The automatic open-close mechanism is supremely smooth, and the bright, red button that activates it positively begs to be pressed.It has a dual-rib assembly that gives it strength when inverted by the wind, as well as when held head-on, and apparently this has been tested in a wind tunnel at up to 150km an hour.It didnâ€™t make the final cut because â€¦while the frame could indeed withstand a battering from the wind, the T200 was just as quick to invert as other lightweight models. So, while it might not sustain damage in windy weather, itâ€™s perhaps not the best brolly to use in these conditions.Weight:320g;length (folded):28cm;canopy diameter:98cm;warranty:five yearsLifeventure Medium TrekView image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£21.99 at LifeventureÂ£22 at Cotswold OutdoorBest for:UV protectionBefore umbrellas were used to keep off rain, parasols shielded people from the sun. A growing trend among trekkers and mountaineers has seen small, lightweight umbrellas added to packing lists for both purposes, making brollies just as relevant on the mission to base camp as they are on the walk to work.This Lifeventure model is a good example of the type, with automatic open-close, a grippy pleather handle and â€“ hereâ€™s the important part â€“ UPF50+ sun protection. I thought it felt strong and light, and the opening mechanism is excellent.It didnâ€™t make the final cut because â€¦the Trekâ€™s wind resistance is modest (although not bad for a folding model), so itâ€™s best suited to sun or rain protection on still days.Weight:380g;length (folded):32cm;canopy diameter:97cm;warranty:three yearsDavek EliteView image in fullscreenPhotograph: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianÂ£159 at DavekBest for:a formal occasionThis sleek city umbrella (or â€œcane umbrellaâ€) from luxury brand Davek is a perfect match for smart outerwear or suiting. In this black colourway, it has a slightly â€œgoth winterâ€ feel to it, with a stitched leather handle and elongated rib tips.During our high-winds testing, the Elite resisted inversion impressively, and it soon returned to the desired shape once turned back to face the wind. The fibreglass frame proved highly flexible and resilient to stress.It didnâ€™t make the final cut because â€¦personally, I preferred other umbrellas in a similar price range. Thatâ€™s not to say this isnâ€™t a great brolly, though.Weight:708g;length (folded):89cm;canopy diameter:112cm;warranty:unconditional lifetime guaranteeWhat youneed to knowPete Wise stands on a rural hill holding various umbrellas â€“ some have reversed in the windStormproof umbrellas fared best in the hilltop tests. Video: Christian Hopewell/The GuardianFeatures to look out forAutomatic opening(and sometimes closure) is a nice-to-have feature that makes using an umbrella that little bit easier. Itâ€™s common in golf umbrellas and even more so in folding umbrellas, which employ a telescopic pole (or shaft) for compact portability.Stormproofor windproof umbrellas have vents or dual layers of fabric to allow gusts through. Models with these features clearly proved to be the best at resisting inversion (or dragging me towards a cliff edge) during my testing in high winds. Another feature widely used in windproof models is a double ribbed frame, which tends to make the umbrella more resilient to the push and pull of high winds.What types of umbrellas are there?City umbrellasare the traditional choice in the UK, with a long, solid pole and a wide canopy. Most have a curved handle called a â€œhookâ€ or â€œcrookâ€ â€“ interchangeable terms in umbrella anatomy.Sportier and often with brighter-coloured canopies,golf umbrellasare another large, non-folding option. For some reason (perhaps in an aggressive move towards caddies), many have straight grip handles.Folding umbrellasâ€“ also known as portable umbrellas or even pocket umbrellas â€“ have been around since the Victorian period. The best modern examples are made with super-lightweight materials and can endure blustery conditions without breaking. Thanks to their telescopic shafts, theyâ€™re easy to slip into a rucksack or handbag, so you can keep one handy for unexpected showers.Whatâ€™s the difference between an umbrella and a parasol?In the UK, it has been largely unfashionable to use handheld umbrellas for sun protection since Victorian times. This is a shame, since blocking potentially harmful rays is one of an umbrellaâ€™s strengths.An umbrella especially for sun protection is called a parasol. These far predate modern (rain-focused) umbrellas, as evidenced by records from ancient Egypt and Assyria, to name a few early parasol hotspots.The two types, or uses, of an umbrella-shaped item are now practically inseparable in terms of silhouette and construction. However, some umbrellas are better for sun protection than others. If keeping off the sun is one of your top priorities, itâ€™s generally best to choose an umbrella that has a wide, deep canopy â€“ and better still, UV-protective material, as used in the Lifeventure model reviewed above.For more, read thebest waterproof jackets for menand thebest waterproof jackets for womenPete Wise is ajournalist from Leeds. Over the past decade or so, heâ€™s reviewed hundreds of products for titles includingthe Filterand written about many other topics, fromaquifersto tutu-making. Pete thoroughly enjoyed readingMarion Rankineâ€™sbook Brolliologyas research for this article. His favourite umbrella is a Bettyâ€™s Tearooms-branded one that once belonged to his mother. title: NHS staff bearing brunt as â€˜uglyâ€™ racism of 70s and 80s returns, says Streeting | NHS | The Guardian
description: Exclusive: Health secretary and NHS England chief warn of winter pressures and rising levels of abuse
Author: Denis Campbell
Headline: Exclusive: Health secretary and NHS England chief warn of winter pressures and rising levels of abuse
Content: Wes Streeting said it was time to put racism â€˜back in its boxâ€™ in the UK.Photograph: Lucy North/PAView image in fullscreenWes Streeting said it was time to put racism â€˜back in its boxâ€™ in the UK.Photograph: Lucy North/PANHSNHS staff bearing brunt as â€˜uglyâ€™ racism of 70s and 80s returns, says StreetingExclusive: Health secretary and NHS England chief warn of winter pressures and rising levels of abuseDenis CampbellHealth policy editorTue 4 Nov 2025 15.08 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 14.33 ESTShareAn â€œuglyâ€ racism reminiscent of the 1970s and 1980s has become worryingly commonplace again in modern Britain and NHS staff are bearing the brunt of it,Wes Streetinghas warned.Incidents of verbal and physical abuse based on peopleâ€™s skin colour now happen so often that it has become â€œsocially acceptable to be racistâ€, the health secretary said.In a joint interview with the Guardian alongside theNHSEngland chief executive, Jim Mackey, Streeting told how he has been â€œshockedâ€ hearing NHS staff, especially those working in A&E, recount growing levels of harassment, aggression and violence when their care gets delayed.Advising the public to brace themselves for the NHS in England getting overwhelmed in the coming weeks because of a triple whammy of flu, Covid and strike action by doctors as winter descends, he admitted that patients would be put in danger as a result of becoming stuck on trolleys or in the back of ambulances â€“ situations that are known to heighten the risk of harm and death.â€œEven if youâ€™ve got a long wait, which I know is frustrating, or you feel like youâ€™ve been sent from pillar to post, which sadly does happen, thereâ€™s no excuse for taking that out on staff,â€ Streeting said.â€œBut the thing that has shocked me most of all is that the rising tide of racism and the way in which kind of 1970s, 1980s-style racism has apparently become permissible again in this country. Iâ€™m really shocked at the way this is now impacting on NHS staff,â€ he said.He also criticised unnamed politicians who condone racism, adding: â€œIâ€™m disgusted that a level of racism last seen when Britain was a very different country, 50 years ago, has made an ugly comeback and Iâ€™m frankly shocked by those in parliament whoâ€™ve leaned into it.â€His remarks come a week after the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) revealed that thenumber of racist incidents that nurses suffer at work has surgedover recent years.Streeting added: â€œI had a Labour [MP] colleague whose daughter â€“ a resident doctor â€“ works in a hospital where a man said he only wanted to be treated by white staff. Although she was Asian, she had slightly fairer skin. And a colleague said: â€˜Will you go and see if maybe heâ€™ll accept you?â€™ And rightly she turned around and said: â€˜No, I wonâ€™t, actually. Go and tell him that he either wants our care or he doesnâ€™t, but he doesnâ€™t get to racially discriminate.â€™ She made the right call.â€œThe NHS is not immune from the prejudices of wider society but weâ€™ve got to take a zero tolerance [approach]. Your right to free healthcare in this country does not come with the freedom to abuse our staff on any grounds.â€œWeâ€™ve got to call time on racism in this country and weâ€™ve got to put that ugly racist sentiment thatâ€™s found expression in our country back in its box and once again create a climate in this country where it is not socially acceptable to be racist.â€Prof Nicola Ranger, the RCNâ€™s chief executive, endorsed Streetingâ€™s remarks about politicians inflaming racial tensions. â€œThe rise in the racist abuse that staff face is a stain on society and a stain on our NHS.â€œRacism is an issue across society and is particularly pertinent in health and care services, with such a diverse workforce. We have to recognise that the increasing use of anti-migrant rhetoric in politics is emboldening racist behaviour.â€Prof Habib Naqvi, the chief executive of the NHS Race andHealthObservatory, said: â€œItâ€™s shocking to see the levels of racism within our communities and across modern Britain today â€“ levels that we have not witnessed for decades. We know our NHS is not immune from this scourge because it is a microcosm of wider society â€“ what happens on our streets and within society does play out in the 1.5 million people that work in the NHS.â€Mackey and Streeting admitted that, despite the NHS in England preparing more thoroughly for winter than ever before, some trusts would â€œstruggleâ€ to maintain normal service during the cold spell, in which A&E units are expected to see record numbers of people seeking care.â€œI want to be upfront with people, especially at a time when trust in politics is in even shorter supply than money. When there are problems this winter, and there will be problems this winter, there will be hospitals where there are people on trolleys in corridors.â€Mackey added that corridor care â€“highlighted graphically by Age UK last weekâ€“ is â€œone of the things that keeps me awake at nightâ€ and â€œone of the horrible, visible signs of drifting standards over recent years. Itâ€™s completely unacceptable.â€He added that: â€œIâ€™m really hopeful that weâ€™ll manage it [winter] well. But itâ€™s important to be realistic. Thereâ€™s a lot of flu around, thereâ€™s been a lot of Covid around and the industrial action issue is a complexity we could do without.â€Nearly 150,000 aged 90 and above wait 12 hours in Englandâ€™s A&Es each yearRead moreThe four hospitals in Bristol and Weston-super-Mare have been on a â€œcritical incidentâ€ â€“ meaning emergency-footing â€“ and receiving help from other NHS trusts since last Thursday because of an â€œexceptionally high demandâ€ for care.Some hospitals, such as those in Lincolnshire have told patients, visitors and staff in some care areas to wear a face mask from next week to curb the spread of viruses.Resident â€“ formerly junior â€“ doctors in Englandwant a 29% pay rise. Tens of thousands of them are due to go on strike for five days from 14 November in pursuit of their claim, in what will be their 13th walkout since March 2023. Their last strike in July cost the NHS an estimated Â£250m.Streeting urged the British Medical Association, the main doctorsâ€™ union, to call off next weekâ€™s action. It is unjustified because resident doctorsâ€™ salaries have risen by 28.9% over the last three years, he said.â€œThe impact it [strikes] will have on winter really worries me. Everyone is going to lose if this goes ahead. Patients are going to suffer because of the disruption and impact on the service. Doctors and other NHS staff will suffer because they have to pick up the pieces of the disruption. And this time it will be taking place against the backdrop of winter. But resident doctors themselves [will also] loseâ€, he added.Explore more on these topicsNHSWes StreetingRaceHealthTrade unionsnewsShareReuse this content

title: Reeves considers cut to green levies in effort to reduce cost of energy bills | Budget 2025 | The Guardian
description: Exclusive: Chancellor hopes to save up to Â£170 from average bill but industry insiders say move would be â€˜disastrousâ€™
Author: Kiran Stacey
Headline: Exclusive: Chancellor hopes to save up to Â£170 from average bill but industry insiders say move would be â€˜disastrousâ€™
Content: If Rachel Reeves carries out the plan, Ed Miliband, right, may have to fund home energy efficiency upgrades through the Â£13bn warm homes plan.Photograph: Kirsty Oâ€™Connor/TreasuryView image in fullscreenIf Rachel Reeves carries out the plan, Ed Miliband, right, may have to fund home energy efficiency upgrades through the Â£13bn warm homes plan.Photograph: Kirsty Oâ€™Connor/TreasuryBudget 2025Reeves considers cut to green levies in effort to reduce cost of energy billsExclusive: Chancellor hopes to save up to Â£170 from average bill but industry insiders say move would be â€˜disastrousâ€™Prospect of breaking 50-year income tax taboo shows scale of Reevesâ€™s challengeKiran Stacey,Pippa Crerar,Jessica ElgotandHelena HortonTue 4 Nov 2025 15.47 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 13.58 ESTShareRachel Reeves is considering slashing funding for more energy efficient homes to pay for a reduction in energy bills, sources have told the Guardian, as the chancellor looks for ways to ease the cost of living in this monthâ€™s budget.Reeves is finalising a multibillion pound energy support package that is likely to cut taxes and green levies from peopleâ€™s bills as she looks to save as much as Â£170 from the average bill.The chancellor is hoping her focus on reducing energy bills will help bolster Labourâ€™s slump in the polls, dent the appeal of Reform UK and mitigate the impact of widely expected tax rises in the autumn budget.In a rare pre-budget speech on Tuesday, the chancellor signalled she was prepared to make controversial decisions, as she and the prime minister debate breaking a pre-manifesto commitment andraising income tax.She said: â€œI could do what previous governments have done, which is to sweep those challenges under the carpet, to cut capital spending, to make the numbers up.â€œBut then weâ€™d be back here in a year, in five yearsâ€™ time, with productivity still on its knees, growth underperforming, national debt continuing to rise. So Iâ€™m being honest with people.â€But she added that easing the cost of living would be one of her three main priorities, alongside reducing the national debt and protecting the NHS.At the early morning Downing Street event, Reeves hinted at tax rises, adding that â€œeach of us must do our bitâ€ for the countryâ€™s future. â€œIf we have to build the future of Britain together, we will all have to contribute to that effort.â€â€œI have to face the world as it is, not the world that I want it to be. And when challenges come our way, the only question is how to respond to them, not whether to respond or not.â€View image in fullscreenRachel Reeves told the media this morning that she had to face â€˜the world as it isâ€™.Photograph: Andy Rain/EPAThe chancellor added the economic challenges facing the UK â€“ including global tariffs, sticky inflation, volatile supply chains and defence spending â€“ had got worse since last yearâ€™s financial statement.Cabinet ministers, braced for a consequential tax-raising budget later this month, warned that the public needed to feel the direct benefit of any increases.â€œWe have to be absolutely crystal clear if weâ€™re doing this about how we link it to what it delivers for voters. What are we doing for them if we do this?â€ one minister said. â€œIâ€™m not saying itâ€™s not high stakes. But it had better fucking work,â€ another added.A third minister said they had concluded that voters wanted Labour to fix public services even if they did not like how it was paid for. Several told the Guardian they believed the election pledge on tax was â€œstupidâ€ for an opposition party.In a sign of internal government concerns over the possible market reaction, Labour has organised a series of pre-budget â€œeconomic insight sessionsâ€ for Labour MPs with economists and former ministers in recent weeks.Reeves and the prime minister have identified high energy bills as being a major source of financial pressure for voters and are planning a relief package likely to cost about Â£3bn a year.Keir Starmer is understood to be particularly worried about the impact of an expected Â£100 rise in energy bills next spring, and wants to do enough to eliminate that and bring down costs even further.A major part of the plan, insiders say, will be eliminating the 5% VAT rate on part or all of domestic energy bills, in a move that experts say would cost Â£2.5bn a year and bring down bills by an average of Â£86.Some economists warn such a move would risk benefiting those with larger homes and encouraging people to use more energy, but the Treasury is understood to be keen on the idea because it is simple and quick to implement.Alongside the VAT reduction, Reeves is planning to reduce or eliminate some of the green levies on bills, which could reduce costs for householders and undercut Reformâ€™s promise to do the same.However, energy industry insiders say raiding energy efficiency funding to help pay for the move would be â€œdisastrousâ€.Prospect of breaking 50-year income tax taboo shows scale of Reevesâ€™s challengeRead moreThose consulted on the plans say the chancellor is particularly looking at reducing or eliminating the energy company obligation, under which energy firms help pay for home improvement measures such as insulation and new heating schemes. Last year, the National Audit Officewarned offraud and poor quality in some of the work undertaken under the scheme.If the programme is reduced or cut entirely, the energy secretary, Ed Miliband, could choose to reallocate money from the Â£13bn warm homes plan, much of which is earmarked to pay for subsidies for electric heat pumps.The government decidedas recently as Juneto protect the scheme, but the chancellor is thought to be willing to see it reduced to help bring bills down now.Reeves is also weighing up cutting other levies, such as the renewable obligation certificate programme, which currently goes up by retail price inflation but could be tied instead to the lower consumer price index.The Treasury declined to comment on budget speculation, but those in the energy industry say the plans could backfire in the longer term.1:48Rachel Reeves avoids answering question on tax rises in pre-budget speech â€“Â videoIn her speech, the chancellor also accused previous governments of putting â€œpolitical convenienceâ€ before â€œeconomic imperativeâ€, raiding capital budgets intended to support the public services to balance the books.â€œThe problem of the last 14 years is that political expediency always came above the national interest. And that is why we are in the mess that we are in today,â€ she added.The cost of UK borrowing fell slightly as the chancellor reiterated her â€œiron-cladâ€ commitment to her fiscal rules, reassuring the bond markets.After the speech, Starmer told his cabinet the budget would neither starve the state of cash nor take â€œrisks with more borrowingâ€, inferring that tax rises are the only option.Government sources said the prime minister had accepted the necessity of the move. â€œEven if everything is exploding around him, he has a plan and knows the direction weâ€™re going in,â€ they added.Dhara Vyas, the chief executive ofEnergyUK, said: â€œBillions of pounds of investment have been on hold while we await the warm homes plan â€“ all of which could be jeopardised by any sudden change of direction. So hijacking the planâ€™s budget and effectively abandoning its original purpose would be a shortsighted and disastrous move.â€œWeâ€™ve had ample previous experience showing how kneejerk cuts to investment in warmer homes have resulted in customers paying billions of pounds more on their energy bills, while also damaging supply chains and businesses with knock on impacts to investment and job losses.â€Explore more on these topicsBudget 2025Rachel ReevesBudgetEnergy billsEnergyHousehold billsTax and spendingnewsShareReuse this content

title: England curriculum should focus less on exams and more on life skills, finds review | National curriculum | The Guardian
description: Experts say pupils should spend less time in exam halls and more time on activities like life skills, sport and work experience
Author: Richard Adams
Headline: Experts say pupils should spend less time in exam halls and more time on activities like life skills, sport and work experience
Content: The proposed changes would cut about three hours from the length of GCSE exams sat by pupils.Photograph: Jim Wileman/The GuardianView image in fullscreenThe proposed changes would cut about three hours from the length of GCSE exams sat by pupils.Photograph: Jim Wileman/The GuardianNational curriculumEngland curriculum should focus less on exams and more on life skills, finds
