For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionLiverpoolâ€™s disbelief turned to disgust when Szoboszlai next took aim at the Real goal. The Hungarianâ€™s drive struck AurÃ©lien TchouamÃ©ni on the hand as he dived in to block. The referee, Istvan Kovacs, awarded a free-kick on the edge of the area but the France international was clearly inside when making contact with the ball. A spot-kick appeared imminent when Kovacs was sent to the pitchâ€‘side monitor but he rejected the penalty claim and overturned the free-kick. TchouamÃ©niâ€™s arms were in a natural position, apparently. Anfield reacted with understandable fury.The controversy emboldened Slotâ€™s side more than the Spanish league leaders. Giorgi Mamardashvili saved from Bellingham and Arda Guler in quick succession but Courtois remained the busier keeper by far. Szoboszlai was denied twice by Realâ€™s No 1 before the break, Mac Allister too, and Courtoisâ€™s one-man stand continued after the restart. Virgil van Dijk could only laugh when his close-range header from a Wirtz corner was tipped over. Courtois repeated the trick when the resulting corner from Szoboszlai was headed goalwards by Hugo EkitikÃ©.Courtoisâ€™s resistance was finally broken after Bellingham picked up a booking for fouling Ryan Gravenberch on the right. Conceding cheap freeâ€‘kicks was Realâ€™s biggest failing on the night, according to Alonso. Szoboszlai swept over a powerful setâ€‘piece â€“ Alexanderâ€‘Arnold might have taken it had he stayed â€“ and the improving Mac Allister bulleted a header through the goalkeeperâ€™s guard. VAR intervened again to check a potential offside against the goalscorer. Anfield would not be enraged this time.Explore more on these topicsChampions LeagueLiverpoolReal MadridEuropean club footballmatch reportsShareReuse this content

title: Arsenal make it 10 wins in a row as they cruise past Slavia Prague with Merino double | Champions League | The Guardian
description: Arsenal took the lead through a Bukayo Saka penalty after a VAR review for handball before Mikel Merinoâ€™s two goals made it 3-0 against Slavia Prague
Author: Ed Aarons
Headline: Arsenal took the lead through a Bukayo Saka penalty after a VAR review for handball before Mikel Merinoâ€™s two goals made it 3-0 against Slavia Prague
Content: Mikel Merino scores Arsenalâ€™s second goal straight after half-time as they continued their unbeaten run in Europe this season.Photograph: Michael Zemanek/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenMikel Merino scores Arsenalâ€™s second goal straight after half-time as they continued their unbeaten run in Europe this season.Photograph: Michael Zemanek/ShutterstockChampions LeagueArsenal make it 10 wins in a row as they cruise past Slavia Prague with Merino doubleEd Aaronsat Fortuna ArenaTue 4 Nov 2025 14.56 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 17.23 ESTShareAnother game, another slew of records for Arsenalâ€™s defensive machine. This time it included one that stretched back more than 55 years, when Leeds were the last English team not to concede a goal in their opening four matches, in the 1969â€‘70 European Cup campaign, under Don Revie.A determinedSlavia Pragueside, that came into this game unbeaten in all domestic competitions, gave it their best shot and thought they had been awarded a late penalty, only for the referee to overturn his decision after the video assistant referee called him to the pitchside monitor. The Czech champions finally recorded a shot on target in stoppage time. It meant Arsenal made it eight successive clean sheets in all competitions for the first time since 1903, when they were in what was the Second Â­Division. A penalty from Bukayo Saka and two secondâ€‘half goals from the makeshift striker Mikel Merino sealed a 10th successive victory for Mikel Artetaâ€™s ruthless side.Tottenham v Copenhagen, PSG v Bayern Munich, and more: Champions League â€“ liveRead moreâ€œThe most pleasing thing probably is not the record, itâ€™s the mindset of the players. They are talking there about how we can still do better,â€ the delighted Arsenal manager said. â€œItâ€™s one or two situations where we could have resolved better. If we do that we can keep improving and that record will have a bigger meaning.â€There was also a special moment for Max Dowman as he became the youngest player inChampions Leaguehistory at 15Â yearsÂ 308Â days when he was brought on to replace the excellent Leandro Trossard with the points already firmly in the bag.â€œWhat heâ€™s done on the pitch, the first ball he takes, he takes people on, he starts to dribble, gets a foul,â€ Arteta said. â€œThatâ€™s personality, thatâ€™s Â­courage and you cannot teach that. You have it or you donâ€™t. It doesnâ€™t matter what his passport says. You throw him in this context and heâ€™s able to adapt.â€It has been to Arsenalâ€™s immense credit that they have maintained their winning run with so many attacking players missing through injury, with Viktor Â­GyÃ¶keres becoming the latest when he limped offagainst Burnley on Saturday. There are fears that the Sweden striker has injured a hamstring but it is hoped he could return with Gabriel Â­Martinelli and the captain, Martin Ã˜degaard, in time for the north London derby againstto play Tottenham after the international break.View image in fullscreenBukayo Saka scores from the penalty spot in the first half against Slavia Prague.Photograph: Petr David Josek/APIn the meantime, Merino was back in the role that he filled so Â­admirably last season and showed he has lost none of his sharpness in front of goal with two well-taken finishes. Â­Christian NÃ¸rgaard performed well in place of the suspended MartÃ­n Â­Zubimendi and Piero HincapiÃ© and Ethan Nwaneri also impressed on rare starts as Arteta rotated his squad.Jindrich Trpisovsky, the Slavia manager, is an experienced character who has won four league titles and he rated Arsenal beforehand as one of the best teams his side have faced, as well as describing Declan Rice as the best freeâ€‘kick taker in the world.However, it was the hosts who made the more encouraging start as Arsenal were unsettled by their allâ€‘action pressing game, with 6ftÂ 6in Czech international striker Tomas Chory providing a stiff physical test for their defence. Gabriel MagalhÃ£es needed treatment for a facial injury midway through the first half but there was never any chance of him coming off.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toFootball DailyFree daily newsletterKick off your evenings with the Guardian's take on the world of footballEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionSaka finally tested Jakub Â­Markovic in the Slavia goal after 25 minutes after powering into the area and a corner from Rice almost sneaked in at the near post. Another Saka shot was just as close and Gabriel was able to make first contact on the resulting corner, with the VAR spotting that Lukas Â­Provodâ€™s left arm had been in an unnatural position when he blocked the Brazilianâ€™s goalbound header. Saka made light of the protestations from the home supporters behind the goal and stepped up to coolly give Arsenal the lead.Slavia Prague 0-3 Arsenal: Champions League â€“ live reactionRead moreSlavia thought they should have had a penalty as well just before the break for handball by HincapiÃ© but this time the referee from Azerbaijan was not interested. Any hopes that they could find a way back into the game were dealt a major blow within 40 seconds of the restart. Rice picked out Trossard in acres of space and his cross was volleyed in emphatically at the near post by Merino. This was Arsenal at their clinical best.Merinoâ€™s second was a real Â­poacherâ€™s finish as he beat Â­Markovic to Riceâ€™s cross to loop his header into the empty net. And it has been some week for Dowman, who became the Â­youngest player to start a game for Arsenal in the Carabao Cup win against Brighton and has now surpassed Youssoufa Moukoko of Borussia Â­Dortmund and his record of 16 years and 18 days set in December 2020. He looked totally at home in these Â­surroundings and not even a late scare, when Ben White was penaliÂ­sed for a high boot before the VAR intervened again, could stop Arsenal on another perfect evening.Explore more on these topicsChampions LeagueSlavia PragueArsenalEuropean club footballmatch reportsShareReuse this content

title: Nick Kyrgios to play womenâ€™s No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in Battle of the Sexes clash | Tennis | The Guardian
description: Nick Kyrgios and Aryna Sabalenka are to star in the latest man-v-woman tennis match, with Kyrgios following several notable Australians in doing so
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Nick Kyrgios and Aryna Sabalenka are to star in the latest man-v-woman tennis match, with Kyrgios following several notable Australians in doing so
Content: Nick Kyrgios will play womenâ€™s No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in the latest Battle of the Sexes tennis match to be played in Dubai in December.Photograph: Joel Carrett/AAPView image in fullscreenNick Kyrgios will play womenâ€™s No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in the latest Battle of the Sexes tennis match to be played in Dubai in December.Photograph: Joel Carrett/AAPTennisNick Kyrgios to play womenâ€™s No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in Battle of the Sexes clashAustralian tennis star to meet Belarusian in December in Dubaiâ€˜Iâ€™m not just here to play, Iâ€™m here to entertain,â€™ says KyrgiosAustralian Associated PressTue 4 Nov 2025 18.15 ESTShareNick Kyrgios, Australian former Wimbledon finalist, is to play womenâ€™s world No 1Aryna Sabalenkain an exhibition match in Dubai.The clash evokes memories of the 1973 Battle of the Sexes match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs â€“ which King won in straight sets in the Houston Astrodome and was later the subject of a Hollywood movie.Kyrgios also follows Australians Margaret Court, Evonne Goolagong Cawley and Pat Cash in playing such a match.WTA Finals tennis: Sabalenka fends off Pegula; Gauff beats ailing Paolini â€“ as it happenedRead moreThe exhibition, to take place on 28 December, was confirmed by both players on social media. It is likely to be played under modified rules including Kyrgios being restricted to a single serve.â€œWhen the world No 1 challenges you, you answer the call. Iâ€™ve got massive respect for Aryna; sheâ€™s a powerhouse and a true champion,â€ said Kyrgios, who shares an agent with Sabalenka.â€œBut Iâ€™ve never backed down from a challenge, and Iâ€™m not just here to play, Iâ€™m here to entertain. This is what I live for.â€View image in fullscreenAryna Sabalenka at the WTA Finals.Photograph: Robert Prange/Getty ImagesKyrgios, 30, has barely played in recent years after being plagued by injuries and is currently ranked 652nd in the world.He was in the top 20 in October 2022 when he was forced to withdraw from the quarter-final of the ATP 500 Tokyo Open with a left knee injury.He has since played six matches, winning one, losing four and retiring in the other. He last played on the ATP Tour at the Miami Open in March.â€œI have a lot of respect for Nick and his talent, but make no mistake, Iâ€™m ready to bring my A-game,â€ Sabalenka, 27, has said of the match.The Battle of the Sexes match came after Riggs, then 55 and a long-retired tennis pro, beat Court in May 1973.Court, who won the Australian, French and US Open titles that year, lost 6-2 6-1 in what was later dubbed the â€œMotherâ€™s Day Massacreâ€.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toSport in FocusFree weekly newsletterSign up to Sport in FocusEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. If you do not have an account, we will create a guest account for you ontheguardian.comto send you this newsletter. You can complete full registration at any time. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionKing, who had initially rejected Riggsâ€™ challenge, then felt she had to respond, in what was promoted as the first official Battle of the Sexes.King won 6-4 6-3 6-3 in front of an estimated 90 million TV viewers.â€œI have so much respect for Billie Jean King and what she has done for the womenâ€™s game,â€ Sabalenka said. â€œIâ€™m proud to represent womenâ€™s tennis and to be part of this modern take of the iconic Battle of the Sexes match.â€There have been plenty of other mixed-gender singles matches right back to 1888 when the Wimbledon menâ€™s and womenâ€™s singles champions played each other. Ernest Renshaw beat Lottie Dod 2-6 7-5 7-5 after Dod began every game 30-0 up.Among them in 1975 Goolagong Cawley, then known as Evonne Goolagong, beat Ilie Nastase 7-5. The latter, a noted entertainer, entered court in a dress, was not allowed to rush the net unless forced to by Goolagongâ€™s shot, and only had one serve while the Australian could hit into the doubles alleys.Cash, then in his early fifties, lost to then-British No.1 Johanna Konta in 2017, 6-3. The match was played in a shopping centre, on an artificial surface, with former player Greg Rusedski umpiring and Cash described as â€œflamboyantâ€ with his shot-making.Explore more on these topicsTennisNick KyrgiosAryna SabalenkaAustralia sportnewsShareReuse this content

title: NFL trade deadline: Jets trade away All-Pros Gardner and Williams in franchise teardown | NFL | The Guardian
description: Indianapolis trades two first-rounders for All-Pro corner Sauce Gardner, signaling a Super Bowl push ahead of the NFL deadline
Author: Guardian sport
Headline: Indianapolis trades two first-rounders for All-Pro corner Sauce Gardner, signaling a Super Bowl push ahead of the NFL deadline
Content: Sauce Gardner of the New York Jets walks off the field prior to a December game against the Bills.Photograph: Kara Durrette/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenSauce Gardner of the New York Jets walks off the field prior to a December game against the Bills.Photograph: Kara Durrette/Getty ImagesNFLNFL trade deadline: Jets trade away All-Pros Gardner and Williams in franchise teardownColts trade two first-round picks for GardnerJets also trade DE Quinnen Williams in teardownNFL teams had until 4pm EST to make tradesGuardian sportand agenciesTue 4 Nov 2025 15.48 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 13.09 ESTShareTheIndianapolis Coltshave acquired two-time All-Pro cornerback Sauce Gardner from the New York Jets in a stunning trade ahead of Tuesdayâ€™s NFL deadline, according to multiple reports.In exchange, the Colts will send two first-round picks to New York, marking one of the most significant deals of the season. Gardner, the No 4 overall pick in the 2022 draft, has quickly established himself as one of the leagueâ€™s premier defenders, earning All-Pro honors in each of his first two years.â€œNew York itâ€™s been real,â€ Gardner posted with a green heart emojion X.New York it's been realğŸ’šâ€” SAUCE GARDNER (@iamSauceGardner)November 4, 2025The move comes just months after Gardner signed a four-year, $120.4m extension with the Jets â€“ a deal that made him one of the highest-paid cornerbacks inNFLhistory. His departure signals a major shift for New Yorkâ€™s defense, which was built around his lockdown coverage skills. The Jets look set for a rebuild after slumping to a 1-7 record this season. The franchise has not made the playoffs since the 2010 season, the longest drought in the NFL.For the 7-2 Colts, the trade represents a clear push toward Super Bowl contention. With Gardner joining a secondary that already ranks among the leagueâ€™s top units, Indianapolis are betting big on an elite defense to power their playoff run.It was the first of two massive trades by Jets general manager Darren Mougey before the deadline Tuesday. New York also agreed to trade defensive lineman Quinnen Williams to the Dallas Cowboys for a second-round pick in 2026, a first-round pick in 2027 and defensive tackle Mazi Smith, two people with knowledge of the deal told the Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the teams hadnâ€™t announced the trade.Elsewhere, the Cowboys acquired linebacker Logan Wilson from the Cincinnati Bengals for a seventh-round pick on Tuesday. Hours beforethe Cowboys lost to the Arizona Cardinalson Monday night to fall to 3-5-1, owner Jerry Jones said the team had a deal in place to add a player who could improve the defense.Wilson had requested a trade after his playing time decreased for the Bengals, who have the leagueâ€™s worst defense. The Cowboys traded two-time All-Pro pass rusher Micah Parsons to Green Bay before the season, leaving a huge void that Wilson doesnâ€™t fill.â€œSome guys have the ability to see a certain key and, at the same time, take a step up in the hole,â€ Jones said on his radio show on 105.3 The Fan. â€œHe knows how to get in the gaps right now. ... For what we need right now, he can come in immediately and help us at linebacker.â€Hall of Fame quarterback Troy Aikman, who led the Cowboys to three Super Bowls in the 1990s, mocked the deal during the ESPN broadcast of Mondayâ€™s loss to the Cardinals.â€œHe may want to cancel that trade,â€ Aikman said. â€œI donâ€™t think one player from what Iâ€™ve seen tonight is going to make a difference for this group.â€NFL teams had until 4pm EST on Tuesday to make a trade.Meanwhile, the reigning Super Bowl champion Philadelphia Eagles have been aggressive. General manager Howie Roseman continues adding players to a talented roster to improve the teamâ€™s chances for a repeat.Since the Eagles (6-2) last played a game, theyâ€™ve acquired edge rusher Jaelan Phillips and cornerbacks Michael Carter II and Jaire Alexander.Phillips, who came from Miami on Monday for a third-round pick, immediately bolsters the pass rush. The 2021 first-round pick had three sacks in his last five games for the Dolphins. All of Philadelphiaâ€™s edge rushers combined have three sacks this season.Carter gives the defense a veteran slot cornerback to allow defensive coordinator Vic Fangio more flexibility to use Cooper DeJean outside. Alexander, a two-time Pro Bowl selection, is a low-risk, high-reward acquisition.The Baltimore Ravens also added an edge rusher, getting Dreâ€™Mont Jones from Tennessee for a conditional fifth-round pick. Jones has 4.5 sacks this season so heâ€™s an upgrade for the Ravens (3-5) at a position of need.Several trades already went down last month. The Bengals acquired Joe Flacco. The Rams got cornerback Roger McCreary. Defensive end Keion White went to the 49ers. Safety Kyle Dugger was traded to the Steelers. The Jaguars and Browns swapped cornerbacks Greg Newsome II and Tyson Campbell.The Chargers added edge Odafe Oweh in a deal that sent safety Alohi Gilman to the Ravens.There are some high-profile players who could be on the move. Bengals All-Pro edge rusher Trey Hendrickson and Jets running back Breece Hall are among the biggest names being mentioned in trade speculation.Explore more on these topicsNFLIndianapolis ColtsNew York JetsUS sportsShareReuse this content

title: Van de Ven stunner inspires 10-man Spurs to emphatic win over Copenhagen | Champions League | The Guardian
description: Brennan Johnson scored the opener and was later sent off in Tottenhamâ€™s 4-0 home Champions League win against Cogenhagen
Author: David Hytner
Headline: Brennan Johnson scored the opener and was later sent off in Tottenhamâ€™s 4-0 home Champions League win against Cogenhagen
Content: Micky Van de Ven shows his delight after scoring a sensational solo goal for Spurs.Photograph: Alex Morton/Tottenham Hotspur FC/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenMicky Van de Ven shows his delight after scoring a sensational solo goal for Spurs.Photograph: Alex Morton/Tottenham Hotspur FC/ShutterstockChampions LeagueVan de Ven stunner inspires 10-man Spurs to emphatic win over CopenhagenDavid Hytnerat Tottenham Hotspur StadiumTue 4 Nov 2025 17.04 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 18.56 ESTShareIt was the moment when the Tottenham home crowd could forget about their recent frustrations and lose themselves in the joy of it all; the glorious release. Their team had been too good for Copenhagen, who showed virtually nothing â€“ certainly not in a positive sense.Spurs were 2-0 up after Wilson Odobertâ€™s goal but there was a glitch when Brennan Johnson, who had opened the scoring, was sent off in the 57th minute. The foul on Marcos LÃ³pez was more clumsy than sinister yet when the referee, Erik Lambrechts, was advised to go to the pitchside monitor, Johnsonâ€™s involvement was over.Mac Allister sinks Real Madrid to ruin Alexander-Arnoldâ€™s return to LiverpoolRead moreEnter Micky van de Ven. The centre-half has becomesynonymous with the swashbucklingand he was at it again when he seized possession on the edge of his own penalty box and started to motor. It was a blur as he left four Copenhagen players in his wake, twisting initially to get through the first couple but picking up an inexorable head of steam when he straightened up.Nobody was going to catch him and there was an inevitability, too, about the finish once he got to the edge of the other area, the ball lashed home left-footed past the hapless Copenhagen goalkeeper, Dominik Kotarski. Spurs have their goal of the season already and it was possible to wonder whether it might compete for the more prestigious individual prizes in this area. There were shades ofSon Heung-min versus Burnleyin 2019 â€“ and that one won the Puskas award.It was Van de Venâ€™s sixth goal of the season and it set Spurs up for a confidence-boosting win, one that took them to eight points from four unbeatenChampions Leagueties. JoÃ£o Palhinha, on as a substitute, added the fourth and they could even shrug off a late penalty miss from another replacement, Richarlison, his shot bouncing down off the crossbar and away.Were the crowd unhappy he took the kick rather than Dane Scarlett, another substitute, who had won it? The pre-match theme had been the ability of those fans to become a little vexed. There were boos for Richarlison as he prepared to step up. But this was not a night for those sort of musings, rather one to celebrate.Xavi Simons needed a performance and delivered; it was just a shame that he was withdrawn after Johnsonâ€™s dismissal, Thomas Frank sending on Palhinha. Johnson was good, too, before the red card and if Randal Kolo Muani missed a couple of sitters, he redeemed himself with a fine assist for Odobert.Spurs had been desperate for something on their own turf, the match framed by the horror of the Premier League defeat hereagainst Chelsea on Saturdayand everything that went with it â€“ the continuation of the dismal home league form, the negativity of the fans, a furious Van de Ven blanking Frank at full time, as did Djed Spence. â€œMicky can keep walking past me if heâ€™s angry after a game,â€ Frank said with a smile. â€œIt seems like we had Lionel Messi turned into Micky.â€View image in fullscreenBrennan Johnson takes the ball past Dominik Kotarski before giving Spurs a first-half lead.Photograph: David Klein/ReutersSpurs made the breakthrough in the 19th minute; the start of a more enjoyable occasion for them. Johnson had blown an early half-chance with a poor first touch but he got everything right when he darted in behind a couple of Copenhagen defenders and was found by a lovely curved ball from Simons.Copenhagen had been caught on a quick transition after Gabriel Pereira misplaced a simple pass. Worse was to come as Johnson surged onto the ball, Kotarski bolting from his line; a race he was never going to win. title: LIV Golf backtracks from short format to 72-hole tournaments after pressure from players | Golf | The Guardian
description: LIV Golf has surprisingly backtracked on one of its founding principles by announcing tournaments in the fourth season will be played over 72 holes
Author: Ewan Murray
Headline: LIV Golf has surprisingly backtracked on one of its founding principles by announcing tournaments in the fourth season will be played over 72 holes
Content: Jon Rahm believes extending the length of tournaments is the logical next step for LIV Golf.Photograph: Matt Marton/USA Today SportsView image in fullscreenJon Rahm believes extending the length of tournaments is the logical next step for LIV Golf.Photograph: Matt Marton/USA Today SportsGolfLIV Golf backtracks from short format to 72-hole tournaments after pressure from playersTourâ€™s name partly based on Roman numeral referenceLeading players want better preparation for majorsEwan MurrayTue 4 Nov 2025 13.59 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 18.59 ESTShareLIVGolfhas surprisingly backtracked on one of its founding principles by announcing tournaments in the fourth season of the Saudi Arabian-backed league will be played over 72 holes. Until now, LIV has proudly operated over 54 holes and three days, with the name itself partly based on a Roman numeral reference point. Could a rebrand to LXXII be imminent?The dramatic shift, which is believed to have come after pressure from players, means LIV will soon mirror the schedule traditional golf tours it once tried to upstage. LIV will, however, continue to run both individual and team competition elements.Jack Nicklaus wins $50m verdict in defamation case over LIV Golf allegationsRead moreâ€œThe most successful leagues around the world â€“ IPL, EPL [English Premier League], NBA, MLB, NFL â€“ continue to innovate and evolve their product,â€ said Scott Oâ€™Neil, LIVâ€™s chief executive. â€œAnd as an emerging league, we are no different. LIV Golf will always have an eye towards progress that acts in the best interest of LIV Golf and in the best interest of the sport.â€A LIV statement added: â€œFor each regular season event, the individual competition will be decided over 72 holes of stroke play, while the team competition will continue to run concurrently, with each teamâ€™s cumulative individual stroke play scores determining the teamâ€™s result.â€The degree of â€œinnovationâ€ to which Oâ€™Neil refers will raise eyebrows given four days and 72 holes had been the model in golfâ€™s existing ecosystem before LIV blasted onto the scene, coaxing household nameswith exorbitant contracts. It is understood some players in the LIV environment felt under-prepared for major championships due to the abbreviated nature of their standard playing domain. Umpteen players own equity in LIV teams. Golfâ€™s official world-ranking system has also failed to recognise LIV, a matter which may change under the 72-hole model.â€œLIV Golf is a playerâ€™s league,â€ said the two-time major winner Jon Rahm. â€œWe are competitors to the core and we want every opportunity to compete at the highest level and to perfect our craft. Moving to 72 holes is the logical next step that strengthens the competition, tests us more fully, and if the growing galleries from last season are any indication, delivers more of what the fans want.â€Dustin Johnson added: â€œPlaying 72 holes just feels a little more like the big tournaments weâ€™ve all grown up playing.â€ Johnson, also a double major winner, has not finished in the top 10 in one of the big four events since 2023.All of this presents something of a public relations quandary. Oâ€™Neilâ€™s predecessor, Greg Norman, explained two years ago why LIV had been given that precise name. The Australian said: â€œIt is the Roman numeral for 54, which has two meanings: 54 is the lowest score you could shoot if you were to birdie every hole on a par 72 course, so there is an aspirational aspect to the thinking. It is also the number of holes to be played in each event.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toThe RecapFree weekly newsletterThe best of our sports journalism from the past seven days and a heads-up on the weekendâ€™s actionEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. title: Roebuck and Steward injuries likely to trigger major England reshuffle against Fiji | England rugby union team | The Guardian
description: Head coach Steve Â­Borthwick was planning to announce Englandâ€™s starting XV early this week but has changed tack after Tom Roebuck limped out of training
Author: Robert Kitson
Headline: Head coach Steve Â­Borthwick was planning to announce Englandâ€™s starting XV early this week but has changed tack after Tom Roebuck limped out of training
Content: Tom Roebuck limped out of training with an ankle injury in the buildup to this weekendâ€™s Test.Photograph: Tom Sandberg/PPAUK/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenTom Roebuck limped out of training with an ankle injury in the buildup to this weekendâ€™s Test.Photograph: Tom Sandberg/PPAUK/ShutterstockEngland rugby union teamRoebuck and Steward injuries likely to trigger major England reshuffle against FijiSmith, Arundell and Lawrence in frame to startBorthwick faces dilemmas to backline selectionRobert KitsonTue 4 Nov 2025 13.34 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 15.16 ESTShareInjuries to Tom Roebuck and Â­Freddie Steward look likely to trigger an eye-catching reshuffle in Englandâ€™s backline for the Test against Fiji on Saturday. Marcus Smith, Henry Arundell and Ollie Lawrence are all in contention to be involved, with Manny Feyi-Waboso potentially the solitary starting back-three survivor fromthe victory against AustralialastÂ Saturday.The head coach, Steve Â­Borthwick, had been hoping to announce his starting XV early this week only for that plan to be mothballed when Roebuck limped out of training prematurely on Tuesday with an ankle problem. Steward has not trained so far this week after sustaining a finger injury late in the win against the Wallabies, opening the way for Smith to replace him at full-back.Steward injury could offer Smith the chance to start for England against FijiRead moreRoebuck was an influential figure against Australia, his aerial skills contributing to two of Englandâ€™s four tries, but if he is ruled unavailable England are not short of options. In an ideal world the management are keen to continue their Â­experiment of deploying Tommy Freeman at Â­centre, which leaves Arundell and Cadan Murley vying for slots in the Â­matchday 23. And if the dancing Smith starts at 15, a Â­bigger Â­ball-carrying presence such as Â­Lawrence would offer useful midfield balance.Arundell, meanwhile, has not played for England since Â­departing for the French Top 14 following the 2023 World Cup, during which he scored five tries in asingle game against Chile. He has been in Â­excellent form this season for Bath and, with his 23rd birthday looming on Saturday, is Â­itching for another chance to show off his startling pace at the highest level.â€œItâ€™s great to have him back and to see him score a crazy amount of tries already in the Prem,â€ the Â­England assistant coach Kevin Sinfield said. â€œHeâ€™s been good in training and is banging on the door.â€If Arundell, Feyi-Waboso and Smith do all start they would rank alongside the most elusive and attack-minded back three England have fielded. title: Dick Cheney, vice-president and giant of Republican politics, dies aged 84 | Dick Cheney | The Guardian
description: Cheney, who served under presidents from Nixon to George W Bush, will be remembered for controversial role after 9/11
Author: Martin Pengelly
Headline: Cheney, who served under presidents from Nixon to George W Bush, will be remembered for controversial role after 9/11
Content: Dick Cheneyâ€™s place in history will be dominated by the decision to invade Iraq.Photograph: Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenDick Cheneyâ€™s place in history will be dominated by the decision to invade Iraq.Photograph: Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty ImagesDick CheneyDick Cheney, vice-president and giant of Republican politics, dies aged 84Cheney, who served under presidents from Nixon to George W Bush, will be remembered for controversial role after 9/11Dick Cheney created the ground for Trumpâ€™s excesses, despite their differencesMartin Pengelly,Chris Michael,George ChidiandOliver MilmanTue 4 Nov 2025 11.42 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 06.35 ESTShareDick Cheney, the divisive US vice-president underGeorge W Bushwho helped lead the country into a disastrous invasion ofIraq, died on Monday, his family has said. He was 84.Cheney at various times held the roles of member of Congress, White House chief of staff and secretary of defense, but it was as one of the countryâ€™s most powerful vice-presidents that he had the biggest impact, wielding great influence over the less experienced Bush.Dick Cheney remembered as steady, influential force in US politicsRead moreCheney was in office on 11 September 2001 during the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington. While Bush was hurried to safety, Cheney worked with the defense secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, toassume policy control. Troops were soon in Afghanistan, fighting the Taliban and hunting al-Qaida.But Cheneyâ€™s place in history will be dominated by the decision to invadeIraq. He had been defense secretary during the first Gulf war against Saddam Hussein, in 1990 and 1991, but now Cheney and Bushâ€™s public rationale for war was that the Iraqi dictator was linked to al-Qaida and thus 9/11, and possessed weapons of mass destruction. By March 2003, when US and coalition forces invaded, no proof had been found for either charge, and both were soon proved false.Although Cheney sought international cooperation, he also thought,he later wrote, that the Bush administration â€œhad an obligation to do whatever it took to defend Americaâ€.View image in fullscreenGeorge W Bush and Cheney embrace following Bushâ€™s acceptance speech during the final night of the Republican national convention in 2004.Photograph: Charles Dharapak/APThe death toll was high.Accordingto the Watson School of International and Public Affairs at Brown University, since 2001 â€œat least 800,000 people have been killed by direct war violence in Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria, Yemen and Pakistanâ€.The treatment of prisoners taken by the US in its â€œwar on terrorâ€ also provedhugely controversial. Out of office, Cheney continued todefendthe use of torture against detainees after 9/11.A Yale dropout who avoided service in Vietnam, Cheney nonetheless became a giant of Republican politics.He was a White House aide under Richard Nixon; the youngest ever White House chief of staff, to Gerald Ford; a member of Congress under Ronald Reagan; secretary of defense toGeorge HW Bush, and vice-president to George W Bush.When the younger Bush plucked him from theHalliburton corporationto be his running mate in the 2000 presidential election, Cheney had already survived three heart attacks. Nor was he immune to mishap: once, while vice-president, heshot a hunting partnerin the face.2:04A look back on the legacy of former US vice-president Dick Cheney â€“ videoCheney underwent a successful heart transplant in 2012, after suffering premature heart disease, but was an â€œincredibly easyâ€ patient to deal with, his long-term physician Jonathan Reiner told CNN.The former-vice president was â€œnever concerned about what people knew about his heart disease. He was very open about it,â€ Reiner said. â€œHe was the easiest patient, unbelievably compliant. And I think thatâ€™s one of the reasons why he was able to live such a long and full life.â€Cheneyâ€™s daughter, Liz Cheney, followed him into Republican politics as a US House representative from Wyoming in the same seat her father had held while a congressman, but she was censured by the party after strongly criticising Donald Trump over the January 6 insurrection.View image in fullscreenDick Cheney and his daughter Liz arrive to vote at the Teton county library, Wyoming, during the Republican primary election in August 2022.Photograph: Jabin Botsford/APThe elder Cheney also attended an event to mark the first anniversary of the attack alongside his daughter, where he expressed â€œdeep disappointmentâ€ in Republican party leadership, saying: â€œItâ€™s not a leadership that resembles any of the folks that I knew when I was here for 10 yearsâ€ and that â€œyou canâ€™t overestimate how important [January 6] isâ€.Cheney announced in 2024 that he would vote for Kamala Harris rather than the Republican nominee Trump, saying that â€œin our nationâ€™s 248-year history, there has never been an individual who is a greater threat to our republic than Donald Trumpâ€ and that he felt a duty to â€œput country above partisanship to defend our constitutionâ€.Speaking to the Guardian in 2018, on the release of Vice, a darkly comic biopic starring Christian Bale, the Cheney biographer Jake Bernstein said: â€œThere has been some rehabilitation with George W Bush. In comparison with Donald Trump, everyone starts to look better. ButDick Cheneyliked the fact everyone called him Darth Vader. I donâ€™t think thereâ€™ll be an effort on his part to soften his image.â€Explore more on these topicsDick CheneyRepublicansGeorge BushGeorge HW BushRonald ReaganRichard NixonUS politicsnewsShareReuse this content

title: GalÃ¡pagos had no native amphibians. Then it was invaded by hundreds of thousands of frogs | Amphibians | The Guardian
description: Scientists are only beginning to grasp the scale of the issue and understand what impact the tree frogs may have on the islandsâ€™ rare wildlife
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Scientists are only beginning to grasp the scale of the issue and understand what impact the tree frogs may have on the islandsâ€™ rare wildlife
Content: Fowlerâ€™s snouted tree frogs (Scinax quinquefasciatus)are thought to have arrived on the islands as stowaways on cargo ships.Photograph: Joshua Vela Fonseca/Charles Darwin Research StationView image in fullscreenFowlerâ€™s snouted tree frogs (Scinax quinquefasciatus)are thought to have arrived on the islands as stowaways on cargo ships.Photograph: Joshua Vela Fonseca/Charles Darwin Research StationThe age of extinctionAmphibiansGalÃ¡pagos had no native amphibians. Then it was invaded by hundreds of thousands of frogsScientists are only beginning to grasp the scale of the issue and understand what impact the tree frogs may have on the islandsâ€™ rare wildlifeThe age of extinction is supported byAbout this contentSofia Quaglia in Santa Cruz, GalÃ¡pagosTue 4 Nov 2025 09.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 18.07 ESTShareOn the way to her office at the Charles Darwin research station, biologistMiriam San JosÃ©crouches down near a shallow pond shrouded by vegetation and reaches deep into the foliage, pulling out a small green plastic box recorder.She left it there overnight to capture the infamous croaks of a Fowlerâ€™s snouted treefrog (Scinax quinquefasciatus), known to GalÃ¡pagos scientists as an invasive threat, with repercussions researchers are only beginning to grasp.Despite abounding with wildlife â€“centuries-old giant tortoises, swimming iguanas, and thefinches that sparked Darwinâ€™s theory of evolutionâ€“ the GalÃ¡pagos archipelago off the coast of Ecuador has long been free from amphibians. Until recently, no frogs, toads, newts, or salamanders waddled or hopped on its volcanic islands.In the late 1990s, that changed. Some small tree frogs made their way from mainlandEcuadorto the islands, likely as stowaways on cargo ships.View image in fullscreenFowlerâ€™s snouted tree frogs arrived in the 90s and have become established on Isabela and Santa Cruz islands.Photograph: Rashid Cruz/Charles Darwin Research StationGenetic studies suggest that, over the years, there have been repeated accidental introductions to the archipelago, and the frogs now have a strong foothold on two islands: Isabela and Santa Cruz. The population is growing so fast that scientists have been struggling to keep track, estimating numbers in the hundreds of thousands on each island, across urban and agricultural areas, but also in the protected GalÃ¡pagos national park.When San JosÃ© marked frogs and tried to recapture them in the following 10 days â€“ a technique commonly used to make estimates of animal populations â€“ she could find just one marked frog every once in a while, suggesting their populations were huge. They estimated 6,000 frogs in a single pond. â€œOur estimates are still very conservative,â€ says San JosÃ©. â€œI am pretty sure there are even more.â€The frogsâ€™ abundance is clear from the acoustic chaos they cause. â€œThe amount of frogs and the noise â€“ itâ€™s really insane,â€ says San JosÃ©.For the scientists, their nightly mating calls are helpful in estimating their presence in far-flung areas, using recorders like the one outside San JosÃ©â€™s office. But local farmers say the calls are so raucous they keep them up at night.â€œDuring the wet season, I constantly hear their calls and theyâ€™re really loud,â€ says Jadira Larrea Saltos, a coffee farmer at Finca La Envidia on Santa Cruz.â€œAt first it was a surprise, seeing the first frogs in the area,â€ says Larrea Saltos, who started noticing their abundance about three years ago when one jumped on her hand as she was walking out of her front door. Now she has more poultry on her property, which she thinks has helped keep the populations relatively at bay.The noise isnâ€™t the fundamental problem, though. While the species has been in the GalÃ¡pagos for almost 30 years, scientists still know very little about its impact on the archipelagoâ€™s delicately balanced land and water ecosystems.View image in fullscreenScientists are finding out more about the frogs, including that they can remain as tadpoles for as long as six months.Photograph: Joshua Vela Fonseca/Charles Darwin Research StationOn islands, it is very common for invasive species to thrive, as they have none of their natural predators. The GalÃ¡pagoscounts 1,645 invasive species, many of which are seriously disrupting the safety of its endemic ones. Avianvampire flies are bleeding rare bird hatchlings dry, and the hardy blackberry plant is encroaching on the Scalesia forests.A2020 study suggests the invasive frogs are voracious insect eaters, and might be disproportionately consuming rare insects found only on the archipelago, or depleting the food sources of the islandsâ€™ rare birds, disrupting the food chain. Since the frogsâ€™ diet is dominated by moths, they could even be affecting pollination on the islands, according to ecologistMarÃ­a del Mar Moretta-Urdiales, who was involved in the study.Bonobos transformed how we think about animal societies. Can we save the last of the â€˜hippy apesâ€™?Read moreThe GalÃ¡pagos frogs have exhibited some unusual traits, including living in brackish water, which is uncommon for amphibians. Their metamorphosis process is also extremely variable, with some tadpoles turning into frogs very quickly and others taking a long time: San JosÃ© observed one which remained as a tadpole in her lab for six months.â€œWe really donâ€™t know this part,â€ she says, worried the tadpoles could be affecting the islandsâ€™ freshwater, a very scarce resource in GalÃ¡pagos. And even though studies show that the GalÃ¡pagos diving beetle now eats large numbers of tadpoles in its diet, it doesnâ€™t seem to be making a dent in their populations.View image in fullscreenMore research is needed to determine the best way to control the frogs without harming other species.Photograph: Rashid Cruz/Charles Darwin Research StationMethods to curb the frogs in the early 2000s were largely unsuccessful. Park rangers tried capturing large numbers by hand and gradually increasing the salinity of lagoons in vain. Researchsuggests spraying coffeeâ€“ which is highly toxic to frogs â€“ or using electrocution could help, but these methods arenâ€™t necessarily safe for other rare GalÃ¡pagos species.Without answers to more of the basic questions about their biology and impact, culling the frogs might not even be the right way to go, says San JosÃ©.While she hopes the growing use of environmental DNA techniques and genetic analysis will help her team make sense of the invader, funding for the project has been hard to come by. â€œEverybody wants to give funding for preserving frogs,â€ says San JosÃ©. â€œBut itâ€™s harder to find funding for an introduced frog that you might want to control for.â€Find moreage of extinction coverage here, and follow the biodiversity reportersPhoebe WestonandPatrick Greenfieldin the Guardian app for more nature coverageExplore more on these topicsAmphibiansThe age of extinctionInvasive speciesGalÃ¡pagos IslandsConservationEcuadorAmericasWildlifefeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜How did we get here?â€™: documentary explores how Republicans changed course on the climate | Documentary films | The Guardian
description: In The White House Effect, now available on Netflix, archival footage is used to show how the US right moved from believing to disputing the climate crisis
Author: Adrian Horton
Headline: In The White House Effect, now available on Netflix, archival footage is used to show how the US right moved from believing to disputing the climate crisis
Content: A still from The White House EffectPhotograph: NetflixView image in fullscreenA still from The White House EffectPhotograph: NetflixDocumentary filmsâ€˜How did we get here?â€™: documentary explores how Republicans changed course on the climateIn The White House Effect, now available on Netflix, archival footage is used to show how the US right moved from believing to disputing the climate crisisAdrian HortonTue 4 Nov 2025 05.02 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 10.43 ESTShareIn 1988, the United States entered into its worst drought since the Dust Bowl. Crops withered in fields nationwide, part of an estimated $60bn in damage ($160bn in 2025). Dust storms swept the midwest and northern Great Plains. Cities instituted water restrictions. That summer, unrelentingly hot temperatureskilledbetween 5,000 and 10,000 people, and Yellowstone national park suffered the worst wildfire in its history.â€˜How is this possible?â€™: a new film looks inside the appalling abuses of the Alabama prison systemRead moreAmid the disaster, George HW Bush, then Ronald Reaganâ€™s vice-president, met with farmers in Michigan reeling from crop losses. Bush, the Republican candidate for president, consoled them: if elected, he would be the environmental president. He acknowledged the reality of intensifying heatwaves â€“ the â€œgreenhouse effectâ€, to use the scientific parlance of the day â€“ with blunt clarity: the burning of fossil fuels contributed excess carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, leading to global warming. But though the scale of the problem could seem â€œimpossibleâ€, he assured the farmers that â€œthose who think weâ€™re powerless to do anything about this greenhouse effect are forgetting about the White House Effectâ€ â€“ the impact of sound environmental policy for the leading consumer of fossil fuels. Curbing emissions, he said, was â€œthe common agenda of the futureâ€.That clip â€“ startling to anyone even glancingly familiar with Republican orthodoxy in the years since â€“ appears early in The White House Effect, a new all-archival documentary that examines the evolution of the climate crisis from non-partisan reality to divisive political issue. The 96-minute film, now available onNetflix, takes its name from Bushâ€™s unfulfilled guarantee of environmental action during his four years as president, a pivotal missed opportunity â€“ if not, as the film implicitly argues,thepivotal missed opportunity â€“ for bipartisan US leadership on the climate crisis. â€œThere was this moment in time when the science was widely accepted, when the public was all about tackling this,â€ co-director Pedro Kos told the Guardian. â€œIt was a mom and pop issue, as American as apple pie. Flash forward to four years later, and you have a completely split electorate. How do we get there?â€The film, directed by Kos with Jon Shenk and Bonni Cohen, first rewinds the clock from Bushâ€™s uncontroversial campaign promise back to the 1970s, when the science on the greenhouse effect became a public talking point. In news footage from the late 70s, ordinary Americans react to Jimmy Carterâ€™s exhortation to face â€œa problem thatâ€™s unprecedented in our historyâ€ with patriotic enthusiasm; sacrifices, they confirm, may be necessary. By the early 1980s, faced with a gas shortages and hours-long lines at the pump, some of that enthusiasm had crumbled. As the Republican presidential candidate, Reagan responded to the discontent by blaming the government and calling for authority to be transferred back to the private sector (or, to use a Reagan euphemism, â€œexperts in the fieldâ€) â€“ setting the stage for the Republican partyâ€™s symbiotic relationship with large oil companies well aware of the impact of emissions on the climate. (To quote an internal Exxon document from 1984: â€œWe can either adapt our civilization to a warmer planet or avoid the problem by sharply curtailing the use of fossil fuels.â€)But the film largely focuses on Bush, a blue blood east coaster who made his fortune in the Texas oilfields, and who nevertheless began his term in office in 1989 determined, at least outwardly, to break from his predecessor on the environment. Bush appointed an environmental activist, William Reilly, as head of the Environmental Protection Agency; he exhorted Congress that â€œthe time for action is now.â€ The White House Effect illustrates the political forces that eroded such purpose: the corporations that, according to their own internal documents, sought to downplay and discredit scientific evidence to protect their profit; the power games by White House chief of staff John Sununu, an ally of corporate lobbyists who outmaneuvered Reilly by encouraging climate skepticism in the aftermath of disasters such as Hurricane Hugo and the devastating Exxon-Valdez oil spill.The film works exclusively with meticulously edited archival footage â€“ the team sorted through more than 14,000 clips from more than 100 sources, including VHS tapes stored in the New Jersey garage of a former Exxon Mobil publicist and a memo from a confidential â€œGlobal Warming Scientific â€˜Skepticsâ€™ Meetingâ€ convened in 1991 by Sununu to empower media appearances by prominent climate contrarians. The reliance on archival was part of an effort to â€œimmerse the public in a time when this wasnâ€™t a political football â€“ where we experience the politicization of the issue, rather than being told itâ€, said Kos. â€œWhenever you turn on a camera and interview someone in the present, thatâ€™s automatically going to come with the political connotations that the present brings.â€View image in fullscreenA still from The White House Effect.Photograph: NetflixCohen and Shenk are veterans of climate change films; the married couple directed An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power, the follow-up to Al Goreâ€™s groundbreaking documentary on looming climate catastrophe. But with The White House Effect, â€œwe wanted to do something very different from what weâ€™ve done in our past work and what we think of as the â€˜climate change genreâ€™ of documentaries: we wanted to just drop the truth bomb of history,â€ said Shenk. â€œWe need that, right? We just need the truth.â€With archival, thereâ€™s â€œan opportunity to expand the conversationâ€, Cohen added. From man-on-the-street interviews to standard network broadcasts from the period, â€œhopefully you can see yourself in the film no matter who you are as an American, and feel that youâ€™re part of the conversation, rather than some liberal film-makers preaching at you.â€The platforming of climate skeptics on mainstream media and Sununuâ€™s counsel seemed to have an effect on Bush. By 1990, speaking at a White House conference on the climate crisis, he equivocated where he once held firm: â€œOne scientist argued that if we keep burning fossil fuels at todayâ€™s rate, by the end of the next century, Earth could be 9F warmer than today. And the other scientist saw no evidence of rapid change,â€ he said. â€œTwo scientists, two diametrically opposed points of view. Now, where does that leave us?â€ It left the US hamstrung by political division. Two years later, the â€œenvironmental presidentâ€ reluctantly attended the 1992 Rio â€œEarth Summitâ€, a major United Nations conference to set international targets for emissions reductions, advocating against such measures in the name of economic development and stability. The move, from the worldâ€™s largest greenhouse gas emitter, angered other countries, but Bush chided the international coalition: â€œI donâ€™t think leadership is going along with the mob.â€ The seeds for outright climate denial, and the Republican partyâ€™s unfettered and open alliance with corporate interests, had been sown.View image in fullscreenA still from The White House Effect.Photograph: NetflixNearly three decades later, in 2019, Reilly rued how the US missed an â€œincalculably importantâ€ opportunity at Rio. â€œThe advantage we might have had if president Bush had committed to seriously undertake the reduction of greenhouse gases is that we might have removed the partisan nature of the dialogue in the United States,â€ he said. If that prospect, in the era of hyper-partisanship, increasingly absurd natural disasters and the Trump administrationâ€™s dismantling of environmental regulation, feels deeply infuriating â€“ well, Cohen argued, thatâ€™s the point. â€œClimate change films, at least in the last 10 years, have been trying to spoon-feed the medicine of the climate crisis, and then have a â€˜hope bucketâ€™ at the end, where you can feel OK,â€ she said. â€œOur job is to create the rage. We canâ€™t shy away from the rage. And if this film, in all of its irrefutable archival historical glory, can create that rage, then weâ€™ve succeeded.â€The hope, she added, is that â€œyou can feel the rage and you can feel the intolerance for the denial of truth, and that youâ€™ll actually do something about at the ballot box. The hopelessness is when you feel like you canâ€™t do anything. But we have a large electorate in this country â€“ letâ€™s get out there.â€Kos, having overseen the mass archival effort, encouraged viewers to look at â€œthe overall arc of historyâ€ â€“ even in the face of the Los Angeles fires, the Texas floods, the rapid and unprecedented intensification of hurricanes like the one that devastated Jamaica just last week â€“ â€œwhat good is despair going to do?â€ The truth of political power, for good and for ill, is â€œright there in front of our eyes.â€â€œThe choice is in our hands,â€ he added. â€œWeâ€™ve shown you a what-if moment from 1988. Weâ€™re now in another what-if moment.â€The White House Effect is now available on NetflixExplore more on these topicsDocumentary filmsNetflixGeorge BushClimate crisisfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Third of British farmers made no profit in past year, report finds | Farming | The Guardian
description: Only 14% of farmers surveyed for Farmdex report had 10% or more profit margin amid drop in subsidies since Brexit
Author: Helena Horton
Headline: Only 14% of farmers surveyed for Farmdex report had 10% or more profit margin amid drop in subsidies since Brexit
Content: While the UK was part of the EU, subsidies from the bloc for UK farmers made up as much as half of their annual income.Photograph: Michael Foley/AlamyView image in fullscreenWhile the UK was part of the EU, subsidies from the bloc for UK farmers made up as much as half of their annual income.Photograph: Michael Foley/AlamyFarmingThird of British farmers made no profit in past year, report findsOnly 14% of farmers surveyed for Farmdex report had 10% or more profit margin amid drop in subsidies since BrexitHelena HortonEnvironment reporterTue 4 Nov 2025 02.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 02.02 ESTShareA third of British farmers are making a loss or breaking even as they struggle with the loss of subsidies and looming inheritance tax changes, a report on post-Brexit farming has found.Only 14% of farmers surveyed for McCain Foodsâ€™ inaugural Farmdex report said they made 10% or more profit in the past year. In fact, many are making no profit at all, with 35% of the farmers reporting making a loss or breaking even.The report found this was true even for the highest-valued farms, with 28% of farmers with farms valued at Â£2.5m or more reporting a loss or no profit in the past year.When the UK was part of the EU, subsidies from the bloc for UK farmers made up as much as half of their income annually. After Brexit, the devolved British nations designed their farming payments regimes differently. In England, automatic payments were sharply cut and instead a scheme was introduced wherefarmers are paid for looking after natureunder the environmental land management scheme (Elm).This money is less than the subsidies they received from the EU, farmers say. The government recently cut Englandâ€™s farmingbudget by Â£100m. The nature schemes have been beset by delays and the application process has been unpredictable. In March the schemeabruptly closedbecause the government said the budget had been allocated.Some farms have lost out under the new scheme. Asurvey by the National Farmersâ€™ Unionfound that on average, upland farming businesses lost 37% of their support payments under the current Sustainable Farming Incentive (SFI) â€“ the first component of Elm â€“ and Countryside Stewardship (CS) options.The governmentâ€™s decision to introduce inheritance tax for farms worth more than Â£1m led to outrage and protests as farmers said they would be unable to pass down the land to their children.Farmers are also on the frontline of climate breakdown, in recent years facing extreme floods and droughts that have led to some of the worst harvests on record.The McCain report reveals that 51% of farmers have considered leaving the industry in the past year due to financial strain, while only 4% believe current government support is adequate. More than six in 10 farmers (61%) say their work negatively affects their mental health, while more than a third endure 70-hour-plus working weeks during peak seasons.James Young, the vice-president of agriculture at McCain GB&I, praised farmersâ€™ â€œunwavering resilienceâ€ and said the findings must serve as a wake-up call.He said: â€œAs a company founded by farmers, weâ€™re proud to stand alongside our 250 growers across the UK. It is crucial that industry bodies, the government and businesses work together to heed the warning signs in the Farmdex and take action to support farmers.â€A spokesperson for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs said: â€œFarming plays a central role in our mission to kickstart economic growth, with farmers acting as stewards for our nationâ€™s food security.â€œWe know there are challenges in the sector and prolonged dry weather, followed by heavy rain, has hit some harvests. We are backing our farmers with the largest nature-friendly budget in history to grow their businesses and get more British food on our plates and are working with all food producers to make sure farmers get a fair deal.â€Explore more on these topicsFarmingRural affairsBrexitnewsShareReuse this content

title: Babies born to black mothers 81% more likely to die in neonatal care, NHS study shows  | Race | The Guardian
description: Analysis of England and Wales units also finds 63% higher risk to babies whose mothers live in most deprived areas
Author: Tobi Thomas
Headline: Analysis of England and Wales units also finds 63% higher risk to babies whose mothers live in most deprived areas
Content: The analysis showed how â€˜socioeconomic and ethnic inequalities independently shape survival in neonatal unitsâ€™, the lead researcher said.Photograph: ER Productions Limited/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenThe analysis showed how â€˜socioeconomic and ethnic inequalities independently shape survival in neonatal unitsâ€™, the lead researcher said.Photograph: ER Productions Limited/Getty ImagesRaceBabies born to black mothers 81% more likely to die in neonatal care, NHS study showsAnalysis of England and Wales units also finds 63% higher risk to babies whose mothers live in most deprived areasTobi ThomasHealth and inequalities correspondentTue 4 Nov 2025 18.30 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 18.32 ESTShareBabies born to black mothers in England and Wales and those from the most deprived areas are significantly more likely to die while in neonatal units, according to analysis revealing the â€œdeeply concerningâ€ figures.The study, led by academics at theUniversity of Liverpool, examined data on more than 700,000 babies admitted to an NHS neonatal unit across England and Wales between 2012 and 2022.Babies born to black mothers had the highest mortality rates for the majority of years in the study, with an 81% higher risk of dying before discharge compared with babies born to white mothers.The highest mortality rate for black babies stood at 29.7 deaths per 1,000 babies, with the highest rate for white babies at 16.9 deaths per 1,000 babies.For babies born to mothers living in the most deprived areas of England and Wales, the elevated risk stood at 63% compared with the least deprived babies.The highest mortality rate for babies born to the most deprived mothers was 25.9 deaths per 1,000 babies in 2022, compared with 12.8 deaths per 1,000 for their least deprived counterparts.Samira Saberian, a PhD student at the University of Liverpool and the lead author of the study, said the analysis showed that â€œsocioeconomic and ethnic inequalities independently shape survival in neonatal units, and maternal and birth factors explain only over half of the socioeconomic and ethnic inequalitiesâ€.She added: â€œTo reduce these inequalities, we need integrated approaches that strengthen clinical care while also tackling the wider conditions affecting families.â€œBy improving services and addressing the root drivers of inequality, we can give the most vulnerable babies a better chance of survival.â€Funded by the National Institute forHealthand Care Research (NIHR), the study is the first to examine both socio-economic and ethnic inequalities in neonatal units.Babies born to mothers from ethnic minority groups living in more deprived areas are at greater risk of dyingThe figures come as previous reports have found that black babies arealmost twice as likelyas white babies to be stillborn. Anational investigationlaunched into NHS maternity services across England, due to conclude at the end of this year, will be looking at racial disparities within maternity care, among other issues.The study also found that babies born to Asian mothers had a 36% higher risk of death than their white counterparts, even after adjusting for other factors that could contribute towards the higher rate of death.The research concluded: â€œThere are stark socioeconomic and ethnic inequalities in babies admitted to and who die in neonatal units in England and Wales.â€Rachel Drain, the quality and standards adviser at the Royal College of Midwives, said that the findings were â€œdeeply concerningâ€ and that â€œurgent, coordinated actionâ€ was needed to tackle the root causes of the disparities.â€œThat means investing in the maternity and neonatal workforce, providing equitable and culturally safe care, and ensuring services are designed with women at their heart,â€ Drain said.â€œEvery baby deserves the same chance of survival regardless of their ethnicity, background or circumstances.She added that the findings â€œpoint to systemic issues in how care is delivered and in the wider social conditions that shape womenâ€™s health before, during and after pregnancy. It is unacceptable that mortality rates in neonatal units are rising and inequalities are widening.â€David Taylor-Robinson, professor of public health and policy in the Institute of Population Health at University of Liverpool, said: â€œOur Labour government has pledged to create the healthiest generation of children in our nationâ€™s history.â€œYet our findings reveal, in stark detail that, even in 2025, too many children face significant challenges from birth â€“ and for some, even before they are born.He added: â€œI hope this evidence drives real action to address the wider factors that shape health outcomes.â€œOur research also highlights how existing biases and injustices in society are reflected in clinical settings, disproportionately affecting women and babies. These are inequalities we cannot afford to ignore.â€Explore more on these topicsRacePremature birthHealthSocial exclusionChildrenUniversity of LiverpoolNHSnewsShareReuse this content

title: Former Met police officer goes on trial accused of sexually abusing a girl | UK news | The Guardian
description: David Carrick is also alleged to have raped a woman, Old Bailey is told
Author: Ben Quinn
Headline: David Carrick is also alleged to have raped a woman, Old Bailey is told
Content: David Carrick denies sexually assaulting a girl and a string of offences against a woman.Photograph: Hertfordshire Police/PA WireView image in fullscreenDavid Carrick denies sexually assaulting a girl and a string of offences against a woman.Photograph: Hertfordshire Police/PA WireUK newsFormer Met police officer goes on trial accused of sexually abusing a girlDavid Carrick is also alleged to have raped and coercively controlled a woman, Old Bailey is toldBen Quinnand agenciesTue 4 Nov 2025 10.30 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 14.03 ESTShareA former police officer engaged in â€œpredatory and controllingâ€ behaviour for many years, his trial on charges of sexually assaulting a girl and a woman has been told.The child told her mother what David Carrick was doing after she was found sleeping behind her bedroom door when she was 14, the Old Bailey in London heard.Carrick, 50, allegedly assaulted the teenager a number of times and would put his hand over her mouth to stop her screaming.On one occasion, she found herself â€œtrappedâ€ between a chair and a sofa and recalled trying to scream and get away, the court was told.Carrick has denied five counts of sexual assault relating to the child in 1989 and 1990.He has also pleaded not guilty to two charges of rape, one of sexual assault and coercive and controlling behaviour toward a woman between 2014 and 2019.Carrick allegedly made admissions about what he had done to the girl in a letter recovered from his medical records and signed â€œDaveâ€.He wrote that the girl was â€œnot crazyâ€ and that it was â€œtrueâ€ but he had stopped about four months previously.â€œI know how (the girl) must feel. Thatâ€™s why I stopped and promised I would never go near her again and I have kept that promise and I always will,â€ Carrick wrote.He offered never to be seen again, adding: â€œSorry to you and especially sorry to (the girl) but she does not have to worry ever again. Please do not try to talk about it.â€More than 20 years later, he allegedly raped and sexually assaulted a woman with whom he was in a â€œtoxic relationshipâ€.Opening the trial on Tuesday, Tom Little KC, prosecuting, said: â€œThis case that you are now trying is primarily about sexual offending committed many years apart by this defendant.â€œBut in respect of all the offending, whenever it was committed, the defendant was, we say, very predatory and controlling. This was not isolated offending but part of a pattern which the defendant perpetrated over many years.â€Little said that, in 2022 and 2023, Carrick pleaded guilty to a â€œlarge numberâ€ of sexual and other offences relating to a significant number of women, nearly all of whom he knew.The first complainant in the trial was aged about 12 when she was sexually assaulted by the defendant, it was alleged.The woman was raped â€œon a number of occasionsâ€ and subjected to a sex act to which she did not consent, Little said.He told jurors: â€œMuch of this offending occurred during the course of what was a toxic relationship between the two of them and which was controlled by him.â€Little added: â€œIt is also relevant for you to know that he was at the time of that relationship, as he was for many years, a Metropolitan police officer.â€Neither of the alleged victims in the case can be identified for legal reasons. The trial continues.Explore more on these topicsUK newsnewsShareReuse this content

Underground staffAgreement that will increase driversâ€™ pay to nearly Â£80,000 by 2027 comes after strike action in SeptemberGwyn TophamTransport correspondentTue 4 Nov 2025 13.55 ESTLast modified on title: MPs ask HMRC to explain child benefit error that froze payments to parents | Child benefits | The Guardian
description: Answers demanded after 23,500 families wrongly suspected of fraud when incorrect data showed they had left UK
Author: Lisa Oâ€™Carroll
Headline: Answers demanded after 23,500 families wrongly suspected of fraud when incorrect data showed they had left UK
Content: Many families were wrongly suspected of fraud after data showed they had flown out of the UK but not returned.Photograph: NicoElNino/AlamyView image in fullscreenMany families were wrongly suspected of fraud after data showed they had flown out of the UK but not returned.Photograph: NicoElNino/AlamyChild benefitsMPs ask HMRC to explain child benefit error that froze payments to parentsAnswers demanded after 23,500 families wrongly suspected of fraud when incorrect data showed they had left UKLisa Oâ€™CarrollTue 4 Nov 2025 17.34 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 12.45 ESTShareMPs are demanding answers fromHMRCover a child benefit error in which payments to 23,500 families were stopped as part of an anti-fraud crackdown.Meg Hillier, a Labour MP and chair of the House of Commons Treasury select committee, has written to the permanent secretary of HMRC asking who made the decisions, why they were made and whether compensation would be offered to the victims.The letter follows a series of reports by the Guardian and investigative website the Detail on families who hadbeen wrongly suspected of fraud after datashowed they had taken flights out of the country but not returned.They received letters demanding they answer 73 questions and provide a mountain of documentation including bank statements, GP and school records on the back of information the Home Office provided.View image in fullscreenLabour MP Meg Hillier has sent several questions to the permanent secretary of HMRC.But the Home Office data was incomplete and did not record return journeys of parents, leading HMRC to believe the families had emigrated and were continuing to collect child benefit illegally.One mother, Sally, told how her child benefit was stopped based on data that showed she had travelled to Italy in July 2023 and never returned.It transpired that Sally and her three children had checked in for the flightbut not boardedafter one of the children had an epileptic seizure at the departure gate.Another woman accused of emigrating and fraudulently claiming child benefit told how she had booked to go to Oslo,but never checked inafter the wedding she was invited to was called off.HMRC has apologised twice and says it has reinstated child benefit to about 2,000 parents so far. It has asked parents who have received the letter to call the phone number on it, promising swift resolution by a new dedicated customer service team.It also said it was confident the majority of payments had been correctly suspended.Hillier wants to know what assurances parents will have that this will not happen again.â€œIs anyone who did not board a flight, train or ferry leaving the UK this year at risk of being considered to have emigrated?â€ she asked.Addressing many peopleâ€™s concerns that individualsâ€™ tax records have been tainted, she added: â€œWill HMRCâ€™s assessment of emigration status affect individuals for the purposes of immigration, or non-domiciled tax status?â€HMRC pauses child benefit crackdown after 23,500 families caught up in data errorRead moreOther questions in the list of 14 demands include how long was HMRC using travel booking data to â€œestablish emigration statusâ€. MPs also want to know why it used booking data, and not boarding data.They have also asked how HMRC came to determine emigration status when travel operators have no idea who is resident in the UK or not: â€œGiven travel operators do not hold the national insurance numbers of passengers, how did HMRC verify it was halting payments of the correct recipients?â€The committee, which will publish the answers, also wants to know what level of seniority was involved in the signoff of the anti-fraud initiative and what safeguards had been put in place to stop innocent victims being caught up in the crackdown.This week, several parents told the Guardian they had received a letter from HMRC despite not receiving child benefit for months, or in one case years.Several complained that they felt they were â€œbeing treated like criminalsâ€ when they had paid tax all their lives and HMRC could have simply checked tax records to see if they were living and paying tax in the UK.Another woman, who had previously suffered a stroke, said the letter was very distressing.â€œThis kind of traumatic situation can cause a severe health breakdown with people like me who already had a minor stroke. Having to deal with providing A to Z information to prove that I havenâ€™t been abroad is a lot of weight on top of tons of stress which is already part of our lives,â€ said Rachel.An HMRC spokesperson said: â€œWeâ€™re very sorry to those whose payments have been suspended incorrectly. Having reviewed our processes, we are now checking claims with customers first before suspending any payments, giving them one month to call us or write back.â€œWe have a duty to protect taxpayersâ€™ money, but we have also listened to our customers and taken swift action to ensure claims are only suspended when appropriate.â€If you have beenaffected by this and want to share your story, email: lisa.ocarroll@theguardian.comExplore more on these topicsChild benefitsBenefitsWelfareHMRCCommunitiesParents and parentingnewsShareReuse this content

title: Sudan civil war spiralling out of control, UN secretary general says | Sudan | The Guardian
description: AntÃ³nio Guterres calls for the violence to end but there appears little appetite for ceasefire proposed by US
Author: Patrick Wintour
Headline: AntÃ³nio Guterres calls for the violence to end but there appears little appetite for ceasefire proposed by US
Content: A child whose family fled violence perpetrated by the Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher receives treatment at a displacement camp.Photograph: Mohammed Abaker/APView image in fullscreenA child whose family fled violence perpetrated by the Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher receives treatment at a displacement camp.Photograph: Mohammed Abaker/APSudanSudan civil war spiralling out of control, UN secretary general saysAntÃ³nio Guterres calls for the violence to end but there appears little appetite for ceasefire proposed by USPatrick WintourDiplomatic editorTue 4 Nov 2025 13.41 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 14.48 ESTShareThe UN secretary general,AntÃ³nio Guterres, has said the war in Sudan is spiralling out of control as he called for a halt to the fighting and an end to the violence.The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which are reportedly backed by the United Arab Emirates, seized El Fasher in Darfur last week after a near 18-month siege. Some of its troops have posted videos of civilians being shot, including in the townâ€™s maternity hospital.As criticism grows, is UAE ready to walk away from Sudanâ€™s RSF militia?Read moreThe two-year civil war between the Sudanese armed forces (SAF) and the RSF has created what the UN has described asone of the worst humanitarian crisesof the 21st century.More than 150,000 peoplehave been killed andmore than 14 milliondisplaced from their homes.Prosecutors at the international criminal court said on Monday that they werecollecting evidence of alleged mass killings, rape and other crimes in El Fasher.Guterres urged the warring parties to â€œcome to the negotiating table, bring an end to this nightmare of violence â€“ nowâ€.â€œThe horrifying crisis inSudanâ€¦ is spiralling out of control,â€ he told reporters on the sidelines of the World Summit for Social Development in Qatar.â€œEl Fasher and the surrounding areas in North Darfur have been an epicentre of suffering, hunger, violence and displacement. And since the Rapid Support Forces entered El Fasher last weekend, the situation is growing worse by the day. Hundreds of thousands of civilians are trapped by this siege. People are dying of malnutrition, disease and violence.â€His call at the Doha conference came as the SAF, based in Port Sudan, discussed whether to support a US-proposed truce, or to insist any ceasefire be dependent on the RSF withdrawing from Sudanâ€™s cities, including El Fasher.View image in fullscreenA satellite image shows smoke rising from fires near El Fasher airport.Photograph: Â©2025 Vantor/EPAThe fall of El Fasher gives the RSF control of all five state capitals in Darfur, raising fears that Sudan could in effect be partitioned along an east-west axis, but the Sudanese ambassador to the UK, Babikir Elamin, said there was little support for partition in Darfur itself.He said the priority was not a ceasefire, but action to end the massacres in El Fasher.The US has been trying since September to persuade the two sides to back a peace plan agreed by Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia that would start with a three-month humanitarian pause, followed by a permanent ceasefire that would start a nine-month transition to a civilian-led government.Washington is hoping that with the two-year civil war finally attracting greater world attention, the publicity may force the warring parties and their external supporters to relent on their maximalist positions.Initial signs from a lengthy SAF security and defence council meeting, however, are that there is strong resistance to the US plan developed by Donald Trumpâ€™s envoy toAfrica, Massad Boulos.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toThe Long WaveFree weekly newsletterNesrine Malik and Jason Okundaye deliver your weekly dose of Black life and culture from around the worldEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties.
