title: London Ulez auto pay blunders have triggered Â£11,445 in fines | Motoring | The Guardian
description: When account was suspended my brother-in-law was caught in debt as 200 penalty charge notices piled up
Author: Anna Tims
Headline: When account was suspended my brother-in-law was caught in debt as 200 penalty charge notices piled up
Content: Problems with a Ulez auto pay account have led to mounting fines.Photograph: NurPhoto SRL/AlamyView image in fullscreenProblems with a Ulez auto pay account have led to mounting fines.Photograph: NurPhoto SRL/AlamyConsumer championsMotoringLondon Ulez auto pay blunders have triggered Â£11,445 in finesWhen account was suspended my brother-in-law was caught in debt as 200 penalty charge notices piled upAnna TimsTue 4 Nov 2025 02.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 11.41 ESTShareMy brother-in-law has received 200 penalty charge notices (PCNs) for unpaid ultra-low emission zone (Ulez) charges in London.He set up anautopay account for his non-Ulez-compliant van, but because of a series of blundershas paid Â£11,445 in fines, owes another Â£1,400, and is facing bills for 70 more fines after losing his appeals.It began last December when hisautopay account wassuspended and PCNs began arriving. The account was reinstated byTfL with a different spelling of his surname, sohis appeals of his PCNs were refused because he was deemed to be a â€œthird partyâ€.TfL has refused to let him pay the debts through anindividualvoluntaryarrangement. He has dyslexia and a serious chronic autoimmune disease triggered by stress. His mental health is at the point where he has mentioned suicide.LM,LondonIt seems misunderstandings, miscommunication and panic has caused your brother-in-lawâ€™s situation to spiral out of control.TfL insists it informed him of alternative ways to pay when his auto pay account was suspended over a disputed payment last December. In a recorded call to customer services in February, he was told that his appeals against the PCNs were rejected because the misspelled surname suggested he was an invalid third party.TfL subsequently corrected its error.Another recording from the summer shows how hard he tried to set up an affordable payment plan but was repeatedly given conflicting information.All the while, the PCNs continued to come thick and fast and he lacked the funds to keep up with payments.It is the responsibility of drivers to ensure they pay all official charges due. It is not in dispute that your brother failed for many reasons to do so on multiple occasions, so I believe the PCNs were technically legitimate.Ethically, Iâ€™m not so sure. It seems that TfLâ€™s system obstructed rather than helped him. TfL, when informed of his deteriorating mental health, hastily cancelled all outstanding PCNs, which removes the terror of never-ending debt, but not the hole in the family finances from the thousands already paid. His auto pay is now active again.â€œWe will always try and support people who are struggling to pay penalty charges,â€ said a spokesperson. â€œWe have been in contact with him and have agreed to accept the amount he has paid to resolve the matter.â€We welcome letters but cannot answer individually. Email us atconsumer.champions@theguardian.comor write to Consumer Champions, Money, the Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please include a daytime phone number. Submission and publication of all letters is subject toour terms and conditions.Explore more on these topicsMotoringConsumer championsConsumer affairsConsumer rightsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Houseplant hacks: can a plastic bag revive a wilting fern? | Houseplants | The Guardian
description: If the fronds have turned brown and crispy, all is not lost â€“ this nifty, cost-free trick is surprisingly effective
Author: Gynelle Leon
Headline: If the fronds have turned brown and crispy, all is not lost â€“ this nifty, cost-free trick is surprisingly effective
Content: A bag traps humidity around a fern.Photograph: Ruksil/Getty Images/iStockphotoView image in fullscreenA bag traps humidity around a fern.Photograph: Ruksil/Getty Images/iStockphotoHouseplant hacksHouseplantsHouseplant hacks: can a plastic bag revive a wilting fern?If the fronds have turned brown and crispy, all is not lost â€“ this nifty, cost-free trick is surprisingly effectiveGynelle LeonTue 4 Nov 2025 05.00 ESTShareTheproblemFew plants test a personâ€™s patience like ferns. One day theyâ€™re full of life; the next they look like tumbleweed left on a radiator. Fern fronds crisp up at the first hint of dry air, and once they turn brown, most think itâ€™s game over.ThehackPut the plant inside a clear plastic bag â€“ but donâ€™t seal it as it still needs some airflow â€“ and place it in bright but indirect light.Houseplant clinic: why is there a chalky crust on my plantâ€™s soil?Read moreThe TheoryThe bag creates a mini terrarium, trapping humidity around the plant. Think of it as recreating the rainforest atmosphere â€“ the moist microclimate where ferns thrive. It doesnâ€™t water the plant for you, but it drastically slows down evaporation and encourages fragile new fronds to unfurl.ThetestI used this trick on a Boston fern that looked beyond saving. After 10 days in its misty cocoon the soil was still damp and tiny green curls began to appear. By the end of the month, the plant was noticeably thicker and greener.The verdictThis isnâ€™t a miracle cure and you may lose some fronds along the way, but the bag trick can genuinely save a fern on the brink. For zero cost, itâ€™s one of the most effective resuscitation methods out there.Explore more on these topicsHouseplantsHouseplant hacksGardening adviceGardensfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Sudan civil war spiralling out of control, UN secretary general says | Sudan | The Guardian
description: AntÃ³nio Guterres calls for the violence to end but there appears little appetite for ceasefire proposed by US
Author: Patrick Wintour
Headline: AntÃ³nio Guterres calls for the violence to end but there appears little appetite for ceasefire proposed by US
Content: A child whose family fled violence perpetrated by the Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher receives treatment at a displacement camp.Photograph: Mohammed Abaker/APView image in fullscreenA child whose family fled violence perpetrated by the Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher receives treatment at a displacement camp.Photograph: Mohammed Abaker/APSudanSudan civil war spiralling out of control, UN secretary general saysAntÃ³nio Guterres calls for the violence to end but there appears little appetite for ceasefire proposed by USPatrick WintourDiplomatic editorTue 4 Nov 2025 13.41 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 14.48 ESTShareThe UN secretary general,AntÃ³nio Guterres, has said the war in Sudan is spiralling out of control as he called for a halt to the fighting and an end to the violence.The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which are reportedly backed by the United Arab Emirates, seized El Fasher in Darfur last week after a near 18-month siege. Some of its troops have posted videos of civilians being shot, including in the townâ€™s maternity hospital.As criticism grows, is UAE ready to walk away from Sudanâ€™s RSF militia?Read moreThe two-year civil war between the Sudanese armed forces (SAF) and the RSF has created what the UN has described asone of the worst humanitarian crisesof the 21st century.More than 150,000 peoplehave been killed andmore than 14 milliondisplaced from their homes.Prosecutors at the international criminal court said on Monday that they werecollecting evidence of alleged mass killings, rape and other crimes in El Fasher.Guterres urged the warring parties to â€œcome to the negotiating table, bring an end to this nightmare of violence â€“ nowâ€.â€œThe horrifying crisis inSudanâ€¦ is spiralling out of control,â€ he told reporters on the sidelines of the World Summit for Social Development in Qatar.â€œEl Fasher and the surrounding areas in North Darfur have been an epicentre of suffering, hunger, violence and displacement. And since the Rapid Support Forces entered El Fasher last weekend, the situation is growing worse by the day. Hundreds of thousands of civilians are trapped by this siege. People are dying of malnutrition, disease and violence.â€His call at the Doha conference came as the SAF, based in Port Sudan, discussed whether to support a US-proposed truce, or to insist any ceasefire be dependent on the RSF withdrawing from Sudanâ€™s cities, including El Fasher.View image in fullscreenA satellite image shows smoke rising from fires near El Fasher airport.Photograph: Â©2025 Vantor/EPAThe fall of El Fasher gives the RSF control of all five state capitals in Darfur, raising fears that Sudan could in effect be partitioned along an east-west axis, but the Sudanese ambassador to the UK, Babikir Elamin, said there was little support for partition in Darfur itself.He said the priority was not a ceasefire, but action to end the massacres in El Fasher.The US has been trying since September to persuade the two sides to back a peace plan agreed by Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia that would start with a three-month humanitarian pause, followed by a permanent ceasefire that would start a nine-month transition to a civilian-led government.Washington is hoping that with the two-year civil war finally attracting greater world attention, the publicity may force the warring parties and their external supporters to relent on their maximalist positions.Initial signs from a lengthy SAF security and defence council meeting, however, are that there is strong resistance to the US plan developed by Donald Trumpâ€™s envoy toAfrica, Massad Boulos.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toThe Long WaveFree weekly newsletterNesrine Malik and Jason Okundaye deliver your weekly dose of Black life and culture from around the worldEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. Nobody can feign ignorance about whatâ€™s going on | Nesrine MalikRead moreSome SAF sources, admitting they were under new pressure from Egypt to accept a ceasefire, countered with a call for the RSF to be confined to camps outside cities. It is not clear how such RSF withdrawals could be enforced.Speaking in London, Elamin called on Washington to designate the RSF a terrorist organisation and for a ban on all arms sales to the UAE.The UAE denies supplying weapons to the RSF.Elamin said: â€œThe RSF are now openly and publicly vowing to commit yet further crimes in cities and parts of the country. They have named the cities, the communities and the ethnic groups they are targeting.â€œParts of the country that have never witnessed violence are now threatened. They are proudly making videos of themselves murdering innocent civilians. Some of them admit they have lost count of the number of people they have killed.â€He said that as the SAF leadership had been exploring the US peace plan, the RSF were attacking El Fasher.â€œWhat is the reason for getting engaged in talks while they are still committing these kind of atrocities,â€ he asked. â€œBefore we can discuss the kind of proposal, the international community should show some kind of seriousness in dealing with these atrocities that are still taking place in El Fasher. The priority now must be to stop the atrocities and this kind of genocide.â€Explore more on these topicsSudanUnited NationsAntÃ³nio GuterresAfricaMiddle East and north AfricanewsShareReuse this content

title: Teenager taken to Ghana away from UK â€˜gang cultureâ€™ to stay for now, court rules | UK news | The Guardian
description: Boy had sought court order to force his return, after parents took him on trip to Ghana and returned without him
Author: Chris Osuh
Headline: Boy had sought court order to force his return, after parents took him on trip to Ghana and returned without him
Content: The boyâ€™s mother and father feared he was â€˜becoming involved in the gang culture which was prevalent in the areaâ€™ where they lived.Photograph: Toby Melville/ReutersView image in fullscreenThe boyâ€™s mother and father feared he was â€˜becoming involved in the gang culture which was prevalent in the areaâ€™ where they lived.Photograph: Toby Melville/ReutersUK newsTeenager taken to Ghana away from UK â€˜gang cultureâ€™ to stay for now, court rulesBoy had sought court order to force his return, after parents took him on trip to Ghana and returned without himChris OsuhTue 4 Nov 2025 11.23 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 13.24 ESTShareA British teenager whose parents left him inGhana, fearing he was at risk from â€œgang cultureâ€ in the UK, should stay there until at least the end of his GCSE exams, a judge sitting at Londonâ€™s high court has ruled.The boy took legal action against his parents, seeking a court order that would force his return, after they enrolled him in a boarding school and arranged for him to live with extended family in Ghana without telling him.But after the boyâ€™s parents told the court they did not want him to return until after his exams and did not believe they could keep him safe in England, his legal efforts to force an immediate return failed.His parents were born in Ghana but he was born in England and â€œregards himself as an outsiderâ€ in the West African country, a social worker told the wardship proceedings.In a judgment published on Tuesday, Mrs Justice Theis ruled that while the boy, who can be identified only as â€˜Sâ€™ for legal reasons, had been â€œtrickedâ€, she concluded he â€œshould remain living in Ghana with the aim of setting out a roadmap and taking the necessary steps for â€˜Sâ€™ to return here after completing his GCSEs.â€He had travelled from his home in England to visit relatives in Ghana in March 2024 with his parents and a sibling, but his family returned in April without him. His mother and father had become â€œincreasingly concernedâ€ for his safety in the year prior, fearing he was â€œbecoming involved in the gang culture which was prevalent in the areaâ€.Videos, photos and messages, which made them fear he was involved in theft, fraud and possessing knives, had been found on his phone by his parents, while his mother had found a kitchen knife hidden at the home.The judge said since his parents did not want him to return home soon, the risk of relationship breakdown would be â€œvery highâ€ if he did, with the likelihood he would be exposed to â€œthe very serious risksâ€ they had tried to protect him from.Before being taken to Ghana, the boy had become â€œsecretive and dishonest about his whereabouts and possessions,â€ with his parents struggling to manage â€œdeteriorating behaviourâ€ that was â€œinfluenced by peer pressureâ€.His mother still â€œconsiders him at risk of serious physical harm or deathâ€ if he returns, her barrister, Michael Gration, KC told a hearing last month.In her judgment, Mrs Justice Theis said while there was â€œvery real concernâ€ about the effect of him remaining in a country where he felt abandoned, he had â€œmore of an understanding of why his parents took the steps they didâ€.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toFirst EditionFree daily newsletterOur morning email breaks down the key stories of the day, telling you whatâ€™s happening and why it mattersEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. However, I do not believe I can ensure [his] safety if he remains in England.â€œThis is not a reflection of a lack of love or care but rather a realistic assessment of the risks involved. title: As criticism grows, is UAE ready to walk away from Sudanâ€™s RSF militia? | Sudan | The Guardian
description: After mass killings in El Fasher and four years on from a coup, UAE now admits its Sudan policy has gone wrong
Author: Patrick Wintour
Headline: After mass killings in El Fasher and four years on from a coup, UAE now admits its Sudan policy has gone wrong
Content: Displaced women and children from El Fasher at a camp in Tawila on Monday.Photograph: APView image in fullscreenDisplaced women and children from El Fasher at a camp in Tawila on Monday.Photograph: APSudanAs criticism grows, is UAE ready to walk away from Sudanâ€™s RSF militia?After mass killings in El Fasher and four years on from a coup, UAE now admits its Sudan policy has gone wrongPatrick WintourDiplomatic editorTue 4 Nov 2025 04.37 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 15.24 ESTShareThe United Arab Emiratesâ€™ diplomatic machine is for the first time admitting to mistakes in its Sudan policy after suffering reputational damage over its support for the Rapid Support Forces, the Sudanese paramilitary group that hascarried out mass killings in El Fashersince it captured the city late last month.Speaking in Bahrain on Sunday, Anwar Gargash, the UAEâ€™s senior diplomatic envoy, said the UAE and others had been wrong not to impose sanctions on the instigators of the2021 coupâ€“ led jointly by the RSF and the army â€“ that overthrew Sudanâ€™s transitional civilian government.Mapâ€œWe all made a mistake when the two generals who are fighting the civil war today overthrew the civilian government,â€ Gargash said. â€œThat was, looking back, a critical mistake. We should have put our foot down collectively. We did not call it a coup.â€It is a striking reversal. The UAE had actively undermined the idea of a strong civilian democratic government in Sudan in the aftermath of the popular uprising that led to the downfall of the 30-year, Islamist-aligned dictatorship of Omar al-Bashirin April 2019.Throughout 2019, â€œin the interests of a stable transitionâ€, the UAE and Saudi Arabia tried to enhance the role of the military and marginalise civilian rule, including by promoting the idea that the RSF commander, Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, known as Hemedti, should be in charge of economic policy.In a piece of bailout diplomacy, Saudi Arabia and the Emiratis quickly agreed a $3bn loan to the transitional military council that initially tried to succeed Bashir. In late 2019, when the civilian side of the government had the upper hand, further payouts from the loan were stopped.Jonas Horner, of the European Council on Foreign Relations, wrote recently that the loss of the loan not only critically undermined the civilian government but also led directly to the coup in 2021, followed by the civil war that broke out between the army and the RSF in 2023.â€œThe fate of the transitional government would likely have been dramatically different had the Gulf backed them with the billions they had pledged to the military,â€ Horner wrote.Finger of blameFour years on from the coup, the Gargash admission is a sign that in public at least the UAE acknowledges that itsSudanpolicy has gone wrong and that it must distance itself from the RSF, the force it so nurtured.That the Emiratis covertly armed the RSF is clear fromevidence compiledby the UN, independent experts and reporters, even though the UAE denies it. In January, the Biden administration pointed the finger of blame when it imposed sanctions on Hemedti and seven UAE-based companies funding him.View image in fullscreenMohamed Hamdan Dagalo, known as Hemedti, centre, in 2019.Photograph: Mahmoud Hjaj/APSudanese civilian groups warned for more than 18 months that the RSF would commit ethnically targeted mass killings if it took El Fasher, the capital of North Darfur. That placed a special obligation on the UAE, the country with the greatest ability to restrain Hemedti. Although the UAE has condemned the atrocities in El Fasher, it also put the blame for what happened on the armyâ€™s failure to compromise.The UAEâ€™s response to international criticism is to insist that it is being traduced and that it is the victim of a disinformation campaign fuelled by Islamists inside the Sudanese army and by leftwing NGOs long opposed to the Gulf state.A Sudanese massacre foretold: the grim familiarity of the RSFâ€™s rampage through El FasherRead moreIt insists it wants a transition back to a civilian-led Sudanese government, and says both the RSF and the army have disqualified themselves from shaping Sudanâ€™s future.Figures such as the UAE foreign affairs minister, Lana Nusseibeh, say the country is not the primary sponsor of the war but rather a neutral party seeking to mediate a return to the civilian, Islamist-free rule that started with the 2019 uprising and ended with the 2021 coup.Yasmine Ahmed, the UK director of Human Rights Watch, said a minimum test of the UAEâ€™s sincerity about breaking with the RSF would be pro-active cooperation with the UN expert panel policing the arms embargo on Sudan.As Cameron Hudson, a former chief of staff to successive US special envoys on Sudan, puts it: â€œWhat we see is a complete and total denial by the UAE authorities they have any role or involvement whatsoever in this conflict. Until we can agree on a basic set of facts about what is happening and who is driving it, it is going to be very difficult to resolve.â€What happens next will also depend on whether the UAE thinks that the RSF â€“ and its tainting brutality â€“ are still indispensable to its two keys goals in Sudan: accessing resources and deterring the influence of Islamism, the belief that Islam is innately political and that it should influence political systems. The UAE in particular regards the Islamist Muslim Brotherhood as a threat to security in the region.Natural resourcesThe UAE is just one of the Gulf states to have been drawn to Sudanâ€™s natural resources for decades.Jaafar Nimeiri, Sudanâ€™s president from 1969 to 1985, promised that in return for Gulf investment Sudan could become the breadbasket of the Arab world, as well as a source of a badly needed and sometimes highly educated workforce.Kuwait, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the UAE all responded, each arriving with different political agendas. Saudi Arabia and the UAE both made multibillion-dollar agricultural investments in Sudan to secure food for their populations, first under Nimieri and then through the authoritarian rule of Bashir, who seized power in 1989 and worked in alliance with Islamists.The fact that Bashir came to be heavily sanctioned by the US proved little constraint as the Gulf states poured money into Sudan. â€œFor these young, wealthy monarchies â€“ which import upwards of 80% of all the food they consume â€“ securing access to Sudanâ€™s agriculture, livestock and mineral resources is a virtually existential concern,â€ said Horner, a visiting fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations.Sudanâ€™s strategic location on the Red Sea made it highly attractive place for the UAE to build ports, and in December 2022 the state-owned Abu Dhabi Ports Group and Invictus Investment signed a $6bn deal to invest in the Abu Amama port, 125 miles north of Port Sudan. The contract has since been cancelled by Sudanâ€™s de factor leader, Gen Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, but the UAE will be keen to revive the scheme under any successor.Emirati banks hold stakes in Bank of Khartoum, the largest commercial bank in Sudan, whose digital platform facilitates money transfers for millions of displaced Sudanese and public institutions. However, it is Sudanâ€™s gold reserves that are of particular importance, not just to the RSF and the army, which operate as businesses as much as fighting forces, but also to the UAE.View image in fullscreenRSF fighters display gold bars seized from a plane that landed at Khartoum airport in May 2019.Photograph: Mohamed Nureldin Abdallah/ReutersGold represents about 49% of Sudanâ€™s exports. In February, the state-owned Sudan Mineral Resources Company said gold production in army-controlled areas reached 74 tonnes in 2024, up from 41.8 tonnes in 2022. The Central Bank of Sudan reported that in 2024 almost 97% of official gold exports (from army-held areas) went to the UAE, earning $1.52bn.Official exports are a drop in the ocean, however. An estimated 90% of Sudanâ€™s gold production, amounting to approximately $13.4bn in illicit trade, is smuggled out of the country, often passing through transit routes in Chad, Egypt, Ethiopia, Uganda and South Sudan before reaching the UAE.In areport last monthfor Chatham House, Ahmed Soliman and Dr Suliman Baldo wrote: â€œThe UAE continues to benefit from Sudanâ€™s conflict gold, as the enforcement of restrictions on artisanal gold imports from countries where there is war or where gold is controlled by armed groups remains limited.â€The UAEâ€™s conduit is Hemedti, with whom they forged a special relationship when he agreed to send RSF troops to Yemen in support of Emirati and Saudi forces fighting the Houthis. He owns many of the mines in Darfur through his family firm Algunade.Politics, as well as profit, also drive the Emirati interest. As with its parallel interventions in eastern Libya and south Yemen, the UAE wants to contest the Islamism with which Bashir was allied.Collective pressureNow that its support for the RSF seems so perilous reputationally, there is an onus on the UAE to contribute to a resolution of the crisis.The US hopes the solution lies in Sudanâ€™s two key external players, the UAE and Egypt, which backs the army and wants keep the conflict within Sudanâ€™s border, finally agreeing they will collectively press their proxies into a ceasefire. The statement agreed by the US, Saudi, Egypt and UAE â€“ four countries engaged in mediation efforts collectively known as the Quad â€“ on 12 September was a breakthrough in that regard in that it set out a course for a three-month humanitarian truce, leading to a permanent ceasefire, and within nine months the establishment of an independent, civilian-led government with broad-based legitimacy and accountability.It added: â€œSudanâ€™s future governance is for the Sudanese people to decide through an inclusive and transparent transition process, not controlled by any warring party.â€One other passage in the joint statement protected UAE interests: â€œSudanâ€™s future cannot be dictated by violent extremist groups part of, or evidently linked to, the Muslim Brotherhood, whose destabilising influence has fuelled violence and instability across the region.â€Talks on these proposals in Washington â€“ so far excluding Sudanese civilians â€“ have not yet borne fruit, suggesting it may yet require more senior US officials to engage before the protagonists of Sudanâ€™s civil war and their supporters accept that further fighting offers only more misery.Explore more on these topicsSudanUnited Arab EmiratesAfricaMiddle East and north AfricanewsShareReuse this content

title: Brazil to seek independent inquiry into deadly police raid that killed 121 people | Brazil | The Guardian
description: Brazilian president Lula called police assault on two of Rioâ€™s largest clusters of favelas â€˜disastrousâ€™ and a â€˜massacreâ€™
Author: Tom Phillips
Headline: Brazilian president Lula called police assault on two of Rioâ€™s largest clusters of favelas â€˜disastrousâ€™ and a â€˜massacreâ€™
Content: A woman cries outside a hospital after her relative was brought there after the police operation in Rio de Janeiro on 28 October 2025.Photograph: Silvia Izquierdo/APView image in fullscreenA woman cries outside a hospital after her relative was brought there after the police operation in Rio de Janeiro on 28 October 2025.Photograph: Silvia Izquierdo/APBrazilBrazil to seek independent inquiry into deadly police raid that killed 121 peopleBrazilian president Lula called police assault on two of Rioâ€™s largest clusters of favelas â€˜disastrousâ€™ and a â€˜massacreâ€™Tom Phillipsin Rio de JaneiroTue 4 Nov 2025 13.31 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 13.49 ESTShareBrazilâ€™s president,Luiz InÃ¡cio Lula da Silva, has said his government will seek an independent investigation into what he called a â€œdisastrousâ€ police â€œmassacreâ€ that left at least 121 people dead.Four officers and at least 117 others were killed when police launched a major assault on two of Rioâ€™s largest clusters of favelas, the Complexo do AlemÃ£o and the Complexo da Penha, early last Tuesday to execute 100 arrest warrants.The police raid â€“ the deadliest in Brazilian history â€“ made international headlines when scores of mutilated bodies were dumped at the entrance to one of the working-class areas where the operation took place. The dead included a 14-year-old and a 19-year-old who was decapitated and had his head exhibited on a tree. One police victim had his leg amputated after being shot.â€˜This was a slaughter, not an operationâ€™: the favela reeling from Rioâ€™s deadliest police raidRead moreThere has been widespread public support for the carnage, with Rioâ€™s rightwing governor, ClÃ¡udio Castro, hailing the operation as a severe blow to the Rio-born Red Command drug faction, one of Brazilâ€™s biggest crime groups.But speaking in the Amazon city of BelÃ©m on Tuesday, Brazilâ€™s leftwing president said that while â€œsome might see the operation as a success from the point of view of the number of deathsâ€ he believed it had been â€œdisastrousâ€ as an action of the state.â€œThere was a massacre, and I think itâ€™s important to verify the conditions under which it occurred,â€ Lula told foreign journalists after arriving in BelÃ©m for the start of the Cop30 climate summit.â€œThe judgeâ€™s order [authorizing the operation] was for arrest warrants to be executed, not a massacre. And there was a massacre,â€ Lula said in BelÃ©m, which despite being nearly 2,500km north of Rio, has also become a major Red Command hub as the faction has pushed deeper into the Amazon. Police say 19 of those killed during Tuesdayâ€™s operation were from ParÃ¡ state of which BelÃ©m is capital.Lula said he wanted to see federal police forensic investigators involved in an inquiry into the killings.Polls show broad public approval for the raid, which had by far the highest death toll in Rioâ€™s history and was even deadlier than 1992â€™s Carandiru prison massacre in SÄo Paulo, when 111 inmates were killed.But security experts and activists argue it will do nothing to fundamentally weaken the Red Command or solve Rioâ€™s four-decade conflict, which has seen heavily armed drug traffickers occupy poor areas abandoned by the police.â€œIf killing people fixed the problem, Brazil would be Switzerland,â€ one of the worldâ€™s safest countries, said security specialist CecÃ­lia Olliveira, whose group, Fogo Cruzado (Cross Fire), tracks armed violence.The massacre has overshadowed the start of Brazilâ€™s climate summit and a visit Prince William is making to Rio ahead of those talks. As the future king toured Rio on Tuesday, newsstands were adorned with copies of Brazilâ€™s bestselling weekly magazinedeclaring the seaside city a â€œwar zoneâ€.Explore more on these topicsBrazilLuiz InÃ¡cio Lula da SilvaRio de JaneiroAmericasnewsShareReuse this content

title: Sheinbaum denies reports US will send troops to Mexico: â€˜Itâ€™s not going to happenâ€™ | Mexico | The Guardian
description: President says sheâ€™s repeatedly rejected such offers from Trump for US to confront Mexicoâ€™s powerful drug cartels
Author: Oscar Lopez
Headline: President says sheâ€™s repeatedly rejected such offers from Trump for US to confront Mexicoâ€™s powerful drug cartels
Content: Claudia Sheinbaum speaks during her daily press conference in Mexico City on Monday.Photograph: Carl de Souza/AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenClaudia Sheinbaum speaks during her daily press conference in Mexico City on Monday.Photograph: Carl de Souza/AFP/Getty ImagesMexicoSheinbaum denies reports US will send troops to Mexico: â€˜Itâ€™s not going to happenâ€™President says sheâ€™s repeatedly rejected such offers from Trump for US to confront Mexicoâ€™s powerful drug cartelsOscar Lopezin Mexico CityTue 4 Nov 2025 13.31 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 13.43 ESTShareMexicoâ€™s PresidentClaudia Sheinbaumhas flatly denied reports that the United States is planning to send troops into Mexico to confront the countryâ€™s powerful cartels, noting that she had repeatedly rejected such offers from Donald Trump.â€œItâ€™s not going to happen,â€ Sheinbaum said during her daily morning news conference on Tuesday. â€œWe do not agree with any process of interference or interventionism.â€Sheinbaumâ€™s comments come after areport from NBC Newsciting current and former US officials that the Trump administration has started planning a mission to send US troops and intelligence officers into Mexico.The report said that although the operation was not imminent and no final decision had been made, the early stages of training had already begun as well as discussions about the scope of the operation.The report also indicated that US troops would operate under the authority of the US intelligence community, and that officers from theCIAwould also participate.But Sheinbaum was insistent that her country had â€œno informationâ€ about such a planned incursion, although she admitted that in phone calls with Trump, the US president had offered to send troops and other support to confront organized crime.â€œIâ€™ve always said thank you very much, President Trump. But no,Mexicois a free, independent and sovereign country,â€ Sheinbaum said.Mexico and the US have long collaborated in tackling drug-trafficking groups, with the US at times sending CIA, military and Drug Enforcement Administration operatives to support Mexicoâ€™s efforts to combat organized crime.But the incursion of US troops into Mexico to directly confront the cartels, particularly without Mexicoâ€™s agreement, would be an unprecedented step that would almost certainly fracture an already tenuous bilateral relationship.Mexico president dismisses US claim of cartel bounties on immigration officialsRead moreThe Trump administration has made confronting drug-trafficking groups a central pillar of its foreign policy: in February, Washingtondesignated six Mexican cartelsas foreign terrorist organizations.It has also launched a series of attacks against alleged drug-trafficking boats, most recentlystriking vessels in the eastern Pacificthat killed 14 alleged traffickers in late October.Although Mexico rescued one of the survivors from the attack, Sheinbaumcondemned the strikesand ordered officials from her government to discuss them with the US ambassador to Mexico.On Tuesday, Sheinbaum also noted that Mexico had reached a security agreement with the United States that was negotiated over several months.â€œWe are going to continue working within this framework of understanding, which has very clear principles â€¦ which respects our sovereignty and our territoriality.â€The Mexican president has also appeared cooler on militarised anti-narcotics tactics than her predecessors: on Monday, she ruled out any changes to the countryâ€™s security strategy despite the recent brutal killing of a mayor in western Mexico.â€œSome are calling for militarization and war, as happened with the war on drugs,â€ Sheinbaum said. â€œThat didnâ€™t work.â€Explore more on these topicsMexicoDonald TrumpClaudia SheinbaumDrugs tradeDrugsAmericasTrump administrationnewsShareReuse this content

title: Peru severs diplomatic relations with Mexico after former prime minister claims asylum | Peru | The Guardian
description: Peru's government has severed diplomatic relations with Mexico over the asylum claim of former Peruvian prime minister Betssy ChÃ¡vez
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Peru's government has severed diplomatic relations with Mexico over the asylum claim of former Peruvian prime minister Betssy ChÃ¡vez
Content: Peruvian former PM Betssy Chavez has claimed asylum at Mexicoâ€™s embassy in Lima.Photograph: MartÃ­n MejÃ­a/APView image in fullscreenPeruvian former PM Betssy Chavez has claimed asylum at Mexicoâ€™s embassy in Lima.Photograph: MartÃ­n MejÃ­a/APPeruPeru severs diplomatic relations with Mexico after former prime minister claims asylumPeru's government has severed diplomatic relations with Mexico over the asylum claim of former Peruvian prime minister Betssy ChÃ¡vezAssociated PressTue 4 Nov 2025 07.56 ESTFirst published on Mon 3 Nov 2025 21.15 ESTSharePeruâ€™s government has announced the country is severing diplomatic relations withMexicoover the asylum claim of the former Peruvian prime minister Betssy ChÃ¡vez, who is under investigation for rebellion.The Peruvian foreign minister, Hugo de Zela, told reporters Mexicoâ€™s decision to grant ChÃ¡vez asylum at its embassy in Peruâ€™s capital, Lima, constituted an â€œunfriendly actâ€ that added to the existing tensions between the two countries. The office of Peruâ€™s president, JosÃ© JerÃ­, issued a statement accusing Mexicoâ€™s government of repeated interference in his countryâ€™s internal affairs.Authorities have accused ChÃ¡vez of participating in a failed effort in 2022 by the then president,Pedro Castillo, to declare a state of emergency and dissolve Peruâ€™s parliament as legislators prepared an impeachment vote against him. Castillo failed to get the militaryâ€™s support for his move, and parliament swiftly deposed him. He was arrested after prosecutors accused him of trying to promote a coup and he remains in custody.â€˜Weâ€™ll march as many times as necessaryâ€™: Peruâ€™s youth protesters defy state of emergencyRead moreThe Peruvian attorney generalâ€™s office has accused ChÃ¡vez of being an accomplice in the crime of rebellion against the powers of the state, and is seeking a jail term of up to 25 years. ChÃ¡vez has denied knowing about Castilloâ€™s plan to dissolve the legislature.â€œToday we learned with surprise and deep regret that the former prime minister Betssy ChÃ¡vez, the alleged co-author of the coup attempted by the former president, Pedro Castillo, is being granted asylum at the residence of the Mexican embassy in Peru,â€ De Zela told reporters.The Mexican government said it regretted Peruâ€™s decision, noting Mexico granted ChÃ¡vez asylum in compliance with international law.â€œMexico rejects Peruâ€™s unilateral decision as excessive and disproportionate in response to a legitimate act by Mexico consistent with international law, which in no way constitutes intervention in Peruâ€™s internal affairs,â€ the countryâ€™s foreign ministry said in a statement.Castilloâ€™s wife and children are in Mexico, where authorities have expressed sympathy for the former Peruvian president, who came to power on a leftist platform.Mexicoâ€™s left-leaning president,Claudia Sheinbaum, reaffirmed her support for Castillo last month, insisting he had been the victim of a coup. She called for his release from jail and and for him to receive a fair trial.The Peruvian foreign ministry said in a statement on Monday that since the events of December 2022, â€œthe Mexican government has been interfering in an inadmissible and systematic manner in Peruâ€™s internal affairsâ€.It said Mexico had not changed its â€œunacceptable positionâ€ despite the Peruvian government repeatedly demanding respect for its sovereignty.Explore more on these topicsPeruMexicoAmericasnewsShareReuse this content

accuses Dutch of prolonging chip war that threatens to halt car factoriesBeijing tells Netherlands to â€˜stop interferingâ€™ after seizure of chipmaker Nexperia as export bans disrupt supply chainBusiness live â€“ latest updatesLisa Oâ€™Carrolland Olivia Konotey-AhuluTue 4 Nov 2025 12.17 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 07.41 ESTShareChina has told theNetherlandsto â€œstop interferingâ€ in the seized chipmaker Nexperia, accusing it of prolonging a dispute that has disrupted the global car industry.The Dutch government took control of the semiconductor-maker at the end of September amid US securityconcerns about the companyâ€™s Chinese parent, Wingtech Technology.In response, China halted exports of Nexperia products, restricting access to the vital components used in everything from airbags to central locking, and prompting carmakers in the EU, the UK and Japan toissue warnings that supply shortages could lead to stoppages.The EU is in the middle of urgent talks with Beijing to lift export controls on the chips and also on crucial rare earth minerals, after a summit with officials from both sides in Brussels on Friday.On Tuesday, however,Chinasignalled its decisions were still being coloured by the Nexperia dispute, accusing the Dutch of failing to cooperate on export exemptions and urging them to work in a â€œconstructive mannerâ€ to ease supply chain issues.â€œThe Netherlands continues to act unilaterally without taking concrete steps to resolve the issue, which will inevitably exacerbate the adverse impact on the global semiconductor supply chain,â€ Chinaâ€™s ministry of commerce said. â€œNeither China nor the global industry wishes to see this.â€In a statement on Tuesday, the European Commission said it had made some progress on Friday and that Beijing had committed to engaging further over other restrictions on rare earths including the magnets that control car window mechanisms and boot openings.The commission will debrief EU ambassadors on Wednesday and has asked member states to report back by Friday on the impact of the chip ban in their factories. Carmakers in the EU warned last weekthey were â€œdays awayâ€ from production stoppages.The trade tensions with the EU are in contrast to the truce struck between China and the US last Thursday.The White House said in its readout after the agreement that Chinawould â€œeliminateâ€ all â€œcurrent and proposed export controls on rare earth elements and other critical materialsâ€ and end the semiconductor â€œretaliationâ€.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toBusiness TodayFree daily newsletterGet set for the working day â€“ we'll point you to all the business news and analysis you need every morningEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. Court documents show the US Bureau of International Security and Nonproliferation told the Dutch foreign ministry in June: â€œThe fact that the companyâ€™s CEO is still the same Chinese owner is problematic â€¦ It is almost certain that the CEO will have to be replaced.â€The dispute escalated last week when Nexperia told customersall supplies to its Chinese factory had been suspended. Although Nexperiaâ€™s chips are manufactured in Europe, about 70% are packaged in China before distribution.Wingtech said the actions of the Dutch government â€œappear to be aimed at allowing a new Dutch-owned company to take Nexperiaâ€. It warned that â€œany Nexperia-successor company is doomed to failâ€, adding that â€œ80% of Nexperiaâ€™s back-end capacity is within mainland Chinaâ€.A spokesperson said: â€œIf this matter is not resolved very soon, there will be no company left for customers to return to, and hundreds of people in the Netherlands, Germany and the UK will lose their jobs with many more affected indirectly across Europe. Nexperiaâ€™s European employees are very concerned about this, but the companyâ€™s senior Dutch management appears oblivious to these concerns.â€The Dutch economic affairs ministry told Reuters that talks between the two governments were still under way. â€œWe remain in contact with the Chinese authorities and our international partners to work toward a constructive solution that is good for Nexperia and our economies,â€ a spokesperson said.The dispute adds to the turmoil that UK auto manufacturers have faced after a cyber-attack forced Jaguar Land Rover, Britainâ€™s largest carmaker, to halt production in September.JLR has resumed production, supporting asmall boostto UK factories in October. title: Backlash after New Zealand government scraps rules on incorporating MÄori culture in classrooms | New Zealand | The Guardian
description: Minister says obligations for school boards to â€˜give effectâ€™ to the treaty are unfair while critics argue the move will sideline Indigenous education
Author: Eva Corlett
Headline: Minister says obligations for school boards to â€˜give effectâ€™ to the treaty are unfair while critics argue the move will sideline Indigenous education
Content: School boards have been obligated since 2020 to â€˜give effectâ€™ to the Treaty of Waitangi, New Zealandâ€™s founding document signed in 1840 between MÄori tribes and the British Crown.Photograph: Fiona Goodall/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenSchool boards have been obligated since 2020 to â€˜give effectâ€™ to the Treaty of Waitangi, New Zealandâ€™s founding document signed in 1840 between MÄori tribes and the British Crown.Photograph: Fiona Goodall/Getty ImagesNew ZealandBacklash after New Zealand government scraps rules on incorporating MÄori culture in classroomsMinister says obligations for school boards to â€˜give effectâ€™ to the treaty are unfair while critics argue the move will sideline Indigenous educationNew Zealandâ€™s Treaty of Waitangi â€“ explained in 30 secondsEva Corlettin WellingtonTue 4 Nov 2025 00.08 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 04.09 ESTShareA plan by New Zealandâ€™s government to scrap a legal requirement on schools to incorporate local MÄori culture in classrooms has been condemned by teachers, principals and school boards.Since 2020, school boards have been obligated to â€œgive effectâ€ to theTreaty of Waitangi, New Zealandâ€™s founding document signed in 1840 between MÄori tribes and the British Crown and instrumental in upholding MÄori rights.That treaty requirement includes ensuring school policies, plans and local curriculums reflect localMÄoricustoms, knowledge and world views.Guaranteed MÄori seats on New Zealand councils to be slashed by more than halfRead moreBut in an unexpected move on Tuesday, the education minister, Erica Stanford, said the treaty requirement would be removed. Teachers, principals and school boards have said the change risks sidelining Indigenous children and damaging social cohesion.In a statement provided to the Guardian, Stanford said the treaty obligation â€œmade no difference to raising the achievement of MÄori [children]â€ and that it was unfair to place the obligation on school boards.School boards are made up of elected representatives including teachers, parents and sometimes students.â€œParents who are effectively volunteers, already responsible for the governance of their local school, were suddenly expected to interpret and implement a treaty obligation that rightfully sits with the Crown,â€ Stanford said.School boards would now be required to â€œseek to achieve equitable outcomes for MÄori studentsâ€, take steps to provide for teaching and learning in MÄori language (te reo MÄori) to students whose parents and caregivers request it, and take steps to ensure the school reflects cultural diversity.But teachers, principals and school boards say that while they might still choose to include MÄori culture in their schools, removing the legal requirement for it risked making Indigenous culture, education and language less visible.â€œThe suggestion that this clause makes no difference simply isnâ€™t true,â€ the president of the school boards association, Meredith Kennett, said in a statement.The treaty clause helped school boardsimplement policies that reflected the needs of MÄori and all New Zealanders, she said.It had been a unifying influence in schools, not a divisive one, Kennett said.â€œIt causes no harm to have it there, but causes plenty of harm â€“ including to social cohesion â€“ by removing it.â€The president of the principalsâ€™ federation, Leanne Otene, said school boards had embraced the treaty obligation and it had helped to create school cultures where MÄori children felt reflected, and where their language and culture was valued and respected.Examples included schools learning about their local history from iwi (tribes), singing and performing traditional song and dance, and incorporating MÄori language in signs and greetings, Otene told the Guardian.â€œThere is rich historic knowledge that is passed down from generation to generation which builds a culture and a uniqueness about why our land â€¦ is different from any other country,â€ Otene said.Other countries looked up to New Zealand for reviving Indigenous language and culture and the change would put the country â€œcompletely out of step as global leadersâ€, she said.Since taking office, the coalition government has said it wants to end â€œrace-based policiesâ€. It has ushered insweeping rollbacksto policies that are designed to improve health, wellbeing and representation outcomes for MÄori.The Labour leader,Chris Hipkins, described the move as a â€œstep backwardsâ€, saying on Tuesday: â€œ[The government] would far rather have culture wars than focus on the mess they are making with the economy.â€Quick GuideContact us about this storyShowThe best public interest journalism relies on first-hand accounts from people in the know.If you have something to share on this subject, you can contact us confidentially using the following methods.Secure Messaging in the Guardian appThe Guardian app has a tool to send tips about stories. title: Albanese government deports two more men to Nauru in secret, infuriating human rights advocates | Australian immigration and asylum | The Guardian
description: Exclusive: Sources say a Sudanese national and another man were chartered to the former regional processing centre last week, joining one other person
Author: Sarah Basford Canales
Headline: Exclusive: Sources say a Sudanese national and another man were chartered to the former regional processing centre last week, joining one other person
Content: The $2.5bn deal with Nauru is expected to last 30 years and will allow Australia to apply for 30-year long-term visas on behalf of the cohort to enable their deportation from the country.Composite: Guardian design/AFP/Getty Images/APView image in fullscreenThe $2.5bn deal with Nauru is expected to last 30 years and will allow Australia to apply for 30-year long-term visas on behalf of the cohort to enable their deportation from the country.Composite: Guardian design/AFP/Getty Images/APAustralian immigration and asylumAlbanese government deports two more men to Nauru in secret, infuriating human rights advocatesExclusive:Sources say a Sudanese national and another man were chartered to the former regional processing centre last week, joining one other personFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet ourbreaking news email,free appordaily news podcastSarah Basford CanalesMon 3 Nov 2025 23.38 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 00.18 ESTShareAnother two men from the NZYQ-affected cohort have been deported toNauruin a process human rights advocates say is shrouded in secrecy.Sources told Guardian Australia a Sudanese national, who was detained in the Yongah Hill centre just outside of Perth, and another man held in a different centre were chartered to Nauru last week.There, theyjoin another man, believed to be a Vietnamese national, in the tiny Pacific island nation that was once home to Australiaâ€™s regional processing for asylum seekers. Just one centre remains open.First person arrives on Nauru triggering Australiaâ€™s $2.5bn deal with island nationRead moreWhen asked about the deportation, the home affairs minister,Tony Burke, said: â€œIf people have had their visas cancelled, we expect them to leave.â€Last month, when Burke was asked how many of the 350 people in the NZYQ group had been re-detained before deportation, he said estimates â€“ which ranged between â€œhigh teens to 20s and beyondâ€ â€“ were roughly correct.The $2.5bn deal between Australia and Nauru was expected to last 30 years and would allow Australia to apply for 30-year long-term visas on behalf of the cohort to enable their deportation from the country.About $20m of the first instalment would become immediately available for the Nauruan government to â€œfacilitate the settlementâ€, while the remaining $388m would go into a sovereign trust fund, which was expected to co-governed by both the Nauruan and Australian governments.Sign up: AU Breaking News emailIan Rintoul, a spokesperson for Refugee Action Coalition Sydney, accused the government of trying to â€œreplace indefinite detention in Australiaâ€ with â€œindefinite detention on Nauruâ€.â€œThe government also seems to be trying to thwart the high court again by sending people before the high court can consider an upcoming challenge to their new deportation laws,â€ he said.Ogy Simic, the advocacy head for the Asylum Seeker Resource Centre, said the deportations were happening under a veil of secrecy.â€œOnce again, we are all piecing together fragments of information to try to find the truth of what is being done in our name,â€ he said.â€œAnd meanwhile, people are being deported in secret, locked up on a remote island and given what is essentially a life sentence with no recourse and no right to justice.â€Another human rights lawyer, Sarah Dale, the Refugee Advice and Casework Service centre director, said she was â€œincensed by the cloak of darkness that this process remains hidden underâ€.â€œTo not know if they were afforded due process, access to legal advice, appropriate health assessments or otherwise only echoes every single concern we have flagged with this process, let alone the repugnance of the policy itself,â€ she said.Details of the agreement between Nauru and Australia remain a secret.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toBreaking News We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionOfficials from the Department of Home Affairs told a Senate hearing those sent to Nauru, many of whom had been found to be refugees, would be able to live freely within the community.The agreement also apparently states they cannot be sent to another country, where they could face persecution in a situation â€“ otherwise known as chain refoulement.Adnan thought heâ€™d served his time. But one night border force raided his home to deport him to NauruRead moreAdnan*, a man within the NZYQ cohort,told Guardian Australialast month he had not heard of Nauru prior to being re-detained earlier this year by Australian Border Force officials in a night-time raid.â€œThese days are like living in a nightmare. I made mistakes since I came to Australia â€“ I have been punished for those mistakes. I have tried everything to put my life back on track.â€œI am not a young man â€“ I cannot keep rebuilding my life. I do not know why Australia has selected me for this terrible punishment,â€ he said.After thedealâ€™s announcement in February, Nauruâ€™s president, David Adeang, said the three men first issued visas had â€œserved their timeâ€ in Australian prisons and were no longer subject to any punishment.â€œEven for the refugees that came here, they have the same history: some of them killed people, some of them are disturbed people. But they will not do that here, instead they will live their life as normal and be happy along with us all,â€ he said.* Not his real nameExplore more on these topicsAustralian immigration and asylumNauruAsia PacificPacific islandsMigrationRefugeesTony BurkenewsShareReuse this content

title: Counter-terror police investigate claim UK university halted research after Chinese pressure | Sheffield Hallam University | The Guardian
description: Sheffield Hallam University ordered professor to cease human rights study into Uyghurs forced labour in China
Author: Nadeem Badshah
Headline: Sheffield Hallam University ordered professor to cease human rights study into Uyghurs forced labour in China
Content: Laura Murphy, professor of human rights and contemporary slavery at Sheffield Hallam University, was ordered to stop her research.Photograph: Christopher Thomond/The GuardianView image in fullscreenLaura Murphy, professor of human rights and contemporary slavery at Sheffield Hallam University, was ordered to stop her research.Photograph: Christopher Thomond/The GuardianSheffield Hallam UniversityCounter-terror police investigate claim UK university halted research after Chinese pressureSheffield Hallam University ordered professor to cease human rights study into Uyghurs forced labour in ChinaNadeem BadshahMon 3 Nov 2025 19.08 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 04.12 ESTShareAn investigation into allegations that a British university was subjected to pressure from Beijing authorities to halt research about human rights abuses inChinahas been referred to counter-terrorism police.TheGuardian reported on Monday morning thatSheffield Hallam University, home to the Helena Kennedy Centre for International Justice (HKC) research institution, had ordered professor Laura Murphy to cease research on supply chains and forced labour in the country in February.UK university halted human rights research after pressure from ChinaRead moreMurphyâ€™s work focuses on Uyghurs, a persecuted Muslim minority in China.A South Yorkshire police spokesperson said the force had referred the investigation on because the â€œallegations fall under Section 3 of the National Security Actâ€, the BBC reported.Section 3 of the act deals with â€œassisting a foreign intelligence serviceâ€. An offence is committed if someone behaves in a way that â€œintends that conduct to materially assist a foreign intelligence service in carrying out UK-related activitiesâ€, or in conduct likely to assist that service.In October the university apologised and said it was lifting the ban on Murphyâ€™s work on China and forced labour.A spokesperson for Sheffield Hallam said the decision to halt the academicâ€™s work was â€œbased on our understanding of a complex set of circumstances at the time, including being unable to secure the necessary professional indemnity insuranceâ€.â€œFollowing a review, we have since approved Prof Murphyâ€™s latest research and are committed to supporting her to undertake and disseminate this important work.â€œWe have apologised to Prof Murphy and wish to make clear our commitment to supporting her research and to securing and promoting freedom of speech and academic freedom within the law.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toFirst EditionFree daily newsletterOur morning email breaks down the key stories of the day, telling you whatâ€™s happening and why it mattersEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. title: Prisoners spending entire jail term in police cells as Victoriaâ€™s justice system buckles | Victoria | The Guardian
description: Prisoners in police cells often have less access to healthcare and less chance of being visited by family and lawyers
Author: Nino Bucci
Headline: Prisoners in police cells often have less access to healthcare and less chance of being visited by family and lawyers
Content: Inmates are being shuffled across police cells and prisons in Victoria as the state balances its tougher bail laws with a shortage of beds and corrections workers.Photograph: Diego Fedele/AAPView image in fullscreenInmates are being shuffled across police cells and prisons in Victoria as the state balances its tougher bail laws with a shortage of beds and corrections workers.Photograph: Diego Fedele/AAPVictoriaPrisoners spending entire jail term in police cells as Victoriaâ€™s justice system bucklesPrisoners in police cells often have less access to healthcare and less chance of being visited by family and lawyersFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet ourbreaking news email,free appordaily news podcastNino BucciJustice and courts reporterTue 4 Nov 2025 09.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 17.55 ESTShareIn winter this year, a young Aboriginal man with a history of self-harm who had been remanded in custody inMelbournewas told he would be moving cells.But he was not shifted across the corridor or to another building nearby: he was driven 300km to the police cells in Wodonga.He had no connection to the city, in the stateâ€™s far north-east. He also had no shoes or socks. Neither his family nor his lawyer were told he would be moved across the state; his lawyer found out after calling the previous cells to be told heâ€™d been moved.The man was relocated as part of a process called â€œdecantingâ€: the shuffling of people across prisons and police cells inVictoriaas the state balances its tougher bail laws with a shortage of beds and corrections workers.Victorian police have an agreement with Corrections Victoria that nobody will be housed for more than 14 days in police cells, as both authorities recognise these cells are not equipped to hold people longer than necessary.â€˜When I came out of prison, I couldnâ€™t wait to createâ€™: leading artists and inmates team up to break the prison cycleRead moreThe agreement is regularly breached. This means that people on remand â€“ those who have either not been found guilty of any offence, or have not been sentenced â€“ are typically housed in cells for 23 hours a day, with less access to healthcare, and less chance of being able to be visited or contacted by family and lawyers, than those in prisons.In cases from the past six months uncovered by Guardian Australia, people have been moved from Melbourne to cells in Bendigo and Geelong.People are even regularly completing entire prison sentences in police cells.There are also unconfirmed reports of people being released from police custody in towns hundreds of kilometres from their homes, with no clear way for them to return.Last month there were about 30 people in police cells who had been there for more than 14 days, according to evidence by senior officers to the inquest of Cody Dwyer, who died in custody in 2021.The inquest had also heard police wanted to renegotiate the agreement with corrections from 14 to seven days, aware of the human rights implications of keeping people in inappropriate cells for longer than necessary.But no agreement could be reached, as the stateâ€™s justice system sags under the weight of record demand for remand beds, while the newly appointed police commissioner, Mike Bush, also pushes for more police to return to the streets.Sign up: AU Breaking News emailGeraldine Veneziano, Corrections Victoriaâ€™s acting general manager of the sentence management team, told the Dwyer inquest that the police cells were needed when prisons â€œbottleneckâ€.The regularity with which this occurs meant little could be done to meet the police request of reducing the number of days people can spend in their cells.Lawyers have taken to emailing Corrections Victoria, when they are concerned about their clients having been moved to police cells across the state or held longer than the 14-day agreement.Corrections Victoria refers them to Victoria police, saying that if people are in their cells, theyâ€™re not correctionsâ€™ responsibility.Sometimes, it will forward the email to Victoria policeâ€™s custody management division.In the emails, seen by Guardian Australia, the opening of Western Plains prison is seen as a possible solution to the issue. The 1,200-bed prison opened on 26 June but there remains a shortage of staff across the corrections system.â€œIf I talk about todayâ€™s custody landscape, we do have people that are in excess of 14 days in custody at a police detention facility,â€ Jacki Kline, a Victoria police superintendent in the custody management division, told the Dwyer inquest.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toBreaking News AustraliaFree newsletterGet the most important news as it breaksEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. He died two days laterRead moreThe Dwyer inquest also heard that as of early October, about 20 people were completing prison sentences in police cells.In a statement, a police spokesperson said the force could only transfer a certain number of people each day to corrections, based on their capacity.â€œThese numbers vary and Victoria police prioritises the transfer of individuals taking into account those who require medical support or other relevant circumstances including those from vulnerable community groups.â€œVictoria police will continue to work with Corrections Victoria to ensure offenders are placed in appropriate detention facilities in a timely manner.â€œNobody is placed in a police cell until the relevant risks, management requirements and considerations for the individual have been assessed.â€A Department of Justice spokesperson tied the higher demand to beds to the bail reforms.â€œCorrections Victoria is working closely with Victoria police to ensure that offenders are managed as quickly as possible,â€ they said.In Australia, the crisis support serviceLifelineis 13 11 14. In the UK and Ireland,Samaritanscan be contacted on freephone 116 123, or emailjo@samaritans.orgorjo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the988 Suicide & Crisis Lifelineat 988 or chat at988lifeline.org. title: Their Eras tour? Radiohead play career-spanning set in first concert since 2018 | Radiohead | The Guardian
description: â€‹British quintet draw from all but one of their studio albums as they perform in Madrid on first of 20 European tour dates
Author: Ashifa Kassam
Headline: â€‹British quintet draw from all but one of their studio albums as they perform in Madrid on first of 20 European tour dates
Content: Thom Yorke performing in 2024.Photograph: Sipa US/AlamyView image in fullscreenThom Yorke performing in 2024.Photograph: Sipa US/AlamyRadioheadTheir Eras tour? Radiohead play career-spanning set in first concert since 2018Radioheadâ€™s 2025 tour: the opening night setlistâ€‹British quintet draw from all but one of their studio albums as they perform in Madrid on first of 20 European tour datesAshifa Kassamin Madrid, andBen Beaumont-ThomasTue 4 Nov 2025 17.04 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 16.00 ESTShareRadiohead chose Madrid as the location for their first concert since 2018, and kicked off a 20-date European tour with a crowd-pleasing yet unpredictable setlist drawing from almost all of their nine studio albums.Were it not for Oasis, it might have been the most anticipated rock tour of the year. Radiohead havenâ€™t recorded a studio album since 2016, and each of the band members has been involved in other successful and creatively stimulating projects, so fans were beginning to wonder if they might never hear from them again.But there was excitement last year at the news the band had reconvened for casual rehearsals, then a frenzied rush for tickets when new shows were announced in September, and finally a rapturous reception in Madrid for this concert in the round.With little chat with the crowd beyond the occasional â€œgraciasâ€, the British quintet played 21 songs, opening with Let Down from 1997â€™s OK Computer and adding other songs from the highly lauded first half of their career including Paranoid Android, Karma Police, Fake Plastic Trees, Idioteque and No Surprises.But while they didnâ€™t shy away from well-known songs, it was no greatest hits set, bringing in numerous album tracks and drawing heavily from 2003â€™s Hail to the Thief.View image in fullscreenFans queue outside Madridâ€™s Movistar Arena on Tuesday.Photograph: Ashifa KassamAn hour or so before the sun rose over Madrid, Francesco Puddu had staked out a prime spot in front of the cityâ€™s hulking Movistar Arena. He was among the first Radiohead fans to arrive at the venue, buzzing with expectations.â€œIâ€™m incredibly excited. Like, I donâ€™t think itâ€™s real,â€ said the 27-year-old, who had travelled from Italy. â€œItâ€™s been so long that even if they play the same song 20 times in a row, Iâ€™ll be happy.â€The hours passed quickly as fans plotted where to position themselves in front of the circular stage, and revelled in the fact that they were among the privileged ones who had scored tickets for a tour that had sold out in minutes.The war in Gaza was another topic that had come up throughout the day, given that the Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israelhad calledon people to boycott the tour, citing band member Jonny Greenwoodâ€™s 2024 performance in Tel Aviv.The topic seemingly remains sensitive for the band: after the Guardian reported onthe boycott callin September, its journalists were blocked from receiving tickets to review the Madrid concert. The band have not commented on the decision.In Spain, wherehundreds of thousandshave taken to the streets in solidarity with Palestine, the bandâ€™s actions had left some fans conflicted.â€œIt would have been nice if they had spoken out about it much earlier,â€ said Lola, 22, who asked that her last name not be published. â€œAs a fan of Radiohead, I was a little bit disappointed. But at least I think they learned their lesson.â€View image in fullscreenAlessandra Fossati: â€˜They always change from one record to another, they never do the same thing.â€™Photograph: Ashifa KassamShe pointed to the incident last year in Melbourne, when the bandâ€™s frontman, Thom Yorke, brieflywalked off stageduring a solo gig after a pro-Palestinian heckler shouted: â€œHow many dead children will it take for you to condemn the genocide in Gaza?â€It was not the right way to respond, said Lola. â€œI didnâ€™t like that reaction.â€ In the end, however, the music had won her over. â€œI obviously canâ€™t control what I feel when I listen to music â€¦ I really wanted to come and listen to the voices and sounds that Iâ€™ve been listening to since I was 12 years old.â€Yorke laterreleased a statementsaying the incident in Melbourne left him â€œin shock that my supposed silence was somehow being taken as complicityâ€, describing the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his administration as â€œextremistsâ€ who â€œneed to be stoppedâ€.Before the European tour, Yorketold the Sunday Timesthat he would â€œabsolutely notâ€ perform in Israel. â€œI wouldnâ€™t want to be 5,000 miles anywhere near the Netanyahu regime,â€he added.Some defended the band, citing their long history of activism. â€œTheyâ€™ve always stood for peace, they canâ€™t have changed now,â€ said Alessandra Fossati. â€œI think the people who know them, know that they are on the right side.â€Tuesdayâ€™s concert was to be the 50th time she had seen Radiohead perform, after becoming hooked when she first saw them live in 1995.This time she had tickets for five of the shows: opening night in Madrid and every single performance in her home country of Italy.â€œThey always change from one record to another, they never do the same thing,â€ she said as she showed off her two Radiohead-themed tattoos. â€œI mean, I used to be a U2 fan but they kept doing the same things. And after a while you get bored.â€For some, the fact that the band had gone seven years without performing together had injected a sense of urgency into the new tour.â€œThere might not be another opportunity, Radiohead is pretty old at this point,â€ said Luka Arreaza, 20, prompting laughter from those waiting in line beside him. â€œSo it was really worth it to come here and share this moment.â€The band, formed when they were at school in Oxfordshire in 1985, have become a byword for cerebral, atmospheric â€“ and non-fans would say morose â€“ rock music. They are still easily able to fill arenas thanks to a run of nine studio albums ranging from solid to utterly classic.View image in fullscreenRadiohead in 1997.Photograph: Roger Sargent/ShutterstockTheir debut, 1994â€™s Pablo Honey, contained their breakthrough hit Creep, which has spent much of the last four months back in the UK Top 100 as the band earn a new generation of fans. Let Down, from third album OK Computer, also re-entered the charts this year.OK Computer is regarded by many critics as the greatest rock album of the 1990s, though if anything the esteem is even higher for its follow-up Kid A, for which the band stretched out further into electronic music.Their sixth, 2007â€™s In Rainbows (made available via a download that fans could set their own price for) is regarded as another creative pinnacle, but the bandâ€™s sense of adventure was clearly still felt on the albums since, The King of Limbs (2011) and A Moon Shaped Pool (2016).Yorke has put out a series of solo and group albums, mostly recently with his trio the Smile, alongsideJonny Greenwood(lead guitar/keyboards).Greenwood has found huge success as a film composer, earning two Oscar nominations for Phantom Thread and The Power of the Dog, and may get a third for the critically adored One Battle After Another, the fifth of his collaborations with director Paul Thomas Anderson.Guitarist Ed Oâ€™Brien released his debut solo album in 2020, and drummer Phil Selway released his third in 2023. Bassist Colin Greenwood has been a sideman for artists including Nick Cave, and in 2024 he published How to Disappear: a Portrait of Radiohead, a book of his photographs of Radiohead taken between 2003 and 2016.Another waiting fan was Sergio Zapater, who had arrived luggage in hand after taking a morning train from Valencia.The last time the 53-year-old had seen Radiohead was 22 years ago. This time, he had arrived at the venue more than nine hours before the concert was due to start, certain that he would be the first in line.Instead he found himself confronted by the fact that a new generation â€“ one that seemingly did not mind early hours or queues â€“ had fallen for Radioheadâ€™s â€œevolved, elaborate, soul-touchingâ€ tunes.â€œI was surprised to find all these young people here,â€ he said with a laugh. â€œHow annoying, I thought I would be first in line because older people donâ€™t do these things. But now Iâ€™m 25th.â€After four nights in Madrid, Radioheadâ€™s tour will travel to Bologna, London, Copenhagen and Berlin, concluding on 12 December.Explore more on these topicsRadioheadSpainThom YorkeJonny GreenwoodEuropenewsShareReuse this content

title: Munich's surfers left stunned after famed river wave vanishes | Germany | The Guardian
description: Eisbach wave in the Bavarian city had been a surfing magnet for decades but disappeared after a recent cleanup
Author: Oliver Holmes
Headline: Eisbach wave in the Bavarian city had been a surfing magnet for decades but disappeared after a recent cleanup
Content: â€˜Weâ€™re at a lossâ€™: surfers have been ruing the loss of the Eisbach wave after a recent cleanup.Photograph: Leonhard Simon/ReutersView image in fullscreenâ€˜Weâ€™re at a lossâ€™: surfers have been ruing the loss of the Eisbach wave after a recent cleanup.Photograph: Leonhard Simon/ReutersGermanyMunich's surfers left stunned after famed river wave vanishesEisbach wave in the Bavarian city had been a surfing magnet for decades but disappeared after a recent cleanupOliver HolmesTue 4 Nov 2025 15.15 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 12.47 ESTShareThe â€œmother of all river wavesâ€ in a German canal that is often credited as the birthplace of freshwater surfing has mysteriously disappeared after decades of flowing smoothly, leaving enthusiasts dumbfounded.The famous stationary wave in the southern city of Munich is known as the Eisbach, or â€œice brookâ€, for its frigid temperatures, and has become a pilgrimage site for surfers worldwide.Unlike ocean surfing, its freshwater cousin takes place on a â€œstanding waveâ€, which is often human-made, with currents often flowing over a concrete slab that manipulates the water into a permanent wave.The sportâ€™s origin is often cited as dating back to the early 1970s, when rule-breaking daredevils rode the naturally forming wave in Munich for the first time.Today, river surfing has a global following, including in the River Severn in the United Kingdom, where surfers ride tidal bores, a phenomenon in which incoming tides form waves that move up a river.In Hawaii, surfers also make river waves by digging a trench between a river and the ocean, with water flowing violently over the sand.The Eisbach wave was originally believed to be formed by gravel, but the Munich surfing community later installed wooden planks that helped artificially stabilise the wave. Over the decades, it has becomea major touristdraw for Bavariaâ€™s state capital.Largest during the winter months â€“ when ice melt can push the wave up to one metre high â€“ the river is now officially managed, including being drained once a year to clean away debris and inspect the streambed.View image in fullscreenPeople look at the spot where there once was the Eisbach wave in Munich.Photograph: Michael Nguyen/NurPhoto/ShutterstockBut after torrents were released back into the canal following its cleanup on Friday, the Eisbach wave did not form as usual, instead leaving unstable white water rapids.â€œWeâ€™re at a loss,â€ surfer Klaus Rudolftold Stern magazine. â€œI was standing at the edge with my board on Friday evening and couldnâ€™t believe it.â€Authorities were looking into the cause of the waveâ€™s disappearance, including whether it could be due to the cleaning or a lack of water.â€œNo structural changes were made to the Eisbach wave or its banks during the cleanup,â€ the city said. An inspection of the site on Monday also did not reveal any damage.On Tuesday, Mayor Dieter Reiter said in a statement that the city administration was â€œworking with the Water Management Office and surfers to find a quick solution so that the famous surf wave will soon be available again as usualâ€.Officials now plan to divert more water into the canal in hopes of a reappearance of the Eisbach, which SurferToday.comdescribesas â€œthe mother of all river wavesâ€. Standing waves require delicately balanced water levels and speeds.The Eisbach wave closed earlier this year for several months after the death of a 33-year-old Munich woman who became trapped under the surface at night. Since it reopened, new rules have banned night-time surfing.Agence France-Presse contributed to this reportExplore more on these topicsGermanyEuropeSurfingRiversnewsShareReuse this content

prime minister of Hungary to support us, at least not block us.â€â€œIf there are the [accession] rules and we comply with them, whatever is needed to open the clusters,we would like [that] to be
