title: NFL great Tom Brady says his dog is a clone of familyâ€™s deceased pit bull mix | Tom Brady | The Guardian
description: Tom Brady says his dog Junie is a clone of his late pet Lua, created by biotech firm Colossal, which announced its acquisition of cloning company Viagen
Author: Guardian sport
Headline: Tom Brady says his dog Junie is a clone of his late pet Lua, created by biotech firm Colossal, which announced its acquisition of cloning company Viagen
Content: NFL great Tom Brady became a minority owner of Birmingham City in 2023.Photograph: MI News/NurPhoto/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenNFL great Tom Brady became a minority owner of Birmingham City in 2023.Photograph: MI News/NurPhoto/ShutterstockTom BradyNFL great Tom Brady says his dog is a clone of familyâ€™s deceased pit bull mixBrady says his dog is a clone of late pet LuaEx-NFL star is investor in biotech firm ColossalCompany also works on de-extinction projectsGuardian sportTue 4 Nov 2025 16.25 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 16.37 ESTShareFormer NFL quarterbackTom Bradysaid Tuesday that his dog, Junie, is a clone of his familyâ€™s late pet Lua, created by Colossal Biosciences, a Dallas-based biotechnology company that Brady has invested in.Barbra Streisandâ€™s dog cloning is a modern tragedy. Pets are meant to die | Stuart HeritageRead moreTheBirmingham City co-ownerrevealed the news in a statement released through Colossal, which also announced its acquisition of another cloning company, Viagen Pets and Equine. The two firms plan to combine their technologies to expand cloning services for pet owners and conservation projects.â€œI love my animals. They mean the world to me and my family,â€ Brady said. â€œA few years ago, I worked with Colossal and leveraged their non-invasive cloning technology through a simple blood draw of our familyâ€™s elderly dog before she passed.â€Lua, a pit bull mix adopted by Brady and his former wife, Gisele BÃ¼ndchen, died in December 2023. The sample used to create Junie was collected before Luaâ€™s death, according to Colossal.Brady said the company â€œgave my family a second chance with a clone of our beloved dogâ€ and added that he is â€œexcited how Colossal and Viagenâ€™s tech together can help both families losing their beloved pets while helping to save endangered speciesâ€.View image in fullscreenTom Brady walks with his son and dog, Lua, along the Charles River in Boston in December 2012.Photograph: Stickman/Bauer-Griffin/GC ImagesViagen, now owned by Colossal, has previously cloned pets for celebrities includingBarbra Streisandand Paris Hilton. The company holds technology licenses from the Roslin Institute of Edinburgh, which clonedDolly the Sheepin 1996.Meet Gem the cocker spaniel â€“ the face of UK pet cloningRead moreColossal, founded in 2021, has drawn attention for its â€œde-extinctionâ€ research, including projects aimed at reviving species such as the woolly mammoth and dodo bird. The company recently claimed to have produced three cloned dire wolf pups, a claim that has been disputed by conservation groups.Financial details of Colossalâ€™s acquisition of Viagen were not disclosed.Cloninga dog through Viagen typically costs between $50,000 and $85,000.Dog cloning has occasionally surfaced in mainstream pop culture, including an episode of Nathan Fielderâ€™sHBO series The Rehearsal, which explored the ethics of replicating a beloved pet.Brady, a seven-time Super Bowl champion andcurrent Fox Sports broadcaster, said his family considers Junie â€œnot a scientific experiment, but part of our familyâ€.Explore more on these topicsTom BradyCloningDogsPetsBirmingham CityNFLGeneticsShareReuse this content

title: Womenâ€™s soccer faces plenty of serious threats. So why the panic about trans players? | NWSL | The Guardian
description: Angel Cityâ€™s Elizabeth Eddy was rebuked by her own teammates for an op-ed on trans players. Itâ€™s easy to understand their objections
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Angel Cityâ€™s Elizabeth Eddy was rebuked by her own teammates for an op-ed on trans players. Itâ€™s easy to understand their objections
Content: Angel Cityâ€™s captain spoke out against her teammate on behalf of the locker room.Photograph: Ronald Martinez/NWSL/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenAngel Cityâ€™s captain spoke out against her teammate on behalf of the locker room.Photograph: Ronald Martinez/NWSL/Getty ImagesNWSLWomenâ€™s soccer faces plenty of serious threats. So why the panic about trans players?Lesley RyderAngel Cityâ€™s Elizabeth Eddy was rebuked by her own teammates for an op-ed on trans players. Itâ€™s easy to understand their objectionsTue 4 Nov 2025 06.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 09.12 ESTShareOn 26 October, Angel City FCâ€™s Elizabeth Eddy made her first post on X in nearly two years. In it, Eddy in essence responded to the Guardianâ€™s report that the NWSL hadquietly droppedits inclusion policy for trans and intersex athletes, leaving the leagueâ€™s future stance on the matter undecided.The New York Post gave Eddyâ€™s writing a signal boost the next day,republishing it in full.â€œIâ€™m concerned that without clarity about who the league is for, it will lose its identity and its momentum,â€ Eddy wrote in the piece, which broadly advocated for a ban on trans athletes from theNWSL, to protect â€œthe integrity of womenâ€™s sportsâ€ so the league does not lose â€œits identity and its momentum.â€The USâ€™s biggest pro womenâ€™s sports unions have found strength togetherRead moreItâ€™s unclear how Eddy thinks the NWSLâ€™s integrity has been harmed â€“ either under its former policy that allowed trans athletes in the league, or its current lack of one. The league, now in its 13th season, has developed a clear identity. Itâ€™s highly competitive. Itâ€™s commercially and culturally powerful. Itâ€™s, well, anintegralpart of the global womenâ€™s soccer scene. The leagueâ€™s momentum appears to be largely fine, too â€“ to pick just two data points, viewership has grown every season, and in 2026 the league will expand to 16 teams, nearly doubling its size in the last five years.Eddy cites the English FAâ€™srecent banon transgender athletes from womenâ€™s soccer as a success story. Yet Englandâ€™sbanis believed to affect only 20 or so grassroots players out of 5.5 million registered athletes. Thereâ€™s reason to believe the effect would be similarly negligible here in the US. In 2021, when the leagueâ€™s trans inclusion policy took effect, the NWSL hadtwotrans players: Quinn and Kumi Yokoyama. Both have since left, and no out trans players currently play in the league. On the 2025 seasonâ€™s opening weekend, the league welcomed its1,000thplayer. Thatâ€™s just two out trans players out of over 1,000 in league history.Eddyâ€™s piece is written as if there is a pipeline of trans players set to take over the league at a momentâ€™s notice. There is no such thing. There are currently no out trans players competing at a professional level in the United States. Federal legislation expresslyprohibitstrans players from competing in NCAA college soccer. And aside from all that, multiple peer-reviewedstudieshave shown that trans athletes have no biological advantages over cis athletes.In the absence of out trans people, transphobic attacks have continued along racial lines. When the Orlando Prideâ€™s Barbra Banda was named the BBCâ€™s player of the year, a wave of online abuse followed. The NWSL waspainfully slowto act in support of their star player. The Kansas City Currentâ€™sTemwa Chawingaand her sister Tabitha have experienced similar abuse. Itâ€™s all derived either from the fraught world of gender testing standards, the players not looking outwardly feminine enough to some, or some combination of both those factors.In her piece, Eddy does manage to identify that there is harm in legislating bodies in this way, saying â€œThis uncertainty serves no one, as questions and controversy abound over intersex and transgender athletes.â€But she doesnâ€™t seem to realize how her op-ed further enables those harms. AsSuzanne Wrack put itin the Guardian earlier this year: â€œWhat the hysteria over an almost impossible hypothetical situation does is open the door for transphobic and racist targeting of female football players and creates an environment that makes trans people, young trans people, or those questioning their gender identity at grassroots level feel as if they donâ€™t belong in football or sport.â€This harm is exponentially increased by the New York Postâ€™s shameful decision to run Eddyâ€™s op-ed with a photo of Banda, who like many athletes of color are frequently targeted by transphobic attacks. And Eddyâ€™s own teammates know it.â€œThat article does not speak for this team in this locker room,â€ Angel City FC captain Sarah Gorden told reporters on Thursday. â€œWe donâ€™t agree with the things written for a plethora of reasons, but mostly the undertones come across as transphobic and racist as well. The article calls for genetic testing on certain players, and it has a photo of an African player as a headline. And thatâ€™s very harmful. As a mixed woman, with a Black family, Iâ€™m devastated by the undertones of this article â€¦ And there are players in this league and in this locker room that are directly harmed by what was written in the article.â€Even if one were to ignore all that and believe that trans inclusion constitutes a real problem for the NWSL, itâ€™s hard to see how it would outrank any number of other issues that have actually blunted the leagueâ€™s momentum and affected its integrity.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toMoving the GoalpostsFree weekly newsletterNo topic is too small or too big for us to cover as we deliver a twice-weekly roundup of the wonderful world of womenâ€™s footballEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionThere are continuing issues around working conditions for the professionals that make the league run. Six former San Diego Wave employees aresuingthe club and the NWSL alleging, in part, racial and disability discrimination, sexual harassment, and negligence to prevent discrimination and sexual harassment. The Guardianreportedthe NWSL denied wrongdoing, saying they had â€œno duty of careâ€ to the six employees.There are issues concerning player care. In May, Angel City defender Savy King collapsed on the field, requiring emergency medical treatment before leaving the field on a stretcher. On-field play resumed, even though players were visibly distraught. The NWSLPA called on the league torevisittheir medical protocols. Then, in August, when a nationally televised match between the Orlando Pride and the KC Current faced an extreme heat delay, NWSL commissioner Jessica Berman reportedlythreatenedto fine the Current over a disagreement in the leagueâ€™s extreme heat procedures.There are more pedestrian, on-field issues too, as European leagues like the WSL grow in financial might enough to start attractingsome of the NWSLâ€™s best playersaway from the league and country where they made their careers.Trans athletes did not factor into any one of these issues. And itâ€™s unlikely they will, regardless of whether Eddyâ€™s suggestions come to pass.Lesley Ryder is a writer and host covering womenâ€™s soccer in Chicagoland.Explore more on these topicsNWSLWomen's footballUS sportsTransgendercommentShareReuse this content

title: WTA Finals tennis: Sabalenka fends off Pegula; Gauff beats ailing Paolini â€“ as it happened | WTA Finals | The Guardian
description: Aryna Sabalenka dug deep to beat Jessica Pegula 6-4, 2-6, 6-3 while Coco Gauff cleaned up her service game to win 6-3, 6-2 against Jasmine Paolini
Author: Yara El-Shaboury
Headline: Aryna Sabalenka dug deep to beat Jessica Pegula 6-4, 2-6, 6-3 while Coco Gauff cleaned up her service game to win 6-3, 6-2 against Jasmine Paolini
Content: 13.34Â ESTGauff downs poorly Paolini while Sabalenka holds nerveDefending champion Coco Gauff kept her hopes alive of reaching the knockout stages of theWTA Finalswith victory over Jasmine Paolini.Defeat by fellow American Jessica Pegula in her opening group match in Riyadh had put Gauff in trouble but she eased to a 6-3, 6-2 win against Paolini.The Italian has been struggling with illness and again was unable to show her best level physically, with Gauff overcoming a wobble midway through the first set.The third seed said: â€œIâ€™m really happy with how I played today, definitely a turnaround from my first match. Itâ€™s the beauty of this tournament, you have another chance to prove yourself. Hopefully I can do well in my next one to give myself a chance to stay in this tournament.â€Paolini is eliminated having not won a set while Gauff is likely to need to beat world No 1 Aryna Sabalenka to give herself a chance of reaching the semi-finals.Sabalenka prevailed in a tough contest against Pegula to claim her second group match victory of the tournament.The Belarusian earned a straight sets win over Paolini in her opening game, but faced a tight battle against Pegula and eventually clinched a 6-4, 2-6, 6-3 victory.Of her opponent, Sabelenka saluted â€œan incredible player. She always pushed me to the limit... I was thinking, Iâ€™m gonna go after my shots, stay aggressive, put all of that speed back on her and hope that I get my chance.â€The US Open champion grew frustrated as she made 13 unforced errors, nearly twice as many as Pegula, as the American got two breaks to build a 5-2 lead before saving two break points to secure the second set.Sabalenka struggled with double faults as Pegula broke early in the third set. However, the world No 1 responded with returns near the sidelines to get two straight breaks, building a 4-2 lead that proved unassailable for Pegula.Sabalenka now has two wins in the Stefanie Graf Group and will face Gauff next, while Pegula comes up against Paolini.PA Media and ReutersShareUpdated at14.23 EST

title: Arsenal make it 10 wins in a row as they cruise past Slavia Prague with Merino double | Champions League | The Guardian
description: Arsenal took the lead through a Bukayo Saka penalty after a VAR review for handball before Mikel Merinoâ€™s two goals made it 3-0 against Slavia Prague
Author: Ed Aarons
Headline: Arsenal took the lead through a Bukayo Saka penalty after a VAR review for handball before Mikel Merinoâ€™s two goals made it 3-0 against Slavia Prague
Content: Mikel Merino scores Arsenalâ€™s second goal straight after half-time as they continued their unbeaten run in Europe this season.Photograph: Michael Zemanek/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenMikel Merino scores Arsenalâ€™s second goal straight after half-time as they continued their unbeaten run in Europe this season.Photograph: Michael Zemanek/ShutterstockChampions LeagueArsenal make it 10 wins in a row as they cruise past Slavia Prague with Merino doubleEd Aaronsat Fortuna ArenaTue 4 Nov 2025 14.56 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 17.23 ESTShareAnother game, another slew of records for Arsenalâ€™s defensive machine. This time it included one that stretched back more than 55 years, when Leeds were the last English team not to concede a goal in their opening four matches, in the 1969â€‘70 European Cup campaign, under Don Revie.A determinedSlavia Pragueside, that came into this game unbeaten in all domestic competitions, gave it their best shot and thought they had been awarded a late penalty, only for the referee to overturn his decision after the video assistant referee called him to the pitchside monitor. The Czech champions finally recorded a shot on target in stoppage time. It meant Arsenal made it eight successive clean sheets in all competitions for the first time since 1903, when they were in what was the Second Â­Division. A penalty from Bukayo Saka and two secondâ€‘half goals from the makeshift striker Mikel Merino sealed a 10th successive victory for Mikel Artetaâ€™s ruthless side.Tottenham v Copenhagen, PSG v Bayern Munich, and more: Champions League â€“ liveRead moreâ€œThe most pleasing thing probably is not the record, itâ€™s the mindset of the players. They are talking there about how we can still do better,â€ the delighted Arsenal manager said. â€œItâ€™s one or two situations where we could have resolved better. If we do that we can keep improving and that record will have a bigger meaning.â€There was also a special moment for Max Dowman as he became the youngest player inChampions Leaguehistory at 15Â yearsÂ 308Â days when he was brought on to replace the excellent Leandro Trossard with the points already firmly in the bag.â€œWhat heâ€™s done on the pitch, the first ball he takes, he takes people on, he starts to dribble, gets a foul,â€ Arteta said. â€œThatâ€™s personality, thatâ€™s Â­courage and you cannot teach that. You have it or you donâ€™t. It doesnâ€™t matter what his passport says. You throw him in this context and heâ€™s able to adapt.â€It has been to Arsenalâ€™s immense credit that they have maintained their winning run with so many attacking players missing through injury, with Viktor Â­GyÃ¶keres becoming the latest when he limped offagainst Burnley on Saturday. There are fears that the Sweden striker has injured a hamstring but it is hoped he could return with Gabriel Â­Martinelli and the captain, Martin Ã˜degaard, in time for the north London derby againstto play Tottenham after the international break.View image in fullscreenBukayo Saka scores from the penalty spot in the first half against Slavia Prague.Photograph: Petr David Josek/APIn the meantime, Merino was back in the role that he filled so Â­admirably last season and showed he has lost none of his sharpness in front of goal with two well-taken finishes. Â­Christian NÃ¸rgaard performed well in place of the suspended MartÃ­n Â­Zubimendi and Piero HincapiÃ© and Ethan Nwaneri also impressed on rare starts as Arteta rotated his squad.Jindrich Trpisovsky, the Slavia manager, is an experienced character who has won four league titles and he rated Arsenal beforehand as one of the best teams his side have faced, as well as describing Declan Rice as the best freeâ€‘kick taker in the world.However, it was the hosts who made the more encouraging start as Arsenal were unsettled by their allâ€‘action pressing game, with 6ftÂ 6in Czech international striker Tomas Chory providing a stiff physical test for their defence. Gabriel MagalhÃ£es needed treatment for a facial injury midway through the first half but there was never any chance of him coming off.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toFootball DailyFree daily newsletterKick off your evenings with the Guardian's take on the world of footballEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionSaka finally tested Jakub Â­Markovic in the Slavia goal after 25 minutes after powering into the area and a corner from Rice almost sneaked in at the near post. Another Saka shot was just as close and Gabriel was able to make first contact on the resulting corner, with the VAR spotting that Lukas Â­Provodâ€™s left arm had been in an unnatural position when he blocked the Brazilianâ€™s goalbound header. Saka made light of the protestations from the home supporters behind the goal and stepped up to coolly give Arsenal the lead.Slavia Prague 0-3 Arsenal: Champions League â€“ live reactionRead moreSlavia thought they should have had a penalty as well just before the break for handball by HincapiÃ© but this time the referee from Azerbaijan was not interested. Any hopes that they could find a way back into the game were dealt a major blow within 40 seconds of the restart. Rice picked out Trossard in acres of space and his cross was volleyed in emphatically at the near post by Merino. This was Arsenal at their clinical best.Merinoâ€™s second was a real Â­poacherâ€™s finish as he beat Â­Markovic to Riceâ€™s cross to loop his header into the empty net. And it has been some week for Dowman, who became the Â­youngest player to start a game for Arsenal in the Carabao Cup win against Brighton and has now surpassed Youssoufa Moukoko of Borussia Â­Dortmund and his record of 16 years and 18 days set in December 2020. He looked totally at home in these Â­surroundings and not even a late scare, when Ben White was penaliÂ­sed for a high boot before the VAR intervened again, could stop Arsenal on another perfect evening.Explore more on these topicsChampions LeagueSlavia PragueArsenalEuropean club footballmatch reportsShareReuse this content

title: Van de Ven stunner inspires 10-man Spurs to emphatic win over Copenhagen | Champions League | The Guardian
description: Brennan Johnson scored the opener and was later sent off in Tottenhamâ€™s 4-0 home Champions League win against Cogenhagen
Author: David Hytner
Headline: Brennan Johnson scored the opener and was later sent off in Tottenhamâ€™s 4-0 home Champions League win against Cogenhagen
Content: Micky Van de Ven shows his delight after scoring a sensational solo goal for Spurs.Photograph: Alex Morton/Tottenham Hotspur FC/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenMicky Van de Ven shows his delight after scoring a sensational solo goal for Spurs.Photograph: Alex Morton/Tottenham Hotspur FC/ShutterstockChampions LeagueVan de Ven stunner inspires 10-man Spurs to emphatic win over CopenhagenDavid Hytnerat Tottenham Hotspur StadiumTue 4 Nov 2025 17.04 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 18.56 ESTShareIt was the moment when the Tottenham home crowd could forget about their recent frustrations and lose themselves in the joy of it all; the glorious release. Their team had been too good for Copenhagen, who showed virtually nothing â€“ certainly not in a positive sense.Spurs were 2-0 up after Wilson Odobertâ€™s goal but there was a glitch when Brennan Johnson, who had opened the scoring, was sent off in the 57th minute. The foul on Marcos LÃ³pez was more clumsy than sinister yet when the referee, Erik Lambrechts, was advised to go to the pitchside monitor, Johnsonâ€™s involvement was over.Mac Allister sinks Real Madrid to ruin Alexander-Arnoldâ€™s return to LiverpoolRead moreEnter Micky van de Ven. The centre-half has becomesynonymous with the swashbucklingand he was at it again when he seized possession on the edge of his own penalty box and started to motor. It was a blur as he left four Copenhagen players in his wake, twisting initially to get through the first couple but picking up an inexorable head of steam when he straightened up.Nobody was going to catch him and there was an inevitability, too, about the finish once he got to the edge of the other area, the ball lashed home left-footed past the hapless Copenhagen goalkeeper, Dominik Kotarski. Spurs have their goal of the season already and it was possible to wonder whether it might compete for the more prestigious individual prizes in this area. There were shades ofSon Heung-min versus Burnleyin 2019 â€“ and that one won the Puskas award.It was Van de Venâ€™s sixth goal of the season and it set Spurs up for a confidence-boosting win, one that took them to eight points from four unbeatenChampions Leagueties. JoÃ£o Palhinha, on as a substitute, added the fourth and they could even shrug off a late penalty miss from another replacement, Richarlison, his shot bouncing down off the crossbar and away.Were the crowd unhappy he took the kick rather than Dane Scarlett, another substitute, who had won it? The pre-match theme had been the ability of those fans to become a little vexed. There were boos for Richarlison as he prepared to step up. But this was not a night for those sort of musings, rather one to celebrate.Xavi Simons needed a performance and delivered; it was just a shame that he was withdrawn after Johnsonâ€™s dismissal, Thomas Frank sending on Palhinha. Johnson was good, too, before the red card and if Randal Kolo Muani missed a couple of sitters, he redeemed himself with a fine assist for Odobert.Spurs had been desperate for something on their own turf, the match framed by the horror of the Premier League defeat hereagainst Chelsea on Saturdayand everything that went with it â€“ the continuation of the dismal home league form, the negativity of the fans, a furious Van de Ven blanking Frank at full time, as did Djed Spence. â€œMicky can keep walking past me if heâ€™s angry after a game,â€ Frank said with a smile. â€œIt seems like we had Lionel Messi turned into Micky.â€View image in fullscreenBrennan Johnson takes the ball past Dominik Kotarski before giving Spurs a first-half lead.Photograph: David Klein/ReutersSpurs made the breakthrough in the 19th minute; the start of a more enjoyable occasion for them. Johnson had blown an early half-chance with a poor first touch but he got everything right when he darted in behind a couple of Copenhagen defenders and was found by a lovely curved ball from Simons.Copenhagen had been caught on a quick transition after Gabriel Pereira misplaced a simple pass. Worse was to come as Johnson surged onto the ball, Kotarski bolting from his line; a race he was never going to win. Johnson touched around him and finished from a tight angle.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toFootball DailyFree daily newsletterKick off your evenings with the Guardian's take on the world of footballEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. If you do not have an account, we will create a guest account for you ontheguardian.comto send you this newsletter. You can complete full registration at any time. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionCopenhagen lag fourth in the Danish Superliga, six points behind the leaders, Aarhus. They arrived in London with a single point from their previous three Champions League ties. In short, all is not well with them. Their threat was minimal and there was too much looseness. They struggled sorely to build up against the Spurs press.Simons sniffed out spaces from the No 10 role; his turns were sharp, he probed with menace. He created two huge chances for Kolo Muani towards the end of the first half, which the on-loan Paris Saint-Germain striker fluffed. First, after Simons had worked a slick give-and-go with Odobert, Kolo Muani dragged wide from close range. And then, following a perfect Simons cross, he headed over when unmarked from six yards.Copenhagen had issues all over the pitch but they began in goal and Spursâ€™s second also had Kotarskiâ€™s prints on it. He looked odds on to get out to a long ball only he was so slow, offering Kolo Muani hope. The Spurs player kept running and he was able to make the block, the ball spinning high towards the empty neat. Whereupon Kolo Muani brought it down with a sumptuous touch before teeing up Odobert.The red card for Johnson never threatened to derail Spurs. If anything, they were more menacing with 10 men, counterattacking in waves, Copenhagen completely losing their way. Johnsonâ€™s challenge looked worse on the relays but he did catch LÃ³pez down the achilles with his studs. It led to Frank withdrawing Simons, who could not suppress his unhappiness. The scene was set for Van de Ven.Explore more on these topicsChampions LeagueTottenham HotspurFC CopenhagenEuropean club footballmatch reportsShareReuse this content

title: Champions League roundup: Two-goal Luis DÃ­az sent off as Bayern edge PSG | Champions League | The Guardian
description: Luis DÃ­az scored twice and saw red in the first half as Bayern Munich maintained their 100% winning record this season against Paris Saint-Germain
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Luis DÃ­az scored twice and saw red in the first half as Bayern Munich maintained their 100% winning record this season against Paris Saint-Germain
Content: Luis DÃ­az scythes down PSGâ€™s Achraf Hakimi after scoring twice for Bayern Munich.Photograph: Christophe Petit-Tesson/EPAView image in fullscreenLuis DÃ­az scythes down PSGâ€™s Achraf Hakimi after scoring twice for Bayern Munich.Photograph: Christophe Petit-Tesson/EPAChampions LeagueChampions League roundup: Two-goal Luis DÃ­az sent off as Bayern edge PSGDÃ­az shown straight red for scissor challenge in 2-1 winJuventus held by Sporting, AtlÃ©tico see off Union SGReutersTue 4 Nov 2025 18.24 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 19.12 ESTShareBayern Munichmade it 16 wins from 16 games this season to underline their credentials as earlyChampions Leaguefavourites, beating the holders,Paris Saint-Germain, 2-1 away as Luis DÃ­az scored two goals and was shown a red card.The Colombia winger struck twice before being sent off for a violent tackle on Achraf Hakimi on the stroke of half-time.Van de Ven stunner inspires 10-man Spurs to emphatic win over CopenhagenRead morePSG, who reduced the arrears through JoÃ£o Neves, dominated possession after the break but failed to make it fully count and slipped to their first defeat in the competition since last seasonâ€™s quarter-final second leg against Aston Villa.The result kept Bayern top of the 36-team league on a maximum 12 points, with PSG third, three points adrift and with more injury concerns after Hakimi and Ousmane DembÃ©lÃ© were replaced early.â€œItâ€™s always hard to lose at home. We need to assert ourselves and play better. We faced a well organised team, especially physically. We couldnâ€™t get our game going,â€ the PSG captain, Marquinhos, said.PSG, who had beaten Bayern 2-0 in the Club World Cup quarter-finals in July, came out flying with their trademark high pressing but were caught cold in the fourth minute when DÃ­az smashed home after Lucas Chevalier had parried Michael Oliseâ€™s effort.DembÃ©lÃ© thought he had levelled midway through the half only for his goal to be ruled out for offside, as PSG pressed but looked unusually fragile at the back.Bayern stayed a step ahead and, after Serge Gnabry struck the post, DÃ­az pounced on a sleepy Marquinhos to steal the ball and slot home a second in the 32nd minute.View image in fullscreenLuis DÃ­az scores his and Bayernâ€™s second after picking Marquinhosâ€™s pocket.Photograph: Matthieu Mirville/DPPI/ShutterstockDÃ­azâ€™s evening ended abruptly just before half-time when he was shown a straight red for a brutal lunge on Hakimi, who limped off in tears with a suspected ankle injury.Neves reduced the arrears with a scissor kick and came close to levelling a few minutes later with a header.Juventusare still without a win in the competition after they were held to a 1-1 draw in Turin bySporting, when Maximiliano AraÃºjo put the visitors ahead and Dusan Vlahovic equalised for the hosts.An eight-game winless run in all competitions led to the recent sacking of the Juventus coach Igor Tudor and, after two victories on the bounce since then, another draw in Europe, this time under Luciano Spalletti, put the Italian side on three points from four matches.Sporting, who move on to seven points, went in front in the 12th minute when Francisco TrincÃ£o played the ball wide to AraÃºjo who drilled a low shot off the far upright and into the bottom corner.Vlahovicâ€™s glancing header from the edge of the six-yard box was saved by Rui Silva. The Serbian had another effort parried away for a corner, and was rewarded in the 34th minute when he toe-poked Khephren Thuramâ€™s pin-point pass to the net.In Athens, Ricardo Pepi scored in stoppage time forPSV Eindhovento secure a 1-1 draw withOlympiakosand deny the Greek club a first win in the Champions League this season. Pepi stuck away a rebound from a free-kick three minutes into stoppage time after Olympiakos had led from the 17th minute through Gelson Martins.AtlÃ©tico Madridearned a 3-1 home victory againstUnion Saint-Gilloise,with goals from JuliÃ¡n Alvarez, Conor Gallagher and Marcos Llorente keeping Diego Simeoneâ€™s side in the hunt for qualification.The result leaves AtlÃ©tico 14th in the league-phase standings on six points from four matches, level with five other teams, while the Belgium champions, Union Saint-Gilloise, sit 26th with three points and outside the qualification spots.AtlÃ©tico struck first in the 40th minute when Giuliano Simeone burst up the right channel and put it on a plate for his Argentina teammate Alvarez to unleash an unstoppable half-volley from inside the box.View image in fullscreenConor Gallagher finds a way through the bodies to score for AtlÃ©tico Madrid against Union Saint-Gilloise.Photograph: ShutterstockAtlÃ©tico came off the break livelier and finally found their second goal in the 72nd minute when Gallagher fired a bullet strike from inside the boxUnion Saint-Gilloise refused to go quietly, cutting the deficit in the 81st minute whenRoss Sykes leaped high to unleash a towering header into the bottom left corner. The goal set up a nervy finish for the hosts who finally managed to score again when Llorente made it 3-1.TheMonacostriker Folarin Balogun got the only goal of the game as the French side grabbed a 1-0 win atBodÃ¸/Glimt, with Jostein Gundersen sent off for the home side for a badly mistimed tackle late on.The Norwegian side won the first-half possession battle but went behind in the 43rd minute when Balogun ghosted in behind the defence and slammed a shot into the top corner from a tight angle.With the rain pouring down, Bodoâ€™s evening went from bad to worse when the defender Gundersen was shown a red card for a clumsy stamp on the ankle of Mika Biereth in the 81st minute that left the Monaco substitute writhing on the ground in pain.That effectively ended any chance of a comeback and Monaco held on comfortably for a win that moves them to 18th in the table on five points, while their hosts slip to 27th spot with two points from a pair of draws in their first two games.NapoliandEintracht Frankfurtplayed out a goalless draw at the Stadio Diego Armando Maradona, with Antonio Conteâ€™s team at least stopping the rot defensively after shipping six goals to PSV in the previous round of fixtures.Explore more on these topicsChampions LeagueEuropean club footballnewsShareReuse this content

title: Anxious Aston residents prepare for Villaâ€™s match against Maccabi Tel Aviv | Aston Villa | The Guardian
description: Residents and business owners living around Aston Villaâ€™s stadium have expressed anxieties before the clubâ€™s Europa League match against Maccabi Tel Aviv
Author: Neha Gohil
Headline: Residents and business owners living around Aston Villaâ€™s stadium have expressed anxieties before the clubâ€™s Europa League match against Maccabi Tel Aviv
Content: A Palestine flag in the wind at Trinity Road, Birmingham, near Villa Park.Photograph: John Robertson/The GuardianView image in fullscreenA Palestine flag in the wind at Trinity Road, Birmingham, near Villa Park.Photograph: John Robertson/The GuardianAston VillaAnxious Aston residents prepare for Villaâ€™s match against Maccabi Tel AvivMaccabi fans banned from attending Europa League gamePro-Palestine rally planned in Aston on ThursdayNeha GohilTue 4 Nov 2025 15.17 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 16.43 ESTShareResidents and business owners living around Aston Villaâ€™s stadium have expressed anxieties before the clubâ€™s Europa League match againstMaccabi Tel Avivon Thursday.More than 700 police officers will be deployed, along with police horses, police dogs and a drone unit, with protests expected by different groups, West Midlands police said.Chelsea have Â£150m buffer against fines from FA, say football finance expertsRead moreThis comes weeks after Birminghamâ€™s Safety Advisory Group announced its decisionto ban Maccabi fans from attendingon public safety grounds after police classified the match as â€œhigh riskâ€, sparking controversy.The decision was criticised by some as a surrender to antisemitism, with calls for the ban to be overturned. Keir Starmer called it the â€œwrongâ€ decision and the opposition leader, Kemi Badenoch, said it was a â€œnational disgraceâ€.On the streets of Aston, and close to the Villa stadium, lamp-posts are covered with Palestinian flags and some local businesses display posters of a rally scheduled on Thursday in support of Palestine and calling for Israel to be suspended from Uefa and Fifa.Abul Lase, who owns an accountancy firm in Aston, said someone had approached him to ask whether they could display the poster in his window. He agreed, although he has no plans to attend the protest.â€œThereâ€™s a lot of anxiousness around here,â€ Lase, 50, said. â€œFor me, I donâ€™t want [the match] to happen. But local people donâ€™t want it to happen â€“ a lot of them because [of what is happening in] Palestine right now. You probably see a lot of Palestine flags here, so you see the feelings for it.â€Afsar Miah, an Aston resident, said he was going to attend the pro-Palestine protest on Thursday, and that the match should not go ahead due to â€œsocial issuesâ€.Miah, like Lase, said the Maccabi fans had caused â€œtroubleâ€ in other countries. â€œIn Holland, they played. These sort of fans, theyâ€™re causing problems.â€According to West Midlands police, the fixture on Thursday was classified as â€œhigh riskâ€ based on current intelligence and previous incidents, including â€œviolent clashes and hate crime offencesâ€ that occurred aroundthe 2024 Europa League matchbetween Ajax and Maccabi Tel Aviv in Amsterdam.View image in fullscreenAbul Lase has put up a poster for the pro-Palestine rally in the window of his accountancy firm but does not intend to attend himself.Photograph: John Robertson/The GuardianYehuda Fink, the managing director of Stand With Us UK â€“ which describes itself as a â€œnon-partisan Israel education organisationâ€ â€“ said the decision to ban Maccabi fans was â€œshocking and disappointingâ€.A petition to overturn the ban, set up by Stand With Us UK, now has more than 17,000 signatures. Fink said: â€œWe had I think within 72 hours over 10,000 people support the petition that the decision should be reversed, and a full explanation as to why that decision was made should be revealed.â€Jack Angelides, the chief executive of Maccabi Tel Aviv, described the ban as â€œunfairâ€ and told the BBC in October the team had travelled to places such as Turkey where the sentiment is â€œnot so kind towards Israeli teamsâ€, but the police â€œwere out in forceâ€ and there were no incidents.Shah Zaman, a 76-year-old Birmingham resident who was not previously aware of the ban on Maccabi Tel Aviv fans, said the decision by local authorities was wrong. â€œEverybody [has the] right to enjoy the game, whatever country is playing,â€ he said.View image in fullscreenShah Zaman said the decision to ban Maccabi Tel Aviv fans was wrong: â€˜Everybody [has the] right to enjoy the game, whatever country is playing.â€™Photograph: John Robertson/The GuardianLarissa Shaw, a 30-year-old Aston resident, said she was aware there was going to be a heightened police presence around the stadium on Thursday but that â€œthere always is when thereâ€™s anAston Villamatch onâ€.She believes the situation around the stadium may be â€œworse this timeâ€ owing to the ban on the fans. â€œIâ€™ve heard a few people say: â€˜Itâ€™s going to be bad, thereâ€™s going to be a lot of police.â€™â€West Midlands police declined to provide further comment.In a statement on Monday the Birmingham police commander, Ch Supt Tom Joyce, said: â€œWe are experienced at policing high-profile football matches and demonstrations, and for many weeks now, we have been working closely with different faith and local community groups to listen to their views and concerns.â€œOur goal throughout planning for this match is to ensure people can enjoy the football fixture while we continue to keep everyone in Birmingham safe, facilitate peaceful protest and maintain the Kingâ€™s peace.â€Explore more on these Brandon Thomas-Asante added a third at the end to secure a ninth win of the season.The defeat made it three in a row for Chris Wilderâ€™s side following losses to Preston and Derby, meaning United stayed in the relegation zone.Football Daily | Wolves, Saints and the baffling choices made in the search for stabilityRead moreThe Bladesâ€™ opener came midway through an end-to-end first half when Ben Mee got ahead of Victor Torp and glanced Sydie Peckâ€™s corner into the path of McCallum to sidefoot home from close range.Shortly after the break, Milan van Ewijkâ€™s long throw broke for Sakamoto, who drilled his effort into the bottom corner to score for the third game in succession.Frank Lampardâ€™s side were ahead on the hour mark when Torpâ€™s hanging corner was nodded in by Thomas, who claimed his second of the season. Then, as time ran out for the visitors, Haji Wright broke the offside trap and squared for Thomas-Asante to tap in.Lewis Baker scored twice asStokebrushed asideOxford3-0 at the Kassam Stadium to move up to second. title: Chelsea have Â£150m buffer against fines from FA, say football finance experts | Chelsea | The Guardian
description: Revelation may make points deduction or suspension from competition over Abramovich-era breaches more likely
Author: Rob Davies
Headline: Revelation may make points deduction or suspension from competition over Abramovich-era breaches more likely
Content: Chelsea's former owner Roman Abramovich sold the club to Clearlake for Â£2.5bn in 2022.Photograph: Martin Meissner/APView image in fullscreenChelsea's former owner Roman Abramovich sold the club to Clearlake for Â£2.5bn in 2022.Photograph: Martin Meissner/APChelseaChelsea have Â£150m buffer against fines from FA, say football finance expertsRevelation may make points deduction or suspension from competition over Abramovich-era breaches more likelyRob DaviesTue 4 Nov 2025 13.09 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 15.14 ESTShareChelsea FC would be unaffected by any financial penalty foralleged breaches of Football Association (FA) rulesduring the Roman Abramovich era, football finance experts have said, after corporate filings revealed its owners have a Â£150m cushion against the cost.Clearlake, a consortium led by the US investor Todd Boehly,agreed to pay Abramovich Â£2.5bn for Chelsea in 2022, shortly after the Russian oligarch was sanctioned by the UK government over his links to Vladimir Putin.The FA has sincecharged the club with 74 rule breachesrelated to payments to agents during Abramovichâ€™s tenure. Deals under the spotlight, highlighted in a2023 investigation by the Guardian and international media partners, include the transfers of star players Eden Â­Hazard, Willian and Samuel Etoâ€™o.On Tuesday, Fordstam Limited, the corporate vehicle that housedChelseaFC during Abramovichâ€™s tenure, revealed that it does not expect to receive Â£150m of the proceeds from the sale of the club.It said this was owing to a â€œholdback amountâ€, a clause inserted into the takeover deal by BlueCo 22, the subsidiary through which Clearlake bought the club.As a result of the clause, a portion of the total payment is withheld for five years, to cover the cost of â€œany proceeding in relation to events which took place before the acquisition date, up to a value of Â£150mâ€, accounts for 2022 show. The figure is higher than the Â£100m buffer that had previously been reported.View image in fullscreenTodd Boehly led the consortium that took ownership of Chelsea in 2022.Photograph: Rafal Oleksiewicz/PAFordstamâ€™s accounts reveal for the first time that it has written off the prospect of receiving the sum from Chelseaâ€™s new owners, owing to â€œdoubts about its recoverabilityâ€.Sources close to Chelsea said such a clause was not unusual in buyouts of companies and that it also covered costs such as lost revenues during a period when sanctions against Abramovich meant Chelsea could not sell tickets or merchandise.But football finance experts said Fordstamâ€™s admission that it does not expect to receive the holdback amount could indicate that a sporting sanction on Chelsea â€“ such as a points deduction or suspension from competition â€“ is more likely than previously thought.â€œThereâ€™s a question mark there as to why the size of the provision is so big,â€ said the football finance expert and lawyer Stefan Borson.â€œThe holdback amount will not just indemnify any financial penalty from a fine. It may also cover claims for consequential losses from any sporting sanctions, such as a loss of a European place or [Premier League] merit payments.â€Borson added that the scale of the holdback amount meant that Chelsea and Clearlake would feel limited impact from a fine.â€œThereâ€™s no penalty for the football club at all if the sanctions are purely financial and all are effectively recovered from the sale proceeds to Fordstam,â€ he said.Kieran Maguire, an associate professor in football finance at the University of Liverpool and the co-host ofThe Price of Football podcast, said: â€œIt [any fine] has effectively been taken into consideration in the offer price for the club.â€œThe club will physically have to pay the penalty, so there would be a financial consequence, but the owners can in theory put an extra Â£150m into the club and be no worse off than if theyâ€™d paid the full agreed sum of Â£2.5bn.â€Chelsea FC has previously raised funds byselling its womenâ€™s team to BlueCo 22.The club has indicated that it expects to receive a financial penalty from the FA, if found to have breached the rules. Spokespeople for Chelsea have highlighted the fact that it self-reported some transactions to the FA, Premier League and Uefa, after analysing Abramovich-era data.If Chelsea are guilty over Abramovich payments a fine would make a mockery of the rules | Rob DaviesRead moreFordstamâ€™s results, filed at Companies House, also reveal the huge fees banked by executives and lawyers involved in the sale.Eugene Tenenbaum, a longtime associate of Abramovich, received a Â£4.8m bonus from Chelsea FC for his role in the takeover, the accounts show. BlueCo 22 covered the cost of Â£41.6m in legal fees incurred by Fordstam, according to the documents.The accounts also confirm that the Â£2.35bn proceeds of the deal are still frozen in a bank account, three years after Abramovich pledged to donate the sums to people affected by the conflict in Ukraine.The UK has said it isprepared to sue Abramovichto release the money. Fordstamâ€™s accounts state that discussions with the Treasury â€œcontinue â€¦ in this regardâ€.In theory, the sum could be reduced by Â£1.5bn, the value of an interest-free loan that Fordstam owes to Camberley International Investments, an offshore financing entity that was used by Abramovich tochannel funds from multibillion pound oil deals into Chelsea.However, repayment of the loan could only be approved by the Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation, a division of the Treasury. The oligarch has also pledged to write off the loan.The Guardian has approachedRoman Abramovichand Chelsea FC for comment.Explore more on these topicsChelseaRoman AbramovichnewsShareReuse this content

Content: Nick Kyrgios will play womenâ€™s No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in the latest Battle of the Sexes tennis match to be played in Dubai in December.Photograph: Joel Carrett/AAPView image in fullscreenNick Kyrgios will play womenâ€™s No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in the latest Battle of the Sexes tennis match to be played in Dubai in December.Photograph: Joel Carrett/AAPTennisNick Kyrgios to play womenâ€™s No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in Battle of the Sexes clashAustralian tennis star to meet Belarusian in December in Dubaiâ€˜Iâ€™m not just here to play, Iâ€™m here to entertain,â€™ says KyrgiosAustralian Associated PressTue 4 Nov 2025 18.15 ESTShareNick Kyrgios, Australian former Wimbledon finalist, is to play womenâ€™s world No 1Aryna Sabalenkain an exhibition match in Dubai.The clash evokes memories of the 1973 Battle of the Sexes match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs â€“ which King won in straight sets in the Houston Astrodome and was later the subject of a Hollywood movie.Kyrgios also follows Australians Margaret Court, Evonne Goolagong Cawley and Pat Cash in playing such a match.WTA Finals tennis: Sabalenka fends off Pegula; Gauff beats ailing Paolini â€“ as it happenedRead moreThe exhibition, to take place on 28 December, was confirmed by both players on social media. It is likely to be played under modified rules including Kyrgios being restricted to a single serve.â€œWhen the world No 1 challenges you, you answer the call. Iâ€™ve got massive respect for Aryna; sheâ€™s a powerhouse and a true champion,â€ said Kyrgios, who shares an agent with Sabalenka.â€œBut Iâ€™ve never backed down from a challenge, and Iâ€™m not just here to play, Iâ€™m here to entertain. This is what I live for.â€View image in fullscreenAryna Sabalenka at the WTA Finals.Photograph: Robert Prange/Getty ImagesKyrgios, 30, has barely played in recent years after being plagued by injuries and is currently ranked 652nd in the world.He was in the top 20 in October 2022 when he was forced to withdraw from the quarter-final of the ATP 500 Tokyo Open with a left knee injury.He has since played six matches, winning one, losing four and retiring in the other. He last played on the ATP Tour at the Miami Open in March.â€œI have a lot of respect for Nick and his talent, but make no mistake, Iâ€™m ready to bring my A-game,â€ Sabalenka, 27, has said of the match.The Battle of the Sexes match came after Riggs, then 55 and a long-retired tennis pro, beat Court in May 1973.Court, who won the Australian, French and US Open titles that year, lost 6-2 6-1 in what was later dubbed the â€œMotherâ€™s Day Massacreâ€.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toSport in FocusFree weekly newsletterSign up to Sport in FocusEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. Content: Emily Fox: â€˜With the game and with our national team thereâ€™s just this buzz of excitement.â€™Photograph: Eurasia Sport Images/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenEmily Fox: â€˜With the game and with our national team thereâ€™s just this buzz of excitement.â€™Photograph: Eurasia Sport Images/Getty ImagesMoving the Goalposts newsletterUSA women's football teamâ€˜Thereâ€™s this buzz of excitementâ€™: Emily Fox on USWNT and Arsenal ambitionsRight-back discusses Emma Hayesâ€™s tactical messages, new blood in the national team and how Champions League win changed herMegan SwanickTue 4 Nov 2025 08.37 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 10.03 ESTShareEmily Fox made her 68th appearance for the United States in the first of two recent friendlies against Portugal and the Arsenal right-back has been a steady hand for Emma Hayes.Hayes has her eye on the 2027 World Cup afterwinning Olympic gold15 months ago, and has used 2025 to evolve and evaluate the pool of players. The 27-year-old says: â€œI feel like every camp there is a huge learning that weâ€™re taking out of it, whether thatâ€™s on the field or even culturally off the field. I think Emma and her staff are really good at that. So even though we didnâ€™t have a major tournament this year, it still felt like there was a lot of growth, a lot of change, a lot of new people getting chances and opportunities.â€Whereas in 2024 Hayes took hold of a programme two months before winning the gold medal, 2025 has allowed the former Chelsea manager more time to work on the teamâ€™s identity and refine tactics. According to Fox, Hayes has focused on the way they adapt. â€œI think really just being tactically flexible and aware and understanding that with a lot of opponents, they come out one way against one team, and then when they play us they play differently. And having that tactical ability to recognise that on the field, and then being able to talk to your teammates and collectively, as well as individually, make those changes on the fly.â€More experienced players such as Fox have provided an essential spine of continuity to a team evolving around them. Thanks to injuries, retirements and myriad other causes, Fox was one of only a handful of players who started the gold-medal match in Paris and the first friendly of this past window. For Fox, itâ€™s important to focus on the teamâ€™s principles as they adjust. But the impact of evolving the team with the younger generation is exciting: â€œWith the game and with our national team thereâ€™s just this buzz of excitement. And I feel like with younger players, they want to see their opportunities. They want to make the most of it. They want to have fun. They want to enjoy it. I think thereâ€™s definitely this level of confidence and creativity that they all want to show, which is really exciting.â€View image in fullscreenEmily Fox says the US were reminded of the importance of â€˜getting our tackles in, bumping, blocking, being aggressiveâ€™.Photograph: Lev Radin/ShutterstockIn 2025, the USWNT lost three times in calendar year for the fifth time. They were beatenby Portugalfor the first time on 23 October but reading too much into that, as well as defeats against Japan and Brazil, would be unwise. They have come in a transitional year when Hayes has prioritised integrating new personnel and experimenting. The overarching importance of this year will be the lessons it provides for 2026.A few days after losing to Portugal in Pennsylvania, the USWNT adjusted their tactics and lineup and beat the same opponents 3-1. Fox says of Portugalâ€™s first showing: â€œI thought they had a lot of patience and that they trusted their gameplan, and they executed it in turn.â€ Echoing Hayes, Fox said the 113 days between their previous friendly and that loss to Portugal had them looking a bit rusty, which was a learning for the team as well.View image in fullscreenEmily Fox (right) says winning the Champions League with Arsenal â€˜added a whole other depth to meâ€™.Photograph: Zed Jameson/PAâ€œI think with us having not seen each other in like four or five months, and then with Portugal being our first game, I think it was a really good lesson also in the sense of how aggressive and physical we need to be, and really non-tactical stuff like getting our tackles in, bumping, blocking, being aggressive. Because I also think with Portugal, theyâ€™re very savvy in the way that they foul and the way that they play the game within the game.â€Fox moved to London nearly two years ago to grow her game and experience it across the pond. The Virginia native has frequently emphasised the appeal of playing in the Champions League as inspiration for her move and last May shewon it with Arsenal. Fox says the experience expanded her perception of the things she was capable of: â€œâ€‹â€‹I feel like it added a whole other depth to me. Last year we had to do all the qualifying rounds going into the Champions League to even be a part of it. And so that started right on the Olympics, and it was so challenging. I mean, the whole Champions League was so challenging. I think at the end of the Champions League, and even through it, I was like: â€˜Look, Iâ€™ve been through this. I can get through this.â€™â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toMoving the GoalpostsFree weekly newsletterNo topic is too small or too big for us to cover as we deliver a twice-weekly roundup of the wonderful world of womenâ€™s footballEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. But Arsenal are no strangers to coming back from defeats to win things or to making a statement as a dark horse. This is how they rode their way to Champions League glory and Fox says: â€œItâ€™s time to turn it around and to come back and make a statement. I mean, thatâ€™s very much my mentality.â€Get in touchIf you have any questions or comments about any of our newsletters please emailmoving.goalposts@theguardian.com.This is an extract from our free weekly email, Moving the Goalposts.
