title: Victor Conte, architect of infamous sport steroids scandal, dies aged 75 | Drugs in sport | The Guardian
description: Victor Conte, who sold undetectable steroids to elite athletes, has died aged 75
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Victor Conte, who sold undetectable steroids to elite athletes, has died aged 75
Content: Victor Conte holds up a signed photo of Marion Jones, with a dedication â€œTo Victorâ€, in his office in 2003.Photograph: Paul Sakuma/APView image in fullscreenVictor Conte holds up a signed photo of Marion Jones, with a dedication â€œTo Victorâ€, in his office in 2003.Photograph: Paul Sakuma/APDrugs in sportVictor Conte, architect of infamous sport steroids scandal, dies aged 75Balco boss revealed Marion Jones used growth hormonesConte served four months in prison over involvementAssociated PressTue 4 Nov 2025 05.33 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 07.46 ESTShareVictor Conte, the architect of a scheme to provide undetectable performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes including the baseball stars Barry Bonds and Jason Giambi and the Olympic track champion Marion Jones decades ago, has died. He was 75.The federal governmentâ€™s investigation into a company Conte founded, the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative (Balco), yielded the convictions of Jones, the elite sprint cyclist Tammy Thomas and the formerNFLdefensive lineman Dana Stubblefield, along with coaches, distributors, a trainer, a chemist and a lawyer.Conte, who served four months in federal prison for dealing steroids, talked openly about his former clients. He went on television to say he had seen the three-time Olympic medallist Jones inject herself with human growth hormones, but always stopped short of implicating Bonds, the San Francisco Giants slugger.Quick GuideHow do I sign up for sport breaking news alerts?ShowDownload the Guardian app from the iOS App Store on iPhone or the Google Play store on Android by searching for 'The Guardian'.If you already have the Guardian app, make sure youâ€™re on the most recent version.In the Guardian app, tap the Menu button at the bottom right, then go to Settings (the gear icon), then Notifications.Turn on sport notifications.Was this helpful?Thank you for your feedback.The investigation led to the book Game of Shadows. A week after the book was published in 2006, Major League Baseballâ€™s commissioner, Bud Selig, hired the former senate majority leader George Mitchell to investigate steroids.Conte said he sold steroids known as â€œthe creamâ€ and â€œthe clearâ€ and advised on their use to dozens of elite athletes, including Giambi, a five-time major league All-Star, the Mitchell report said.â€œThe illegal use of performance-enhancing substances poses a serious threat to the integrity of the game,â€ the Mitchell report concluded. â€œWidespread use by players of such substances unfairly disadvantages the honest athletes who refuse to use them and raises questions about the validity of baseball records.â€Mitchell said the problems did not develop overnight. He said everyone involved in baseball in the prior two decades â€“ including commissioners, club officials, the playersâ€™ association and players â€“ shared some responsibility for what he called â€œthe steroids eraâ€.View image in fullscreenThe San Francisco Giantsâ€™ Barry Bonds hits his 700th career home run off the San Diego Padres pitcher Jake Peavy in September 2004.Photograph: Jeff Chiu/APThe federal investigation into Balco began with a tax agent digging through the companyâ€™s trash. Conte wound up pleading guilty to two of the 42 charges against him in 2005 before a trial. Six of the 11 convicted people were ensnared for lying to grand jurors, federal investigators or the court.Bondsâ€™ personal trainer Greg Anderson pleaded guilty to steroid distribution charges stemming from his Balco connections. Anderson was sentenced to three months in prison and three months of home confinement.Bonds was charged with lying to a grand jury about receiving performance-enhancing drugs and went on trial in 2011. Prosecutors dropped the case four years later when the government decided not to appeal to the supreme court against an overturned obstruction of justice conviction.A seven-time National League MVP and 14-time All-Star outfielder, Bonds ended his career after the 2007 season with 762 homers, surpassing the record of 755 that Hank Aaron set from 1954-76. Bonds denied knowingly using performance-enhancing drugs but has never been elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.Bonds did not respond to an email seeking comment.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toThe RecapFree weekly newsletterThe best of our sports journalism from the past seven days and a heads-up on the weekendâ€™s actionEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. If you do not have an account, we will create a guest account for you ontheguardian.comto send you this newsletter. You can complete full registration at any time. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionConte told the Associated Press in a 2010 interview: â€œYes, athletes cheat to win, but the government agents and prosecutors cheat to win, too.â€ He also questioned whether the results in such legal cases justified the effort.Conteâ€™s attorney, Robert Holley, did not respond to an email and phone call seeking comment. Snac System, the company that announced Conteâ€™s death, did not respond to a message sent through the companyâ€™s website.After serving his sentence in a minimum security prison he described as â€œlike a menâ€™s retreat,â€ Conte got back in business in 2007 by resuscitating a nutritional supplements business he had launched two decades earlier called Scientific Nutrition for Advanced Conditioning (Snac) System. He located it in the same building that once housed Balco in Burlingame, California.View image in fullscreenVictor Conte holds up one of the drugs he sold, at his office in Burlingame in 2003.Photograph: Paul Sakuma/APConte remained defiant about his central role in doling out designer steroids to elite athletes. He maintained he simply helped â€œlevel the playing fieldâ€ in a world already rife with cheaters.To Dr Gary Wadler, a then-member of the World Anti-Doping Agency, Conte may as well have been pushing cocaine or heroin. â€œYou are talking about totally illegal drug trafficking. You are talking about using drugs in violation of federal law,â€ Wadler said in 2007. â€œThis is not philanthropy and this is not some do-gooding. This is drug dealing.â€Explore more on these topicsDrugs in sportAthleticsBaseballCyclingMLBNFLUS sportsnewsShareReuse this content

title: Andrew Wiggins: how a shy NBA player negotiated growing up a star in the social media era | NBA | The Guardian
description: In an extract from his new book on the rise of Canadian basketball, Oren Weisfeld examines the pressures of being a teenage star in the modern game
Author: Oren Weisfeld
Headline: In an extract from his new book on the rise of Canadian basketball, Oren Weisfeld examines the pressures of being a teenage star in the modern game
Content: Andrew Wiggins played a huge part in the Golden State Warriorsâ€™ title in 2022.Photograph: Elsa/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenAndrew Wiggins played a huge part in the Golden State Warriorsâ€™ title in 2022.Photograph: Elsa/Getty ImagesNBAAndrew Wiggins: how a shy NBA player negotiated growing up a star in the social media eraIn an extract from his new book on the rise of Canadian basketball, Oren Weisfeld examines the pressures of being a teenage star in the modern gameOren WeisfeldTue 4 Nov 2025 05.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 05.02 ESTShareAndrew Wiggins was among the first superstar prospects of the social media era. Born in Thornhill, Ontario just north of Toronto, Wiggins was known internationally by the time he was 13. It wasnâ€™t always easy for the shy, small-town kid to embrace the spotlight.After just one full season at Vaughan, Wiggins needed better competition than Canada could provide and moved on to Huntington Prep in Huntington, West Virginia â€” a relatively new prep school set in a small, blue-collar, sports-oriented college town near Kansas.The head coach, Rob Fulford, had been recruiting Wiggins since he was 13, at one point watching 24 consecutive CIA Bounce games in person. â€œWe developed a relationship with him,â€ Fulford said. â€œWe recruited him harder than anyone else.â€What stood out to Fulford was the same quality that would later get the young Wiggins in trouble, which was that everything he did looked so effortless. â€œHe could just dominate a game from a talent perspective,â€ Fulford says. â€œIt just was a clear difference between Andrew and everyone else.â€But there was nothing quiet about the show Wiggins was putting on the basketball court, as Huntington quickly became the most popular high school team in the country, going from having 50 fans at a regular home game prior to his arrival to packed gyms with over 1,000 fans there to see the Canadian high school phenom with their own eyes. â€œA lot of people just wanted to see him play,â€ Rathan-Mayes says. â€œWe tried to go and put on a show the best that we could every single night.â€7ft 4in (at least) of menace: the Victor Wembanyama Era is already here | Lee EscobedoRead moreBut being at the centre of the basketball universe didnâ€™t come naturally to the quiet kid from Vaughan. After all, shyness, like athleticism, runs in the Wiggins family: Wigginsâ€™s father, Mitchell Sr, said the reason it didnâ€™t work at his first college, Clemson, was that â€œI was so quiet, you couldnâ€™t get a whisper out of me.â€ While a track teammate of his mother, Marita, said, â€œShe was very quiet, still is very quiet and very unassuming.â€Unlike LeBron James, who was happy to engage with the media and put on a show for the crowd since being crowned â€œThe Chosen Oneâ€ as a teenager, Wiggins was soft-spoken and shy, preferring to pass the attention on to his teammates instead of beating his chest after a big dunk. Many people wanted Wiggins to be the version of an alpha athlete that they were used to seeing on TV, like James and Kobe Bryant. And that dissonance created a tension with the basketball media and certain segments of the fan base, who wanted more from Wiggins.â€œI think we all have a certain kind of perception of what we want a great athlete to look like,â€ his junior national team coach, Roy Rana, says. â€œWe want them to be fiery. We want them to be emotional. We want them to be extroverted. We want them to be demonstrative. Thatâ€™s not Andrew.â€The criticism picked up during Wigginsâ€™s second and final season at Huntington Prep when, in February of 2013, a Sports Illustrated article questioned his work ethic, suggesting that he only showed up in big games while lofting through less important ones. â€œAndrew Wigginsâ€™ work ethic and motor have yet to catch up to his athleticism and raw ability,â€ it read, bringing up examples of previous Canadian prospects whose careers stagnated as a result of poor decision-making or a lack of skill development. And it questioned the role models in his life, including his father, who was pushed out of theNBAfor cocaine use decades earlier.The day after the article came out, Wiggins dropped a career-high 57 points in a statement win. â€œI think it pissed him off,â€ Fulford says. â€œHe wanted to prove a point.â€â€œJust responding in a positive way,â€ Wiggins says. â€œNot saying anything, not â€¦ going on Twitter and saying anything â€¦ whenever you think you got something to say, just go on the court and do my thing.â€Wiggins compiled one of the most memorable campaigns in high school basketball history that season, averaging 23 points, 11 rebounds, three assists, and three blocks per game and winning the Naismith Prep Player of the Year and the Gatorade National Player of the Year awards, earning a trip to the McDonaldâ€™s All-American Game. After that, he left to go to the University of Kansas.But the spotlight didnâ€™t stop there. In fact, when Wiggins arrived at Kansas City International Airport in June of 2013, he emerged from the gate to find 15 fans waiting for his autograph after his itinerary had been posted on an online message board. When classes started, students began Twitter-stalking him, tweeting pictures of the back of his head in class and posting his whereabouts when he was spotted at local stores. Meanwhile, back home in Canada, Wiggins picked up the nicknames â€œMaple Jordanâ€ and â€œAir Canada,â€ and all of his Kansas games were broadcasted on the national TV network TSN.While all this might seem normal now, 2013 was the beginning of the social media era. And between the fans stalking him, the student sections taunting him at away games, and the rapidly expanding media landscape criticizing his every move, it was hard for Wiggins to feel comfortable. â€œWe talk about it sometimes, but he doesnâ€™t like talking about it. Thatâ€™s how bad it stresses him out,â€ his wife, Mychal Johnson, said at the time. â€œSometimes he doesnâ€™t know what to do.â€â€œIt was a lot,â€ Wiggins says now. â€œIt was a lot.â€Wiggins just wanted to be a normal kid. He happened to love basketball and be really good at it, but he wanted an average life away from the spotlight, playing Call of Duty after games and announcing his college decision without any media present. In fact, his Twitter bio used to read â€œJust a average kid trying to make it.â€But when he was asked about it during his freshman year at Kansas, Wiggins said, â€œI used to be an average kid, when I put that up. But that â€¦ was a while ago.â€Some of the criticism directed towards Wiggins was warranted. Even Fulford acknowledged that he was no gym rat â€“ that things came so naturally to Wiggins that he needed to fall in love with the process of improving if he was going to reach his ceiling. â€œI donâ€™t think at any point ever that anyone had to go tell Michael Jordan or Kobe Bryant to pick it up,â€ Fulford said.Wiggins quietly improved under head coach Bill Self at Kansas, averaging 17 points, six rebounds, two assists, one steal, and one block as a freshman for the No 2-ranked Jayhawks, who went 24-9 before losing in the second round of the NCAA tournament. He even set the Kansas freshman single-season scoring record with 597 points.Still, there were times that Self had to get on Wiggins to play harder or be more aggressive offensively, instituting a special rule at some practices that only Wiggins was allowed to shoot. â€œAndrew is the type of guy who could score 28, and youâ€™d say, â€˜Why didnâ€™t he score more?â€™â€ Self said. â€œCritics want him to do more. I understand that because the game comes so easy to him, itâ€™s so natural.â€Some of that on-court reticence came from the way Wiggins was raised, learning the game from his brothers and dad, who carved out a 20-year pro career as a defensive role player. â€œHis dad taught him how to play basketball the right way,â€ Reid-Knight says, noting that Mitchell Sr always harped on the importance of being selfless and making the right reads. â€œPlaying within your game and not forcing an action.â€After one season at Kansas, Wiggins declared for the 2014 NBA Draft and was selected first overall by the Cleveland Cavaliers â€“ a foregone conclusion since Wiggins was in 10th grade. What made the selection even more amazing was that his CIA Bounce teammate, Brampton native Anthony Bennett, went first overall to Cleveland the year prior, giving Canada back-to-back first overall picks for the first time ever.The 2014 NBA Draft also featured Canadians Tyler Ennis, Nik Stauskas, and Dwight Powell, giving Canada a record 12 NBA players. That year Canada overtook France as the second-most represented country in the league behind the United States â€“ a record it has held ever since.However, the best player in the world, James, returned to his hometown Cleveland in free agency that same summer. And before playing a single game in the NBA, Wiggins and Bennett were both traded to the rebuilding Minnesota Timberwolves in exchange for Kevin Love, making Wiggins the cornerstone of a franchise that had not been to the playoffs in 10 years. â€œI just gave in to it and figured Iâ€™d be good wherever I go,â€ Wiggins said. â€œThe whole thing has worked out. [Minnesota has] put me in a situation where I can grow a lot more than on the team that drafted me.â€Wiggins got off to a slow start in his NBA career before breaking out against the team that snubbed him, dropping 27 points in his first game against Jamesâ€™s Cavaliers. He followed it up with a stretch of six straight 20-point games, eventually becoming the first Canadian to win the NBA Rookie of the Year award after averaging 17 points, five rebounds, and two assists a game in 2014â€“15.While he never turned into the NBA superstar that many people had him pegged to become when he was a teenager, Wiggins went on to have an incredible career, spending five and a half seasons in Minnesota before getting traded to the Golden State Warriors in 2020. In the Bay, Wiggins became the third Canadian NBA All-Star and won an NBA championship as the teamâ€™s second-leading scorer in the 2022 NBA Finals, when he averaged 18 points and nine rebounds.But, for better or worse, the huge spotlight and unbalanced criticism that started to shine on Wiggins when he was a teenage phenom never left him, especially in Canada â€“ a basketball-crazed nation that was growing hungry for a superstar.As Wiggins once said, â€œI know I can never live up to expectations.â€This is an edited extract from The Golden Generation: How Canada Became aBasketballPowerhouse by Oren Weisfeld. Itâ€™s published by ECW Press for $19.95 (USD) wherever you get your books.Explore more on these topicsNBABasketballUS sportsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Jacoby Brissett steps up for Cardinals to sink Cowboys and end losing streak | NFL | The Guardian
description: Arizona won for just the second time in the past 18 games when Kyler Murray didnâ€™t take at least five snaps or sat out entirely
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Arizona won for just the second time in the past 18 games when Kyler Murray didnâ€™t take at least five snaps or sat out entirely
Content: Arizona Cardinals wide receiver Marvin Harrison Jr is lifted after his touchdown catch in the first half.Photograph: Richard Rodriguez/APView image in fullscreenArizona Cardinals wide receiver Marvin Harrison Jr is lifted after his touchdown catch in the first half.Photograph: Richard Rodriguez/APNFLJacoby Brissett steps up for Cardinals to sink Cowboys and end losing streakKyler Murray said to be not ready after foot problemsDallas fall to 3-5-1 as Arizona move to 3-5 with winAssociated PressTue 4 Nov 2025 02.05 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 11.42 ESTShareJacoby Brissett had a stock answer ready for the question of whether the Arizona quarterback has done enough to be the replacement, not just the fill-in, for Kyler Murray. The coach, Jonathan Gannon, barely had an answer at all. The Cardinals will worry about what appears to be a full-blown controversy later. For now, they will enjoy ending a five-game losing streak.Brissett threw for two touchdowns and ran for a score in another game with Murray sidelined by a foot injury, and the Cardinals beat theDallas Cowboys27-17 on Monday night. Brissett made his third consecutive start after the week began with expectations of Murray returning coming off the teamâ€™s open week.The Chiefs-Bills rivalry is incapable of producing a bad gameRead moreInstead, the Cardinals pivoted to Brissett, with Gannon saying Murray wasnâ€™t quite ready. Arizona (3-5) won for just the second time in the past 18 games in which Murray didnâ€™t take at least five snaps or sat out entirely. â€œNothingâ€™s changed,â€ Gannon said both times he was asked if Brissett had done enough to become the starter.The Cowboys (3-5-1) couldnâ€™t build on the momentum of Sam Williamsâ€™ blocked punt that was recovered in the end zone by Marshawn Kneeland, giving up long touchdown drives on Arizonaâ€™s next two possessions on either side of half-time to fall behind 24-7. Marvin Harrison had a career-high seven catches for 96 yards, including a four-yarder for the gameâ€™s first touchdown. Tight end Trey McBride had a 12-yard TD grab.After their punt block and recovery for a score, the Cowboys gave up an average of 10.8 yards on the next 15 Arizona plays, including consecutive 16-yard passes right after the Dallas TD and Michael Wilsonâ€™s 50-yard catch and run on the second play after half-time.The Cowboys easily reached the Arizona 7 with a first down on the gameâ€™s first possession, but came away with nothing when Dak Prescott was sacked on fourth down by Josh Sweat, who had two of the five sacks on the Dallas quarterback. Calais Campbell also had two in his 250th career regular-season game.Dallas, who lost consecutive games for the first time under their first-year coach, Brian Schottenheimer, totalled just three points on its first three drives inside the Arizona 25, leading to the 17-point deficit in the fourth quarter. The Cowboys could have closed to within 14 with a field goal on the first play of the fourth quarter, but Prescott threw incomplete to CeeDee Lamb on fourth-and-3. Dallas were 0 for 3 on fourth down.View image in fullscreenArizona Cardinals quarterback Jacoby Brissett throws a pass in the first half.Photograph: Julio Cortez/APâ€œWe were going to be aggressive all game,â€ Schottenheimer said. â€œThat was part of the deal. If I like the call, Iâ€™m going to go. I trust our offense. But we didnâ€™t make the plays tonight.â€The Cardinals lost Brissettâ€™s first two starts, but not because the 32-year-old veteran was ineffective. He was solid again, going 21 of 31 for 261 yards without an interception, giving him 860 yards, six touchdowns and one pick in three games without Murray.Murray â€“ the No 1 overall pick in 2019 â€“ is 9-0 at AT&T Stadium, with state championships as a high school quarterback, two Big 12 titles with Oklahoma and a pair of victories over the Cowboys. Well, Brissett is now 1-0 as a starter against Dallas.â€œI donâ€™t get into that stuff, man,â€ Brissett said when asked if he had done enough to replace Murray. â€œIâ€™m just trying to go out here and win games and be a good teammate. And do the best I can when I get my opportunities. Thatâ€™s all I can ask for.â€Commanders coach accepts blame for leaving Jayden Daniels in game before serious injuryRead moreThe last hope for the Cowboys ended with their second lost fumble. Javonte Williams had the ball ripped out as he was going down on a short catch with less than five minutes to go. Prescott had just one touchdown pass a week after having none as one of the leagueâ€™s best offenses was sluggish again. The scoring toss was a 5-yarder in the fourth quarter for Ryan Flournoyâ€™s first career TD.â€œWeâ€™ve got to figure out how we need to improve in all phases of the game,â€ said Prescott, who was 24 of 39 for 250 yards with a late interception on a desperation fourth-and-28 throw. â€œSpecial teams did a hell of a job getting us a touchdown, and that was the only spark I think in the game, especially in the first half.â€The Cardinals started the season 2-0 before losing five in a row by a total of 13 points. Gannonâ€™s first win as a head coach was against the Cowboys two years ago â€“ part of a 1-8 start.â€œIâ€™m looking at my watch, and I donâ€™t remember the last time we won,â€ Gannon said. â€œIt falls on me. At the bye, I was sitting in the shower, thinking about, â€˜How did I let this happen?â€™ Everybody in there takes that attitude.â€Explore more on these topicsNFLUS sportsDallas CowboysArizona CardinalsShareReuse this content

title: Rise of the â€˜porno-trollsâ€™: how one porn platform made millions suing its viewers | Pornography | The Guardian
description: A company called Strike 3, owner of Vixen and Tushy, has clogged US courts with lawsuits, mostly against porn watchers who feel shamed into settling privately
Author: Tarpley Hitt
Headline: A company called Strike 3, owner of Vixen and Tushy, has clogged US courts with lawsuits, mostly against porn watchers who feel shamed into settling privately
Content: Illustration: Guardian Design/Guardian Design; Source images via Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenIllustration: Guardian Design/Guardian Design; Source images via Getty ImagesPornographyRise of the â€˜porno-trollsâ€™: how one porn platform made millions suing its viewersA company called Strike 3, owner of Vixen and Tushy, has clogged US courts with lawsuits, mostly against porn watchers who feel shamed into settling privatelyTarpley HittTue 4 Nov 2025 07.18 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 09.14 ESTShareWhen 73-year-old Tom Brown*,a retired police officer from Seattle, received a letter from Comcast, he might have mistaken it for a broadband bill. Instead, it was a subpoena. He had been sued in federal court for illegally downloading 80 movies. Some of the titles sounded cryptic â€“ Do Not Worry, We Are Only Friends â€“ or banal, like International Relations Part 2. Others were less subtle: He Loved My Big Ass, He Loved My Big Butt, and My Big Booty Loves Anal.Brown, who had spent decades investigating sex crimes, claimed he had never watched any of them. His years â€œdealing with pimpingâ€, he wrote in a court filing, left him â€œwith no interest in pornographyâ€. He had been married for 40 years, he did not need to download Hot Wife, another title in the list. But the subpoena did not seem like something he could laugh off. It said he could face damages of up to $150,000 per movie â€“ as much as $12m for all 80 films. If he did not respond promptly, the letter said, Comcast would identify him to the plaintiff in the case: a company called Strike 3 Holdings.â€˜I didnâ€™t start out wanting to see kidsâ€™: are porn algorithms feeding a generation of paedophiles â€“ or creating one?Read moreStrike 3 is not a name that Brown, or most people outside the world of copyright law, would recognize. The Delaware-based corporation, formed in 2015, owns the intellectual property rights to a catalog of about 2,000 adult films, mostly made by Vixen Media Group, its porn production subsidiary. It had very little online footprint; no social presence to speak of. But its associates were better known. The company was co-founded by Greg Lansky, the French porn director whose recent pivot to the art world has yielded works such as Algorithmic Beauty,amarble reproductionof the Venus de Milo with breast implants taking a selfie.Lansky, a 42-year-old Parisian, was something of a celebrity in the adult industry, having formed Vixen, the production company behind some of the porn worldâ€™s most popular brands: Vixen, Slayed, Wifey, Milf-y, Tushy, Tushy Raw, Blacked, Blacked Raw. The studioâ€™s commitment to high-production value had attracted dozens of awards in adult media and write-ups from outlets outside it. How One Pornographer Is Trying to Elevate Porn to Art, read a Forbes profile of Lansky from 2017.View image in fullscreenGreg Lansky and adult film actors Vicki Chase, Teanna Trump, Riley Reid, Abigail Mac and Lena â€˜The Plugâ€™ Nersesian pose at Lanskyâ€™s Blacked, Tushy and Vixen studios booth at 2019 AVN Adult Entertainment Expo at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino on 23 January 2019 in Las Vegas, Nevada.Photograph: Ethan Miller/Getty ImagesLansky courted the press, branding himself as the â€œSteven Spielberg of pornâ€, and his company as a home for â€œfeminist, ethical pornâ€. His free videos regularly ranked among the most-viewed scenes on PornHub, pushing viewers towards a paid tier. And his websites, Lansky has said, follow the â€œsame business model as HBOâ€: premium subscription services, charging between $9.95 and $29.95 a month.What Lansky left out was that, since September 2017, Vixenâ€™s owners had been pursuing another revenue stream: filing thousands of boilerplate copyright lawsuits against individual â€œJohn Doesâ€ and collecting millions in settlement fees â€“ a mass litigation campaign one federal judge likened to â€œa hi-tech shakedownâ€.Brown, who was sued in November of 2017,numbered among Strike 3â€™s earliest targets. But in the eight years since, Strike 3 has become the most prolific copyright plaintiff in the country â€“ filing, bythe Guardianâ€™s analysis of Pacer data, more than 20,000 federal copyright cases since September 2017.[Strike 3] treats this Court not as a citadel of justice, but as an ATMJudge Royce C LamberthMore recently, Strike 3 has been in the news for a higher profile case: a $350m copyright lawsuit against Facebookâ€™s parent company Meta. Meta is a rare corporate defendant; the overwhelming majority of Strike 3â€™s suits are aimed at anonymous users across the country. Lansky, who sold his stake in Vixen Media in 2020, did not respond to multiple requests for comment, nor did a representative for Vixen Media Group. A spokesperson for Strike 3 declined to answer specific questions about its legal strategy, but provided a statement to the Guardian: â€œStrike 3 is a legitimate film studio, that has created award-winning content, distributed through paid subscription platforms,â€ she wrote, â€œand has resorted to litigation only when necessary to protect the livelihood [sic] and its paying subscribers from widespread piracy.â€Some judges are furious at just how many cases Strike 3 are filing. Armed with â€œhundreds of cut-and-pasted complaints and boilerplate discovery motions, Strike 3 floods this courthouse (and others around the country) with lawsuits smacking of extortionâ€, district judge Royce C Lamberth wrote. â€œIt treats this Court not as a citadel of justice, but as an ATM.â€The sheer number of lawsuits has spawned a cottage industry of defense attorneys looking to take on the John Doesâ€™ cases. â€œI see new ones popping up all the time,â€ said attorney Steve Vondran, who is something of an influencer in this community, having defended more than 500 Strike 3 cases. He answers questions on YouTube and LinkedIn like: â€œAm I going to lose my house?â€ or â€œWill I have to file for bankruptcy?â€Thousands of lawsuits follow a similar formula: Strike 3 claims to use a proprietary software called VXN Scan to track IP addresses that have downloaded porn they own. The software cannot identify the user beyond a rough geographic location, so Strike 3 files suit against an anonymous John Doe, and subpoenas their internet service provider (ISP) to unmask the user. The ISP in turn alerts the subscriber â€“ which is when most people find out they have been sued.These people are often keen to settle, being cheaper than litigation and the only way to ensure their anonymity.That was certainly the case for Ken Jones*, a 28-year-old mental health worker, who received his own subpoena earlier this year. (Jones was the only defendant out of the dozen the Guardian contacted who was willing to discuss his case on the record, and he agreed to do so only on the condition of anonymity and without specifics to his settlement agreement.) â€œI remember being terrified. I had no idea what to do,â€ he said. â€œMy mind kept going to the worst case scenario: life savings gone because of a few downloads. It felt unreal. I was unable to eat or sleep for some time.â€Though he maintained to the Guardian he had never seen any of their films, Jones decided to settle because â€œit was the quickest way to leave this in the pastâ€, he said.The â€œshame and tabooâ€ made â€œthe decision to fight the allegations a bit more challengingâ€.As Strike 3 tells it, these lawsuits are merely a defense against piracy. Its films, the company claims, â€œare among the most pirated content in the worldâ€ (though they did not provide data to support that claim).Critics see Strike 3 differently â€“the countryâ€™s leading â€œcopyright trollâ€, or a rightsholder who treats litigation as a business model, rather than a means of protecting their work. Strike 3 does not disclose how much it makes from lawsuits, but several defense attorneys who spoke to the Guardian estimated that the company makes millions each year. Though copyright law allows for statutory damages of up to $150,000 per film, in reality, most defendants pay about $750 per title, according to Vondran. But for several dozen titles, that can quickly become settlements that range between $20,000 and $30,000.â€œThey want usually, minimum, what I call â€˜five-figure settlementsâ€™: $10,000 or more,â€ Vondran said. â€œItâ€™s why I think they wait to get at least 24 movies before they sue you, because that takes them right into that zone.â€ Even if only half of their cases settle in a given year, Strike 3 could collect between $20m and $30m in fees.The rise of theâ€˜copyright trollsâ€™Copyright trolls, a category which many have argued includes Strike 3, have skirted much notice outside legal circles, in part because they are seen as a relic of a bygone era.The copyright troll emerged from the 2000s internet, when the proliferation of peer-to-peer sharing tools first gave the public unprecedented access to almost any copyrighted work â€“ be it My Little Pony Crystal Princess: The Runaway Rainbow(2006) orbootleg footage of the heavy metal Fuck Christ Tour â€˜93.Between 2003 and 2008, the Recording Industry Association of America responded by filing more than 35,000 lawsuits against music pirates. Their campaign focused more on deterrence rather than revenue, but they created a model others soon copied. By the new decade, the courts were inundated by a new kind of mass copyright litigation â€“ what law professor and part-time trolling historian Matthew Sag called, the â€œBitTorrent eraâ€, after the sharing protocol popularized by sites like the Pirate Bay.View image in fullscreenThe homepage of the Pirate Bay, the popular filesharing website.Photograph: FocusDigital/AlamyThese suits were perfectly legal; any copyright owner is entitled to sue for infringement. But between 2011 and 2014, several entities emerged as what Aaron Moss,author of the Copyright Lately newsletter, calls â€œfrequent flyersâ€â€“ plaintiffs who seemed more interested in a â€œsue and settleâ€ approach, rather than earnestly deterring pirates. Theserepeat litigants tended to come from struggling industries such as newspaper and independent movies (Voltage Pictures, the production company behind The Hurt Locker and later, Dallas Buyers Club,is notoriously aggressive for pursuing lawsuits against individual John Does).But the vast majority came from porn companies â€“ so many that the subset earned its own name: â€œporno-trollingâ€.[Most] reluctantly pay rather than have their names associated with illegally downloading porn ... For these individuals, resistance is futileJudge Otis WrightPorno-trolls had â€œdiscovered the nexus of antiquated copyright laws, paralyzing social stigma, and unaffordable defense costsâ€, Judge Otis Wright wrote in the opinion that coined the term. â€œThey exploit this anomaly by accusing individuals of illegally downloading a single pornographic video. Then they offer to settle â€“ for a sum calculated to be just below the cost of a bare-bones defense.â€ Most â€œreluctantly pay rather than have their names associated with illegally downloading pornâ€, he went on. â€œFor these individuals, resistance is futile.â€Porn was itself a struggling industry; the proliferation of free streaming sites cut into producersâ€™ profits. But the early porno-trolls seemed to stretch the bounds of what copyright law allowed. The bulk of these cases were represented by a firm called Prenda Law, many of whose clients, it turned out, did not exist.The firm, prosecutors later alleged, had ahabitof creating â€œshamâ€ porn companies with fake executives and suing on their behalf. (One of the â€œofficersâ€ of their supposed clients was in fact, per theLos Angeles Times, â€œthe unpaid caretaker of Steeleâ€™s cabin in rural Minnesotaâ€ who had been promoted to fake porn executive without his knowledge.) By 2016, partners at Prenda Law, John Steele and Paul Hansmeier, were arrested by federal authorities and charged on 18 counts of fraud, perjury, and money laundering. At times, the complaintalleged, Steele and Hansmeier went so far as to film low-budget porn themselves and upload it to torrent sites â€œin order to lure people to download the moviesâ€. Steele was eventually sentenced tofiveyears in federal prison; Hansmeier to14.Not every porno-troll went to such overtly illegal lengths. If Prenda Law invented the model, Malibu Media professionalized it. The most prolific of the porn plaintiffs, Malibu Media was the legal arm of softcore website X-Art, run by the pornographer couple Colette Pelissier and Brigham Field. The coupleâ€™s prolific caseload attracted national press and aprofilein the New Yorker.(The headline read: The Biggest Filer of Copyright Lawsuits? This Erotica Website.) In 2014, the couple had filed a third of all US copyright litigation that year: 1,300 infringement cases.By the end of the Obama administration, however, it seemed that copyright trolling had peaked. BitTorrenting was on the wane, as streaming platforms took over popular entertainment. Many of the biggest players seemed to burn out: the Prenda partners went to jail, and Malibu imploded into infighting. (In late 2016, Malibuâ€™s founders sued their own lawyer, Florida attorney Keith Lipscomb, for professional negligence and breach of fiduciary duty; the case was later dismissed). The era of copyright trolling appeared to be winding down. â€œFilesharing lawsuit numbers drop by more than half,â€ Ars Technicareportedthat year. Sag, the fieldâ€™s most-cited scholar, moved on to other research. â€œMy gut says that it has decreased in volume somewhat,â€ one IP attorney told me, â€œbut thatâ€™s just my gut feeling.â€But in reality, the field was merely changing shape. In 2017, a lawyer from the Lipscomb firm, which had led Malibu Mediaâ€™s copyright campaign, found a new job as general counsel at Vixen Media Group. Strike 3 filed its first copyright claim three months later. These days, bulk copyright cases still account for the majority of federal copyright filings; the field of participants has merely become more concentrated. According to Westlaw and Pacer data from the past three years, Strike 3 accounted for 50% of the federal copyright docketall on its own.I first heard about Strike 3 in September, when some legal clerk friends mentioned that nearly every judge on their circuit was handling a stack of Strike 3 cases â€“ which are now so consistent as to have become routine. One would be hard pressed to find a federal judge in America who has not encountered the porn company; in a 2022 article about intellectual property experience in the western district of Texas, for example, half of the justices explicitly cited Strike 3:Chief judge Orlando Garcia: â€œThe chief judgeâ€™s docket features a hefty amount of trademark and copyright work, particularly from a litigious porn studio, Strike 3 Holdings.â€Judge Fred Biery: â€œJudge Bieryâ€™s docket, like the chiefs, is full of copyright suits filed by Strike 3.:Judge Robert Pitman: â€œHis docket is likewise filled with cases from Strike 3.â€Judge Jason Pulliam: â€œJudge Pulliam â€¦ like several of his colleagues, has Strike 3 filing up a big portion of his intellectual property work.â€Judge Xavier Rodriguez: â€œAnd like some of his peers, he has faced a series of copyright suits from Strike 3.â€The vast majority of Strike 3â€™s cases are settled or voluntarily dismissed for undisclosed reasons. None of the lawyers I spoke to could name a single claim that had gone to trial, and according to Westlawâ€™s litigation analytics, no case ever has.Only 10 or so people have even tried â€“ one of them was Brown, the retired cop. Shortly after receiving his subpoena, he countersued the company for negligent emotional distress. He hired the intellectual property lawyer J Curtis Edmondson, a recurring figure on the Strike 3 circuit. Of the maybe 10 cases that â€œhave gone the distanceâ€, as he puts it, to litigate Strike 3â€™s allegations, Edmondson has represented all but one.Edmondsonâ€™s interest in litigating Strike 3 cases stems from the fact that, despite the companyâ€™s broad success in bringing copyright infringement claims, there remain several open questions about its methods. For one, IP addresses are notoriously fickle; it is easy to spoof an IP address through a virtual private network (VPN) or to use someone elseâ€™s address via malware that bypasses passwords. More to the point, as Mitch Stoltz, IP litigation director at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, puts it: â€œIn a lot of cases, many, many people are using the same IP address.â€ Any given address may be shared between roommates, colleagues or members of a family.The prevalence of shared IP addresses has yielded some high-profile misfires; in 2011, for example, a porn company called Hard Productions sued a grandma in her 70s for torrenting hours of hardcore. (The retired widow â€œdoesnâ€™t know what BitTorrent isâ€, SF Gatereported at the time, though she did live next to â€œa handful of young menâ€.) A few years later, the production company behind the 2014 Adam Sandler film The Cobbler sued an Oregon man for allegedly downloading the film multiple times. The defendant, it turned out, ran an adult foster care, and his internet was regularly accessed by his residents. The case, Cobbler Nevada v Gonzales, went up to the ninth circuit, which ruled that IP addresses alone were insufficient for identifying infringement. In order to state a claim, the justices wrote, the plaintiff had to allege â€œsomething moreâ€ â€“ some additional evidence to establish â€œa reasonable inference that a subscriber is also an infringerâ€.Brown found himself in a similar situation. As it turned out, the retired cop had an adult son who lived at home, who had not held a job in 10 years and lived with a social anxiety so absolute it prevented him from â€œtalking to strangersâ€ or driving, during which he would â€œconstantly worry about how other people on the road can run into meâ€. As a result, the son later wrote in a legal filing: â€œI rarely leave my house and spend most of the time in my own room.â€ As the case progressed, Strike 3 found their â€œsomething moreâ€ â€“ namely, the sonâ€™s profile on a uTorrent forum, where he wrote things such as â€œutorrent is a keeper.â€ But in this case, that was neither here nor there; they had sued Brown, not his son. Strike 3 quickly dropped the claims, and in 2020, a judge sided with Brown on his countersuit, affirming that he had not infringed any copyright and awarding him $47,777.26 in attorneyâ€™s fees. It remains the biggest victory any John Doe has notched against Strike 3, and yet for many critics, somewhat bittersweet.The black box suing softwareFor Edmondson, the real question at the heart of Strike 3â€™s cases, and others like it, concerns the detection software used to identify those downloading Vixenâ€™s porn videos. As part of a case, Strike 3 and its peers submit records that a given IP address is linked to specific downloads. But the software that produces those records is shrouded in mystery. â€œThe corporate entities, people, software, and processes relied upon to prove infringement,â€ Sag wrote, â€œare somewhat shadowy and opaque.â€And there are many reasons, Edmonson argues, to doubt their accuracy. When geolocation services cannot match an IP address with a specific location, as Vondran has noted, they may â€œrandomly assign addresses to a general locationâ€. In one prominent example from 2017, for example, Venice PI, the company that owns the copyrights to the Bruce Willis film Once Upon A Time in Venice, filed two suits against the same defendant: a 91-year-old man named Wilbur Miller who was not only deceased but had, as his widow attested, â€œsuffered from dementiaâ€ for at least five years, rendering him â€œboth mentally and physically incapable of operating a computerâ€.For a time, nearly every John Doe copyright case in the US claimed to use a suite of detection services based in Germany. These companies went by many names â€“ Guardaley, IPP International, Maverickeye UG, Excipio Gmbh or Crystal Bay Corp â€“ but they employed many of the same staff, filed many near-identical declarations in court cases, and seemed on the whole to be, per Sag, â€œessentially the same entityâ€. At the very least, they seemed to all be controlled by the same few people, though who those people were exactly was somewhat unclear. Crystal Bay Corp, for example, filed more than 500 declarations signed by an expert witness identified as â€œDarren M Griffinâ€ â€“ a man who, as Edmondson laterwrote, â€œis in fact a completely fictitious personâ€. (Griffin did, however, have two flesh-and-blood colleagues at Crystal Bay, who variously attested to work at Guardalay, IPP and Maverickeye.)We were all waiting to see ... What was their technology going to show?Steve Vondran, attorneyStrike 3 relied on these same services until 2018,when they debuted their own tracking software, VXN Scan. In legal filings, Strike 3 claims it functions much like a BitTorrent client â€“ downloading pieces of a given work from peers within the torrent network, and tracing those pieces back to the IP addresses seeding them. But Edmondson and others argue that the new detection tool, like its German predecessors, is a â€œblack boxâ€. As Edmondson put it: â€œNobody knows how it works.â€Because none of Strike 3â€™s cases have ever gone to trial, the company has never had to disclose the source code, or submit the software to closer scrutiny. In 2023, the Strike 3 legal community watched as one Florida defendant, a defense contractor and another Edmonson client, got closer than anyone ever had. After three years of litigation, a jury trial had been scheduled that spring. â€œWe were all waiting to see â€“ what was going to be the outcome?â€ Vondran recalled. â€œWhat was their technology going to show?â€ They never found out; on the eve of trial, the parties reached a confidential settlement.Strike 3â€™s critics may now get another chance. The companyâ€™s lawsuit against Meta, first filed in July, takes its copyright litigation to new heights, and a much larger target.The case emerged amid a flood of copyright lawsuits against the AI firms that now dominate the US economy. Meta and its peers have argued their use of copyrighted material is â€œtransformativeâ€, meaning it changes the original work enough to amount to fair use. But in a lawsuit filed by a group of authors, Meta emails revealed the company had torrented as much as 81.7 terabytes of pirated books and academic papers from such sites as Annaâ€™s Archive. (A district judge later ruled against the authors on procedural grounds, without determining if Metaâ€™s use of copyrighted work was lawful).The case prompted Strike 3 to examine its archive of recorded infringement, where it claims to have identified 47 different IP addresses owned by Meta. Strike 3 alleges that, over the course of years, Meta torrented at least 2,396 of its films for training artificial intelligence â€“ infringements which could, if proven, amount to $350m in damages.â€˜Would love to see her fakedâ€™: the dark world of sexual deepfakes â€“ and the women fighting backRead moreThe tech company is fighting the case â€“ filing a motion to dismiss last week that argued Strike 3 had failed to show that Meta â€œwas aware of the downloadsâ€ or â€œdirected this activityâ€. The motion instead pointed the finger at Strike 3â€™s more common target: â€œunidentified usersâ€ who downloaded porn for â€œprivate personal useâ€. In a statement to the Guardian, Strike 3â€™s spokesperson contested that characterization: â€œThis case is not about isolated personal activity,â€ she wrote. â€œThis complaint reflects coordinated, corporate-scale conduct and the unauthorized distribution of creative works across multiple networks and jurisdictions.â€)For Strike 3 defense lawyers, the larger case presents a new opportunity to scrutinize the porn firmâ€™s piracy detection practices because, according to the complaint, the company tracked Metaâ€™s downloads the same way they had the Doesâ€™: VXN Scan. If the case proceeds to trial, it may finally let the public look inside Strike 3â€™s black box.Strike 3â€™s spokesperson indicated they are keen to fight the case. â€œIf the Meta case represents anything, it is Strike 3â€™s belief in its company and confidence in its technology,â€ she wrote. â€œMeta will undoubtedly bring the most powerful legal team to bear, but that does not change the facts or the law.â€For Edmondson, the concern is the precedent it sets in a world where digital records are easy to falsify. â€œI kind of look 10 years into the future when it will be ridiculously easy to fabricate information,â€ he said. As he sees it, the courts should â€œtake a stand now, at the beginning of a case, as to whether the evidence is good evidence or notâ€, because in the future, â€œyou could just create that all using AI.â€*Using a pseudonym

title: The mind-boggling valuations of AI companies  | Technology | The Guardian
description: You try wrapping your head around a string of deals worth nearly $600bn
Author: Blake Montgomery
Headline: You try wrapping your head around a string of deals worth nearly $600bn
Content: Microsoft are building a datacenter in Wales.Photograph: Dimitris Legakis/Athena PicturesView image in fullscreenMicrosoft are building a datacenter in Wales.Photograph: Dimitris Legakis/Athena PicturesTechScape newsletterTechnologyThe mind-boggling valuations of AI companiesYou try wrapping your head around a string of deals worth nearly $600bnBlake MontgomeryTue 4 Nov 2025 10.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 11.33 ESTShareHello, and welcome to TechScape. Iâ€™m your host, Blake Montgomery. If you like reading our newsletter, forward this email to five friends with a demand they sign up like itâ€™s a chain letter warning of bad luck for five years. In this weekâ€™s news, AI companies hit mind-boggling financial milestones such as a $5tn valuation, a $100bn quarter, and a string of deals worth nearly $600bn.The AI boomâ€™s incomprehensibly vast numbers make it hard to criticizeLast week, the chipmaker Nvidia hit a valuation of $5tn. Just three months prior, it became the worldâ€™s first $4tn company. Microsoft reached a $4tn valuation last week, as did Apple. On a smaller scale, Meta, Microsoft, Amazon and Alphabet all reported their quarterly earnings. The sums were vast. Googleâ€™s parent reaped its first $100bn quarter. Amazon reported stellar growth in its cloud computing unit and added 13% to its stock price. Meta faced an unexpected tax bill of $16bn. All of the tech giants, except Apple, revised their capital expenditure figures upward, declaring to their investors that they would spend billions more on the real-world infrastructure that underpins artificial intelligence. The revisions added tens of billions to a total thatâ€™s already in the hundreds of billions. Alphabet alone estimated its capital expenditure at between $91bn and $93bn for the upcoming year. That estimate is up from an original declaration of $75bn in February and a revised figure of $85bn announced in July.Not to be outdone by its publicly traded rivals, OpenAI,recently converted to a for-profit enterpriseand mulled an initial public offering at a valuation of $1tn. The worldâ€™s most valuable startup has been on a dealmaking spree, signing agreements with Nvidia, which committed to investing $100bn in OpenAI in September; Microsoft, which signed an agreement in early October for OpenAI to spend $250bn on Azure cloud services; and Oracle, another cloud computing giant that OpenAI agreed to spend on in September, this time $300bn. On Monday, the ChatGPT-maker announced a deal with Amazon Web Services for $38bn. In total, OpenAI has promised to spend $588bn in the coming years.Nvidiaâ€™s valuation is now larger than Germanyâ€™s entire annual economic output in 2025 ($4.66bn). Put another way, the market capitalization of Nvidia is two and a half times the market capitalization of every publicly traded company in Germany put together, roughly $2.04tn in 2024, per the World Bank. How can one company be worth more than the worldâ€™s third largest economy, a nation of 83.5 million people, a country whose economy forms the financial backstop of an entire continent?Read more:Boom or bubble? Inside the $3tn AI datacentre spending spree | Artificial intelligence (AI) | The GuardianThe difficulty in comprehending the financials of the AI boom makes it difficult to criticize with clarity or force. What could I say to an avalanche? Even the most insightful analysis seems like it will be bowled over and crushed beneath the weight of a billion-dollar datacenter. All of these numbers buck understanding. There is nothing in your individual human life that you could compare them with. How would I spend $91bn? How would I make hundreds of billions of choices? Thinking about them feels bizarre. Describing Metaâ€™s earnings as â€œmixedâ€ is strange, though they were, by Wall Street expertsâ€™ estimates.The circular, multibillion-dollar deals between the companies atop the boom have given rise to fears of overinflated value and financial fragility. Should one company falter, it seems the others might follow suit and bring the US economy down with them. So far, they show no signs of stopping their joint rampage.View image in fullscreenAn Nvidia Blackwell GPU is displayed at Computex in Taipei, Taiwan, last year.Photograph: Ann Wang/ReutersOn the more populist side of that criticism are reports that AI has yet to find an essential use case other than cheating on homework assignments. It canâ€™t adequately replace workers, no matter how many of them a CEO might lay off. About 95% of AI pilots conducted in businesses to date have failed,MIT researchers foundin August.The financials of the AI boom are so enormous as to defy comprehension; its digital size is immense as well. Large language models such as ChatGPT, Claude Sonnet and others function in part via parameters, variables that define how the model makes predictions of what word should come next. These unseen knobs tweak the response number in the hundreds of billions, with some reports indicating GPT-5 might make use of a trillion of them.AIâ€™s physical imprint on the world matches the magnitude of the technologyâ€™s financial scale. Dara Kerr, one of the Guardianâ€™s technology reporters, visited the Tahoe-Reno Industrial Center, home to the largest data center in the US and several of its smaller siblings, on a reporting trip last week. Here she describes its unbelievable scale:The Tahoe-Reno Industrial Center stretches from Interstate 80 up into the dry Nevada desert mountains. The complex spans tens of thousands of acres and is home to nearly 200 companies, both for fulfillment and logistics operations and tech data centers. That includes Google, Microsoft and Tesla. Some businesses have several data centers, each multiple football fields long, that snake up the desert valleys. The industrial centerâ€™s landmass makes up 65% of the countyâ€™s territory. Itâ€™s so big, itâ€™s almost hard to comprehend.Should you buy that gadget?How do Appleâ€™s AirPods Pro 3 compare against hearing aids? If you do not have an account, we will create a guest account for you ontheguardian.comto send you this newsletter. You can complete full registration at any time. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionYou will be able to bet on US elections by giving money to the US presidentView image in fullscreenDonald Trump.Photograph: President Donald Trump via truth Social and ReutersDonald Trumpâ€™s Truth Social is partnering with Crypto.com on a feature for betting on election results, the parent company announced in apress releaselast week. The Trump Media and Technology group will introduce its â€œTruth Predictâ€ feature, which will allow users â€œto trade prediction contracts related to major events and milestones, such as political elections, interest and inflation rate changes, commodity prices on gold and crude oil, events across all major sports leagues, and moreâ€ using the new product, though when it will go live is unclear.Devin Nunes, TMTGâ€™s head, said of the feature: â€œFor too long, global elites have closely controlled these markets â€“ with Truth Predict, weâ€™re democratising information and empowering everyday Americans to harness the wisdom of the crowd, turning free speech into actionable foresight.â€ In classic Trumpian fashion, Nunes hypocritically gnashes his teeth at â€œglobal elitesâ€ from a perch high in the eyrie of US power.Something feels off about this arrangement, like if the boxer in the fight was also the bookie. Trump is the president of the United States and is asking his constituents to put money on the outcome of elections that he will be campaigning in. He is in control of the policies that can determine the rates users bet on. Though heâ€™s heading towards his two-term limit in the presidency, he hasflirted with an unconstitutional third term. Would US citizens bet on whether he can make it happen?Even the creation of the Truth Predict feature feels like inside basketball (more on that sport in the next paragraph). Crypto.com has donated $11m to Trumpâ€™s causes, theFinancial Timespoints out. The US Securities and Exchange Commission has closed an investigation during Trumpâ€™s term, and the company has applied for a banking charter with the regulator. Trump Media and Technology group signed a deal to buy billions of dollarsâ€™ worth of Cronos, Crypto.comâ€™s token.Gambling pervades US society more than ever. Trading on election outcomes was legalized just last year. Betting volumes on the prediction market Kalshi have reached $1bn per week, according to another Financial Times analysis. The infection began with sports betting, which has reached a fever pitch. My colleague Bryan Armen Graham describes the implications of scandal, dubbed Operation Nothing But Bet by FBI investigators, that rocked professional basketball in the week before Halloween, with an NBA player, a head coach and 30 others arrested:The NBA gambling scandal represents a culmination of the years-long embrace between professional leagues and the multibillion-dollar gambling industry that has now crossed the line from synergy into scandal. Itâ€™s the most significant corruption crisis to hit a major American league since betting was legalized in most US states, and the most revealing picture yet of how deeply gambling has fused itself into the bloodstream of professional sports.When will politics face its own version of Operation Nothing But Bet?The wider TechScapeNHS hospitals to test AI tool that helps diagnose and treat prostate cancerIn Grok we donâ€™t trust: academics assess Elon Muskâ€™s AI-powered encyclopediaUkrainian computer game-style drone attack system goes â€˜viralâ€™Character.AI bans users under 18 after being sued over childâ€™s suicideRevealed: Israel demanded Google and Amazon use secret â€˜winkâ€™ to sidestep legal ordersExplore more on these topicsTechnologyTechScape newsletterArtificial intelligence (AI)newslettersShareReuse this content

title: LOL: is this the ultimate texting faux pas (and what should you use instead)? | Mobile phones | The Guardian
description: From abbreviations to happy poos, gen Z has strong opinions on appropriate texting behaviour. But can anyone keep up with the ever-changing rules?
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: From abbreviations to happy poos, gen Z has strong opinions on appropriate texting behaviour. But can anyone keep up with the ever-changing rules?
Content: The cry-laugh emoji: preserve of the oldies only.Photograph: Posed by model; atomicstudio/Getty Images/iStockphotoView image in fullscreenThe cry-laugh emoji: preserve of the oldies only.Photograph: Posed by model; atomicstudio/Getty Images/iStockphotoPass notesMobile phonesLOL: is this the ultimate texting faux pas (and what should you use instead)?From abbreviations to happy poos, gen Z has strong opinions on appropriate texting behaviour. title: Apple Watch SE 3 review: the bargain smartwatch for iPhone | Apple Watch | The Guardian
description: Cut-price watch offers most of what makes the Series 11 great, including an always-on screen, watchOS 26 and wrist-flick gesture
Author: Samuel Gibbs
Headline: Cut-price watch offers most of what makes the Series 11 great, including an always-on screen, watchOS 26 and wrist-flick gesture
Content: The Apple Watch SE 3 fits modern chips and screen into an older design at a deep discount.Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The GuardianView image in fullscreenThe Apple Watch SE 3 fits modern chips and screen into an older design at a deep discount.Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The GuardianApple WatchReviewApple Watch SE 3 review: the bargain smartwatch for iPhoneCut-price watch offers most of what makes the Series 11 great, including an always-on screen, watchOS 26 and wrist-flick gestureSamuel GibbsConsumer technology editorTue 4 Nov 2025 02.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 02.02 ESTShareThe Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.Appleâ€™s entry level Watch SE has been updated with almost everything from its excellent mid-range Series 11 but costs about 40% less, making it the bargain of iPhone smartwatches.The Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.The new Watch SE 3 costs from Â£219 (â‚¬269/$249/A$399), making it one of the cheapest brand-new fully fledged smartwatches available for the iPhone and undercutting the Â£369Series 11and the top-of-the-line Â£749Apple Watch Ultra 3.The Watch SE line is updated only every few years and has been good value but was missingsome crucial thingsthat make Appleâ€™s other watches great. The Watch SE 3â€™s biggest upgrade is an always-on display, which brings it up to par with the Series line, allowing you to see the time and notifications at a glance without having to twist your wrist to turn the screen on.View image in fullscreenThe screen on and active with the flow watch face (left) and in its idle always-on position (right) with the time still visible.Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The GuardianThe SE 3 has the older Apple Watch design from 2020â€™sSeries 6with smaller screens, larger bezels and a choice of 40mm or 44mm case sizes compared with the current Series watches. The screen is also not quite as bright as the more expensive watches, but that is noticeable only in bright direct sunlight. It is still sharp and good looking.The SE 3 has the same S10 chip as the Series 11 and Ultra 3, and is just as responsive. It also has the same excellent touch-free gestures, including double tap and wrist flick, which allow you to dismiss notifications, timers and alarms easily.The watch also supports all the rest of the general Apple Watch features inwatchOS 26, including Apple Pay contactless payments, rich notifications, music control, third-party apps and a range of watch faces.View image in fullscreenThe SE 3 runs all the same apps and services as its more expensive siblings.Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The GuardianThe battery life of the SE 3 is a little shorter than the Series 11, lasting about a day and a half of general use, including sleep tracking overnight. Most will have to charge it every other day, particularly if they track any workouts. The SE 3 will last up to seven hours of running tracking with GPS and heart rate, which should be long enough for a marathon. A full charge using the magnetic puck takes about an hour, hitting 70% in 30 minutes.SpecificationsCase size:40mm or 44mmCase thickness:10.7mmWeight:about 26g or 33gProcessor:S10Storage:64GBOperating system:watchOS 26Water resistance:50 metres (5ATM)Sensors:HR (2nd-gen), skin temp, NFC, GNSS, compass, altimeterConnectivity:Bluetooth 5.3, wifi 4, NFC, optional 5GHealth and workout trackingView image in fullscreenThe SE 3 has the same crown and side button as the Series 11 but lacks the metal contacts on the back for taking ECGs.Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The GuardianOne of the biggest cuts for the SE 3 is the removal of the electrical sensor from the back of the watch, which enables electrocardiograms (ECG) of your heart on the Series and Ultra watches. It also lacks a blood oxygen sensor and hypertension monitoring but it still has an accurate optical heart rate sensor that covers most bases, including high and low heart rate notifications.The SE 3 also has a skin temperature sensor, which is used as part of theVitals app, the sleep tracking and forretrospective ovulation estimatesfor the cycles tracking app. The watch also does a good job of tracking general workouts, including walks, runs, cycles and other common sports and activities with its GPS.The watch also supports offline music playback via Bluetooth headphones, including from subscription services such as Spotify. And it has offline Apple Maps, should you get lost without your phone.SustainabilityView image in fullscreenThe recycled aluminium body is available in starlight (as pictured) or midnight (black).Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The GuardianApple says the battery should last more than1,000 full-charge cycleswith at least 80% of its original capacity and can be replaced forÂ£95. Repairs costbetween Â£195 and Â£229depending on the model.It contains more than 40% recycled material, including aluminium, cobalt, copper, glass, gold, lithium, rare-earth elements, steel, tin, titanium and tungsten. Apple offers trade-in and free recycling for devices, and breaks down the watchâ€™s environmental impactin its report.PriceThe Apple Watch SE 3 costs fromÂ£219(â‚¬269/$249/A$399) for the 40mm version orÂ£249(â‚¬299/$279/A$449) for 44mm.For comparison, theApple Watch Series 11costsÂ£369and theApple Watch Ultra 3costsÂ£749.VerdictTheApple WatchSE 3 is the best deal in Appleâ€™s smartwatch line this year, offering almost everything thatâ€™s great about the Series 11 but at a significantly cheaper price.The new always-on display, S10 chip and watchOS 26 make the SE 3 just as good day to day. The only meaningful feature you miss out on is the ability to take ECGs, but if you know you donâ€™t need it then thatâ€™s no loss. The 1.5-day battery life of the 40mm isnâ€™t too bad but the larger 44mm should last a little longer.The limited choice of colours is easily remedied with a bright strap, while the older design with smaller screens, larger bezels and a thicker body is easy to live with for the price.Pros:great value Apple Watch, always-on screen, Apple Pay, double-tap and wrist-flick gestures, decent health and fitness tracking, long software support, recycled materials, 50-metre water resistance.Cons:no ECG, no blood oxygen monitoring, no hypertension alerts, old design, only works with an iPhone, no third-party watch faces, screen not super bright in sunlight.View image in fullscreenThe new Exactograph face from watchOS 26 looks good on the 40mm Apple Watch SE 3.Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The GuardianExplore more on these topicsApple WatchAppleWearable technologySmartwatchesreviewsShareReuse this content

title: AI firm wins high court ruling after photo agencyâ€™s copyright claim | Intellectual property | The Guardian
description: Ruling in case brought by Getty Images against Stability AI is seen as a blow to copyright owners
Author: Robert Booth
Headline: Ruling in case brought by Getty Images against Stability AI is seen as a blow to copyright owners
Content: James Cameron, the Oscar-winning film-maker behind Avatar, is one of Stability AIâ€™s directors.Photograph: Joanne Mcarthur/The GuardianView image in fullscreenJames Cameron, the Oscar-winning film-maker behind Avatar, is one of Stability AIâ€™s directors.Photograph: Joanne Mcarthur/The GuardianIntellectual propertyAI firm wins high court ruling after photo agencyâ€™s copyright claimRuling in case brought by Getty Images against Stability AI is seen as a blow to copyright ownersRobert BoothUK technology editorTue 4 Nov 2025 06.54 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 15.24 ESTShareA London-based artificial intelligence firm has won a landmark high court case examining the legality of AI models using vast troves of copyrighted data without permission.Stability AI, whose directors include the Oscar-winning film-maker behind Avatar, James Cameron, successfully resisted a claim from Getty Images that it had infringed the international photo agencyâ€™s copyright.The ruling is seen as a blow to copyright ownersâ€™ exclusive right to reap the rewards of their work, with one senior lawyer, Rebecca Newman, a legal director at Addleshaw Goddard, warning it means â€œthe UKâ€™s secondary copyright regime is not strong enough to protect its creatorsâ€.There was evidence that Gettyâ€™s images were used to train Stabilityâ€™s model, which allows users to generate images with text prompts. Stability was also found to have infringed Gettyâ€™s trademarks in some cases.The judge, Mrs Justice Joanna Smith, said the question of where to strike the balance between the interests of the creative industries on one side and the AI industry on the other was â€œof very real societal importanceâ€. But she was only able to rule on relatively narrow claims after Getty had to withdraw parts of its case during the trial this summer.Getty Images sued Stability AI for infringement of its intellectual property, alleging the AI company was â€œcompletely indifferent to what they fed into the training dataâ€ and scraped and copied millions of its images.Boom or bubble? Inside the $3tn AI datacentre spending spreeRead moreThe judgment comes amid a row over how the Labour government should legislate on the issue of copyright and AI, with artists and authors including Elton John, Kate Bush, Dua Lipa and Kazuo Ishigurolobbyingfor protection. Meanwhile, tech companies are calling for wide access to copyrighted content to allow them to build the most powerful and effective generative AI systems.The government is consulting on copyright and AI and has said: â€œUncertainty over how our copyright framework operates is holding back growth for our AI and creative industries. That cannot continue.â€It is looking at whether to introduce a â€œtext and data mining exceptionâ€ into UK copyright law, which would allow copyright works to be used to train AI models in the UK unless the rights holder opts their works out of such training, said lawyers at Mishcon de Reya who have been following the issue.Getty had to drop its original copyright claim as there was no evidence the training took place in the UK. But it continued with its suit claiming Stability was still using within its systems copies of its visual assets, which it called the â€œlifebloodâ€ of its business. It claimed Stability AI had infringed its trademarks because some AI-generated images included Getty watermarks, and that it was guilty of â€œpassing offâ€.In a sign of the complexity of AI copyright cases, it essentially argued that Stabilityâ€™s image-generation model, called Stable Diffusion, amounted to an infringing copy because its making would have constituted copyright infringement had it been carried out in the UK.The judge ruled: â€œAn AI model such as Stable Diffusion which does not store or reproduce any copyright works (and has never done so) is not an â€˜infringing copyâ€™.â€ She declined to rule on the passing off claim and ruled in favour of some of Gettyâ€™s claims about trademark infringement related to watermarks.In a statement, Getty Images said: â€œWe remain deeply concerned that even well-resourced companies such as Getty Images face significant challenges in protecting their creative works given the lack of transparency requirements. We invested millions of pounds to reach this point with only one provider that we need to continue to pursue in another venue.â€œWe urge governments, including the UK, to establish stronger transparency rules, which are essential to prevent costly legal battles and to allow creators to protect their rights.â€Christian Dowell, the general counsel for Stability AI, said: â€œWe are pleased with the courtâ€™s ruling on the remaining claims in this case. Gettyâ€™s decision to voluntarily dismiss most of its copyright claims at the conclusion of trial testimony left only a subset of claims before the court, and this final ruling ultimately resolves the copyright concerns that were the core issue. We are grateful for the time and effort the court has put forth to resolve the important questions in this case.â€Explore more on these topicsIntellectual propertyMedia lawNews photographyArtificial intelligence (AI)newsShareReuse this content

title: Elon Muskâ€™s $1tn Tesla pay deal to be rejected by huge Norway wealth fund | Elon Musk | The Guardian
description: Carmakerâ€™s seventh biggest single investor will vote against package at annual shareholder meeting
Author: Lauren Almeida
Headline: Carmakerâ€™s seventh biggest single investor will vote against package at annual shareholder meeting
Content: Elon Muskâ€™s wealth could rise to more than $2tn if the Tesla pay package is agreed by shareholders.Photograph: ReutersView image in fullscreenElon Muskâ€™s wealth could rise to more than $2tn if the Tesla pay package is agreed by shareholders.Photograph: ReutersElon MuskElon Muskâ€™s $1tn Tesla pay deal to be rejected by huge Norway wealth fundCarmakerâ€™s seventh biggest single investor will vote against package at annual shareholder meetingBusiness live â€“ latest updatesLauren AlmeidaTue 4 Nov 2025 06.09 ESTFirst published on Tue 4 Nov 2025 04.42 ESTShareNorwayâ€™s sovereign wealth fund has said it will vote against a $1tn (Â£765bn) pay package for the Tesla chief executive,Elon Musk.The fund, which is the biggest national wealth fund in the world, said that while it appreciated the â€œthe significant value created under Mr Muskâ€™s visionary roleâ€ it would vote against his performance award.â€œWe are concerned about the total size of the award, dilution and lack of mitigation of key person risk â€“ consistent with our views on executive compensation,â€ it said. â€œWe will continue to seek constructive dialogue withTeslaon this and other topics.â€Boom or bubble? Inside the $3tn AI datacentre spending spreeRead moreThe warning from Norges Bank, which is the seventh biggest single shareholder in Tesla with a stake worth $17bn, comes two days before the carmaker hosts its annual shareholder meeting.On Thursday, investors will vote on proposals for anunprecedented incentive package that could make Elon Musk the worldâ€™s first trillionaire.If Musk increases the value of Tesla from about $1tn to $8.5tn over the next 10 years, Musk will receive new shares that would push his stake in the company from nearly 16% to more than 25%.This would increase the fortunes of the worldâ€™s richest man to more than $2tn.The Tesla chair, Robyn Denholm, has argued the vote is essential to retain the 54-year-old Musk as chief executive of the company, writing in a letter to shareholders that the company risks losing â€œsignificant valueâ€ if he were to leave.Last year, the Norwegian oil fund voted against what was then the biggest pay package in US corporate history of $56bn for Musk. The deal was approved by shareholders in June but wasrejected for a second time by a court in Delaware in December.Nicolai Tangen, the chief executive of the Norwegian fund, invited Musk and other chief executives to dinner in Oslo last year. However, Musk turned down the invite after the fund voted against the $56bn pay deal.A text exchange between Tangen and Musk was revealed in a freedom of information request by the Norwegian business publication DN. It reported that Musk wrote to Tangen in October last year: â€œWhen I ask you for a favour which I very rarely do, and you decline, then you should not ask me for one until youâ€™ve done something above nothing to make amends. Friends are as friends do.â€Shareholders are divided on the new deal, although two influential shareholder advisory groups â€“ Glass Lewis and ISS â€“ have both recommended that investors reject the $1tn package.Some big pension funds have also opposed the pay package, including the American Federation of Teachers and the California Public Employeesâ€™ Retirement System, the largest public scheme in the US.Musk, who is Teslaâ€™s biggest single shareholder, can also vote on the proposal.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toBusiness TodayFree daily newsletterGet set for the working day â€“ we'll point you to all the business news and analysis you need every morningEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionLast month, the Tesla boss said on X, the social media website he bought in 2022: â€œTesla is worth more than all other automotive companies combined. Which of those CEOs would you like to run Tesla? It wonâ€™t be me.â€Tesla has been trying to find ways to keep Musk as chief executive as it grapples with falling sales â€“ global vehicle deliveries fell 13% in the first half of the year. That was partly due to the disruption from the redesign of its popular Model Y car.The carmaker reported a 7% rise in its most recent quarter, as many US consumers rushed to buy electric cars before a $7,500 government purchase incentive ended in September. However, now these tax credits have expired, and the company faces a potential slowdown in its home market.Tesla sales have also been falling across much of Europe: new car registrations dropped 89% in Sweden, 86% in Denmark, 50% inNorwayand 48% in the Netherlands in October, according to local industry data.France was an outlier, where the company made a small gain in sales for the second month in a row.Meanwhile, data from the Chinese Passenger Car Association released on Tuesday, showed that shipments from its Shanghai factory continued to decline, with 61,497 units shipped in October, down about 10% compared with last year.Tesla was approached for comment.Quick GuideContact us about this storyShowThe best public interest journalism relies on first-hand accounts from people in the know.If you have something to share on this subject, you can contact us confidentially using the following methods.Secure Messaging in the Guardian appThe Guardian app has a tool to send tips about stories.
