title: â€˜Music is my remedyâ€™: how DJing is helping Ukraineâ€™s war veterans with their recovery | Electronic music | The Guardian
description: At the Superhumans centre in Ukraine, the EnterDJ music therapy programme teaches war-wounded soldiers how to mix, rehabilitating them with dance music and providing purpose and opportunities to perform
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: At the Superhumans centre in Ukraine, the EnterDJ music therapy programme teaches war-wounded soldiers how to mix, rehabilitating them with dance music and providing purpose and opportunities to perform
Content: Veteran Dmytro Melnik works with the EnterDJ system, as part of his rehabilitation.Photograph: Bohdan LozytskyView image in fullscreenVeteran Dmytro Melnik works with the EnterDJ system, as part of his rehabilitation.Photograph: Bohdan LozytskyElectronic musicâ€˜Music is my remedyâ€™: how DJing is helping Ukraineâ€™s war veterans with their recoveryAt the Superhumans centre in Ukraine, the EnterDJ music therapy programme teaches war-wounded soldiers how to mix, rehabilitating them with dance music and providing purpose and opportunities to performDarcie ImbertTue 4 Nov 2025 11.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 15.30 ESTShareInUkraine, sound carries a different weight: the cautionary blurt of sirens, Shahed drones humming overhead, the concussive thwack of air defence interception and the subsequent explosion. But as well as the sounds of war, which continue three and a half years into Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion, music still plays, clubs remain open during the day (closing well before the midnight curfew), and electronic dance music remains an intrinsic part of many Ukrainian lives.Kyivâ€™s iconic clubs,such as K41, became bomb shelters before transforming into frontline fundraisers. Parties doubling up ascleanup operationsare held at strike sites. New venues such asAbo Recordsâ€“ the first of many creative spaces to set up shop in an abandoned liquor factory â€“ have emerged as gathering points where you might share a cigarette with a sniper or combat medic as easily as with a DJ. But the rehabilitative power of dance music is most evident at the Superhumans centre, near Lviv in the west of Ukraine. Here, the most critically war-wounded are treated with prosthetics and reconstructive surgery, and psychological support is given to children and adults affected by the war. And within the range of treatment is music therapy.Howard Buffett, the son of Warren Buffett and one of the centreâ€™s chief funders, suggested forming a Superhumans band, so the centre teamed up with music charityVictory Beats, which was set up one year into the war to provide veterans with relaxation and a nonverbal outlet for emotional expression.â€œWe were working with a 25-year-old soldier with severe brain damage and limited use of his hand,â€ the charityâ€™s founder, Volodymyr Nedohoda, remembers. â€œWe started with a [sound-based] relaxation session designed to calm the nervous system, but stopped almost immediately because the low frequency triggered pain. When he started to feel better, he asked for a DJ console.â€If I go two days without playing music, thatâ€™s when the phantom pains and bad thoughts startRoman CherkasHaving witnessed the efficacy of electronic music as therapy firsthand, Negodada and Vlad Fisun â€“ a DJ and former editor-in-chief of Playboy Ukraine â€“ partnered to create theEnterDJprogramme, which teaches veterans the basics of mixing. All that users require is a laptop, headphones and an internet connection; some tune in from home, others show up to a dedicated space in the Superhumans centre. â€œImmersed completely in the process, playing track by track without paying attention to low or high frequencies, the soldier started to use his injured hand,â€ Negodada says. The patient remained with EnterDJ for the duration of his stay at Superhumans, and Negodada saw him perform a DJ set a year later: â€œHe still has health issues but remains passionate about DJing.â€Speaking with the same stoicism that underpins most of my conversations with Ukrainians, another veteran, Oleksandr, tells me about the incident that led him to Superhumans and EnterDJ. â€œI was serving in Poltava when a missile destroyed my leg,â€ he says. â€œI remember everything about it. The blast, phoning my commander to say I was alive, realising Iâ€™d have to drive an automatic car, worrying about the blood in my car after the evacuation.â€ He laughs at the absurdity, and continues. â€œIn hospital, I lost nearly all my blood and had to be resuscitated. I woke up knowing my leg was gone, but thankful the rest of my body and brain were OK. Thatâ€™s most important.â€View image in fullscreenOleksandr Ivanko performing.Photograph: Solomia GavrylyakFor Oleksandr, EnterDJ became a daily routine, â€œto get some good moments if the day was hard, or to celebrate if I gained something in rehabilitationâ€. Within six months, he was performing alongside the Lviv Philharmonic Orchestra, using a Midi controller to layer sounds over a composition written with British composer Nigel Osborne.Oleksandr had started off using singing bowls in a sound therapy session. â€œThen I saw the DJ console and it reminded me of my school days, trying to mix music on a laptop.â€ Before being fitted with a prosthetic leg, EnterDJ â€œhelped distract me from the trauma and rehabbingâ€, he says, holding his kind gaze steady. â€œI now listen more deeply, breaking music into parts for mixing, and even composing. We have composed ambient music for therapeutic purposes; I added electronic effects to live classical instruments. The audience relaxed deeply; some even fell asleep. So we met our goal!â€ Most recently, Oleksandr played for Prince Harry on a visit to Kyiv.EnterDJâ€™s students are encouraged to find their own DJ style. They are able to pull tracks from a catalogue of music donated by record labels across the world, including Lyonâ€™s Hard Fist, Sao Pauloâ€™s Tropicana, and Lisbonâ€™s Disco Extendes, as well as Ukrainian labels such as Mystictrax, 2064, Regulardisco, and Trance Pandemic.Roman Cherkas, who served in the Third Tank brigade in eastern Ukraine, has gravitated towards drumâ€™nâ€™bass. He joined the EnterDJ programme after months of surgeries, prosthetics and rehabilitation at the centre, after losing both of his lower limbs in a mortar strike. He speaks to me on a call from his home, ready with a drumâ€™nâ€™bass mix. â€œRight now, I still donâ€™t feel mobile, I canâ€™t move around normally. Music has become energy for me, life energy,â€ he says. â€œIf I go two days without listening or playing, thatâ€™s when the phantom pains, bad thoughts, and even depression start. For me, music is a normal task, my remedy.â€After six months in the programme, Roman performed in Lviv at a showcase by one of the worldâ€™s leading drumâ€™nâ€™bass labels, Hospital Records. He speaks slowly and thoughtfully about how music shifts his headspace. He becomes completely absorbed by it, sometimes sitting in his chair mixing for six-hour stretches. â€œI tried working with psychologists but it didnâ€™t work for me. You have to consciously switch your brain on and imagine lifting your legs, which is very difficult. With music, itâ€™s the opposite, it switches my mind automatically and makes me feel better.â€View image in fullscreenRoman Cherkas performs live.Photograph: Yury StefanyakOlga Rudneva, chief executive of Superhumans, is proud of how veterans who pass through Superhumans are performing on big stages, but underlines what she finds most important about the program: â€œPositive healing effects for patients; reduced phantom pain; positive mood and more socialisation.â€However, the EnterDJ programme is used not just by injured veterans but by children and adults across Ukraine, and its creators highlight its broader power. Chief executive Yevhen Skrypnyk introduced techno to his hometown of Sloviansk in eastern Donbas with Shum Rave(â€œshumâ€ meaning noise in Ukrainian), a party with the purpose to rebuild the city and its culture after liberation from Russian occupation back in 2014. â€œWe all grew up too early,â€ he says. â€œWe know what it means for a friend to die in the war, or what it means to wait for your friend in captivity. Iâ€™ve been in the events industry for more than 10 years, but it was never just about the party; itâ€™s about how we could connect people and destroy stereotypes. In Ukraine, we are fighting for our lives, and for our culture.â€Andreas Boesch, partnership curator at EnterDJ, agrees, saying that music and culture are the best means Ukraine has to fight against Russian propaganda. â€œItâ€™s an international language, it can be understood everywhere, by everyone. You can try and convince people of everything thatâ€™s happening here, but itâ€™s hard to touch them in a big way because theyâ€™re so far away and it can be difficult to understand. But with music, you can pass on greatness.â€Explore more on these topicsElectronic musicDance musicUkraineEuropeRussiaHealthHospitalsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: The art of the possible: the Nottingham art gallery being run by citizensâ€™ assembly  | Art | The Guardian
description: New Art Exchange believes it is first cultural institution in world to hand permanent leadership to the community
Author: Jessica Murray
Headline: New Art Exchange believes it is first cultural institution in world to hand permanent leadership to the community
Content: Saad Eddine Said, New Art Exchange chief executive and artistic director, left, and executive director Adam Roe in front of part of the galleryâ€™s Beyond the Wall Project, which commissioned murals to adorn surrounding buildings and walls.Photograph: Fabio De Paola/The GuardianView image in fullscreenSaad Eddine Said, New Art Exchange chief executive and artistic director, left, and executive director Adam Roe in front of part of the galleryâ€™s Beyond the Wall Project, which commissioned murals to adorn surrounding buildings and walls.Photograph: Fabio De Paola/The GuardianArtThe art of the possible: the Nottingham art gallery being run by citizensâ€™ assemblyNew Art Exchange believes it is first cultural institution in world to hand permanent leadership to the communityJessica MurraySocial affairs correspondentTue 4 Nov 2025 08.15 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 18.41 ESTShareâ€œI used to see this place on the street but I didnâ€™t know what was here, I didnâ€™t even know it was an art gallery,â€ says Felix, a 20-year-old nursing student. â€œAnd now Iâ€™m here shaping its future.â€Felix is one of 40 residents of Hyson Green inNottinghamwho run the show at New Art Exchange (NAE), which believes it is the first cultural institution in the world to hand permanent leadership to a citizensâ€™ assembly.These people, representative of a diverse community that speaks 52 languages, decide everything from what events the gallery should put on, to where money should be spent and what artists should be exhibited. They have allocated Â£285,000 in funding since starting out.View image in fullscreenAssembly member Rudy, 70, a volunteer support worker, making a point at a progress report meeting.Photograph: Fabio De Paola/The Guardianâ€œWithout citizens and community around the table shaping the direction and showing the horizon, we would quickly become an average organisation,â€ says Saad Eddine Said, chief executive and artistic director at NAE, which is the UKâ€™s largest gallery dedicated to African, Caribbean and south Asian artists.â€œThis neighbourhood is such a huge treasure of culture and of talent so we wanted it to play a key role, not just in terms of consultancy, but in real terms of coleadership.â€A street gallery outside the building, designed to entice people in, was removed after assembly members said it was intimidating and off-putting, and more money was invested in making the cafe a welcoming space that would bring people through the door instead.After reporting that a major problem in the area was a lack of places to socialise on a Friday evening, NAE started hosting socials, such as poetry and DJ events, which draw large crowds.â€œWe believe in [the assembly] and we donâ€™t want it to become just a trendy thing, just ticking boxes,â€ says Said. â€œRemoving the street gallery felt counterintuitive to us. But straight away that street gallery was in the bin, and in the bin for ever.View image in fullscreenThe cafe area at the New Art Exchange. The citizensâ€™ assembly made the cafe a welcoming space that would bring people through the door.Photograph: Fabio De Paola/The Guardianâ€œIt didnâ€™t matter whether we understood it. There is no compromise in that conversation.â€Adam Roe, the galleryâ€™s executive director, says: â€œIâ€™ve been asked: â€˜Do you think that youâ€™ve lost power as a result of this?â€™â€œActually, I think Iâ€™ve gained power. Collectively, weâ€™ve got so much more knowledge because weâ€™re doing the things we know we need to do.â€œAnd some of the artists and the performers we work with now we probably would never have known about before.â€Citizensâ€™ assemblies have long been used in local democracy and public policy to gauge national opinion, but in recent years they have spread into other sectors â€“ and cultural institutions are the latest to try using them.In August, the National Gallery announced it was creating a citizensâ€™ assembly of 50 people from across the UK who will make recommendations that will be built on by a smaller citizensâ€™ panel over the next five years.Birmingham Museum &ArtGallery recruited a citizensâ€™ jury in 2024 which published several recommendations, including later opening times and promoting the work of young people.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toArt WeeklyFree weekly newsletterYour weekly art world round-up, sketching out all the biggest stories, scandals and exhibitionsEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. If you do not have an account, we will create a guest account for you ontheguardian.comto send you this newsletter. You can complete full registration at any time. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionBut there is some scepticism about the effectiveness of these initiatives and over whether senior leadership teams consider them as anything more than a public engagement exercise.View image in fullscreenVisitors interacting with an exhibition by Heather Agyepong in the mezzanine gallery at the New Art Exchange.Photograph: Fabio De Paola/The Guardianâ€œLots of people were very sceptical and wondering whether anything would come of this,â€ says assembly member Lily, a 21-year-old fine art graduate, sitting alongside Rudy, a 70-year-old retired youth worker. â€œIâ€™m impressed theyâ€™ve actually done the things we said.â€Many of the assembly members said they were tired of seeing Hyson Green, which has some of the highest deprivation rates in the country, receive attention for all the wrong reasons â€“ crime, antisocial behaviour and fly-tipping.â€œIâ€™ve lived out here a long time, and I was sceptical, and I was cynical, because Iâ€™ve seen so many initiatives come and go,â€ says Kathy*, a retired resident.â€œThis area has been ignored and if people experience the negative for too long, it can disempower them. So for me, it has been a real boost. I feel invigorated by being part of this process.â€Said says the assembly was â€œhugely expensive and time consumingâ€ to set up, but has had a drastically positive impact â€“ overall engagement at NAE is up 22% and the number of visitors from global ethnic majority backgrounds has grown by 48%.He has nowdeveloped a blueprintfor other organisations to implement citizensâ€™ assemblies in a similar way.â€œIt has helped us navigate one of the most challenging times for the cultural and art industry in a very long time â€“ just look at how many organisations are closing down,â€ he says. â€œOur citizens make us relevant.â€* Not her real nameExplore more on these topicsArtNottinghamMuseumsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Allâ€™s Fair review â€“ Kim Kardashianâ€™s divorce drama is fascinatingly, existentially terrible | Television | The Guardian
description: Not even Glenn Close can save this Ryan Murphy disaster from its dismal plots, clueless characters â€“ and the worst kissing scenes ever filmed
Author: Lucy Mangan
Headline: Not even Glenn Close can save this Ryan Murphy disaster from its dismal plots, clueless characters â€“ and the worst kissing scenes ever filmed
Content: Not giving their best â€¦ Sarah Paulson, Kim Kardashian and Niecy Nash in Allâ€™s Fair.Photograph: DisneyView image in fullscreenNot giving their best â€¦ Sarah Paulson, Kim Kardashian and Niecy Nash in Allâ€™s Fair.Photograph: DisneyTV reviewTelevisionReviewAllâ€™s Fair review â€“ Kim Kardashianâ€™s divorce drama is fascinatingly, existentially terribleNot even Glenn Close can save this Ryan Murphy disaster from its dismal plots, clueless characters â€“ and the worst kissing scenes ever filmedLucy ManganTue 4 Nov 2025 08.02 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 13.09 ESTShareIdid not know it was still possible to make television this bad. I assumed that there was some sort of baseline, some inescapable bedrock knowledge of how to do it that now prevents any entry into the art form from falling below a certain standard. But I was wrong. The new series from Ryan Murphy, Allâ€™s Fair â€“ starringKim Kardashian, Naomi Watts and Niecy Nash as the founders of an all-female law firm delivering divorce-y justice to incredibly rich but slightly unlucky women under the azure skies of California â€“ is terrible. Fascinatingly, incomprehensibly, existentially terrible. While I try to get my thoughts in order after bearing witness to the first episode, Iâ€™m going to give you a few direct quotes, so you can see why Iâ€™m struggling.â€œLetâ€™s put the â€˜teamâ€™ in â€˜teamworkâ€™.â€â€œMy flight was turbulent and so is my mood,â€ says Liberty (Watts) to a man barring her way to a client.â€œHeâ€™s wolf-like in his possessiveness,â€ says a client of her husband.Itâ€™ssoawful, it feels almost contemptuous.â€˜I wanted to scrape it from my eyeballsâ€™: critics on their zero-star savagingsRead moreI looked for Julian Fellowesâ€™ name in the credits, but apparently this is all the responsibility of Murphy and his co-creators, Jon Robin Baitz and Joe Baken.They are also executive producers, along with Kim K, her mother Kris Jenner, Watts, Glenn Close (who also has a small role as the protagonistsâ€™ early mentor â€“ I cannot imagine what kompromat the Kardashian clan have on her that led to her participation in this dreadful business), Nash and many, many more. The list goes on for ages. I suspect a variation of the bystander effect (whereby the more witnesses there are to a mugging â€“ for example â€“ the less likely any one is to intervene) is in operation. Thus, the more exec producers linked to it, the worse the show.View image in fullscreenSo awful it feels almost contemptuous â€¦ Niecy Nash, Glenn Close and Kim Kardashian in Allâ€™s Fair.Photograph: Ser Baffo/DisneyStill, thereâ€™s worse and then thereâ€™s Allâ€™s Fair. Beyond the embarrassment of the script, there is the embarrassment of the performances; although I take the point that when someone â€“ in this case, Murphy stalwart Sarah Paulson as psychopathic rival â€œladyâ€ lawyer Carrington â€“ is required to scream â€œAre you calling me an ugly duckling? So what if I give myself home perms? Itâ€™s economical!â€, while smashing up her mentorâ€™s office, they are probably not going to be able to give their best.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Beyond the embarrassment of the script, there is the embarrassment of the performancesâ€™ â€¦ Kim Kardashian and Naomi Watts in Allâ€™s Fair.Photograph: Ser Baffo/DisneyKim K as Allura, married to a football star who is resentful of the shadow cast over his own success by hers, is as expressionless as you might expect, but is at least inoffensively useless. Watts preens and pouts and poses in search of a character, and reminds you of nothing so much asAlly McBeal at her very worst, delivering her lines so archly that you can almost hear her joints cracking. The guest stars are worse. Nash â€“ an unstoppable onscreen force â€“ fares better in a role where the comic intent suits her well. But how parts for Black women are still being written as nothing more than Loud! And Sassy! I do not know. The one good thingAnd Just Like That â€¦ever did was seem to be the nail in that coffin. But Allâ€™s Fair makes it look like Heimat.View image in fullscreenDo not even be tempted to watch â€¦ Kim Kardashian in Allâ€™s Fair.Photograph: Ser Baffo/DisneyIf this was all part of a lurid, camp drama played with gusto by all and narratively stuffed with treats, Murphy might have got away with it. But no one seems to know what theyâ€™re doing; the performances seem to respond to about nine different ideas of what the show is and the plots are dismal. The trio (â€œYouâ€™re the best divorce lawyers in town â€“ maybe the countryâ€) wrap up multiple cases in the time it takes Kim Kâ€™s nail varnish to dry. Thereâ€™s the younger wife who falls in love with the woman her husband hires for a threesome, then walks off 10 minutes later with a $210m settlement once Nash acquires video evidence of his extensive perversions. (â€œSow teatsâ€ is all Iâ€™m prepared to say here. Do not let this tempt you into watching.)View image in fullscreenIts concept of female empowerment would have shamed the Spice Girls 30 years ago â€¦ Kim Kardashian and Niecy Nash in Allâ€™s Fair.Photograph: Ser Baffo/DisneyThereâ€™s the older wife caught cheating (â€œHe wasnâ€™t even attractive! He just looked at me the way you used to look at me!â€) and about to be thrown out of the New York marital home by her billionaire husband (â€œThe guy who, like, owns all of cosmeticsâ€) until Liberty flies out on the private jet to tell her she can take the $40m worth of jewellery she owns with her. These are fitted in around a couple of the worst kissing scenes ever seen on screen, the collapse of Alluraâ€™s marriage, a jarringly unfashionable obsession with brand names (â€œLetâ€™s get those Goyard travel cases and start stuffing!â€) and conspicuous consumption (â€œOh my God â€“ didnâ€™t this belong to Elizabeth Taylor?â€). All this, and a concept of female empowerment (â€œI settled â€¦ Did I not love myself enough?â€) that would have shamed the Spice Girls 30 years ago.So bad itâ€™s not good. Nowhere near.Allâ€™s Fair is on Disney+ now.Explore more on these topicsTelevisionTV reviewKim KardashianGlenn CloseNaomi WattsreviewsShareReuse this content

title: Wright of Derby: From the Shadows review â€“ science, skeletons and a suffocated cockatoo | Art | The Guardian
description: Joseph Wright of Derbyâ€™s vivid paintings depicted Enlightenment thinking and illumination amid the dark. So why are they so terrifying?
Author: Jonathan Jones
Headline: Joseph Wright of Derbyâ€™s vivid paintings depicted Enlightenment thinking and illumination amid the dark. So why are they so terrifying?
Content: A nightmarish theatre of science, power, cruelty and death â€¦ An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump, 1768, by Joseph Wright of Derby.Photograph: The National Gallery Photographic Department./Â© The National Gallery, LondonView image in fullscreenA nightmarish theatre of science, power, cruelty and death â€¦ An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump, 1768, by Joseph Wright of Derby.Photograph: The National Gallery Photographic Department./Â© The National Gallery, LondonArtReviewWright of Derby: From the Shadows review â€“ science, skeletons and a suffocated cockatooNational Gallery, LondonJoseph Wright of Derbyâ€™s vivid paintings depicted Enlightenment thinking and illumination amid the dark. So why are they so terrifying?Jonathan JonesTue 4 Nov 2025 12.22 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 15.24 ESTShareHe looks like heâ€™s up to no good. In the depths of the night, under trees and clouds turned silver and black by the full moon, a man is at work with a shovel. Is he burying a body or digging bits up for a Frankensteinian experiment? After all, this painting was done by Joseph Wright of Derby, a friend of pioneering scientists and industrialists in the Lunar Society of Birmingham, leaders of the new science that would inspire Mary Shelley.But the man beside the foaming river Derwent is not collecting body parts. Heâ€™s doing something just as nefarious by 21st-century moral standards: blocking a fox den so the foxes canâ€™t get back in and will be easy game for the hunt tomorrow. Maybe Wright shares my compassion for foxes, because An Earthstopper on the Banks of the Derwent genuinely is a bit sinister. Yet it has a hypnotic beauty. Two light sources â€“ a lantern and the moon â€“ make this night anything but dead as we almost hear leaves rustle, white water rush and the earthstopperâ€™s spade clunk. Itâ€™s one thing to paint a landscape by day. Wright makes one come fantastically alive by night.The National Galleryâ€™s close look at Wrightâ€™s paintings of darkness and illumination reveals him as the first gothic artist. The gothic novel was invented when Horace Walpole published The Castle of Otranto in 1764; Wright painted his journeys into the horrors of the night in the 1760s and 70s. But the bloodcurdling secret at the heart of these paintings is scientific not supernatural.View image in fullscreenBloodcurdling secrets â€¦ Earthstopper on the Banks of the Derwent, 1773, by Joseph Wright of Derby.Photograph: Â© Derby MuseumsInA Philosopher by Lamplight, two young travellers have found more than they bargained for. Stumbling over a moonlit stream to a cave lit by a lonely candle, they look in terror upon an old man playing with a skeleton, lifting a bony leg as its skull stares from hollow eyes. The hermit is a philosopher trying to puzzle out what happens when we die. But the answer is nothing. For as science took hold in 18th-century Europe as a way of rationally understanding nature, God might be dead, according to radical minds like Wright of Derbyâ€™s friend Erasmus Darwin, grandfather of Charles.InThe Blacksmithâ€™s Shop, the glowing metal on which the blacksmith is working lights up a ruinous building: the workshop is inside a classical temple with Corinthian pilasters. This is an unmistakable reference to Renaissance paintings of the nativity where the stable is often a dilapidated Roman temple, symbolising the death of paganism and rise of Christianity. What can it represent here except the modern material world being born in turn from Christianityâ€™s wreckage?Open your eyes to the nature of the universe, the true magic of science, urges this artist of Enlightenment in his spectacular canvasA Philosopher Giving That Lecture on the Orrery in which a Lamp Is Put in Place of the Sun. The National Gallery provides a real orrery, a mechanical model of the solar system, for comparison.View image in fullscreenDifferent scales â€¦ A Philosopher Giving That Lecture on the Orrery in Which a Lamp Is Put in Place of the Sun, 1764-1766, by Joseph Wright of Derby.Photograph: Joseph Wright of Derby/Â© Derby MuseumsOne reason Wrightâ€™s painted orrery is so bewitching is that you see it at different scales from the perspectives of the audience gathered round the model in a shadowy library. Go close to the enthralled faces of the children and it seems vast; stand further back and itâ€™s a scientific toy, small compared with the lecturer and the gentleman beside him who assiduously takes notes. The scientist looks at him sceptically; a woman in a hat and jewels seems a little blank-eyed. Compared with the children, these adults are less electrified by curiosity.Maybe shock tactics are needed. Wrightâ€™s Orrery, like other paintings here from the superb collection of his work at Derby Museum, is reunited with his other great science spectacle, the National Galleryâ€™sAn Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump.Painted two years after his Orrery, it shifts the focus from wonder to dread. One girl hides her face, too appalled to look â€“ for the lecturer is about to create a vacuum in a glass chamber, killing the white cockatoo inside.Wright gives this experiment hard-edged reality. Itâ€™s the summit of his use of light cutting through darkness to define objects and spaces. The machine at the heart of the action is a formidable structure, its wooden column and brass fittings suggesting the steam engines being perfected by Lunar Society members. In the immortal words of the societyâ€™s co-founder Matthew Boulton: â€œI sell here, Sir, what all the world desires to have: power!â€The audience in Wrightâ€™s painting includes members of the local gentry in a Georgian country house, but the power is not in their hands. It is a new kind of power possessed by the scientist. This 18th-century Oppenheimer gazes at us as he prepares to crank the handle, kill the bird, detonate the bomb. Wright isnâ€™t rejecting science but intuiting that it will change these peopleâ€™s world â€“ and ours â€“ as surely as that bird will die. Candlelight from behind fills a glass vessel with liquid light as if it were radioactive, illuminating a human skull. This is meant to be a rational exposition of the vacuum, but has become a nightmarish theatre of science, power, cruelty and death. Perhaps the youngest girl, who canâ€™t take her eyes from the horror, is plotting a gothic novel of her own.Wright of Derby: From the Shadows is atthe National Gallery, London, from 7 November to 10 MayExplore more on these topicsArtNational GalleryreviewsShareReuse this content

title: Sharp, subtle and effortlessly Lynchian: Diane Ladd had a potent star power | Movies | The Guardian
description: In a hugely successful TV and film career, her waitresses, neighbours, moms and daughters ranged from comedy to drama to David Lynch films, always with compelling authenticity
Author: Peter Bradshaw
Headline: In a hugely successful TV and film career, her waitresses, neighbours, moms and daughters ranged from comedy to drama to David Lynch films, always with compelling authenticity
Content: Astringent â€¦ Diane Ladd in Wild at Heart.Photograph: Moviestore/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenAstringent â€¦ Diane Ladd in Wild at Heart.Photograph: Moviestore/ShutterstockMoviesSharp, subtle and effortlessly Lynchian: Diane Ladd had a potent star powerIn a hugely successful TV and film career, her waitresses, neighbours, moms and daughters ranged from comedy to drama to David Lynch films, always with compelling authenticityDiane Ladd, Oscar-nominated star of Alice Doesnâ€™t Live Here Anymore, dies aged 89Peter BradshawTue 4 Nov 2025 05.40 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 17.49 ESTShareDiane Ladd was part of a Hollywood aristocracy of character actors who from the golden period of the American New Wave onwards lent star quality to supporting roles. She brought an authentic, undiluted American screen-acting flavour to everything she was in, and ran hugely successful movie and TV careers in parallel for decades, playing waitresses, neighbours, moms, sirens and daughters, and ranging from comedy to drama.She was famously the mother of screen actor Laura Dern and wife of Bruce Dern, and repeatedly acted with Laura in a remarkable mother-daughter partnership in which the two womenâ€™s closeness always shone through. You might compare it to Judy Garland and Liza Minnelli, or Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher â€” although Diane Ladd and Laura Dern were far more trouble-free and without that kind of angst. They were Oscar-nominated together for their joint appearance in Martha Coolidgeâ€™s Depression drama Rambling Rose from 1991. And they also both appeared in David Lynchâ€™s Wild at Heart and Inland Empire, Alexander Payneâ€™s Citizen Ruth, and in Mike Whiteâ€™s HBO drama Enlightened â€“ and in three of these they played, naturally, a mother and daughter. In Joel Hershmanâ€™s 1992 comedy Hold Me, Thrill Me, Kiss Me, Ladd acted alongside her own mother, the stage actor Mary Lanier.View image in fullscreenMother-daughter partnership â€¦ Ladd (left) with Laura Dern in Rambling Rose.Photograph: Carolco/Rambling Rose/Midnight Sun/Kobal/ShutterstockShe had a minor but potent, mysterious part in Polanskiâ€™s Chinatown as Ida Sessions, the woman who has posed as Faye Dunawayâ€™s character Evelyn as part of a sinister conspiracy. But more prominent was her role in the classic and time-honoured role as the brassy, heart-of-gold diner waitress in Martin Scorseseâ€™s Alice Doesnâ€™t Live Here Anymore â€“ playing a slightly different part in the TV spinoff â€“ whose job is to deliver down-home banter and hard-won unimpressed wisdom with Ellen Burstynâ€™s Alice and to be the witness of the latterâ€™s budding romance with Kris Kristofferson. In Bill Dukeâ€™s silver-years comedy The Cemetery Club from 1993, Ladd was reunited with Ellen Burstyn and Olympia Dukakis, to play one of three widowed women who are determined to get some enjoyment out of life.But it was perhaps Laddâ€™s destiny to play more in an intergenerational context, portraying older characters and mothers and sisters, in various comic or forbidding forms. In Bob Rafelsonâ€™s Black Widow she was the sister of one of the murdererâ€™s black-widow predations; in National Lampoonâ€™s Christmas Vacation she was Chevy Chaseâ€™s mom; and in Mike Nicholsâ€™ Primary Colors she was the mother of John Travoltaâ€™s Clintonesque Governor Jack Stanton.View image in fullscreenLadd in Wild at Heart.Photograph: Landmark Media/AlamyDavid Lynch tapped into the sharpness, the astringency and the darkness within or behind the all-American veneer that Ladd could present to the camera. In Wild at Heart (opposite Laura Dern), she got one of her three Oscar nominations in the very sensual role of Marietta, who conceives a sexually ambiguous resentment against her daughterâ€™s association with the smouldering Sailor (Nicolas Cage) and tries different ways to sabotage their relationship and murder him. In Lynchâ€™s far more complex and experimental Inland Empire, again of course with Dern, she plays the host of a TV celebrity gossip show which is very preoccupied with Dernâ€™s actor character: again, Ladd is vivid, cartoony, but not satirical or grotesque; she is an effortlessly Lynchian character.Explore more on these topicsFilmLaura DernDavid LynchMartin ScorsesefeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Handbags at dawnâ€™: Daniel Day-Lewis discusses his method acting conflict with Brian Cox | Daniel Day-Lewis | The Guardian
description: The triple Oscar-winning actor, who immerses himself in his characters, took issue with Coxâ€™s questioning of Jeremy Strongâ€™s behaviour on the set of Succession
Author: Catherine Shoard
Headline: The triple Oscar-winning actor, who immerses himself in his characters, took issue with Coxâ€™s questioning of Jeremy Strongâ€™s behaviour on the set of Succession
Content: Method man â€¦ Daniel Day-Lewis.Photograph: Antonietta Baldassarre Insidefoto/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenMethod man â€¦ Daniel Day-Lewis.Photograph: Antonietta Baldassarre Insidefoto/ShutterstockDaniel Day-Lewisâ€˜Handbags at dawnâ€™: Daniel Day-Lewis discusses his method acting conflict with Brian CoxThe triple Oscar-winning actor, who immerses himself in his characters, took issue with Coxâ€™s questioning of Jeremy Strongâ€™s behaviour on the set of SuccessionCatherine ShoardTue 4 Nov 2025 06.51 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 07.19 ESTShareDaniel Day-Lewis has spoken out over being drawn into what he called a â€œhandbags at dawn conflictâ€ with fellow actor Brian Cox over method acting.Speaking to the Big Issue, Day-Lewis reflected on his commitment to the technique being pitted against the scepticism of Cox, who had made disparaging remarks about the approach adopted by actors including his Succession co-star Jeremy Strong, suggesting heâ€™d found his on-set behaviour â€œirritatingâ€.â€œListen, I worked withBrian Coxonce and got somehow drawn into this handbags at dawn conflict inadvertently,â€ said Day-Lewis. â€œBrian is a very fine actor whoâ€™s done extraordinary work. As a result, heâ€™s been given a soapbox â€¦ which he shows no sign of climbing down from. Any time he wants to talk about it, Iâ€™m easy to find.â€œIf I thought during our work together Iâ€™d interfered with his working process, Iâ€™d be appalled. But I donâ€™t think it was like that. So I donâ€™t know where the fuck that came from.Jeremy Strongis a very fine actor, I donâ€™t know how he goes about things, but I donâ€™t feel responsible in any way for that.â€â€˜Theatre is an elitist artform for privileged peopleâ€™: Daniel Day-Lewis talks class, cinema and his crush on Mary PoppinsRead moreDay-Lewisâ€™s unhappiness with the representation of method acting â€“ whereby an actor immerses themselves in their character both on and off set â€“ has become apparent on the press tour for his new film,Anemone.He has addressed the issue in most, if not all, of his recent interviews.Appearing at the BFI Southbank last month, Day-Lewis said â€œrecent commentaryâ€ about the technique â€œis invariably from people who have little or no understanding of what it actually involves. Itâ€™s almost as if itâ€™s some specious science that weâ€™re involved in, or a cult.â€He told the Big Issue: â€œI canâ€™t think of a single commentator whoâ€™s gobbed off about the method that has any understanding of how it works and the intention behind it.â€œThey focus on, â€˜Oh, he lived in a jail cell for six monthsâ€™ [for 1993 film In the Name of the Father]. Those are the least important details. In all the performing arts, people find their methods as a means to an end. Itâ€™s with the intention of freeing yourself so you present your colleagues with a living, breathing human being they can interact with. Itâ€™s very simple.â€œSo it pisses me off this whole, â€˜Oh, he went full method,â€™ thing â€¦ Because itâ€™s invariably attached to the idea of some kind of lunacy.â€Day-Lewis went on to contrast his own on-set professionalism with that of some of his colleagues, who instead spend their time playing pranks.â€œI choose to stay and splash around,â€ said Day-Lewis, â€œrather than jump in and out or play practical jokes with whoopee cushions between takes or whatever people think is how you should behave as an actor.â€Anemone, the directorial debut of Ronan Day-Lewis, who co-wrote it with his father, opens in the UK on 7 November.Explore more on these topicsDaniel Day-LewisBrian CoxActingJeremy StrongSuccessionnewsShareReuse this content

title: Donna Jean Godchaux-MacKay, Grateful Dead singer, dies aged 78 | Music | The Guardian
description: The musician, who also provided backing vocals on Suspicious Minds and When a Man Loves a Woman, died of cancer in Nashville on Sunday
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: The musician, who also provided backing vocals on Suspicious Minds and When a Man Loves a Woman, died of cancer in Nashville on Sunday
Content: Donna Jean Godchaux-MacKay of the Grateful Dead performs during a 2012 tribute to Jerry Garcia in San Rafael, California. She has died aged 78 of cancer.Photograph: C Flanigan/WireImageView image in fullscreenDonna Jean Godchaux-MacKay of the Grateful Dead performs during a 2012 tribute to Jerry Garcia in San Rafael, California. She has died aged 78 of cancer.Photograph: C Flanigan/WireImageMusicDonna Jean Godchaux-MacKay, Grateful Dead singer, dies aged 78The musician, who also provided backing vocals on Suspicious Minds and When a Man Loves a Woman, died of cancer in Nashville on SundayAssociated PressMon 3 Nov 2025 23.13 ESTLast modified on Mon 3 Nov 2025 23.14 ESTShareDonna Jean Godchaux-MacKay, a soulful mezzo-soprano who provided backing vocals on such 1960s classics as Suspicious Minds and When a Man Loves a Woman and was a featured singer with theGrateful Deadfor much of the 1970s, has died aged 78.A spokesperson for Godchaux-MacKay confirmed that she died of cancer on Sunday at Alive hospice in Nashville.Godchaux-MacKay and other Grateful Dead members were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1994.Grateful Dead: where to start in their back catalogueRead moreBorn Donna Jean Thatcher in Florence, Alabama, she had yet to turn 20 when she became a session performer in nearby Muscle Shoals, where many soul and rhythm and blues hits were recorded, and also was on hand for numerous sessions at the Memphis-based American Sound Studio. Her credits included Elvis Presleyâ€™s Suspicious Minds, Percy Sledgeâ€™s When a Man Loves a Woman and songs with Neil Diamond, Boz Scaggs and Cher.View image in fullscreenDonna Jean Godchaux-MacKay (centre) performing in the Grateful Dead with Bob Weir and Jerry Garcia in November 1978.Photograph: NBC/NBCUniversal/Getty ImagesIn the early 1970s, she and her then-husband Keith Godchaux joined the Grateful Dead and remained with them for several tours and albums, including Terrapin Station, Shakedown Street and From the Mars Hotel. Godchaux appeared on numerous songs, whether joining with Jerry Garcia on Scarlet Begonias or writing and taking the lead on From the Heart of Me.The Godchauxs left the Dead in 1979, with hopes of forming their own group, but Keith Godchaux died the following year from injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Donna, who married bassist David MacKay in 1981, continued to tour and record over the following decades.Her albums include Back Around and Donna Jean and the Tricksters. In the 1970s, she and Keith Godchaux released Keith & Donna.In addition to David MacKay, survivors include sons Kinsman MacKay and Zion Godchaux and two siblings, Gogi Clark and Ivan Thatcher.Explore more on these topicsMusicGrateful DeadPop and rocknewsShareReuse this content

title: Worker dies after being rescued from partially collapsed medieval tower in Rome | Italy | The Guardian
description: Romanian worker was taken to hospital in â€˜serious conditionâ€™ after being saved from Torre dei Conti rubble, but died soon after
Author: Angela Giuffrida
Headline: Romanian worker was taken to hospital in â€˜serious conditionâ€™ after being saved from Torre dei Conti rubble, but died soon after
Content: Firefighters rescue the man trapped inside the collapsed tower.Photograph: Angelo Carconi/EPAView image in fullscreenFirefighters rescue the man trapped inside the collapsed tower.Photograph: Angelo Carconi/EPAItalyWorker dies after being rescued from partially collapsed medieval tower in RomeRomanian worker was taken to hospital in â€˜serious conditionâ€™ after being saved from Torre dei Conti rubble, but died soon afterAngela Giuffridain Rome, and agenciesMon 3 Nov 2025 19.35 ESTFirst published on Mon 3 Nov 2025 08.59 ESTShareA Romanian worker who was trapped for hours under rubble in Rome after the partial collapse of a medieval tower has died in hospital, just a short time after he was pulled free by emergency services.â€œI express deep sorrow and condolences, on behalf of myself and the government, for the tragic loss of Octay Stroici, the worker who was killed in the collapse of the Torre dei Conti in Rome,â€ Italyâ€™s prime minister Giorgia Meloni said in a statement after midnight. â€œâ€‹We are close to his family and colleagues at this time of unspeakable suffering.â€Two sections of the 29-metre (95ft) Torre dei Conti, near the Colosseum, crashed to the ground, videos posted on social media showed. The first collapse took place at about 10.30am UK time, the second about 90 minutes later.Clouds of dust billowed out of the windows, along with the sound of collapsing masonry. The second collapse happened while firefighters worked on the structure with aerial ladders. None of the firefighters were injured.â€œThe rescue operation took a long time because every time a part of the workerâ€™s body was freed, further collapses occurred, burying him again under the rubble,â€ Romeâ€™s police chief, Lamberto Giannini said, soon after Stroici was freed.Authorities said he was conscious during the lengthy rescue operation before he was hospitalised in critical condition. He died shortly after he arrived at the hospital.A second worker, also Romanian, was pulled out almost immediately and taken to hospital with serious but not life-threatening head injuries, while two more workers suffered minor injuries and declined hospital treatment.1:06Moment part of medieval tower in Rome collapses â€“ videoWitnesses reported hearing a loud bang and seeing clouds of dust. One told Corriere della Sera: â€œI saw a worker fall.â€Firefighters flew a drone through a window to inspect the site.One worker inside at the time of the first collapse said he escaped from a balcony. â€œIt was not safe. I just want to go home,â€ said the man, white dust covering his uniform, who gave his name as Ottaviano and his age as 67.Elena, from the UK, who like others did not want to give her last name, works at Shamrock, a pub with views of the tower from its outside seating area. She said she had been preparing to open the pub when the first collapse happened.â€œIt felt a bit like an earthquake,â€ she said. â€œI saw a man trying to get out by walking down the scaffolding â€“ I didnâ€™t realise people were inside working on it.â€Sue and Don, a couple from the UK, had been eating breakfast at a restaurant in front of the monument earlier in the morning when they heard loud drilling. â€œIt seemed they were drilling deeply into the building and we wondered what they could be doing,â€ Sue said.Caterina, who was born in the Italian capital, was among the large crowd of onlookers gathered at the scene. â€œI have never experienced anything like this in central Rome before,â€ she said.Queen Paglinawan was working in a nearby gelato shop when she heard two loud noises in quick succession. â€œI was working and then I heard some like falling, and then I saw the tower collapse in a diagonal way,â€ said Paglinawan, 27, as yet another collapse occurred in the background.Viktoria Braeu, a student from Germany, passed by the scene just as the collapse during the firefightersâ€™ rescue happened. â€œWe were just at the Colosseum â€¦ and we were just walking to get some food. And then we were like: â€˜Itâ€™s probably not long until itâ€™s going to go down,â€™ and then it just started erupting,â€ said Braeu, 18.The area of the Forum and Piazza Venezia, which is continuously packed with tourists and traffic, was cordoned off. The mayor of Rome, Roberto Gualtieri, and Italyâ€™s culture minister, Alessandro Giuli, were at the scene.The Torre dei Conti was built in the 13th century by Richard Conti, brother ofPope Innocent III, as a fortified residence for his family. It was damaged in an earthquake in 1349 and there were collapses in the 17th century.The restoration works are being financed by funds from the EUâ€™s post-pandemic recovery fund in order to make the building more secure.Agence France-Presse, Reuters and the Associated Press contributed to this reportExplore more on these topicsItalyEuropenewsShareReuse this content

title: Trade me a goat for some turnips! Nothing is more outdated than the 2025 John Lewis Christmas advert | Television | The Guardian
description: A child going into an actual shop and buying a vinyl record? It will make you feel old and decrepit, and itâ€™ll utterly bamboozle young people â€¦ but shut up â€“ itâ€™s Christmas!
Author: Stuart Heritage
Headline: A child going into an actual shop and buying a vinyl record? It will make you feel old and decrepit, and itâ€™ll utterly bamboozle young people â€¦ but shut up â€“ itâ€™s Christmas!
Content: No lip-syncing algorithm kids here! â€¦ the 2025 John Lewis Christmas advert.Photograph: John Lewis/PAView image in fullscreenNo lip-syncing algorithm kids here! â€¦ the 2025 John Lewis Christmas advert.Photograph: John Lewis/PATelevisionTrade me a goat for some turnips! Nothing is more outdated than the 2025 John Lewis Christmas advertA child going into an actual shop and buying a vinyl record? It will make you feel old and decrepit, and itâ€™ll utterly bamboozle young people â€¦ but shut up â€“ itâ€™s Christmas!Stuart HeritageTue 4 Nov 2025 02.41 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 12.13 ESTShareThe weird thing about tradition is that it has a tendency to long outlive its usefulness. Bonfire Night, once a way for the government to remind the public of its capacity to murder revolutionaries, has simply become an excuse to eat a jacket potato in a field. Church bells still ring on Sunday mornings, when it would be quicker and way more considerate to ping the congregation on WhatsApp. And the John Lewis Christmas advert is somehow still a thing.True, it wasnâ€™t so long ago that the John Lewis Christmas advert was a cultural institution; a teargas grenade lobbed into the television schedules to make viewers cry in the middle of The Cube. But now it is the year 2025, and things have changed. The John Lewis advert is a linear television commercial about a department store, even though the only way to describe either of those two things to a child is as a YouTube with no search function and an Amazon you actually have to walk to.Nevertheless, this yearâ€™s John Lewis Christmas advert has landed â€“ 10 days earlier than last year â€“ and it is absolutely business as usual. A boy buys his dad a vinyl copy of the house banger Where Love Lives by Alison Limerick. The record causes the dad to be transported to a dancefloor, where his son greets him as a baby, a toddler, and finally as an adolescent. And then, through the sheer power of John Lewis, the song slows down into a sludgy plink-plonk cover version of itself.In other words, this is the mashup between Love Actually and Aftersun nobody knew they needed. In the former, you will remember that Alan Rickman gifted his wife Emma Thompson a Joni Mitchell CD, an act that moved her to tears. In the latter, you will remember that a father and his daughter dance euphorically to Under Pressure.2:07Watch the 2025 John Lewis Christmas advert â€“Â videoOh, sure, you could read more into those references if you wanted. You could suggest that the scene in Aftersun represented the very last moment father and daughter spent together before he abandons her forever, causing her a lifetime of unsolvable trauma. And maybe youâ€™d want to point out that Emma Thompson was actually crying because the CD was confirmation that Alan Rickman was cheating on her and their marriage was over. But shut up, itâ€™s Christmas.Either way, whatâ€™s clever about the advert is that fathers and sons will each take something different from it. The fact that the son bought such a thoughtful present is a sign that he realises his dad was once an actual person with his own desires and interests who didnâ€™t just exist to be in service of his family. Itâ€™s a profound moment for a child, and one that cannot help but change the nature of the relationship.View image in fullscreenA dad is transported back to a dance floor with his toddler â€¦ it can only be the 2025 John Lewis Christmas advert.Photograph: John Lewis/PAMeanwhile, the advert perfectly captures a very common moment of fatherhood. Iâ€™m talking, of course, about the time you decide to go clubbing, only to realise that since having a child youâ€™ve become horrifically old and decrepit and that, to all the young people around you, you now basically represent the creeping spectre of death, and youâ€™re suddenly hit by the realisation of how ancient you are, and you go home depressed and never attempt anything fun or exciting again until you die.And then anyone under the age of 20 will take something else from the advert. That is: what the hell does any of this mean? Itâ€™s a film about someone buying a vinyl record from a bricks and mortar shop, thatâ€™s being shown on linear broadcast television? Why? Why go to all this bother? Why doesnâ€™t the son just play him the song on Spotify? Why doesnâ€™t he type â€˜Where Love Livesâ€™ into TikTok and give his dad the gift of an algorithmically generated feed of some Russian children lip-syncing to it? Wouldnâ€™t that be easier?Honestly, to Gen Z or younger, this whole thing must be like watching a highly commended entry from an obsolete technology competition. You know what? Next year, why not go even further? Why not release the John Lewis advert as a phÃ©nakisticope about a farmer trading a goat for a sack of stubble turnips? It couldnâ€™t possibly be any more of an anachronism than this.But maybe Iâ€™m being cynical. Thereâ€™s still a romance to clinging on to traditions that are no longer useful. A tangible record will always be more special than an online stream. Visiting a shop will always be more special than clicking an object on a website. Thereâ€™s something reassuring in the way that weâ€™re still discussing a television commercial. And weâ€™re doing it via the medium of print journalism, the most obsolescent technology of them all. Merry Christmas everyone!This article was amended on 4 November 2025 to remove a suggestion that print journalism is â€œobsoleteâ€.Newspapers and magazines are still available.Explore more on these topicsTelevisionJohn Lewis Christmas adfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Squid Game: The Challenge season two review â€“ nothing you see here is OK | Television & radio | The Guardian
description: Cash-strapped people forced to do shameful things because theyâ€™re desperate for money? How can this rot be real? If I recreated the idea in my local park, Iâ€™d surely end up in prison
Author: Hannah J Davies
Headline: Cash-strapped people forced to do shameful things because theyâ€™re desperate for money? How can this rot be real? If I recreated the idea in my local park, Iâ€™d surely end up in prison
Content: â€˜Itâ€™s just a game!â€™ â€“ but is it? â€¦ Squid Game: The Challenge.Photograph: NetflixView image in fullscreenâ€˜Itâ€™s just a game!â€™ â€“ but is it? â€¦ Squid Game: The Challenge.Photograph: NetflixTV reviewTelevision & radioReviewSquid Game: The Challenge season two review â€“ nothing you see here is OKCash-strapped people forced to do shameful things because theyâ€™re desperate for money? How can this rot be real? If I recreated the idea in my local park, Iâ€™d surely end up in prisonHannah J DaviesTue 4 Nov 2025 03.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 03.01 ESTShareThereâ€™s missing the point, and then thereâ€™s Netflix making its capitalism-skewing Korean hit about a ruthless contest intoan actual gameshow.The producers of Squid Game: The Challenge have previouslydenied thatâ€™s what happened here, stating that, in fact, the series is also about camaraderie and how people work under pressure, and is, I quote, â€œa critique of how we are ingrained from childhood to be ultra-competitiveâ€. Come on â€“ itâ€™s a reality show about people doing humiliating things because theyâ€™re desperate for money, based on a drama about people doing humiliating things because theyâ€™re desperate for money. If I rounded up a load of debt-ridden people and recreated Squid Game: The Challenge in my local park, Iâ€™m pretty sure Iâ€™d be put in prison.The thing about Squid Game: The Challenge that makes it all OK (although really, none of it is OK) is that everyone here is completely mesmerised by the amount of money on offer. Its prize is among the largest in gameshow history, with the winner of series one, Mai Whelan, cashing a cheque for an extremely cool $4.56m (Â£3.47m). Itâ€™s the sort of money that makes people go gaga from the off, and the treachery is off the charts.For series two, theyâ€™ve made it meaner than ever, with the twists coming in thicker and faster and the sob stories more abject. If there was a brief moment in series one where it felt as if maybe this whole â€œcritiqueâ€ thing was, perhaps, not a clear bid to have oneâ€™s cake and eat it, that moment has definitely passed.The undoubted stars of this first batch of episodes (Netflix will release another lot on 11 November, before the finale on the 18th) are British twins and TikTok personalities Jacob and Raul Gibson. The Gibsons, AKA players 431 and 432, are charming schemers who have the other betracksuited competitors under their spell during a challenge to count 456 seconds exactly â€“ that is, until they eliminate three other players to keep themselves in the game. People are outraged as the losers fall to the ground in mock-death but, well, thereâ€™s $4.56m dollars on the line here, guys!View image in fullscreenNever has a fun pastime been so unpleasant to watch â€¦ Squid Game: The Challenge.Photograph: NetflixLike The Traitors â€“ which is made by the same production company, Studio Lambert â€“ Squid Game: The Challenge has a dark campiness to it (at a pivotal moment in episode one, Nina Simoneâ€™s Donâ€™t Let Me Be Misunderstood plays, cocking a snook at the playersâ€™ differing tactics and opinions). But unlike The Traitors, Squid Game: The Challenge doesnâ€™t always feel like fun. Sure, watching someone assemble a house of cards should be low-stakes enough. But when that person is physically shaking, sweat pouring off their face like water running from a tap, while their teamâ€™s chances of staying in the game are on the line? Not so much. Never has catching a ball in a cup been so urgent â€“ or so unpleasant to watch.Perhaps, as viewers, weâ€™re supposed to find the â€œcritiqueâ€ in just how quickly players turn on one another, using words like â€œdorkyâ€ and, er, â€œfraudalentâ€ to describe each other, and judging who should stay or go based on what they would use the prize money for (leukaemia research â€“ good! Yacht party â€“ bad!). People say things like â€œitâ€™s just a gameâ€ while gritting their teeth in a way that says â€œthis is very muchnotjust a gameâ€. There is the occasional air of theStanford Prison Experiment, and seeing how quickly power corrupts.But I feel all of this is giving Squid Game: The Challenge far too much credit. The last episode of this batch, Mingle, is particularly grim, and is based on a game from the original drama that was described as one of its most brutal and upsetting. At the very least, it will be very triggering for anyone who was ever picked last in PE.For a brief moment, I do consider whether Squid Game: The Challenge could be so bad that it is good, but I think that would be letting its makers off too lightly. The way many of its contestants conduct themselves is dreadful, but then again, this is a dreadful contest. Still, I donâ€™t blame the people who signed up to win $4.56m. Donâ€™t hate the player â€“ hate the utterly grotty game.Squid Game: The Challenge is on Netflix nowExplore more on these topicsTelevision & radioTV reviewSquid GameGame showsTelevisionreviewsShareReuse this content

title: I spent four weeks as a Traitor in my office â€“ and almost lost my mind | Ed Campbell | The Guardian
description: After a colleague had the bright idea of a workplace version of the hit BBC show, I lied and cheated with impunity. Then the strain began to show, says journalist and podcaster Ed Campbell
Author: Ed Campbell
Headline: After a colleague had the bright idea of a workplace version of the hit BBC show, I lied and cheated with impunity. Then the strain began to show, says journalist and podcaster Ed Campbell
Content: Charlotte Church, Alan Carr and Tom Daley on The Celebrity Traitors.Photograph: Euan Cherry/BBC/Studio Lambert/Euan CherryView image in fullscreenCharlotte Church, Alan Carr and Tom Daley on The Celebrity Traitors.Photograph: Euan Cherry/BBC/Studio Lambert/Euan CherryOpinionTelevision & radioI spent four weeks as a Traitor in my office â€“ and almost lost my mindEd CampbellAfter a colleague had the bright idea of a workplace version of the hit BBC show, I lied and cheated with impunity. Then the strain began to showTue 4 Nov 2025 01.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 11.40 ESTShareThere arenâ€™t many people who understand the stress that the celebrity Traitors Cat Burns and Alan Carr have been feeling as their stintwearing that famous green cloakdraws to an end â€“ but I do. I spent four weeks lying, cheating and murdering friends and colleagues in our office version of The Traitors.I almost lost my mind.Everyone watches The Traitors and sees the contestants, Traitors and Faithfuls alike, act irrationally and make poor decisions and thinks: â€œThat wouldnâ€™t be me. Iâ€™d be rational. I wouldnâ€™t beLinda from series three, immediately giving the game away. Iâ€™d be Harry from series two,emotionally manipulatinga girl with a colostomy bag.â€Reader, I was once like you. I was so certain of my rationality that on New Yearâ€™s Day Itweeted my confidenceI would be â€œextremely normalâ€ if I were ever on the show.Little did I know that one of my colleagues was donning metaphorical eyeliner and fringe to act as Claudia Winkleman. Just a week later, I received a Slack explaining that three of my colleagues and I had been selected as Traitors in a game in my office. Iâ€™m not sure why God chose this example to teach me a lesson about being careful what you wish for. Or was it about pride? Iâ€™m just glad the stakes were so low. And maybe his message should have been clearer.The rules were simple. Everyone in the office had been made either a Faithful or a Traitor. In the morning, the Traitorsâ€™ latest victim would be announced on Slack. In the evening, weâ€™d vote on who we wanted to banish. If there were any Traitors left at the end of the game, the Traitors would win the grand prize, a day of annual leave. On paper, it all seems like a low-stakes team-building exercise. No one was competing so they could afford a bionic hand, asNicky did in season one. And Iâ€™m sure the colleague who donned the metaphorical eyeliner as our Claudia didnâ€™t intend to induceMcCarthy-level paranoiain me. But she did.I left the Slack channel we were in at once. The idea of forming a brand-new group called â€œProject costsâ€, with four people from entirely different parts of the business, seemed too suspicious to me. We moved to a WhatsApp group, our digital turret. It was easier than trying to have hooded meetings in the supply cupboard after work.We called the group â€œNanâ€™s birthdayâ€ so that it could be open on our work laptops without attracting suspicion. To make it seem more authentic, I made the group photo an actual photo of my nanna at her 90th birthday. Only when Iâ€™d saved my fellow Traitorsâ€™ numbers under fake names was I happy that the digital level of OpSec was high enough.In person, it was a different story. We were subjected to a 24/7, cross-platform interrogation. WhatsApps, pitch meetings, client lunches â€“ all became accusatory terrain. Lying became second nature. I lied to colleagues as I warmed up my lunch in the microwave, I lied at work drinks, I even lied to my manager who worked in a different office, and wasnâ€™t even playing the game.I spoke about almost nothing else. Iâ€™d wake my girlfriend up, boring her stupid about what Faithfuls had which theories, and who had nearly been caught, and who we were going to murder next. I dreamed about it.There was a farcical moment where I discussed the game with some colleagues on my PoliticsJOE podcast. Through gritted teeth, I claimed to be a Faithful. Now I wasnâ€™t just lying to people I knew. Ifelt like Richard Nixon.On the way up to Manchester with two Faithful colleagues, we didnâ€™t talk about anything apart from who we thought were Traitors and Faithfuls. We turned the spotlight on one another, each subjected to about 45 minutes of scrutiny. After my turn, my colleagues looked at each other.â€œYouâ€™d have to be some sort of psychopath to be able to lie like that,â€ one said.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toMatters of OpinionFree weekly newsletterGuardian columnists and writers on what theyâ€™ve been debating, thinking about, reading, and moreEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain information about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. If you do not have an account, we will create a guest account for you ontheguardian.comto send you this newsletter. You can complete full registration at any time. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionWe Traitors went undetected for about four weeks, massacring Faithfuls with barely contained glee. Weâ€™d even managed some pretty audacious murders in plain sight. It got to the point where if everything went to plan, we would win without any of us having been voted out. We got cocky. â€œSurely you expected them to be better than this,â€ I messaged our Claudia. I imagine thatâ€™s when she decided to level the playing field.You thinkJonathan Rosswas sweating when Joe Marler revealed the â€œbig dogâ€ theory? Imagine how I felt when our Claudiarevivedthe first two Faithfuls.Our perfect game ground to a halt. We turned on each other, and one by one were picked off by the Faithfuls. I was eventually banished after a sloppy murder in plain sight, where I loudly offered my boss a â€œpoisonedâ€ Picnic bar.About a month later, I had to take some time off work due to stress. Who could possibly say whether the two events are related?Ed Campbell is a journalist who reports on British culture, politics and the internet. He also co-hosts the PoliticsJOE podcastExplore more on these topicsTelevision & radioOpinionThe TraitorscommentShareReuse this content
