title: â€˜I can quiz for 17 hours a day!â€™: how Ã‰milien became Europeâ€™s greatest ever gameshow winner | Game shows | The Guardian
description: The 22-year-old history student spent almost two years on a popular French quiz show â€“ becoming a multimillionaire in the process. He discusses the importance of curiosity, frugality and 10-11 hours sleep a night
Author: Angelique Chrisafis
Headline: The 22-year-old history student spent almost two years on a popular French quiz show â€“ becoming a multimillionaire in the process. He discusses the importance of curiosity, frugality and 10-11 hours sleep a night
Content: â€˜Being curious is the starting point for everythingâ€™ â€¦ Ã‰milien at home in Toulouse, France.Composite: Guardian Design; FrÃ©dÃ©ric Scheiber for The GuardianView image in fullscreenâ€˜Being curious is the starting point for everythingâ€™ â€¦ Ã‰milien at home in Toulouse, France.Composite: Guardian Design; FrÃ©dÃ©ric Scheiber for The GuardianGame showsâ€˜I can quiz for 17 hours a day!â€™: how Ã‰milien became Europeâ€™s greatest ever gameshow winnerThe 22-year-old history student spent almost two years on a popular French quiz show â€“ becoming a multimillionaire in the process. He discusses the importance of curiosity, frugality and 10-11 hours sleep a nightAngelique ChrisafisTue 4 Nov 2025 00.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 02.31 ESTShareBeing a TV general-knowledge quiz champion is a funny kind of fame, because random strangers want to test you on all sorts of trivia. â€œSometimes Iâ€™ll be walking down the street, a car slows, the window goes down and someone screams: â€˜Capital of Brunei?â€™ I answer and they drive off â€“ itâ€™s amusing really,â€ says Ã‰milien, a 22-year-old history student who this summer became not only the most successful French gameshow contestant of all time, but the biggest gameshow winner in European history and the world record-holder for the most solo consecutive appearances on a TV quizshow.And everyone, of course, wants to know how he did it.Ã‰milien, known only by his first name, bounded on to Franceâ€™s popular general knowledge quizshow,Les Douze Coups de Midi(The Twelve Strokes of Noon) in September 2023 â€“ wearing odd socks for good luck â€“ with only one aim: to reach the next round.â€œWhat did the American aerospace engineer Edward Murphy give his name to?â€ washis first question. â€œMurphyâ€™s lawâ€, he replied, explaining about toast inevitably falling butter-side down. The showâ€™s format means that each dayâ€™s winner can return the next day to compete again. Ã‰milien kept winning â€“ on topics ranging from 16th-century painting to French nuclear power stations, ice-skating partnerships to Greek myths, French rap to cocktail recipes. No other contestants could beat him. He returned day after day for an astonishing 647 consecutive appearances, over nearly two years.His run ended in July after 21 months â€“ in a 60-second, timed round, he fell down on questions including â€œWhat Breton football club is going up into Ligue 1 next season?â€ But by then he was a household name. He had boosted audience ratings to more than 7 million and sparked a rush of interest in general knowledge among young people. His daily appearances had become a rare force for stability in a nation inpolitical crisis: while he was on the show, France burned through four prime ministers.We meet at his modest, sparsely furnished flat on an unassuming street on the outskirts of Toulouse. He had been studying for a history degree here that he had to pause because of the punishing quizshow shooting schedule. Only a very shiny new toaster on the kitchen counter, which looks conspicuously like a prize, hints at his fame. You would never guess he has been handed a giant cardboard cheque for more than â‚¬2.5m (Â£2.2m) â€“ a rollover of almost two yearsâ€™ worth of prizes that made him Franceâ€™s first quizshow multimillionaire.When he first appeared on the show he was 20 and had passed his driving test in a borrowed car less than two weeks before. Within a week, heâ€™d won a Ford Fiesta. But by the time he had finished his run, his knowledge of geography, history and Eurovision song contest winners had won him a total of 23 cars, not to mention scores of vacuum cleaners, food hampers, waffle-makers, televisions, musical instruments, games consoles and board games (as well as a parachute jump and a trip to Lapland). â€œI had to hire a van to collect the prizes from the studio and put it all in storage,â€ he says. He also won 40kg of sweets, which he donated to a school. Many of the prizes, he has sold or given away.â€œNow if Iâ€™m at the supermarket, I donâ€™t have to worry about paying 50 centimes more for a branded product, which is something Iâ€™d never have done before,â€ Ã‰milien says. Otherwise, he continues to live in his usual frugal way.â€œIt was never about the prizes,â€ he says. â€œThe principal objective was always answering questions. Thatâ€™s what I love. Itâ€™s really about a passion for quizzes.â€Only the pure joy of quizzing could have got him this far, he says.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Walking encyclopediaâ€™ â€¦ Ã‰milien on Les Douze Coups de Midi with quizmaster Jean-Luc Reichmann.Photograph: YouTubeÃ‰milien grew up in a small village in the VendÃ©e in the west of France. His mother was a health assistant and his stepfather a builder. He was constantly asking questions as a child â€“ on the quizshow, the presenter called him a â€œwalking encyclopediaâ€.In his living room, there are no piles of huge reference books, just a memoir of the French singer Barbara, which heâ€™s currently halfway through. Instead, he now works by compiling an extraordinary Google Doc of facts that he has largely honed, tested and updated through online general knowledge quizzes. â€œI can sit and quiz for 16â€“17 hours a day without doing anything else,â€ he says. But equally as important is his membership of quiz club meet-ups in Toulouse, where he competes and sets questions in a room at the town hall â€“ largely with pensioners, but with membership getting younger as trivia quizzes gain popularity in France.â€œI just love learning,â€ he says. As a child he ploughed through scores of books about world records and interesting facts. â€œIâ€™d learn them by heart, thatâ€™s how it all started.â€ Asked on the show to name the worldâ€™s busiest airport, he knew it was in Atlanta because he had read it in a book of world records when he was 10. He had begun watching The Twelve Strokes of Noon with his grandparents from the age of seven, and was soon taking notes. It was his grandmother, Yvonne, a retired childminder, who encouraged him to keep auditioning for the show â€“ he had first tried when he was 18 but was deemed too shy. When he did get on the show, Yvonne came up to Paris for some of the filming, or appeared by video link encouraging him, and, she too, is now regularly recognised in the street.It was during the Covid pandemic that Ã‰milienâ€™s quizzing went up a level. He was in his final year of school and spent much of the lockdowns in his bedroom. â€œI started watching and rewatching TV quizshow reruns on a loop,â€ he says. â€œI loved it. I noticed that sometimes the same questions would come round again and Iâ€™d memorised the answer. I thought if I keep watching, then Iâ€™ll have more answers and it was a kind of snowball effect. I really got into the addictive side of it at that point.â€He reckons he has watched and annotated so many quizshows that he must have been through hundreds of thousands of questions, noting down answers in one-word memory prompts in his Google Doc that is now about 180 pages long. He can sit for hours revising and testing his memory.The things he chooses to note down are often linked to topics that frequently come up. â€œIf a question is â€˜What Finnish classical composer â€¦â€™ thereâ€™s really only one Finnish classical composer who comes up in the quizzing world: Jean Sibelius. So I noted him down a few years ago and heâ€™s come up so often I now donâ€™t need to look at my notes.â€What about the football questions? Do you watch sports channels, I ask. He looks surprised. â€œI donâ€™t learn the makeup of teams, for example Paris Saint-Germain, which would interest a fan. I learn older information that a football fan wouldnâ€™t have or necessarily be interested in.â€ These include the intricacies and stats of World Cup history and the Ballon dâ€™Or.But revision sheets are only going to get you so far â€“ particularly when TV general knowledge quizshows span such a wide breadth of questions, from medieval monarchs to winners of Drag Race France. Ã‰milien believes there is no such thing as a hierarchy of better or worse trivia â€“ Beethoven and PokÃ©mon are on a par when the question timer starts. For that broad breadth of knowledge, he has another quite simple but very fulfilling skill, he says: â€œlisteningâ€.View image in fullscreenÃ‰milien: â€˜Filming a quizshow is like doing two to three exams a day.â€™Photograph: FrÃ©dÃ©ric Scheiber/The GuardianIf you listen extremely carefully when youâ€™re in conversation with anyone about anything, facts will pop up that you can jot down, he says, which makes life pretty enjoyable, and conversations very enriching. This was particularly true when he had to revise contemporary music â€“ it proved much more efficient to listen carefully in every single conversation where someone might mention a playlist. â€œItâ€™s simple,â€ he says. â€œIn any everyday conversation with anyone about anything at all, the discussion might turn to, â€˜Oh, didnâ€™t you know that?â€™ And Iâ€™ll go and jot it down. A fact might come up that interests me and Iâ€™ll take out my phone and say â€˜hang on a second, Iâ€™m noting that downâ€™. There are so many interesting facts everywhere around us.â€The secret of his success is ultimately paying attention. â€œI realised that when you pay very careful attention to new things, even to new words that youâ€™ve skipped when reading a book, itâ€™s like making new discoveries for the first time. Being curious is the starting point for everything in life. Iâ€™ve always loved learning things and I think that curiosity is the basis for anyone interested in quizzing.â€That ability for close listening and concentration sometimes made him appear to have supernatural powers on screen. Once, the presenter began a question â€œOn what sea â€¦â€ and Ã‰milien immediately interjected: â€œThe sea of tranquilityâ€. It was the right answer (the rest of the question was about the Apollo 11 landings) and there was stupefaction on set. How was this possible? â€œGenerally when someone asks, â€œonâ€ what sea, rather than â€œinâ€ what sea, the answer is a sea on the moon,â€ he says. â€œSo in terms of probability it was likely to be that and in a split second I decided to try it.â€The filming of the quizshow was intense. It was compressed into shoots of several weeks of five to six back-to-back episodes a day, where contestants would stay in a hotel near the studio outside Paris. Between filming sessions, Ã‰milien would have a break of often more than a month, returning to Toulouse to revise at home every day for 16â€“17 hours.â€œYou could film 75 episodes in three weeks,â€ he says. â€œI like to compare it to an exam â€¦ Filming a quizshow is like doing two to three exams a day.â€To counter the stress (â€œwhich peaked just before you went on and carried on all through the episodeâ€), sleep was his rule. â€œI need 10 to 11 hours a night,â€ he says. Once, after a train delay, he got to his hotel at 2am the night before shooting, and only got five hoursâ€™ sleep. His mind wandered for a split second during a question about the French town of Albertville in Savoie â€“ meaning he missed a crucial part of the question. He got it right from guesswork but it was stressful.There were rituals when filming, little superstitions to try to help him through. â€œI always ate a fruit compote before each episode. If I hadnâ€™t had time to do that, Iâ€™d feel quite unsettled.â€ He always entered the set by the same door and put his water bottle in the same place.Was he eating special food for his brain? He looks perplexed. â€œHonestly, Iâ€™d be the last person to advise on nutrition â€¦ I didnâ€™t drink enough water, Iâ€™d have a burger at night and a sandwich during the day and that was it.â€The question now is what does he do with all these facts, post-quizshow? Do they still bring joy? Ã‰milien is adamant they do. And the key is moving certain topics from the Google doc into real life. â€œI knew nothing about botany when I started quizzing,â€ he says. â€œAnd I built up a vast knowledge of theory. If you gave me a plantâ€™s name, I could tell you what family it was from. But although I could categorise a carnation, I couldnâ€™t actually recognise a carnation in real life. So now Iâ€™ve started paying lots more attention to trees and flowers, and the other day I recognised a strelitzia plant in a garden and I was so happy. It doesnâ€™t take much to make me happy, but there you are.â€His cultural tips also come from his quizzing knowledge. Perhaps inevitably, quizzers know about a lot of films they havenâ€™t actually watched. He decided to watch Louis Malleâ€™s 1950s French masterpieceLift to the Scaffoldbecause it came up so often in questions. He loved it. Likewise,Milan Kunderaâ€™s The Unbearable Lightness of Being is now his favourite book after it came up so often and so many other quizzers recommended it.He is now taking a year off before potentially resuming his history studies, taking part in online general knowledge meet-ups with the influential French trivia and gaming streamer, Ã‰toiles, and investigating whether he could have a future as a quiz streamer or question-setter.He still goes to his regular Toulouse quiz club meet-ups. How do the others feel about your stardom, I wonder. He looks surprised. â€œNothing changes just because youâ€™ve been on TV,â€ he says. Others have been on TV quizshows, too, and no one is in the slightest bit fazed. â€œWeâ€™re all there to quiz, to share questions, to learn things, we have fun and thatâ€™s it.â€Heâ€™s still curious, and heâ€™s still adding facts to his Google doc. As weâ€™re packing up, FrÃ©dÃ©ric, our photographer talks about a photo project in the Tadrart Rouge mountain range in Algeria. â€œHow do you spell that again?â€ Ã‰milien asks as we leave.Explore more on these topicsGame showsFranceTelevisionEuropeEntertainment TVfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Tomâ€™s Crossing by Mark Z Danielewski â€“ House of Leaves author returns with a 1200-page western | Fiction | The Guardian
description: A quarter century after that landmark cult novel, this new epic has aspects of brilliance but seems designed for academic study rather than readerly enjoyment
Author: Marcel Theroux
Headline: A quarter century after that landmark cult novel, this new epic has aspects of brilliance but seems designed for academic study rather than readerly enjoyment
Content: Heading for the hills â€¦ wild horses in Monument Valley, Utah.Photograph: Karl Hendon/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenHeading for the hills â€¦ wild horses in Monument Valley, Utah.Photograph: Karl Hendon/Getty ImagesBook of the dayFictionReviewTomâ€™s Crossing by Mark Z Danielewski â€“ House of Leaves author returns with a 1200-page westernA quarter century after that landmark cult novel, this new epic has aspects of brilliance but seems designed for academic study rather than readerly enjoymentMarcel TherouxTue 4 Nov 2025 02.00 ESTShareIn this moment of cultural panic about the decline of reading, it takes an enviable confidence to deliver a volume such as Tomâ€™s Crossing. Weighing in at more than 1,200 pages of closely printed text, the novel contains, I would hazard, about half a million words â€“ roughly two Ulysses. Itâ€™s also, for that matter, about twice the length of Danielewskiâ€™s debut,House of Leaves, which secured cult status for its author on publication 25 years ago. Tomâ€™s Crossing is so big that when I got it out on the tube, I felt like that character on Trigger Happy TV with his enormous mobile phone. â€œLook,â€ I seemed to be telling the passengers scrolling Instagram on their devices, â€œIâ€™m reading a book!â€The novel is not merely long, itâ€™s also a challenging, deliberately arcane work that insists on its own epic status, yet has at its heart a straightforward and compelling story. Kalin March, a 16-year-old nerdy outsider in the town of Orvop in Utah, is a preternaturally talented horse rider. Through a shared love of horses, he strikes up an unlikely friendship with handsome and popular Tom Gatestone.When Tom dies of cancer, he extracts a promise from Kalin to save the two horses they love from the knackerâ€™s yard. The bulk of the novel tells the story of Kalinâ€™s quest to take these horses, Mouse and Navidad, to safetyÂ in the wilderness beyond the Isatch mountain range. Along the way, Kalin is joined unexpectedly by Tomâ€™s plucky adopted little sister Landry and, even more unexpectedly, by Tomâ€™s ghost. A violent series of events raises the stakes: the evil Orvop patriarch, Orwin Porch, owner of Porch Meats, and mortal enemy of theÂ Gatestones, sets off to foil Kalinâ€™s already difficultÂ mission.There are so many choric figures that I wondered if they belonged to Danielewski superfans who had crowdfunded the novelThis bald summary doesnâ€™t do justice to the ambition of the book or the brilliance of its plotting. The events take place over a five-day period leading up to Halloween, 1982. Purely as story, Tomâ€™s Crossing hits a western-inflected cinematic sweet spot, with a 1980s setting, young central characters and sweeping landscapes. There are guns, horses, ghosts, a primal struggle for survival in hostile terrain, family feuds and a steadily intensifying sense of mortal threat, as Old Porchâ€™s ambition and psychopathy escalate the drama. And the compressed timeframe of the story ticks down to a hugely satisfying climactic encounter in the mountains.And yet, for all its obvious virtues, I found Tomâ€™s Crossing a baffling and often infuriating experience. Danielewski is a writer of enormous power and vision. He has invented a gripping story with mythic undertones that need no extra emphasis. Yet he makes a number of aesthetic choices that seem deliberately designed to frustrate normal enjoyment of the novel. One of these is the conceit, established on page one, that the epic events described in the book are already widely known. At umpteen points in the novel, we cut away from the action and explore the thoughts and attitudes of a vast chorus of named characters who have used moments in the story as the basis for their own artworks: opera, songs, sculptures, drawings, art installations. We hear about these in mindboggling detail. There are so many of these choric figures â€“ at one point, a thousand or so names are simply listed in the text without comment â€“ that I wondered if they belonged to Danielewski superfans who had crowdfunded the novel.The other decision that struck me as perverse is the narrative voice of the book. The novel purports to be the transcription of an oral account of the events it relates. The voice reproduced on the page is a weird mixture of Homeric and hayseed, dropping terminal â€œgâ€ on participles, using double negatives, now and again renderingforasfer, yet conversant with arcane words such as cynegetic, rupestral, epicrisis, noctilucent and teichoskopia. The result is prolix and wandering and makes a long book feel much longer.â€œEarlier that afternoon, when for some reason Allisonâ€™s thoughts had angrily returned to the curse sheâ€™d laid upon Kalin before heâ€™d left, warnin him from guns, makin it clear by insubstantial decree that even handlin a gun might cost him the horses he loved, and for the rest of his life, she and Sondra had returned to the Isatch Canyon parkin lot, where theyâ€™d promptly learned about the great rockfall.â€This passage is one of the shorter and less challenging sections of the novel, but thereâ€™s still something characteristically inconsiderate about the way itâ€™s constructed. The warning about the guns â€“ though pertinent to the plot â€“ has nothing to do with the unfolding action. In fact, it just distracts the reader from the essence of this paragraph which is:Allison and Sondra went back to the Canyon and learned about the rockfall.Why not say it like that? Well, the narratorâ€™s voice is committed to its special idiolect, with repetition, slang and its own winding rhythms. Space prevents me quoting the weirdest examples at length, but at times it reads as though the Stranger from the film The Big Lebowski is channelling the brambly 17th-century prose of John Milton or Thomas Browne. The Stranger, youâ€™ll remember, has a gravelly voice and a big hat, and is prone to saying things such as: â€œI guess thatâ€™s the way the whole durned human comedy keeps perpetuatin itself down through the generations. Westward the wagons, across the sands of time, until we â€“ ah! Look at me, Iâ€™m ramblin again.â€ Throw in a reference to the Iliad and an obscure adjective, say, quaquaversal, and this is basically the voice of Tomâ€™s Crossing.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toInside SaturdayFree weekly newsletterThe only way to get a look behind the scenes of the Saturday magazine. For more information about how we use your data see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionThis narrator â€“ whose implausible identity we learn late in the book â€“ also possesses a kind of hyperomniscience. There is deep knowledge about â€“ off the top of my head â€“ horse riding, geography, geology, myth, Mormon scripture, card games, land development, 1980s music, modern art, guns, outdoor survival and the conventions of classical literature. Furthermore, every moment in the story is exploded into second-by-second detail, irrespective of its importance to the plot. On occasions, this is sublime and thrilling. Danielewskiâ€™s ability to visualise and convey unfolding action is amazing. At other times, I was scratching my head as we disappeared down another extended digression, wondering why I was being told so much about minor characters and their irrelevant enthusiasms.In the end, Tomâ€™s Crossing feels as though itâ€™s been written with at least one eye on the literary immortality bestowed by academic study. Its aesthetic decisions seem designed to stimulate seminars rather than enjoyment. And to be fair, Danielewski doesnâ€™t hide the bookâ€™s challenges: a glance at the novelâ€™s first page will let readers know what theyâ€™re in for. Less obvious is that beneath the carapace of difficult writing and literary allusion, thereâ€™s the gratifying gooey centre of a blockbuster PG western, with limited nudity, violent scenes and oddly simple moral choices.Tomâ€™s Crossing by Mark Z Danielewski is published by Pantheon (Â£30). title: Brief Encounter at 80: why weâ€™re still falling for David Leanâ€™s 1945 romance | Drama films | The Guardian
description: The story of hot tea and unconsummated love hails from a very different era â€“ and was far from easy to make. Yet it remains a key influence for film-makers from Sofia Coppola to Celine Song, James Ivory to Greta Gerwig
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: The story of hot tea and unconsummated love hails from a very different era â€“ and was far from easy to make. Yet it remains a key influence for film-makers from Sofia Coppola to Celine Song, James Ivory to Greta Gerwig
Content: Celia Johnson remembered running to the wireless between takes to hear Winston Churchill announce Germanyâ€™s surrender â€¦ David Lean with Johnson and Trevor Howard on set.Photograph: Everett Collection Inc/AlamyView image in fullscreenCelia Johnson remembered running to the wireless between takes to hear Winston Churchill announce Germanyâ€™s surrender â€¦ David Lean with Johnson and Trevor Howard on set.Photograph: Everett Collection Inc/AlamyDrama filmsBrief Encounter at 80: why weâ€™re still falling for David Leanâ€™s 1945 romanceThe story of hot tea and unconsummated love hails from a very different era â€“ and was far from easy to make. Yet it remains a key influence for film-makers from Sofia Coppola to Celine Song, James Ivory to Greta GerwigJames HarveyTue 4 Nov 2025 02.03 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 12.37 ESTShareThe first time David Leanâ€™s 1945 romantic masterpiece was shown to the public, the audience were in stitches. It not being a comedy, this was far from ideal. The director was so embarrassed, he returned to his hotel planning to break into the film lab and burn the negative at the earliest opportunity.Eighty years on, the legacy of Brief Encounter has proved anything but. First, its train station setting and ubiquity on British TV led to parodies by everyone from Victoria Wood to Birds Eye ready meals.Allow Instagram content?This article includes content provided byInstagram. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. To view this content,click 'Allow and continue'.Allow and continueIn 1999, it was voted #2 on the BFIâ€™s 100 best British films of the century. Greta Gerwig hascalledit â€œthe most romantic movie ever madeâ€. Its central struggle â€“ the pull of doomed, unconsummated love, of yearning between two people putting responsibility before happiness â€“ has become the template for some of the greatest romantic stories committed to the big screen.Getting there has not been an easy ride. Set in a noirish and literally (if not figuratively) steamy 1930s, the film stars Celia Johnson as Laura - perfectly ordinary, perfectly married, and painfully middle-class. Laid low by a piece of grit in her eye at a train station, sheâ€™s attended to by a passing doctor, Alec (Trevor Howard). The pair begin a whirlwind romance â€“ despite their better natures.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Pleasant, but rather stupidâ€™ â€¦ Trevor Howard with Everley Gregg (left) and Celia Johnson in Brief Encounter.Photograph: Album/AlamyThough based on NoÃ«l Cowardâ€™s pre-war 1936 short play, Still Life, Brief Encounter was conceived and shot in the less film-friendly environment of wartime Britain. The changes made from stage to screen would change the storyâ€™s soul. A year-long affair would become a seven-week infatuation. A tale of extramarital guilt became one of middle-class self-restraint. It was a sort of wish-fulfilment Lean, for one, could relate to: his accountant father had abandoned his family in similar circumstances 22 years earlier.Location filming in early 1945 was cold but happy, despite the misgivings some were beginning to have over the male lead. Howard was â€œpleasant, but rather stupidâ€, Johnson wrote. Lean agreed: â€œHe later became a wonderful actor, but oh dear, there were a lot of things that went straight over his head.â€Carnforth railway station â€“ now a Lancashire tourist attraction complete with replica tearoom â€“ stood in for the Home Counties setting, chosen to give the crew time to cover their lamps in the event of a German air raid. Filming was still ongoing when the crew heard the UKâ€™s supply of Technicolor cameras was being diverted to Buckingham Palace â€“ Johnson remembered running to the wireless between takes to hear Winston Churchill announce Germanyâ€™s surrender.View image in fullscreenRebuilding British prestige â€¦ filming Brief Encounter.Photograph: Album/AlamyThis meant that by the time Brief Encountermade it in front of an audience it was a wartime film, set before the war, playing to a postwar crowd. Perhaps that explains its curiously muted reception: despite critical adoration and Cowardâ€™s pedigree as a writer, it did solid but unremarkable business at the UK box office. Posters in the countryâ€™s industrial heartlands resorted to singing its praises â€œin spite of the wild praise of the London criticsâ€.For some, the film came to embody a kind of Britishness now lost in its pre-war origins. Lord Mountbatten, writing to Coward in 1947, said: â€œThere is no doubt in my mind that films of this sort must help to rebuild British prestige which is now temporarily eclipsed.â€ Months later, Mountbatten oversaw the partition of India, which left the British empire in tatters and as many as two million dead.For others, the filmâ€™s story now felt too close to home. The constant wartime movement around the countryâ€™s rail network and abroad had triggered any number of â€œbrief encountersâ€ all on its own â€“ affairs without the filmâ€™s determination to stay unconsummated. Despite the storyâ€™s pre-war setting and conception, it nonetheless now conjured spectres of guilt some audiences would rather have forgotten.Adoration in certain circles, though, kept the Brief Encounter flame alive long after it left cinemas. One of 11 Grand Prix (the predecessor to the Palme dâ€™Or) winners at the 1946 Cannes film festival, it escaped from that yearâ€™s Academy Awards with three nominations but no statuettes. The first of Sight & Soundâ€™s now infamous criticsâ€™ polls in 1952 placed it a rung above Citizen Kane.View image in fullscreenDavid Lean and Celia Johnson arrive at Parisâ€™s Gare du Nord station en route to pick up their prize at Cannes.Photograph: Keystone-France/Gamma-Keystone/Getty ImagesAnd its reputation among the public grew over time. Lean remembered, coincidentally, waiting for a train when a man approached threatening to punch him. â€œDo you realise, sir,â€ Lean recalled he said, â€œthat if Celia Johnson could contemplate being unfaithful to her husband, my wife could contemplate being unfaithful to me?â€ Divorce still a touchy subject in the UK, Brief Encounterâ€™s popularity would rise as public attitudes liberalised.In the meantime, the film received an indirect boost in the US, where Billy Wilder was feeling inspired by one of Brief Encounterâ€™s smallest characters. Valentine Dyallâ€™s uncredited turn as a man whose empty flat almost serves as the coupleâ€™s love nest would morph into a career-best, sad-puppyish turn from Jack Lemmon.View image in fullscreenShooting the film.Photograph: Album/Alamyâ€œI think that the interesting character is the friend who returns to his home and finds the bed still warm,â€ Wilder said. His more risque American take on forbidden love â€“ 1960â€™s The Apartment â€“ transplants the story from a social ladder to a corporate one, winning the best picture Oscar for which Brief Encounter had failed to secure a nomination.In the UK, the filmâ€™s recurrent place on those newfangled TV schedules meant that, by the 1970s, ad man director Alan Parker could use it to advertise Birds Eye roast beef dinners. Rachmaninovâ€™s Second Piano Concerto â€“ which recurs throughout the film â€“ regularly topped polls as the UKâ€™s favourite piece of classical music, as it continues to do today.Other influences are more subtle. Kazuo Ishiguroâ€™s 1989 Booker prize winner The Remains of the Day bears a striking resemblance to Cowardâ€™s dialogue of middle-class repression. Its mid-century butler has internalised the same lessons of duty and propriety to such an extent he may have forgotten how to feel love at all. And the shot-reverse-shot of When Harry Met Sallyâ€™s diner scene perfectly mirrors Alec and Lauraâ€™s first lunch in a Kardomah cafe, as does the filmâ€™s conceit of a relationship built over repeat chance encounters.Following Cowardâ€™s death, too, the filmâ€™s LGBTQ+ resonances have been brought to the fore. His penchant for packing his scripts with affairs, love triangles and secret crushes had hardly gone unnoticed among the gay community of 1945.View image in fullscreenRe-encounter â€¦ Anthony Hopkins and Emma Thompson in Remains of the Day (1993).Photograph: AJ Pics/AlamyDying just six years after homosexuality was first decriminalised in 1967, the writerâ€™s post-mortem exit from the closet only confirmed that the filmâ€™s study of forbidden love may have meant something more to its author than the social stigma that scared Alec and Laura into obedience.In the 21st century, Sofia Coppola cited itas an inspiration for her 2003 film Lost in Translation. â€œYou feel so much in just a gesture or a pause,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s so emotional but everythingâ€™s under the surface. Maybe thatâ€™s very English? But I love that.â€Brief Encounterâ€™s ideas have proved more universal than Johnsonâ€™s cut-glass accent suggests. Wong Kar-waiâ€™s In the Mood for Love explores similar themes of buttoned-up infidelity, as much about the social pressure imposed on a relationship as the infatuation itself.View image in fullscreenTrain dreams â€¦ Teo Yoo and Greta Lee in Past Lives.Photograph: Twenty Years Rights/A24 FilmsCanadian director Celine Song explored its â€œwhat if?â€ question through the Korean concept ofinyeon(the romantic mystery of a sense of connection between two strangers) in her 2023 film, Past Lives. Its opening shot of a love triangle spotted across a bar mirrors Alec and Lauraâ€™s last moments together.Today, Brief Encounter holds an odd place in the lives of both Lean and Coward: a tearoom romance from a director famed for his bombastic epics, and the last great film from a writer who never thought much of the medium anyway. Still, of all their works, it might just be the one thatâ€™s lasted the longest. For 80 years, weâ€™ve never been able to stop asking: â€œWhat if?â€The National Film Theatre, London, hosts an 80th anniversary screening of Brief Encounter on 16 NovemberThis article was amended on 4 November 2025 because in an earlier version, the caption to the second picture said the person on the left was Joyce Carey, when it is a different actor in Brief Encounter, Everley Gregg.Explore more on these topicsDrama filmsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜How did we get here?â€™: documentary explores how Republicans changed course on the climate | Documentary films | The Guardian
description: In The White House Effect, now available on Netflix, archival footage is used to show how the US right moved from believing to disputing the climate crisis
Author: Adrian Horton
Headline: In The White House Effect, now available on Netflix, archival footage is used to show how the US right moved from believing to disputing the climate crisis
Content: A still from The White House EffectPhotograph: NetflixView image in fullscreenA still from The White House EffectPhotograph: NetflixDocumentary filmsâ€˜How did we get here?â€™: documentary explores how Republicans changed course on the climateIn The White House Effect, now available on Netflix, archival footage is used to show how the US right moved from believing to disputing the climate crisisAdrian HortonTue 4 Nov 2025 05.02 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 10.43 ESTShareIn 1988, the United States entered into its worst drought since the Dust Bowl. Crops withered in fields nationwide, part of an estimated $60bn in damage ($160bn in 2025). Dust storms swept the midwest and northern Great Plains. Cities instituted water restrictions. That summer, unrelentingly hot temperatureskilledbetween 5,000 and 10,000 people, and Yellowstone national park suffered the worst wildfire in its history.â€˜How is this possible?â€™: a new film looks inside the appalling abuses of the Alabama prison systemRead moreAmid the disaster, George HW Bush, then Ronald Reaganâ€™s vice-president, met with farmers in Michigan reeling from crop losses. Bush, the Republican candidate for president, consoled them: if elected, he would be the environmental president. He acknowledged the reality of intensifying heatwaves â€“ the â€œgreenhouse effectâ€, to use the scientific parlance of the day â€“ with blunt clarity: the burning of fossil fuels contributed excess carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, leading to global warming. But though the scale of the problem could seem â€œimpossibleâ€, he assured the farmers that â€œthose who think weâ€™re powerless to do anything about this greenhouse effect are forgetting about the White House Effectâ€ â€“ the impact of sound environmental policy for the leading consumer of fossil fuels. Curbing emissions, he said, was â€œthe common agenda of the futureâ€.That clip â€“ startling to anyone even glancingly familiar with Republican orthodoxy in the years since â€“ appears early in The White House Effect, a new all-archival documentary that examines the evolution of the climate crisis from non-partisan reality to divisive political issue. The 96-minute film, now available onNetflix, takes its name from Bushâ€™s unfulfilled guarantee of environmental action during his four years as president, a pivotal missed opportunity â€“ if not, as the film implicitly argues,thepivotal missed opportunity â€“ for bipartisan US leadership on the climate crisis. â€œThere was this moment in time when the science was widely accepted, when the public was all about tackling this,â€ co-director Pedro Kos told the Guardian. â€œIt was a mom and pop issue, as American as apple pie. Flash forward to four years later, and you have a completely split electorate. How do we get there?â€The film, directed by Kos with Jon Shenk and Bonni Cohen, first rewinds the clock from Bushâ€™s uncontroversial campaign promise back to the 1970s, when the science on the greenhouse effect became a public talking point. In news footage from the late 70s, ordinary Americans react to Jimmy Carterâ€™s exhortation to face â€œa problem thatâ€™s unprecedented in our historyâ€ with patriotic enthusiasm; sacrifices, they confirm, may be necessary. By the early 1980s, faced with a gas shortages and hours-long lines at the pump, some of that enthusiasm had crumbled. As the Republican presidential candidate, Reagan responded to the discontent by blaming the government and calling for authority to be transferred back to the private sector (or, to use a Reagan euphemism, â€œexperts in the fieldâ€) â€“ setting the stage for the Republican partyâ€™s symbiotic relationship with large oil companies well aware of the impact of emissions on the climate. (To quote an internal Exxon document from 1984: â€œWe can either adapt our civilization to a warmer planet or avoid the problem by sharply curtailing the use of fossil fuels.â€)But the film largely focuses on Bush, a blue blood east coaster who made his fortune in the Texas oilfields, and who nevertheless began his term in office in 1989 determined, at least outwardly, to break from his predecessor on the environment. Bush appointed an environmental activist, William Reilly, as head of the Environmental Protection Agency; he exhorted Congress that â€œthe time for action is now.â€ The White House Effect illustrates the political forces that eroded such purpose: the corporations that, according to their own internal documents, sought to downplay and discredit scientific evidence to protect their profit; the power games by White House chief of staff John Sununu, an ally of corporate lobbyists who outmaneuvered Reilly by encouraging climate skepticism in the aftermath of disasters such as Hurricane Hugo and the devastating Exxon-Valdez oil spill.The film works exclusively with meticulously edited archival footage â€“ the team sorted through more than 14,000 clips from more than 100 sources, including VHS tapes stored in the New Jersey garage of a former Exxon Mobil publicist and a memo from a confidential â€œGlobal Warming Scientific â€˜Skepticsâ€™ Meetingâ€ convened in 1991 by Sununu to empower media appearances by prominent climate contrarians. The reliance on archival was part of an effort to â€œimmerse the public in a time when this wasnâ€™t a political football â€“ where we experience the politicization of the issue, rather than being told itâ€, said Kos. â€œWhenever you turn on a camera and interview someone in the present, thatâ€™s automatically going to come with the political connotations that the present brings.â€View image in fullscreenA still from The White House Effect.Photograph: NetflixCohen and Shenk are veterans of climate change films; the married couple directed An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power, the follow-up to Al Goreâ€™s groundbreaking documentary on looming climate catastrophe. But with The White House Effect, â€œwe wanted to do something very different from what weâ€™ve done in our past work and what we think of as the â€˜climate change genreâ€™ of documentaries: we wanted to just drop the truth bomb of history,â€ said Shenk. â€œWe need that, right? We just need the truth.â€With archival, thereâ€™s â€œan opportunity to expand the conversationâ€, Cohen added. From man-on-the-street interviews to standard network broadcasts from the period, â€œhopefully you can see yourself in the film no matter who you are as an American, and feel that youâ€™re part of the conversation, rather than some liberal film-makers preaching at you.â€The platforming of climate skeptics on mainstream media and Sununuâ€™s counsel seemed to have an effect on Bush. By 1990, speaking at a White House conference on the climate crisis, he equivocated where he once held firm: â€œOne scientist argued that if we keep burning fossil fuels at todayâ€™s rate, by the end of the next century, Earth could be 9F warmer than today. And the other scientist saw no evidence of rapid change,â€ he said. â€œTwo scientists, two diametrically opposed points of view. Now, where does that leave us?â€ It left the US hamstrung by political division. Two years later, the â€œenvironmental presidentâ€ reluctantly attended the 1992 Rio â€œEarth Summitâ€, a major United Nations conference to set international targets for emissions reductions, advocating against such measures in the name of economic development and stability. The move, from the worldâ€™s largest greenhouse gas emitter, angered other countries, but Bush chided the international coalition: â€œI donâ€™t think leadership is going along with the mob.â€ The seeds for outright climate denial, and the Republican partyâ€™s unfettered and open alliance with corporate interests, had been sown.View image in fullscreenA still from The White House Effect.Photograph: NetflixNearly three decades later, in 2019, Reilly rued how the US missed an â€œincalculably importantâ€ opportunity at Rio. â€œThe advantage we might have had if president Bush had committed to seriously undertake the reduction of greenhouse gases is that we might have removed the partisan nature of the dialogue in the United States,â€ he said. If that prospect, in the era of hyper-partisanship, increasingly absurd natural disasters and the Trump administrationâ€™s dismantling of environmental regulation, feels deeply infuriating â€“ well, Cohen argued, thatâ€™s the point. â€œClimate change films, at least in the last 10 years, have been trying to spoon-feed the medicine of the climate crisis, and then have a â€˜hope bucketâ€™ at the end, where you can feel OK,â€ she said. â€œOur job is to create the rage. We canâ€™t shy away from the rage. And if this film, in all of its irrefutable archival historical glory, can create that rage, then weâ€™ve succeeded.â€The hope, she added, is that â€œyou can feel the rage and you can feel the intolerance for the denial of truth, and that youâ€™ll actually do something about at the ballot box. The hopelessness is when you feel like you canâ€™t do anything. But we have a large electorate in this country â€“ letâ€™s get out there.â€Kos, having overseen the mass archival effort, encouraged viewers to look at â€œthe overall arc of historyâ€ â€“ even in the face of the Los Angeles fires, the Texas floods, the rapid and unprecedented intensification of hurricanes like the one that devastated Jamaica just last week â€“ â€œwhat good is despair going to do?â€ The truth of political power, for good and for ill, is â€œright there in front of our eyes.â€â€œThe choice is in our hands,â€ he added. â€œWeâ€™ve shown you a what-if moment from 1988. Weâ€™re now in another what-if moment.â€The White House Effect is now available on NetflixExplore more on these topicsDocumentary filmsNetflixGeorge BushClimate crisisfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: The Lost Boys of Mercury review â€“ heartbreaking film on the enduring wounds of church-school abuse  | Movies | The Guardian
description: ClÃ©mence Davigoâ€™s uncompromising film gives voice to three survivors of a French correctional school, and the difficult path towards healing
Author: Phil Hoad
Headline: ClÃ©mence Davigoâ€™s uncompromising film gives voice to three survivors of a French correctional school, and the difficult path towards healing
Content: Davigo keeps a steady, observant hand on the directorial tiller â€¦Photograph: True StoryView image in fullscreenDavigo keeps a steady, observant hand on the directorial tiller â€¦Photograph: True StoryMoviesReviewThe Lost Boys of Mercury review â€“ heartbreaking film on the enduring wounds of church-school abuseClÃ©mence Davigoâ€™s uncompromising film gives voice to three survivors of a French correctional school, and the difficult path towards healingPhil HoadTue 4 Nov 2025 06.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 06.02 ESTShareGreat courage, physical and moral, is shown by the three principal interviewees in this heartbreaking French documentary. AndrÃ©, Michel and Daniel are former wards of the church-run Belle Ã‰toile correctional school in the Savoie town of Mercury and, now in their 60s and 70s, they recount a barrage of abuse at the hands of Abbot Garin and his lackeys: beatings that inflicted permanent damage, sleep deprivation, cold-water baths, starvation, nocturnal molestation.As director ClÃ©mence Davigo sits in on their long reminiscence sessions, the damage is clear. Michel weeps at the memory of his humiliations: deprived of a nurturing education, AndrÃ© became a career criminal, spending decades in prison; the alert-eyed Daniel, sexually abused and trapped in â€œhellâ€, speaks of later being emotionally crippled, unable to tell anyone he loves them. Michel and Daniel, an indefatigable chef and runner respectively, have found displacement activities, the means by which it is possible to empty their heads of the horror.But the trio also talk of emptying in a different sense: to relieve themselves of this burden and seek restitution. Davigoâ€™s attention shifts in the filmâ€™s second half to whether this is possible, and in what form. AndrÃ© and Michel disagree on whether the Catholic church as an institution is culpable â€“ or just, as the latter believes, the specific individuals at the Belle Ã‰toile. The two diocese counsellors they meet indicate that, in its willingness to acknowledge the wrongs done, the church is sorry. But when they finally meet the presiding archbishop, Philippe Ballot, he seems slow to commit to concrete actions.Davigo keeps a steady, observant hand on the directorial tiller, her calm interludes letting metaphors emerge naturally. For example, Daniel slowly climbs a nearby mountain, a dragonfly sloughing off its old skin. The film isnâ€™t a systematic inquest into institutional abuse, cover-ups and the feasibility of reform, which are certainly pertinent questions in France after the likes of theAbbÃ© Pierre scandal. Rather, it participates intimately in the healing process by giving these men the platform to tell their truths â€“ and is no less valuable for it.The Lost Boys of Mercury is on True Story from 7 November.Explore more on these topicsFilmDocumentary filmsFranceCatholicismChristianityEuropeReligionreviewsShareReuse this content

title: There Was, There Was Not review â€“ how four womenâ€™s dreams are destroyed by the shock of war | Movies | The Guardian
description: Emily Mkrtichianâ€™s feature debut was shot in the now defunct republic of Artsakh, a tender, intimate meditation on the impermanence of life
Author: Phuong Le
Headline: Emily Mkrtichianâ€™s feature debut was shot in the now defunct republic of Artsakh, a tender, intimate meditation on the impermanence of life
Content: Disrupted lives â€¦ There Was, There Was Not.Photograph: Indox FilmsView image in fullscreenDisrupted lives â€¦ There Was, There Was Not.Photograph: Indox FilmsMoviesReviewThere Was, There Was Not review â€“ how four womenâ€™s dreams are destroyed by the shock of warEmily Mkrtichianâ€™s feature debut was shot in the now defunct republic of Artsakh, a tender, intimate meditation on the impermanence of lifePhuong LeTue 4 Nov 2025 04.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 04.02 ESTShareWith a title taken from the traditional opening phrase of Armenian fairytales, Emily Mkrtichianâ€™s feature debut hints at the impermanence of life itself. Shot in thenow defunct republic of Artsakh, the film follows four extraordinary women who find their hopes and ambitions cruelly derailed by war. The breakaway state was formed in 1991, after decades of political discrimination under the Soviet Union and military conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan. For the predominantly Armenian population here, their peace has always been under threat.The personal journeys of Mkrtichianâ€™s subjects feel even more remarkable in the face of these uncertainties. A judo champion, Sose aspires to represent her country at the Olympics; Siranush campaigns to be on the city council; and Gayane runs a support group for women. For those living in Artsakh, memories of the last war are more than a spectre; working in bomb disposal, Sveta defuses mines that are still lodged in the verdant landscape. Though their professions vary, they are all committed to bettering the community, a testament to the strong cultural bonds that exist here.Captured with dynamism and intimacy, their individual stories collide whenwar breaks out in 2020. As the Azerbaijani army closes in, the womenâ€™s daily lives are disrupted by the sounds of sirens, and even explosions. Gayane and her family become displaced; they now live in Armenia as refugees. Sose, heartbreakingly, has to put her sports career on hold as she joins the military. In a contrast to an earlier scene, in which the bubbly young woman teaches judo to a class of children, she is now seen instructing a group of women on weapon assembly. With such burdens on their shoulders, it is a tragedy that Gayane and the rest of her community are forced to leave their dreams behind.There Was, There Was Not isat Bertha DocHouse, London, from 7 November.Explore more on these topicsFilmDocumentary filmsNagorno-KarabakhWomenAzerbaijanArmeniaEuropereviewsShareReuse this content

title: Fantaisie review â€“ study of a modern Ophelia swamped by audiovisual overwhelm | Movies | The Guardian
description: Isabel Pagliaiâ€™s film introduces her central character Louise with a thrillingly eclectic blend of handheld footage and cascades of still images
Author: Phuong Le
Headline: Isabel Pagliaiâ€™s film introduces her central character Louise with a thrillingly eclectic blend of handheld footage and cascades of still images
Content: Modern-day Ophelia â€¦ Fantaisie.Photograph: 5A7 FilmsView image in fullscreenModern-day Ophelia â€¦ Fantaisie.Photograph: 5A7 FilmsMoviesReviewFantaisie review â€“ study of a modern Ophelia swamped by audiovisual overwhelmIsabel Pagliaiâ€™s film introduces her central character Louise with a thrillingly eclectic blend of handheld footage and cascades of still imagesPhuong LeTue 4 Nov 2025 02.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 02.01 ESTShareReminiscent of a dark fairytale, Isabel Pagliaiâ€™s feature debut conjures a multitude of thresholds, lingering somewhere between documentary and fiction, dream and reality. Louise, the young woman at the centre of this beguiling film, is a mirage of a character; introduced in fragments, we first hear her lilting lamentations against a darkened screen. This is followed by closeups of a yellow notebook, in which her fears and desires overflow on every page, as they are read out by a mysterious, unseen man.When Louise finally materialises on screen, her everyday existence unfurls over deceptively mundane episodes. Through these sequences, Pagliai builds a fascinating tension between the stillness of the compositions and Louiseâ€™s agitated psyche. She is often seen in darkness, her face lit by the glow of various screen devices that flicker with snippets of songs and film scenes. This virtual flood of audiovisual materials takes on a literal form as if by magic, we see Louise out of her room and into the woods. Here, she encounters Thomas, the male narrator whose voice appears at the beginning of the film. At one point, Louise is partially submerged in a moonlit pond, a modern-day Ophelia swept up by unanswered fantasies.In contrast to this melancholic mood, Pagliaiâ€™s visual style is thrillingly eclectic. The mix of painterly static shots and lo-fi, handheld footage channels a state of emotional paralysis. When Louise speaks of a violent sexual assault that might or might not have taken place, her story is accompanied by a dizzying cascade of images where human figures are grotesquely distorted. Her tone, however, is as detached as when she describes her masturbation habits; that the images might have been generated by AI further emphasises her alienation. In this age of constant distraction, even the realm of imagination and memory is not safe from the intrusion of technology.Fantaisie is at the ICA, London from 7 November.Explore more on these topicsFilmDrama filmsDocumentary filmsreviewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜I want to ride out on a unicorn every nightâ€™: swordsâ€™nâ€™sorcery heavy metal band Castle Rat | Metal | The Guardian
description: Wielding fantasy weapons and splashing fake blood, the New Yorkers have even learned how to make chainmail outfits â€“ and theyâ€™re already aiming to conquer stadiums
Author: Alex Deller
Headline: Wielding fantasy weapons and splashing fake blood, the New Yorkers have even learned how to make chainmail outfits â€“ and theyâ€™re already aiming to conquer stadiums
Content: Eye-popping â€¦ Castle Rat (from left) Charley Ruddell, Riley Pinkerton, Franco Vittore and Joshua Strmic.Photograph: Peter BesteView image in fullscreenEye-popping â€¦ Castle Rat (from left) Charley Ruddell, Riley Pinkerton, Franco Vittore and Joshua Strmic.Photograph: Peter BesteMetalInterviewâ€˜I want to ride out on a unicorn every nightâ€™: swordsâ€™nâ€™sorcery heavy metal band Castle RatAlex DellerWielding fantasy weapons and splashing fake blood, the New Yorkers have even learned how to make chainmail outfits â€“ and theyâ€™re already aiming to conquer stadiumsTue 4 Nov 2025 05.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 05.47 ESTShareWhile many a rocker has cribbed from high fantasy, few have truly walked the walk. Sure, they might bedeck their album sleeves with ghouls, goblins, manacled maidens and brawny barbarians, but did a member of Cirith Ungol ever have to retrieve a missing unicorn horn from a snowy field in the depths of winter? Has Yngwie Malmsteen spent time squinting in the back of a tour bus, repairing his own chainmail?Formed in 2019, Brooklynâ€™s Castle Rat have had to face both these scenarios and more as they live out their epic fantasies. From heraldic, earworm-heavy anthems to eye-popping live shows, costume design, videos and album art, theyâ€™re not so much a metal band as a full immersive experience.â€œCastle Rat wasnâ€™t meant to be a costumed concept band,â€ says singer, guitarist, sword-wielder and creative overlord Riley Pinkerton as the bandâ€™s tour van speeds from a sold-out gig in Cologne to another in Aschaffenburg â€“ theyâ€™re also doing five gigs in the UK this week. â€œWe played two shows and got booked on a Halloween gig, where I made a last-minute decision to dress up. It was all super-DIY, but we had so much fun and the feeling in the room was electric. I thought, â€˜What if we could have this much fun every time?â€™â€Since then, the band â€“ which features Pinkerton as the â€œRat Queenâ€ alongside a plague doctor (Charley Ruddell, bass), haughty vampire (Franco Vittore, guitar) and mysterious druid (Joshua Strmic, drums) â€“ havenâ€™t looked back. The Bestiary, the bandâ€™s second album, conjures visions ofBlack Sabbath,Iron Maidenand Manowar joining forces to battle their way through a Frank Frazetta fantasy world â€“ a heroic opus that places them on the brink of far grander things.The Bestiary was a first for Pinkerton in that she opened the floor to her bandmates. â€œIt made it a lot stronger,â€ she says of the collaborative process. â€œI struggled at first â€“ Iâ€™d always felt a certain amount of pride being a woman in music going it alone. Thereâ€™ve been so many times where Iâ€™ve got off stage and some guy will say, â€˜Those guys write great riffs!â€™ and Iâ€™m like, â€˜Hey â€“Iwrote all that.â€™â€As the bandâ€™s stature has grown, so has the scope of their production design. â€œMy motto is always that if itâ€™s worth doing, itâ€™s worthoverdoing,â€ Pinkerton laughs. She was originally on course for a fine art degree before balking at the prospect of so much debt. â€œThe fun thing about Castle Rat is thereâ€™s so many different ways to apply artistic expression,â€ she says. â€œWhether itâ€™s making masks, costume design, learning how to edit music videos â€¦ itâ€™s all stuff I donâ€™t know how to do, but itâ€™s fun to figure it out on the fly.â€As if building the bandâ€™s intricate lore (â€œEveryoneâ€™s urging me to write it down because itâ€™s all in here,â€ Riley says, tapping her head) and stitching garments wasnâ€™t enough, the singer taught herself how to make chainmail â€“ no mean feat, though she admittedly left her all-new scalemail look to a New York-based specialist. â€œIt feels like actualarmour,â€ she beams.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Thereâ€™s not an alternative version of the show where I donâ€™t have a swordâ€™ â€¦ Riley Pinkerton.Photograph: Peter BesteAs for audiences? They took to the fake blood, foam swords and papier-mache rat skulls with as much gusto as the band. â€œWe played a show in Detroit and it looked like a Renaissance fair,â€ recalls Riley fondly. â€œEveryone was in cloaks, sheepskin, chainmail.â€This isnâ€™t to say, however, that life on the road as swordâ€™nâ€™sorcery vagabonds has been plain sailing. â€œEverything is constantly breaking and ends up duct-taped together,â€ Riley says. â€œPlus Iâ€™ll have endless ideas as to how I want things to look, but weâ€™re travelling in a van with only so much space. Itâ€™s an interesting challenge to make it feel like a larger-than-life story, then pack it down into nothing.â€There have been other logistical problems that would never have plagued Conan the Cimmerian or Dark Agnes de Chastillon. â€œWe did have an â€˜oh shitâ€™ moment when we played SonicBlast festival in Portugal and my luggage â€“ which had my sword in it â€“ got lost,â€ says Riley. â€œThat was a worst-case scenario, because thereâ€™s not an alternative version of the show where I donâ€™t have a sword.â€Like a true warrior queen, Riley is gung-ho about the future. â€œI want to go all the way â€“ letâ€™s do stadiums,â€ she says. â€œThe only thing thatâ€™s really important to me is keeping the DIY aesthetic, making sure everything is handmade. Thatâ€™s an element I want to keep true, no matter what we scale to. Oh, and I want to ride out on a unicorn every night. You know howRob Halforddoes the motorcycle thing? That, but with a unicorn.â€Castle Ratâ€™s UK tour commences at Concorde 2, Brighton, on 4 November.Explore more on these topicsMetalPop and rockfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Smythâ€™s Der Wald and Respighiâ€™s Lucrezia review â€“ Wagnerâ€™s spirit presides over double bill | Opera | The Guardian
description: The UK premiere of Respighiâ€™s 1937 work was paired with Ethel Smythâ€™s dark and dramatic Der Wald, both imaginatively staged by Stephen Barlow
Author: Flora Willson
Headline: The UK premiere of Respighiâ€™s 1937 work was paired with Ethel Smythâ€™s dark and dramatic Der Wald, both imaginatively staged by Stephen Barlow
Content: Lucrezia: A modern US courtroom setting for Respighiâ€™s telling of the ever shocking story.Photograph: David Monteith-HodgeView image in fullscreenLucrezia: A modern US courtroom setting for Respighiâ€™s telling of the ever shocking story.Photograph: David Monteith-HodgeOperaReviewSmythâ€™s Der Wald and Respighiâ€™s Lucrezia review â€“ Wagnerâ€™s spirit presides over double billSilk Street theatre, LondonThe UK premiere of Respighiâ€™s 1937 work was paired with Ethel Smythâ€™s dark and dramatic Der Wald, both imaginatively staged by Stephen BarlowFlora WillsonTue 4 Nov 2025 09.14 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 09.38 ESTShareAs the near-capacity audience settled and orchestra members warmed up ahead of Guildhall Schoolâ€™s latest double bill of operatic rarities, a familiar tune emerged from the pit: a tuba parping its way throughWagnerâ€™s Ride of the Valkyries. Talk about setting the tone.Ethel Smythâ€™s Der Wald (premiered in Berlin in 1902) and Ottorino Respighiâ€™s Lucrezia â€“ first performed in 1937 although this, remarkably, was its UK premiere â€“ will have been new to most in the Silk Street theatre. Yet both scores could have â€œRW woz â€™ereâ€ graffitied on them, such is Wagnerâ€™s impact on their musical language.Der Waldveers into total fandom. Hereâ€™s a dark, Romantic forest inhabited by innocent lovers. Thereâ€™s a dramatic soprano wreaking social havoc. â€œTod und Liebeâ€ â€“ death and love â€“ sings the female innocent at the end in her own miniature Liebestod. InStephen Barlowâ€™s production, the lighting is set at â€œgloomyâ€ and the action is in 1950s North America, the woodlanders clad in denim and plaid while Iolanthe the pseudo-Valkyrie arrives on a motorbike.View image in fullscreenPalpably having fun: Ethel Smythâ€™s Der WaldPhotograph: David Monteith-HodgeThe cast was palpably having fun. The chorus and smaller roles were an energetic, vibrant presence, Sonny Fieldingâ€™s turn as the peddler andRedmond Sandersâ€™ as local landowner Rudolf (here an all-mouth-and-trousers cowboy) especially persuasive.Avery Lafrentzmanoeuvred her huge, hard-edged soprano effectively as Iolanthe, Harry Jacques was a warm, sympathetic Heinrich andSeohyun Gowas excellent as his fiancee RÃ¶schen, her tone both generous and carefully controlled. If the impassioned climax of the operaâ€™s love duet felt underheated as RÃ¶schen took off her cardigan, it was partly down to the orchestra, conducted byDominic Wheeler. The lush string tone of the opening never quite returned and, despite some shapely woodwind solos, the playing lacked the polish and amplitude needed to make this opera truly compelling.The orchestra fared better in Respighiâ€™s Lucrezia, where Wagner lurks behind the twin filters of Puccini andStraussin a score that embraces extremes of harshness and beauty. There were moments of tactile earthiness from the cellos and basses, terrifying, febrile activity in the woodwind and hefty slabs of brass, while the strings eked out slow, traumatised drags as the heroine (better known to operagoers viaBrittenand to classicists viaLivy and Ovid) narrates how she had been raped.Barlowâ€™s staging places the ever-shocking plot in a modern US courtroom, the men in suits and sandals, the women in toga-like dresses. Gabriella Giulietta Noble demonstrated a gift for storytelling as La Voce (here a black-suited legal professional providing periodic commentary), while Manon Ogwen Parryâ€™s Venilia and Hannah McKayâ€™s Lucrezia stood out from the impressive cast in their assured dramatic and vocal intensity. It was a powerful argument for a work we should clearly know better.Further performances on 5, 7 and 10 November,Silk Street theatre, Barbican, LondonExplore more on these topicsOperaClassical musicreviewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜The Irish landscape whispers tales of the pastâ€™: a trip beyond the blarney in far-flung Donegal | Ireland holidays | The Guardian
description: Our writer explores the cliffs, beaches and villages of the Gaeltacht area of Donegal and sees the landscape afresh through the Irish language
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Our writer explores the cliffs, beaches and villages of the Gaeltacht area of Donegal and sees the landscape afresh through the Irish language
Content: Fanad Lighthouse, where even the sights from your sitting room are something else.Photograph: Agnieszka Glowala/AlamyView image in fullscreenFanad Lighthouse, where even the sights from your sitting room are something else.Photograph: Agnieszka Glowala/AlamyIreland holidaysâ€˜The Irish landscape whispers tales of the pastâ€™: a trip beyond the blarney in far-flung DonegalOur writer explores the cliffs, beaches and villages of the Gaeltacht area of Donegal and sees the landscape afresh through the Irish languageFergal McCarthyTue 4 Nov 2025 02.00 ESTLast modified on Tue 4 Nov 2025 02.02 ESTShareEarlier this year, a trailer for a film calledDear Erinappeared in cinemas featuring bloody-knuckled, flat-capped â€œPaddyâ€ penning a letter on a table strewn with empty porter and whiskey glasses to Erin, his long-lost American flame. Much online brouhaha and frustration ensued at yet another Hollywood misrepresentation of modern day Ireland. The trailer was eventuallyrevealed to be an elaborate rusebyEpic, the Irish Emigration Museum in Dublin, to call out the tired stereotypes and â€œto find out who the Irish really areâ€.Fanad lighthouse map and surrounding areaIreland, and the Irish, are many things. The countryâ€™s economic and social structures have changed rapidly in recent decades but that doesnâ€™t necessarily mean the culture has altered unrecognisably. What has changed is the increasing draw to connect with Irelandâ€™s natural landscapes. Writers such as the lateTim Robinson,ManchÃ¡n Maganand the popular podcasterBlindboyboatclubhave been pivotal in mining the connection between the natural world and the countryâ€™s past. TheIrish language has seen a renaissancein the past few years for the same reason. In his 2020 bestselling bookThirty-Two Words for Field, Magan writes: â€œIrish has a rich store of words that offers a more soulful and nature-connected way of seeing the world. It lets you live more deeply in your environment.â€To test Maganâ€™s hypothesis, I travelled with my family to the Fanad peninsula in theGaeltacht(Irish speaking) area of County Donegal this summer. The bilingual road sign that welcomed us to Fanad/FÃ¡naidimmediately delivered a geographical context, fÃ¡na being the Irish word for sloping ground. Knockalla mountain (Cnoc Colbhaâ€“ the hill of the edge) loomed to the east, calling to mind images of the ice sheets that carved the ridge along the twin peaks about 14,000 years ago.View image in fullscreenFergal and family enjoy having the beach to themselves.Photograph: Fergal McCarthyThe ice age also had an impact on Fanadâ€™s coast. The rocks that still line the foreshores of its pristine beaches were left behind by retreating glaciers and pounded ever since by the North Atlantic to make sand. We sought out one of those white beaches at Ballyhiernan Bay (BÃ¡ BhaileUÃ­ThiarnÃ¡in â€“the townland of TiarnÃ¡n). My phone offered no details of shadowy TiarnÃ¡nâ€™s biography, but I wanted to find out more about why a whole bay was named after him â€“ Robinson was right: â€œplace names tell storiesâ€. We were alone on the beach, our only company the swallows that surfed the air currents above the crashing waves. My 16-year-old son and I had spent the past year attending â€œpop-upGaeltachtsâ€in Dublin pubs in preparation for his stint working at an Irish college, a rite of passage for Irish teenagers, yet the Irish word for swallow eluded him. It isfÃ¡inleog, probably fromfÃ¡nmeaning to wander or to leave, perfectly capturing the penchant of these summer visitors for travelling to Africa in the winter.Irish has a rich store of words that offers a more soulful and nature-connected way of seeing the worldManchÃ¡n MaganThe process of anglicising Irish place names began in the early 19th century, following the 1800 Act of Union, with towns being renamed as part of the Ordnance Survey of Ireland, which began in 1824. This act of cultural erasure was soon followed by the great famine, from 1845 to 1852, which decimated the Irish-speaking population. In 1980, decades before the recent resurgence of interest in Irelandâ€™s linguistic past, the Donegal playwright Brian Friel mined this pivotal era for his 1833-set opus Translations. The playâ€™s erudite schoolmaster Hugh, who refers to Irish as â€œa syntax opulent with tomorrowsâ€, might have smiled warmly at the idea of musicians such asCMAT,Fontaines DCandKneecapreleasing songs in the language nearly two centuries later.Settling in for our stay at acottage within the grounds of Fanad lighthouse, the view from our sitting room looked west to the towering cliffs of Tory Island (Toraighâ€“ place of steep rocky heights), another far-flung corner where the native language maintains a grip, and famous for having akinguntil 2018. Ascending the vertiginous steps to the lantern room afforded us an even better view, with Malin Head (Cionn MhÃ¡lannaâ€“ high headland), Irelandâ€™s most northerly tip, clearly visible across Lough Swilly (Loch SÃºilÃ­â€“ lake of eyes or shadows). The enormous expanse of sea to the north created a sense of the earthâ€™s curvature, and Scotland and Iceland seemed almost within reach, somewhere in the distance.The next morning, whilekayakingunder the nearby cliffs and blowholes with knowledgable local guide Hugh Hunter, oystercatchers dived overhead, calling out angrily as we paddled by their nesting grounds. These black and white seabirds with orange, chisel-like beaks migrate here from the neighbouring Nordic countries every autumn. My son is none the wiser about the Irish for oystercatcher:Roilleach an Giolla Brighde, meaningthe servant of Saint Brigid. The story goes that Irelandâ€™s patroness saint was hidden from an angry mob by a flock of oystercatchers who covered her in seaweed.View image in fullscreenKayaking with knowledgable guide Hugh Hunter.Photograph: Fergal McCarthyThat afternoon, we joined the throng in theLighthouse Tavernto watch the All-Ireland football final between Donegal and Kerry. There was a loud cheer in a mixture of Irish and English each time the home team scored. At half-time we joined a group of local teenagers as they discussed their impending university courses in Dublin. I wondered how their lives would change and who among them might come back, like the swallows and oystercatchers, to this far-flung peninsula.Later in the week, stopping for directions to Port Na Ling (harbour of the ships) beach, a local man engaged us in conversation, explaining he hadnâ€™t spoken a word of English until he went to secondary school. He pointed out the house where he grew up with 11 siblings, among a constellation of white-washed bungalows on the hillside the other side of Mulroy Bay (An Mhaoil Ruaâ€“ meaning the bare hill). Irelandâ€™s pre-famine, largely rural population, peaked at about 8.2 million and a sense of how the countryâ€™s built environment looked back then is somehow still tangible in many coastal Donegal communities. Gweedore (Gaoth Dobhairâ€“ estuary of water), an hour away to the west, is described as one of Europeâ€™s most densely populated rural areas. In the aftermath of the famine, people in Donegal largely survived by travelling to Scotland as potato pickers, and this seasonal work allowed the countyâ€™s population to remain relatively buoyant, with locals returning home in the winter months rather than emigrating permanently.View image in fullscreenView over the coastline of Gweedore, described as one of Europeâ€™s most densely populated rural areas.Photograph: Gareth McCormack/AlamyWe finished our time in Fanad by following theWay of the Crossup Knockalla to an outdoor altar with three crosses looking out across the peninsula. Blindboyboatclub explains that â€œthe Irish landscape itself acts as a storyteller, whispers tales of the pastâ€. The pathway we had just ascended has been a place of spiritual significance for millennia, long before being co-opted by Christianity. The many standing stones and ancient sites strewn across the fields are signifiers of a secret history. We were the only people to climb the mountain that morning, and what a privilege to have this sacred site to ourselves.Our time in Fanad had been a portal to viewing the landscape afresh. Magan was right: the Irish language is an extraordinary conduit to the past and offers us a better understanding of the present.Two-nightstays atFanadlighthousefromâ‚¬350. Kayak trips withEco Atlantic Adventuresfromâ‚¬35pp. Further information:tourismireland.comExplore more on these topicsIreland holidaysEurope holidaysBoating holidaysSelf-cateringCultural tripsfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: The many uses of leftover chutney, from breakfast to soups and glazes | Chefs | The Guardian
description: With Christmas around the corner, our panel of experts recommends creative ways to finish off half-eaten jars before the new ones arrive â€¦
Author: Anna Berrill
Headline: With Christmas around the corner, our panel of experts recommends creative ways to finish off half-eaten jars before the new ones arrive â€¦
Content: Approach your leftover chutney on a meal-by-meal basis, because itâ€™s as good with breakfast as it is with after-dinner cheese.Photograph: Elena Heatherwick/The GuardianView image in fullscreenApproach your leftover chutney on a meal-by-meal basis, because itâ€™s as good with breakfast as it is with after-dinner cheese.Photograph: Elena Heatherwick/The GuardianKitchen aideChefsThe many uses of leftover chutney, from breakfast to soups and glazesWith Christmas around the corner, our panel of experts recommends creative ways to finish off half-eaten jars before the new ones arrive â€¦Anna BerrillTue 4 Nov 2025 08.00 ESTShareThe Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.Every Christmas Iâ€™m given chutney, and I still have four barely used jars. What to do with them before the next lot arrive?Christine, OxfordThis sounds like a job for Claire Dinhut, author ofThe Condiment Book, who also goes by the moniker Condiment Claire. She would approach this meal by meal, starting with breakfast. â€œIt might not seem so obvious,â€ she says, â€œbut I put Branston pickle on my avocado toast. If you think about it, you often add acidity, which is usually lemon, but chutney is punchy and has that same tang, as well as a bit of texture.â€ Regardless of what jars Christine has hanging around, Dinhut would also consider the breakfast bap: â€œWhether itâ€™s spicy mango, peach, chilli or tomato chutney, that would be so delicious with an egg yolk.â€The Guardianâ€™s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link.Learn more.Roger Pizey, executive head of pastry atFortnum & Mason, is no stranger to Christineâ€™s chutney conundrum: â€œSometimes weâ€™ve got so much left over that Iâ€™m at my witâ€™s end knowing what to do with it.â€ And, often, the best solution is the simplest, which is why Pizey often spoons a good dollop of, say, fig and fennel chutney into a golden, gooey toastie. â€œYou can geta lotof chutney in there with a few generous layers of Ogleshield [a raclette-style cheese], which takes the tart, acidic flavour of chutney really well.â€Of course, chutney also plays very well in other sandwiches and wraps (ham, turkey, coronation chicken), or use it as a glaze or marinade for meat. â€œItâ€™s already balanced,â€ Dinhut says, â€œso you donâ€™t necessarily need to add anything else. If youâ€™re putting chicken breasts in the air fryer, for example, smear mango chutney [peach also works well] all over the meat, which will give it a really nice glaze.â€ Cyrus Todiwala, author ofModern Indian: Small Plates, Big Flavours, Fabulous Feasts, meanwhile, puts his mango chutney in a blender and purees it: â€œThatâ€™s the ideal glaze for brushing on chicken, turkey or pork before roasting.â€Soup is hot right now, so if youâ€™re having a bowl of squash or pumpkin soup, you could do a lot worse than spreading a piece of baguette with soured cream and chutney and using that for dunking, Dinhut says. She also has form for adding chutney (think apple or tomato) to salad dressings instead of honey: â€œIt brings that bit of texture, vinegar and sweetness, which is especially good in a rice or barley salad with roast sweet potato, dried cranberries and goatâ€™s cheese.â€But do remember to keep things clean. â€œIt burns me up when people take a spoon and scrape it around the sides of the jar,â€ Todiwala says. â€œThatâ€™s the place where fungus will start to grow, so keep the lid and edges of the jar clean by wiping them with a dry cloth or some kitchen paper after use.â€ That way, no jar will ever be left behind: â€œWhen you do finish a jar, use up the last few bits of chutney by cracking in a couple of eggs, sealing the jar and giving it a good shake. Then use the contents to make scrambled eggs,â€ Dinhut says. And those will happily do you for breakfast, lunch or dinner.Got a culinary dilemma?
